PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Pensions: Assets Test
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Governments failure to act to correct the anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions bring to its notice and due to have effect from the 21 March, 1985 the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners, and calls upon the Australian Democrats to support Senator Messner's bill for the abolition of the Assets Test.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the passage of the Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill to repeal the Labor Governments iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Additional Capital Gains Taxes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
They adversely effect the small and the medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
The Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

Any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ''windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
The owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;
Your Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Pass Senator Harradines's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilisation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Brownhill (from 294 citizens), Chipp (from 301 citizens), Cooney (from 380 citizens), Hamer (from 323 citizens), MacGibbon (from 1,004 citizens), Messner (from 209 citizens), Missen (from 336 citizens), Primmer (from 345 citizens), Robert Ray (from 481 citizens), Richardson (from 222 citizens) and Zakharov (from 369 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth; That the proposed Human Embryo Experimentation Bill is a retrogressive step which could deprive thousands of couples of the chance to have children. The planned prohibition on experimentation on a human embryo would have the effect of ending the breakthroughs made in the study of infertility.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should seek the prevention of the passage of the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 65 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1. That the functions of local government involve assessing local demand for services and either providing, or facilitating the provision of, those services;
2. That a transfer of responsibility for the provision of services from one level of government to another must be accompanied by a corresponding transfer of funds;
3. That local government in Victoria is becoming increasingly involved in the planning and provision of human services in particular;

4. That the level of services currently provided by or through local government cannot be maintained, and certainly cannot be increased, if the funds made available to local government through the personal income tax-sharing arrangement are not maintained at the present level;
5. That we are totally opposed to any reduction in the percentage of personal income tax allocated to local government.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the funding of local government without the consent of representatives of local government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 3, standing in my name for today for disallowance of certain words in the Supervision of Offenders (Community Service Orders) Ordinance 1985. I seek leave to make a statement to explain the position of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under this Ordinance, an authorised officer can 'as far as practicable' take a person's 'religious beliefs' into account when directing community service work to be performed in lieu of some other punishment. The Committee considered that the authorised officer should not have the personal discretion implied by the words 'as far as practicable'. The Committee also objected to the apparent exclusion of 'genuine conscientious beliefs' from those matters to be taken into account in directing what kinds of community service should be performed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) has agreed to delete the words 'as far as practicable' and thus remove the objectionable discretion. He has also agreed to include in the Ordinance a requirement that an authorised officer shall consult with an offender before giving directions and to take into account any matters raised by the offender in the course of that consultation. The Committee understands that this will ensure that a person is not exposed to the legitimate moral distress that might arise from a genuine conscientious objection to a direction. The committee was able to discuss and accept the Minister's undertaking only this morning and thus I was unable to give notice of intention to withdraw yesterday. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, the Committee's and the Minister's letters in order to record for the information of honourable senators the issues which were discussed between us.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA. THE SENATE
STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES
14 May 1985 Gordon Scholes, M. P.
Minister for Territories
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
At its meeting on 9 May 1985, the Committee again considered the Supervision of Offenders (Community Service Orders) Ordinance 1985 (A.C.T. Ordinance No. 10 of 1985) and your letter of 9 April 1985.

The Committee thanks you for the advice you have given. However, the Committee remains of the view that the expression ''as far as practicable'' in paragraph 6 (3) (a) of the Ordinance, referring to the directions which an authorised officer may give to an offender, does leave open the possibility that an offender could be required, by the authorised officer, to work in circumstances contrary to his or her genuine religious beliefs.
Further, the Ordinance does not make allowance for genuine conscientious beliefs to be taken into account. Such beliefs might include a genuine conscientious objection to performing work-
(a) for a voluntary organisation, such as a church, the beliefs or policies of which he or she disapproves;
(b) on a day on which a person's trade union is engaged in lawful industrial action;
(c) on a day on which the trade union of other persons, whose paid work is performed on the premises where the community service is to be performed, are engaged in lawful industrial action; or

(d) at a hospital performing or not performing medical procedures which may be the subject of genuine conscientious (rather than religious) objections (for example abortions, electro-convulsive therapy or experimental biological research with human embryos).

The Committee's concern is with genuine conscientious objection which would compel a person to refuse to comply with a direction or which would cause a person to experience legitimate moral distress if he or she did comply with the direction.

In the context of conscientious beliefs, the Committee notes the comment made, in the last paragraph of your letter, in relation to the expression ''as far as practicable''. A court could consider religious beliefs prior to making a community service order. It is, however, a matter of interpretation whether the expression ''work of a suitable nature'' in paragraph 5561 (1) (c) of the Crimes Act 1900 (N.S.W.) in its application to the A.C.T. could exclude the categories of work described in (a) to (d) above. In any event, a discretion appears to remain with the authorised officer to take religious beliefs into account, but only to such extent as that officer perceives is practicable with reference to the performance and supervision of the work. The Committee is inclined to the view that such a discretion should not exist.

In the light of these considerations, the Committee remains committed to its attitude which led to its decision to give the notice of motion. The Committee intends to amend the notice to limit it to disallowance of the expressions ''as far as practicable'' and ''religious'' where occurring in sub-section 6 (3) and paragraph 6 (3) (a) respectively, so that the substance of the Ordinance is not affected.
However, your agreement to amend the Ordinance would be an outcome preferable to any disallowance and the Committee would welcome your acceptance of its proposals.
John Coates
Chairman
24 May 1985 Senator J. Coates
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator
I refer to your letter of 14 May 1985 concerning the Supervision of Offenders (Community Service Orders) Ordinance 1985.

Having considered the matters raised in your letter I would be agreeable to the removal of the words ''as far as practicable'' from sub-section 6 (3) of the Ordinance. I also accept that there may be other kinds of conscientious belief that should be taken into account by the authorized officer but it seems to me that it would not be realistic to expect that in every case the authorized officer would have the competence to make a judgment about whether the offender entertains, to use the Committee's words, a ''genuine conscientious objection which would compel a person to refuse to comply with a direction or which would cause a person to experience legitimate moral distress if he or she did comply with the direction''.

It occurs to me that the same result could be secured if the Ordinance were to contain a provision imposing an obligation on the authorized officer to consult with the offender before giving directions under section 6 and to take into account any matters raised by the offender in the course of that consultation.
I have asked my Department to arrange the preparation of amendments to the Ordinance to this effect.
Your sincerely
GORDON SCHOLES

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee commends the Minister for his decision to accommodate the Committee's concerns about the Ordinance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the statement on the report of the Handicapped Programs Review incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
I am pleased today to table the report of the Handicapped Programs Review with an associated summary of recommendations. I seek leave to make a statement regarding the report.

Honourable senators will recall that in September 1983 I launched a review of the Commonwealth Government's program of special services for disabled people. The Handicapped Programs Review has been the most comprehensive public examination ever attempted of any aspect of an Australian Government's social policy and programs. The Review received some 1700 submissions. Over 5,000 people participated in an unprecedented program of open public consultation entailing public meetings, seminars, site visits, drop-in sessions and interviews. This extensive consultation process covered sixty-five cities and provincial centres throughout Australia.

The Review Report outlines the major concerns and options raised in submissions and consultations and makes recommendations arising from extensive consideration of these issues, indicating possible future policy directions relevant to the needs of people with disabilities.

The report is called 'New Directions', reflecting the positive approach of the Government in setting up the Review and of the community in responding to it. Its primary focus is the aspirations of people with disabilities who want independent living options, realistic training and employment opportunities and better access to generic or mainstream community services. Moreover, it challenges both governments and service providing agencies to re-examine their objectives and outcomes in the light of these aspirations.

The Review Report makes 52 recommendations on a variety of issues including human rights, education, income maintenance, transport, sport, recreation and leisure and prevention of disability as well as those relating more directly to my particular responsibilities as Minister for Community Services.
Too many people with disabilities are still confronted with limited or no choice in housing, employment or training.

Many have no choice in securing accommodation other than that provided in institutional settings which are isolated from the general community. As a result, a disproportionate number of disabled people are accommodated in institutions. Physically disabled young people frequently have no options other than nursing homes designed for dependent elderly people. There is currently a significant lack of respite care and other home-based support services for severely disabled people and their families.

Of those who manage to gain access to services which purport to provide independent living, vocational skills or training programs, many are forced to rely on outdated or unrealistic training methods and environments.

Very low wages, poor working conditions and limited work options are characteristic of too many sheltered workshops. There is a lack of appropriate training, placement and support programs for disabled people capable of entry into open employment.
Many activity therapy centres are unable to provide necessary training in independent living and social integration because they are inappropriately staffed and funded.

The poor co-ordination of related Federal and State Government programs was a matter for adverse comment all over Australia. Added to this is the absence of clearly specified program objectives for clients of services and a lack of consumer involvement in planning and review of services. Positive consumer outcomes should be a mandatory focus for all funded programs, but at present this is simply not achievable.

These shortcomings are exacerbated by the restrictive nature of the existing legislation which prevents funding of many worthwhile programs, especially those designed to achieve greater integration in the community. Although the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974 was designed to assist people with disabilities, in practice it served to channel government funding to larger organisations which generally saw their role as developing institutional and program care. The Review has identified the need for a major revision of this legislation to allow for significant changes and improvements in the provision of services so that they respond more flexibly to individual needs and promote better integration of people with disabilities into mainstream community activities.

It is my intention to develop as a matter of urgency new funding and program directions identified as necessary by the Review. Program planning and administration will be changed to focus on the needs of disabled people rather than on the needs of funded organisations. This means we will have to develop ways of enabling people with disabilities to live independently within the community, of improving their access to mainstream community services and ensuring that better and more realistic training and employment opportunities are opened to them.
Among the key reforms that will aim at achieving these objectives are:
Providing more resources for community based accommodation and support services with particular emphasis on relocating people inappropriately housed in institutional settings;
Providing transitional funding to establish a network of post-school independent living and training programs in and through TAFE colleges;

Revamping the sheltered workshop program to develop two main tiers of service, one focussing on extending competitive employment training and placement for those able to move into open employment and the other focusing on improving options in special employment services for those unable to be employed elsewhere; and
Funding a number of new special service models for disabled people such as citizen advocacy, information services, community education and recreation.

Finally, we will strengthen our commitment to ensure that the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) makes itself more accessible to disabled people needing such services through a community outreach approach. In particular, the regional network will be further developed to focus more strongly on the greater participation of disabled people in community life.

A range of demonstration project grants will be provided to establish new programs to examine the feasibility, effectiveness, and relative cost of the new consumer outcomes approach to services for people with disabilities. In addition, program development grants will be provided to existing services in accommodation, respite care, employment, training and special support service areas to assist with restructuring programs to conform to the consumer outcomes approach. The new specific support service types to be developed will include initiatives in information services, citizen advocacy, self help and recreation.

To bring about these reforms, it will be necessary to develop new Disability Services Legislation to replace the existing Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and Part VIII of the Social Security Act covering the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service. I propose to introduce this legislation during the Autumn Session of Parliament next year.

This Disability Services Legislation will reflect the new directions identified by the Review and provide a basis for the provision of a more flexible range of services and associated funding arrangements designed to improve opportunities for disabled people in community based settings.
The new legislation will emphasise the development of a needs based planning approach and a service delivery structure involving closer co-operation with State Governments.
Particular attention will be given to involving consumers/clients in planning as well as program delivery and review.

The legislation will require clearly defined consumer outcome objectives as the basis for program development, implementation and review. An individual can expect to see programs designed in terms of a place to live, paid employment, ability to live independently, community participation, security and choice of lifestyle.

A number of the recommendations contained in the Report refer to the need to provide personal and social support services. This will need to be addressed not only in the new Disability Services Program, which will be closely linked with the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service, but also in the Home and Community Care Program which has always been intended to cater for younger disabled people as well as the elderly.

In addition I intend to initiate discussions with the State Governments to explore the possibility of a joint Commonwealth/State Government programs of special services for people with disabilities. These discussions will be aimed at enabling us to develop, where appropriate, complementary legislation, cost sharing and effective co-ordination with generic or mainstream community services.

Within the new Department of Community Services, the Office for Disability, together with the Disability Advisory Council of Australia, will be handling arrangements for continuing the consultation process started by the Review. Consumers of services, their families and representatives of service provider organisations will be asked to assist in elaborating and refining the wide range of developmental objectives put forward for consideration in the Report of the Handicapped Programs Review.

Clearly the major reforms I have outlined will not be achieved overnight but will require much consideration, negotiation and hard work by everyone concerned with disability matters. I look forward to initiating action and achieving results on these matters, in consultation with my government colleagues, State Governments, non-government organisations and community groups and, in particular, disabled people themselves.

Finally, I wish to record my appreciation of the contributions made by the Review Steering Committee, members of the Disability Advisory Council of Australia and Professor Tom Bellamy of the University of Oregon, all of whom assisted in developing the actual proposals made in the Report. In particular, I am grateful for the efforts of the members of the Review Secretariat, headed by Mr Brian Luby, all of whom have worked hard over a long period and have maintained a consistently high standard of performance with an unfailing enthusiasm and commitment.

Above all, I want to thank all those individuals and organisations who so readily assisted the Review by making submissions and participating in the Review's consultations around Australia. Without their support it would not have been possible to produce this New Directions Report on behalf of all those concerned about disability and opportunity in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement. The purpose of my statement is to clarify the position with regard to the handling of the report of the Handicapped Programs Review.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I was apparently misinformed this morning by the office of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) as to the procedures for handling this very important report that was to be tabled today. In fact, I expected a ministerial statement to be made by the Minister with regard to the tabling of this document on the Handicapped Programs Review. That procedure was not followed. As a result, I am unable to respond to the statement that has been tabled with the document. This is a very important issue, one on which I think all of us in the Senate will have something to say. Consequently, I now seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the statement.
—It's coming on in papers.
—Would the honourable senator mind if I handle it my way?
—Order! Is leave granted for Senator Messner to move such a motion?
—No. Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement on the same subject.

—I share Senator Messner's view that the report of the Handicapped Programs Review is an important document. It is very important not only to the Opposition but also to the Government. We have introduced it as a paper which will be able to be debated this afternoon in the debate on the presentation of papers. It is item No. 1. The statement Senator Messner refers to was brought down in association with the paper, I think it is sensible that we treat this paper like other papers and that Senator Messner move that the Senate take note of the paper this afternoon and initiate debate then. It is an important statement for the Government and for me, as I said. I would be perfectly happy to get up and read a very long document, but in the circumstances of our being near the end of the session, I thought that this was the reasonable way to handle it. I apologise to Senator Messner if he thought he was misled. I can assure him that no member of my staff intended to mislead him. We intended to handle the tabling of this document in this way for some time, because of the log-jam that we have now. I just do not see why this paper should receive special attention above other papers, despite the fact that I would be perfectly happy for that situation to apply.

—by leave-There is no question that, as Senator Messner and the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, have both said, the statement relating to the report of the Handicapped Programs Review is an important statement. The establishment of the Review was long overdue. There are a lot of recommendations contained in it, and I would certainly appreciate being given until this afternoon to have a look at the details instead of having to go straight into it this morning. I think that this matter is too important just to deal with it on an ad hoc basis on the run.
—Order! Senator Messner sought leave to move a motion. That application for leave is still before us unless Senator Messner seeks to withdraw it at this stage, or does he seek to proceed?
—Mr President, I really believe that the Government is mishandling this issue and avoiding its responsibilities in this matter. I believe that the Minister's statement should be debated.
—Order! Does Senator Messner still seek leave to move that motion?
—Yes, Mr President, I do.
—Is leave granted for Senator Messner to move that motion?
—Do you intend to have a full scale debate now on this matter?
—Yes; that is why I want to move that motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) although we will be moving amendments in the course of the Committee stage. I do not propose to detain the Senate at any length during the second reading debate. However, this legislation appears to me to be getting somewhat out of hand. When this Government came to office it made a statement in relation to the original purpose of this legislation which is a feature of each sitting period of the Senate. In fact, two such Bills are introduced each year. The purpose to which the Government adhered originally was to provide a convenient way of making a number of very technical amendments to legislation. Certainly these were to be amendments which could not be controversial in nature.

SPEECH.PARA: It appears now that the scope of such legislation-this Bill embodies some examples-is expanding every year. Such legislation is rather losing sight of some of the limitations originally intended for it. This Bill contains a series of amendments to a great many Acts of Parliament. I have not actually counted them all but probably 60 or 70 Acts are amended by this legislation. Amendments of a very significant nature are proposed, for instance, to the composition of the Trade Union Training Authority. Also there is an amendment proposing the implementation of a treaty. I think that these important policy decisions, even if in fact they do not result in controversy, demand further consideration and time should be provided for that consideration to be given properly to them. This type of legislation is a vehicle for making nuts and bolts amendments to other legislation. Such amendments are necessary because of the great volume of legislation which this Parliament has been passing over the last 10 to 15 years. It really is a sorry commentary on the extent of that legislative activity over so many years that it is necessary to have legislation of this sort at all. Regrettably it is necessary. Mistakes are revealed and technical matters have to be changed or adapted for one reason or another. Clearly, the Government is now using this legislation as a vehicle for implementing amendments-some of which are substantial-on the assumption that they are not controversial. I suppose that in that sense the Opposition will support them. On the other hand, even though the Parliament may be prepared to support the amendments, the fact is that they deal with subjects that ought to be debated and this legislation is not a convenient form for that sort of debate.

When this legislation was being considered in another place under a guillotine, the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), wished to debate important amendments to the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act and the Australian Citizenship Act. He was able to speak for a short while on them, but that prevented further debate and prevented the amendments which the Opposition wished to move to the Public Works Committee Act and the Defence Act from being moved. I think that reveals the fact that too many legislative provisions are included in one omnibus Bill of this kind. Too many subjects are dealt with in it. I think the time has come when the Government ought to be giving further consideration to just what its policy is in relation to measures of this kind.

I do not propose to go through this legislation in any detail, as was done in the House of Representatives. I simply point out that, from the Opposition's point of view, this legislation is not in a satisfactory form. It should be able to be passed without any debate at all because it deals with just technical matters. However, once the Government seeks to use it as a vehicle to make amendments to a whole lot of Bills simply because they seem to be useful and ones which are not likely to cause controversy, it rather misses the point. Even though the legislation will be supported, it may well need to be debated.

It is a pity that we do not have time now-we are in the dying hours of this session and we have a lot of other legislation to consider-to consider this Bill and give it the attention that it properly deserves. I do not propose to talk in this second reading debate about the specific amendments that the Opposition proposes to move. I will deal with them at the Committee stage. However, the Opposition certainly supports the measure. The vast majority of the contents of the legislation gives the Opposition no concern; but, as I have said, the Government's policy as a whole is giving us some concern. Unfortunately, it is preventing debate in this Parliament on a number of important matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer to one aspect of the proposed amendments and comment on the remarks of Senator Durack. Having a Bill such as the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1985 to fix mistakes and technical matters is bad enough and ought not to be encouraged. However, in one respect at least in which I am interested, the Bill is much more than that. I refer to the second reading speech as it relates to the amendment of the Defence Act 1903 and that portion which states that the purpose of the amendment is to bring the conditions of Service personnel into line with those applying to other Commonwealth employees. I think that comment needs to be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: There are very significant differences between the serving conditions of Commonwealth employees and defence personnel. I am not suggesting that this legislation ought not to be brought in as long as it has the amendment which will be moved, but this is the worst possible reason for suggesting that it be introduced. I have no doubt that someone will suggest that this amendment would benefit defence personnel in that they could borrow money more easily if their wages could be garnisheed. That may be appropriate in a few cases. But the amendment as presented to the Senate has no regard to the fact that frequently defence personnel are away from home and unable to attend to their own affairs, as other people are. They could be on ships, in war zones, on a peace-keeping mission, or on a goodwill trip somewhere. Events could go wrong within their family finances for a whole variety of reasons. It may be because of a mistake made by their bank, or by their pay officer within the Services, or by their wife at home who for very good reasons indeed did or did not get round to doing something. The marriage may even have broken up during the time the serving officer was away and unable to attend to his own affairs. Not to pay some regard to that fact shows a total disregard for the life of Service personnel. But to suggest that they be brought into line with other Commonwealth employees gives some indication of this Government's attitude to defence. It shows a total lack of comprehension for the lives of defence men and women and a total lack of concern for their welfare and care.

I do not intend to take up too much time this morning. I shall refer particularly to some of the conditions that are quite different between service personnel and other Commonwealth employees. Other Commonwealth employees have their entitlements and needs and they need to be addressed. It is offensive to suggest that when defence personnel have some other benefit or facility, it should be reduced to that of Commonwealth employees. It does not always work that way. I can give an instance relating to work at the Fairbairn air base where Commonwealth employees who work in what is regarded as an out-of-the-way place are paid a travel allowance to get to work. But serving personnel who also live out in Canberra, in places such as Wanniassa, Giralang or Charnwood and who have to travel to Fairbairn, get no travel allowance to go to the same place to work alongside a person who is a Commonwealth employee and not a defence person.

I am not suggesting that it is not appropriate, as there is not a bus service to that area, for a Commonwealth employee to get a travel allowance, but it is not made available to the defence employees. They are on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week. They are expected to turn up for flood and fire, and they are happy to do so. They do not get overtime or penalty rates and there is no appeal system; they are subject to regular transfers every two years or so, frequently with little notice. Many times one finds people who live in the Services, especially those in the Army and Air Force, who have spent fifteen years in the Services and who have lived in 12 different homes, their children having attended 12 different schools. They are not the same conditions as those applying to most other Commonwealth employees

Defence personnel frequently live in what could be described as sub-standard rental accommodation, in houses that have not been properly maintained for many years, and they have no choice but to do so. They finish up being 20 years behind in attempts to purchase their first home compared with others in the community who have different types of jobs. Such personnel do not get sick leave on the same basis and have deductions made from their pay. Their position is totally different from that of Commonwealth staff. They are not able to form the same sort of friendships and stable relationships, although perhaps the Government may not think that important. Their children are not able to form the same sort of friendships as other children who stay in one place for a long period of time. Defence personnel wives are not able to pursue the same sorts of careers as other wives who live in a particular place for a long time. The conditions are different. I am not suggesting that this amendment should not be made, apart from the specific aspect to which I have referred, but to put in a second reading speech that the reason for so doing is the fact that Defence Force employees should be subject to the same conditions as other Commonwealth employees is, I suggest, totally unacceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak in this debate at the second reading stage on the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill but, in view of Senator Reid's comments, I think it is necessary for the Australian Democrats to do so and to state our position. I have had some consultations with ex-service organisations on this matter, and it is not quite as simple as Senator Reid has presented it. The basic problem is that if ex-servicemen are not placed on much the same basis as other public servants, when it comes to the position of their incurring debt-that is, obtaining a loan, hire purchase and so on-they will be disadvantaged. I spoke to a group of wives of ex-servicemen at Holsworthy camp only a couple of weeks ago and they raised this very matter with me. Because they were married to servicemen they found that the banks would say: 'We cannot let you have this money because there are limitations on the extent to which it could be recovered from you in the event of default'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats, however, respect what the Opposition is trying to do. The Opposition is trying to say: If servicemen are placed on the same basis as public servants, what will be the situation of a man if away fighting in a war? I think the Opposition has raised a valid and legitimate point there, one which, at this stage-as it has been raised by Senator Reid in this second reading debate-I ought to draw to the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) so that he can give us some sort of commitment, perhaps in the Committee stage. I think the Government ought to try again on this provision. We will not support the amendment of the Liberal Party of Australia for the reasons I have stated, but we respect the principle. The Government should look at that amendment to see if it cannot do something in this area in the future.

I would like the Minister to give us some sort of undertaking that in a situation where a soldier is away fighting at war his family will not be knocked around in Australia because of this provision. I do not really think the Liberal amendment covers that point. What is needed to cover that point I suggest, will be a good deal more complex and it will have to be thought out. It will have to take into account the other aspect that I have raised, which is a very real one to service men and women. The last thing this Senate wants to do is to place servicemen and their families in a position where they cannot get the same reasonable access to credit as to other members of the community, and certainly other public servants. I ask the Minister at this stage to take that on board and to give us some idea of what can be done in the Committee stage. Within reason I would like some undertaking from him that that matter might be looked at in a realistic way so that that protection is given to ex-servicemen and their families without any deleterious effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Senator Durack, has pointed out, this Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1985, which has been brought into this chamber in the dying stages of this parliamentary session, contains a lot of matters which deserve a great deal of debate. Aspects of the amendments incorporated in this Bill which relate to the Citizenship Act are matters which obviously are topical and of very great concern to the Australian community generally. Yet we are denied the opportunity of a wider debate on the issues concerning citizenship because of the way in which the Government is handling this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the three citizenship Acts are fairly minor. The point that I would like to make in respect of the amendments to section 15 of the Australian Citizenship Act is that whereas currently the oath or affirmation of allegiance must be taken before a citizenship certificate is conferred, it is at that time that citizenship is being deemed to have been granted. The amendment will alter the time at which citizenship is deemed to have been granted to the date the certificate was conferred or the oath of affirmation made, depending on which is later. While we can see the administrative convenience that is involved in such a decision it seems clear to me that a change of that kind can have a far wider effect unless it is handled with sympathy and concern by the Government. I hope that the way in which this new legal provision will be administered will lead to that situation.

The second point that I want to make relates to the requirement that those people who will be administering the oath of citizenship must be Australian citizens. Many local government bodies conduct citizenship ceremonies but ratepayers may elect a mayor who is not an Australian citizen. Ratepayers are allowed to vote in local government elections these days and they do not have to be Australian citizens. The point I make is that, while this amendment sounds reasonable-that is, to make it mandatory that those people administering the oath are Australian citizens-we ought to have respect for the fact that it is the office, rather than the individual, which is administering the oath. I believe that point ought to be remembered, insofar as we are not dealing with individuals one by one, but rather with the nature of the office itself.

Finally, I simply make the point that it is a shame that due to the shortness of time we are unable to have a far wider debate on the question of citizenship generally, which is raising very considerable concern and interest in the community today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since we appear to be doing in the second reading stage what I thought would have been undertaken in the Committee stage, I too raise a problem with the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) with regard to the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act which is being amended under the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. I say, firstly, that it does seem rather extraordinary that, in a Bill which is supposed to be non-controversial, we have an amendment to the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act which is six pages long and which has raised some concern in the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, particularly in relation to the proposed new sub-sections in section 11, which will be repealed by this Bill and replaced with a new section relating to duty to report certain incidents involving oil or an oily mixture, which is the heading of the section.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has raised a quite lengthy concern about the reversal of the onus of proof which occurs in this amendment. New sub-sections 11 (2) and 11 (4) and sub-sections 22 (2) and 22 (4) each impose on the defendant in a prosecution under sub-sections 11 (1), 11 (3), 22 (1) or 22 (3) for failure to notify incidents involving the discharge of oil or other liquid substance, the burden of establishing to the satisfaction of the court on the balance of probabilities the defences made available under those sub-sections; namely, that the person was unable to comply, that the person was not aware of the incident, or was not aware that the master of the ship was unable to comply with the relevant obligation.

The Senate Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has pointed out that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, in its report entitled 'The Burden of Proof in Criminal Proceedings', urged that such a persuasive onus should not be placed on defendants, but rather that they should merely be required to bear an evidential onus; that is, the onus of adducing evidence of the existence of a defence, the burden of negativing which would then by borne by the prosecution. The Committee drew to the attention of the Senate, under principle 1A (1) of its terms of reference, the effect of new sub-sections 11 (2) and 11 (4) and 22 (2) and 22 (4). Those sub-sections, by imposing a persuasive onus on defendants in criminal proceedings, might be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties.

The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) did respond by pointing out that because the House of Representatives had risen, which of course was the case at the time, the making of any amendments to the Bill in the Senate as a result of the Committee's comments would have the effect of postponing the amendments to the entire Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill until the Budget session. That was clearly something that at that stage no one wanted, since, as is usual with this Bill, a lot of necessary amendments are being made. I simply ask the Minister to consider the Committee's comments in this area and make some sort of undertaking with regard to the impact this amendment, if passed, is likely to have on the civil liberties of the people concerned, and to ask whether or not there is some way around this predicament, other than the one which is before us today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Schedule 1 of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1985 contains amendments to the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980. Perhaps unlike other senators, I wish to compliment the Government on these amendments and to draw attention to some of the history of this matter. My colleague Senator Puplick is not in the Senate but has asked that we draw these few points to the attention of the Senate. These amendments in part put into the operation of Australian domestic law, insofar as it applies within the Australian Antarctic Territory and to Australian citizens, the provisions required under the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a couple of words about that Convention. Between 1959, when the Antarctic Treaty was negotiated and signed, and 1972, when Australia added its signature, Australia was under Liberal Party government. During that time we had a proud record in the Antarctic. Australia took a lead in dealing with all matters of wildlife and animal conservation. I notice that Australia signed the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals on 5 October 1972. This legislation also fits in with the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980, which again was another notable piece of Liberal Government legislation. Both these measures had bipartisan support in the Parliaments of the day. The legislation was for the preservation of the environment of the world's most fragile continent.

This legislation also complements the Whale Protection Act 1980, another notable achievement of the Fraser Liberal Government following the report of the Frost Inquiry into Whales and Whaling. Again, it was a measure which attracted wide support in the Parliament in extending protection to threatened and endangered Antarctic species as part of the fragile ecosystem of animal life on the Antarctic continent.

Finally, it should be noted that this Act and these amendments give some application to a Convention which is itself a real tribute to the continuing success and international value of the Antarctic Treaty regime. This regime should be preserved from threats being made against its continued existence by forces within the United Nations. I hope that this country, which has done so much to promote, advance and extend this regime, will take a strong stand for its preservation in the United Nations. Both political parties in Australia are proud of the treaty system and have until now been, and I hope still will be, united in seeking the preservation of this Treaty in its current form when it comes up for renegotiation in 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was my impression that the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills as we receive them from time to time were designed to dot the i's and cross the t's, to correct technical problems and difficulties in legislation. That being so, I threw my copy of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1985 into the waste paper basket because I had plenty of other things to do.
—Don't we all.

—We certainly do. I was in the process of doing some of those other things when wafting across the air waves came Senator Durack's mellifluous voice. He raised the point that the legislation included very substantial amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975. I then retrieved my document from the wastepaper bin and had a look at it. Indeed, this legislation does contain very substantial amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975. In fact it contains 60 amendments to that Act, no fewer than nine of which are quite substantial in character and go to the rights and responsibilities of individuals and groups within the Trade Union Training Authority.

SPEECH.PARA: I make this point in the second reading stage because I am still examining the legislation. I have made certain notes as to how the rights and responsibilities of these individuals and groups will be substantially altered by this measure. I believe this measure is not appropriate for this purpose. It was never designed as such and I believe it is a misuse of the measure. I acknowledge that it is probably not designed to pull the wool over anybody's eyes, but if the Department concerned wanted to have these measures dealt with, it should have included these 60 amendments in a Bill to amend the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975. Then the measure could have been properly debated and considered on its merits. I gather that 90 per cent of senators would probably not have done the same thing with the Bill as I did.

TALK.START.PARA: —They probably would have filed it.

—Yes, they probably would have filed it. I am very concerned that this legislation contains 60 amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act, at least nine of which I have so far detected are very substantial amendments indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate, particularly one or two of them, such as Senator Peter Baume who had something favourable to say about the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1985). I say at the outset that it is a longer miscellaneous provisions Bill than usual. It amends some 164 separate Acts and that makes it quite a substantial mouthful to bite off on this occasion. Some 65 Acts are amended to remove obsolete provisions relating to the rights of Commonwealth public servants. About 10 of those Acts related to the citizenship clauses which were mentioned by Senator Messner and are purely consequential. Twenty-five Acts have been amended purely as a consequence of changes to the machinery of government allocation of responsibilities between departments and so on following the election last year. But it is the case that in addition to there being many amendments, a number of them are quite substantial and lengthy. Senator Harradine has pointed to one such example in referring to the amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Government has acknowledged the force of these sorts of criticisms, that perhaps matters of excessive length are starting to creep into the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. I am pleased to be able to tell the Senate that this matter has been addressed in the last couple of weeks by the Government and the relevant Cabinet committee has endorsed some changes to the guidelines to reflect that point, and in particular the desirability of not having matters of excessive length or complexity cluttering up this Bill in the future. I further mention that there is nothing in those guidelines in their original form or their revised form which undermines our commitment not to put forward in this Bill anything of a contentious nature. It may be that from time to time matters emerge which nobody thinks will be contentious but which, in fact, prove to be. It is certainly not the Government's intention to use this Bill in any way for that purpose. Perhaps for the record it would be appropriate for me to table and incorporate in Hansard, with the leave of the Senate, the revised guidelines which the Government will be using for the next one of the Bills in this series.
Leave granted.
The guidelines read as follows-
Proposed New Guidelines for Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills

(a) Only matters that deal with tidying up, correction and up-dating (including modernisation of style), with routine administrative changes or, with the approval of the Prime Minister, with changes of minor policy significance may be included.
(b) No matter that is contentious, or is closely related to a contentious matter, may be included.
(c) Matters that involve lengthy and complex drafting (particularly of a kind that may hold up the Bill) must not be included.
(d) Matters that involve substantial policy issues (including legal policy issues) must not be included.

(e) If the amendments proposed to a particular Act are of such a lengthy nature that they ought fairly to be the subject of a separate Bill (whether or not such a Bill is likely to be included in the legislative program for the sittings in which the relevant Statute Law Bill is to be introduced), the amendments must not be included in the Statute Law Bill.
(f) No matter that would constitute a change to the National Companies and Securities legislation may be included.
(g) No matter that imposes, abolishes or varies a tax, or varies the incidence of a tax, may be included.
(h) No matter involving an appropriation may be included (except the repeal of a ''spent'' appropriation power).

(i) A decision on whether a matter falls within the guidelines as being suitable for inclusion in the Bill should be made in the first instance by parliamentary Counsel after consulting, when appropriate, with the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

(j) In addition, if Parliamentary Counsel consider that the number or nature of some amendments proposed for inclusion in the Bill would result in the Bill becoming unduly lengthy, Parliamentary Counsel should have a discretion to require the amendments to be deferred for inclusion in the Statute Law Bill proposed for a later sittings or to be dealt with when the relevant Principal Act is next being amended by a separate Bill.

(k) If a Department seeking the inclusion of a provision in the Bill is dissatisfied with a decision of Parliamentary Counsel, the matter should be referred to the Attorney-General for decision and, if the Attorney-General considers it necessary to do so, to the Legislation Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is another gesture in the direction of open government which I know will win the heart and soul of Senator Durack, and no doubt lose me more favour with my colleagues.
—Do you take account of the point that even though something may not be contentious, it may be of such importance that it ought to be properly debated?

—I think one has to tread rather delicately on that. If one is to take the point raised by Senator Messner that there is nothing at all contentious about the citizenship amendments but he would like an opportunity to debate the whole question of citizenship, I think that might well be said of about 50 or 60 areas that are traditionally incorporated and incorporated again in this legislation. It would continue to be more appropriate for other forms of this House, such as the first readings of Bills and so on, to be used as the vehicle for simply raising matters of general public interest. However, I take into account what the honourable senator says. It is to do with the question of the complexity or length of the amendments. If there are substantial changes, albeit uncontroversial ones, being made to some piece of legislation, I accept that it is probably not appropriate, except in some exceptional circumstance, for them to be incorporated in a Bill of this kind. We want to avoid a situation where we get into lengthy debates of this kind on this Bill. We would much prefer such Bills to be able to go through rapidly.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the points made first by Senator Harradine about the TUTA amendments, let me say that these amendments had the approval of the National Labour Consultative Council, combining the forces, of course, of government, trade unions and employers. It was on that basis that the Government took them to be uncontroversial in character. Although there is a relatively large number of amendments to the TUTA Act, as Senator Harradine has pointed out, they do not alter the powers or functions of the Authority itself. They are concerned simply with the internal structure and the internal allocation of functions within the organisation. As such, we believe that they are properly described as technical and administrative changes and, in the Government's view, are therefore appropriate for inclusion in the Statute Law Bill. That being the case, there was no need, we thought, to incorporate them in a separate piece of legislation.

If there is any suggestion that incorporating these changes in the Statute Law Bill was nonetheless some kind of device to conceal their significance from public gaze, let me again state for the record that there can be no foundation for any such suggestion. On 7 May this year, two days before the Bill was introduced in the House of Representatives, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, issued a news release drawing attention to the fact that the amendments were included in the Bill and outlining what the amendments were and the reasons for them. I guess that Senator Harradine must have let that slide into his waste paper basket too. Had he responded to that not very well reported news release, it may have been possible to have avoided his intervention here today. On the previous day, 6 May, the Minister also wrote to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), informing him that the amendments were to be included in the Statute Law Bill. So there was an intention, certainly, to put the matters out for public gaze. I hope that as a result we can avoid further contention on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't suggest at all-

—I do not want to suggest that Senator Harradine was making any such imputation. However, there was a general impression of pain and angst wafting across the chamber about this matter. I thought that perhaps I might have been able to deal at least with some of the concerns that the honourable senator might otherwise feel about the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Two other matters were raised which it is appropriate to deal with at this stage, although arguably they are properly matters for the Committee stage. Hopefully, we can get rid of them now and avoid a Committee stage debate as a result. The first matter was the question of the amendments to the defence legislation, a question addressed critically by Senator Reid and much more favourably by Senator Mason on behalf of the Australian Democrats. What is in contention here is one small part of a significant amendment to the Defence Act which is designed to put the payment of defence personnel on a proper basis and, as the second reading speech said, a similar basis to that prevailing for other public servants. The particular matter that causes concern here apparently is that which enables, under certain constraints, the pay of defence personnel to be garnisheed to satisfy a judgment debt.

I make clear that the scope of this provision is limited and is motivated by exactly the consideration that Senator Mason adverted to, that is, the desirability of putting defence personnel on the same basis as other public servants, or as close as possible to that basis, in order that they will not be disadvantaged in competing for funds in the private loan market. Defence personnel have in the past had difficulty getting credit because lenders have been doubtful about their ability to enforce judgments against salary. This provision is designed quite specifically to cope with that problem.

There are some safeguards in the way the provision will operate which are important to understand against the argument that people overseas, in particular, will be in difficulty as a result of this provision. In the first place, the procedures apply only in relation to judgment debts. A member will accordingly have had the prior opportunity to defend the claim leading to the judgment in the court proceeding, whatever it is. Further safeguards are built into the proposed section to the extent that a member must have the opportunity to state his case to his paying officer before the deductions are actually proceeded with. Further, it is the case that deductions are limited to 20 per cent of net salary each pay day. There is an argument that in the absence of that provision-if it were taken out, as apparently is sought to be done by the Opposition-servicemen would be rather worse off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you express it in that way in the second reading speech? Why didn't you say you were conferring an advantage?

—I did not write the second reading speech. I am sorry if Senator Reid misunderstood it. But when one is dealing with amendments to 164 different pieces of legislation, necessarily the second reading explanation will be cursory. I would have thought that Senator Reid, as a trained lawyer-I understand that she was one who kept body and soul together during her practising days-would have been able to read the actual text of the legislation for herself and would not have been misguided by any too cursory an explanation of it in the second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that I am making is that the other provisions introduced here giving servicemen the right to sue for their wages mean that in effect they have a legal, quite explicitly set out right which they have not had previously to receive pay. It is certainly arguable as a matter of law that, because there is now the legal right to receive pay, the full amount of that pay so receivable could be attached by a judgment creditor. So, instead of being able to garnishee nearly 20 per cent of that wage, in accordance with this statutory limitation, a much higher percentage of the wage would be exposed to attack if this amendment were to go through. I hope that some thought will be given to that point by the Opposition before it goes to the point of moving an amendment in the Committee stage.

It also has to be said, although I will not labour this point unnecessarily at this stage, that there is a technical difficulty with the amendment as it is presently drafted insofar as the definition of war service, which is here relied upon, will be repealed when the Defence Force (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1982 comes into force in the near future. However, picking up the point made by Senator Mason, who sought an undertaking from the Government to keep this provision under review, I am certainly happy to give an undertaking on behalf of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) that the section will be very closely monitored in its operation and that if it proves to be the case that members are being disadvantaged, in particular by reason of overseas service which is the preoccupation of the Opposition, the section will be revised. I cannot be much more explicit than that.

The final point that was raised in the second reading debate was by Senator Haines, again in anticipation of a Committee stage argument. Again, maybe we can avoid that at this stage by dealing directly with her concerns now. Her point relates to that part of the Bill which amends the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983. Senator Haines was reflecting the concern which had been expressed by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills that there were provisions in the Bill that unacceptably reversed the normal persuasive burden of proof. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) has taken the view, on advice from the Attorney-General's Department that to the extent that there is a reversal of the normal persuasive burden of proof with some aspect of that being located on the defendant, that is justifiable by the particular circumstances of this legislation. The main point to be appreciated, which does not seem to have been appreciated in any of the discussion to this point by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee or anyone else, is that although the language of these sections is being changed in some respects, the persuasive burden is not being relocated by these provisions. The crucial sections so far as the burden of proof is concerned are identical to the present sections 11 (2), 11 (4), 23 (2) and 23 (5), of the 1983 Act in respect of which the very same Committee had no comments at all to make in its Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest report No. 2 of 11 May 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that it slipped through then; but I do not think we can let it slip through again.

—As I said the other day in answer to Senator Crichton-Browne who raised this whole question of reversal of onus of proof, I was one of the authors of that Senate Committee report that expressed a very strong concern with the continued existence of persuasive burden reversals in legislation and I was one of those who penned the paragraphs in that report saying that it is only in the most exceptional circumstances that such can be justified.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record, and without going through it because it is a long argument, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a one-page summary of the advice which was received from the Attorney-General's Department by the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) and which satisfied the Minister, at least prior to the debate on this Bill on this issue, in order that the Senate may be aware of the reasoning which lies behind the provisions in their present form.
Leave granted.
The summary read as follows-
Summary of Points
Amendments of the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983: Advice from the Attorney-General's Department

The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has commented that new ss. 11 (2), (4) and 22 (2), (4) of the Act reverse the normal persuasive burden of proof and that thus ''they may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties''.

The Attorney-General's Department has advised the amendments are justified because there were three possible alternatives which are neither viable nor practicable. The Department of Transport has accepted this advice.
Alternative One

Repeal the new sections: This is not viable since it would result in a failure to comply with the reporting of incidents provisions of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973 (as amended).
Alternative Two

Lay on the prosecution the burden of disproving the defences created in the new sections by making these matters elements of the offence: This is not practicable since the prosecution would face considerable difficulties in disproving the defences created in the new sections since those would be matters known exclusively to the defendant and that compliance with Article 4 of the Convention would be seriously obstructed.
Alternative Three
Amend the new sections so that only the evidential burden of proof is reversed: For reasons similar to the objections to Alternative Two this procedure would also be impracticable.

Finally, the Department points out that the Committee's objections to the new sections are difficult to reconcile, so far as burden of proof is concerned, with the present sections of the Act about which the Committee had no comment when introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —However, having said all that and having said that in the view of the relevant Ministers there is justification for these provisions, I am also advised by the Minister for Transport that he is perfectly prepared to re-examine this question in the light of the concerns that have been expressed not only in the original Scrutiny of Bills Committee report but now again in this chamber by Senator Haines. The Minister undertakes, and I repeat that undertaking, so we undertake not to proclaim into effect the provisions of this particular amendment until some time into the Budget session of the Parliament, to enable further consideration to be given to this matter and, if necessary, further discussion to take place with the Australian Democrats and others on the Committee who may be concerned about this matter, in order to see whether there may not be some ability to convert these into evidentiary reversals rather than persuasive reversals and so on. Attention has been given to it, but more attention will be given to it and the provision will not be proclaimed into effect until that occurs. Senator Haines could not get a nicer response than that. What will be the quid pro quo for today for that? Under the circumstances we may, hopefully, have a very short Committee stage for this Bill, since it seems that most, if not all, of the matters that were sought to be raised have now been raised.
—Not all.
—Senator Rae mutters some threatening noises over there.
—I just showed some restraint which wasn't shown by everybody else.
—Under those circumstances, I just commend the Bill and hope that it gets the speedy passage which it so obviously deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 99, proposed amendment of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, add the following:
''Section 18-
Add at the end the following sub-sections:

'(10) A public work, the estimated cost of which exceeds $2,000,000 but does not exceed $6,000,000 shall not be commenced unless the Committee has been advised by notice in writing by the Minister of the proposed work.
'(11) If the Committee is advised pursuant to sub-section (10) by the Minister of a proposed work and the Committee-
(a) does not advise the Minister by notice in writing within 14 days that it wishes to inquire into the matter-the proposed work shall be proceeded with, or
(b) within 14 days advises the Minister that it wishes to inquire into the matter-the proposed work shall be dealt with in accordance with sub-sections (1) to (7).'.''.

This amendment, which was circulated in the name of the Opposition, is a measure to take account of inflation. The last amendment to the Public Works Committee Act was made in the very early 1970s and this amendment proposes to increase the discretionary area to $6m. It is also a means of ensuring that departments cannot escape the scrutiny of the Public Works Committee by staging work on various projects, which is something the Committee has been concerned about. This amendment will make departments, and the Government generally, more directly answerable to and subject to scrutiny by the Parliament. As I understand it, this amendment is supported by the majority of members of the Public Works Committee. It has been moved by us to provide a desirable addition to the scrutiny of public works being carried out and to the role of the Public Works Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty with the Opposition's amendment is that we have not had anything from the Public Works Committee stating that it supports it. As I understand the problem, the Public Works Committee has said the exact opposite. There is a conflict as to whether it actually supports the proposed change to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1). The difficulty is that we need really to have a statement from the Public Works Committee on this matter. I would have thought the way out might be for the Government to undertake to make sure that it continued to refer to the Public Works Committee all works the estimated cost of which exceeded $2m, as it has done to date, pending some further discussion by the Public Works Committee on this matter and a clear indication from that Committee as to whether or not it agreed to increase the threshold from $2m to $6m. If the Government were to give some kind of indication along those lines, it would be possible to pass this Bill without the Opposition's amendment; otherwise, we will be forced to support the amendment, pending further advice from the Public Works Committee.

—I am a member of the Standing Committee on Public Works. As Senator Foreman, the Chairman of that Committee, is not here at the moment, I can reassure Senator Macklin that it is the wish of the Public Works Committee that this amendment be passed. As Senator Peter Rae said, it is an updating, an incremental measure, which will bring the work of the Public Works Committee into line with what was intended under the original Act, which I think was introduced in about 1904. The amendment will not preclude any work from coming before the Public Works Committee. In fact, anyone can refer any public work to the Committee for inspection and analysis. Therefore, if Senator Macklin is happy to receive the reassurance of at least one of the newer members of the Committee, I can tell him that it was a unanimous decision that the Public Works Committee recommend this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the way through this at the moment is to accept the course proposed by Senator Macklin.
