TALK.START.PARA: — I draw the attention of honourable senators to pages 112 to 117 inclusive of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1985. Therein honourable senators will see 60 amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975 and, as I have said, at least nine of them are substantial. I believe that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) inferentially acknowledged that these were very substantial amendments. In mitigation of their being placed within the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill which, incidentally, is generally regarded as legislation which dots the i's, crosses the t's and fixes up some minor technical problems, he inferentially recognised that this is not the place to have them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) issued a Press statement-incidentally, I did not see it; I do not think it hit the Press, which must have had other things on its mind at that time-indicating that the amendments were approved by the employers and the unions in the National Labour Consultative Council. So what? Do we have to lick its boots because it does something? Are we going to bow down every time the NLCC says something? The only explanation for the substantial amendments is that the NLCC says we should have them. I have been on State NLCC committees which have later regretted certain decisions that they have made. The NLCC committees are not infallible; I do not think that the NLCC is infallible. The Parliament deserves better treatment than the Government giving no reason at all for these amendments other than the fact that the NLCC has agreed to them. There has been no other explanation. The second reading speech states:

These amendments abolish the present Australian Council for Union Training and the Authority's Executive Board replacing them with a new Australian Council for Union Training responsible for formulating TUTA's policy. A smaller Executive Committee, responsible for implementation of the Australian Council's policy, will be appointed from the Council.
Incidentally, where is this said in this legislation? The speech continued:

State Councils for Union Training will be re-named Regional Councils for Union Training and be given responsibility for ensuring that TUTA's training activities in their State or Territory accord with the policy of the Australian Council.
What this second reading speech does not say is that the State councils will be abolished as a result of this Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are to be called regional councils.
—They are to be called regional councils and their constitution is being amended.
—Slightly.
—Slightly amended.
—They are not being abolished.

—We are getting into the argument of the merits or otherwise of the case. It is not appropriate for this measure to be included in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. Had it been done the right way-that is, by an amendment to the Trade Union Training Authority Act-honourable senators would have been able to propose other amendments that they thought desirable to the Trade Union Training Authority Act. Because the Government has brought in this measure in this manner honourable senators are prevented from moving amendments to the Act which might, in their view, be necessary after consideration of these measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go through the measures one by one. There are 60 of them. As I have said, I do not want to go into the whole 60 of them because some of them are of a consequential character. However, at least nine of them are not. Let me deal with some of those. Honourable senators may not have the Trade Union Training Authority Act with them but Part IIB establishes an Executive Board of the Australian Trade Union Training Authority. Part IIB establishes by statute the Executive Board's constitution, the Executive Board's authority and the provisions for the meetings of the Executive Board. All of that Part is being omitted by this legislation. We will have an Executive Committee whose constitution, functions, meeting times, et cetera will not be governed by statute. This kitchen cabinet of the Australian Council for Union Training will be appointed by the Australian Council and, as I read it, it will run the week to week operations of the Authority. Will it still be called 'the Authority', because there are redefinitions of what the Council will be? Let us call it 'the Authority'. Previously Parliament decided that there would be an Executive Board, Parliament decided the constitution of the Executive Board, Parliament decided its functions and Parliament decided the question of meetings of the Executive Board. Now, through this legislation, all those decisions of Parliament are sought to be wiped out. No reasoned explanation has been given as to why that should be. It might have been a different matter had it been thought that the Australian Council-the statutory body established by this Parliament, whose functions and meeting procedures are established by this Parliament-should be reduced in size and considered to be able to manage the affairs of the Trade Union Training Authority. One sees from the amendments in this Bill that the Australian Council, far from being reduced in size, will be expanded.

How will the Council be expanded? There is a provision in section 14 of the Trade Union Training Authority Act for two members of parliament to be on the Authority. Section 14 (1) (j) refers to 'one member of the Parliament appointed by the Prime Minister' and paragraph (k) to 'one member of the Parliament appointed by the Leader of the Opposition'. Under the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) the Parliament will be deprived of its membership on the Council. That is slipped in through a statute law miscellaneous provision. Surely it is a substantial matter whether the Parliament is to be represented on the Council or whether it is not. I might happen to agree that it should not be represented, but that is beside the point. The point is that Parliament is being asked, through this back-door method, to approve of its membership on the Trade Union Training Authority being taken away. If nothing else convinces members of the Parliament to vote against this particular provision, that should convince them. Here we have representation from the Parliament on the Council being removed by a Bill which seeks to remedy technical defects. Parliamentarians have a lot of defects, but I do not think they are necessarily technically defective. That exemplifies how ludicrous it is to place such substantial amendments in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. This provision may well have been okayed by employers, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock)-

TALK.START.PARA: —But it certainly has not been okayed by you.

—No, but it has not been okayed by the Parliament, and I believe that the Parliament should not okay it by simply remedying a technical defect. Was it a technical defect to put members of parliament on the Australian Council in the first place? If it was, then of course I agree that it should come to us via this legislation. But it was not a technical defect. It was deliberately decided by the Interim Council at that stage-I remind the Senate that I was a member of the Council at that time, and we deliberately included the provision, probably for reasons of smooth relations and so on-that two members of parliament be appointed to the Australian Council to oversee trade union education and the like. Let me deal with what else is done to the constitution of that body. Two members of parliament are taken off that body and three more members from the Australian Council of Trade Unions are slipped in under paragraph 14 (1) (d)-
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two issues running through this debate in the Committee stage of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. I support the amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act, which I think are commendable, but, unfortunately, what has arisen in this debate is whether they are appropriately placed in this Bill. I agree with Senator Harradine that there is no way that this is the appropriate mechanism by which these provisions should have appeared in this Parliament. However, I do not want to see the efficiency and good name of the Trade Union Training Authority sacrificed on this occasion simply because we now no longer have an opportunity to put through separate legislation on this matter to be dealt with today. I think that would be a pity.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that these amendments are not aimed at just correcting technical defects; I concede that. Given the remarks of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) earlier and the new guidelines that are to be issued, it would appear that amendments of this kind will not appear in future in this sort of legislation. They should have been included in separate legislation. The amendments themselves will do a lot to lift the performance of TUTA. The Senate had an unexpected and extended debate on this organisation some weeks ago, courtesy of Senator Lewis, who provided the Senate with a couple of hours of debating time on the subject.

The amendments relate to two or three areas. Firstly, they restructure the Australian Council and give a wider representation to the trade union movement; secondly, they reduce the size of the Executive Board; and thirdly, they create regional rather than State councils. The idea behind it is to try to get a more efficient running and overseeing of TUTA, which has not been the case in the last few years. Unfortunately, the Australian Council has, at best, met twice a year, and the Council, given its composition, has had difficulty in getting a quorum for its meetings. What has tended to happen is that the Australian Council has met in the morning, discussed broad issues, and then the same type of issues have been discussed by the Executive Board later that morning or in the afternoon. It is possible to assert that that sort of administration and duplication that has occurred was not beneficial to the Trade Union Training Authority.

Senator Harradine was probably right to say that just because the National Labour Advisory Council has approved something does not mean that Parliament also has to approve it. That body makes as many mistakes as, or more mistakes than, any other organisation. Nevertheless, it is a broad indicator of the support for these amendments. Senator Harradine drew attention to the fact that the Bill will remove the two parliamentary members from the Council. That is true, and one of the ostensible reasons put up was the non-attendance of parliamentarians at its meetings. I assure honourable senators that parliamentarians representing the Labor Party have attended all the meetings; perhaps Opposition members on the Council had more pressing commitments at the time and were unable to attend. That gave us problems with quorums and meeting times. Nevertheless, removing the parliamentarians from trade union training in no way diminishes parliamentary control over that organisation.

I faced the somewhat ironical situation when I served on the Australian Council of discussing issues there and then, twice a year, when I sat as Chairman of an Estimates Committee, of hearing the Council explaining what it had done throughout the year. There is no doubt that such a body can be made properly accountable to this Parliament via the Estimates Committee. The Council appears here, in common with similar bodies, and is able to be cross-examined as to its activities. I think the presence of parliamentary representatives did not add a lot to the original organisation. The provision was there originally as an inducement or persuasion to both political parties that at least they would have one friend in court when the future of the body came up. Senator Harradine will realise that from the time of its inception and a change in government its future was in doubt for several years. I think the Liberal Party often considered whether the organisation should continue. To its credit, the coalition Government continued that organisation, continued to fund it properly, and to oversee its growth. The Liberals are to be congratulated on that.

As I have said, we have two conflicting issues before us in this chamber. One is that these amendments should not have been in this Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill; I think we on this side of the chamber concede that. But to reinforce that principle and to make this an example will hurt the organisation itself. We do not have time now to bring in the changes. Very shortly, if it has not already been announced, we will have a new director of this organisation and new directions for it. I would like to see them operating under the new guidelines rather than their being delayed for six months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can reply on behalf of the Government along the same lines as Senator Robert Ray, it may be on reflection that this is a measure which, because of the substantive structural changes involved, should have been the subject of separate legislation. I do not protest too strongly against that ground of the criticism that has been advanced by Senator Harradine. I think Senator Ray addressed that point. As to the actual substance of the changes, I think it is necessary to say a word or two because the matter has been raised now by Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems that were experienced with the previous structure of the organisation were pretty much as Senator Robert Ray has described them. More than half of the members of the Council will also serve on the Executive Board and there has been considerable duplication in matters considered by the two bodies. It is said that those who serve only on the Council feel that they have only a limited opportunity to contribute to the Trade Union Training Authority particularly in the area of policy development. It is proposed now to vest basically the policy responsibility of the Executive Board in the Council itself. Again, it has been increasingly difficult to secure a quorum on the Council, perhaps because of the limited opportunity that the members have had to contribute to the character of the organisation's development in their role as Council members. Again, State Council members have been concerned about their limited role in developing TUTA's programs and there has also been some misunderstanding within TUTA about the responsibilities and relationship between the positions of Director of Studies and the National Director. All these questions are addressed in these amendments.

The restructuring of the various Council bodies has been done to provide a broader representation by the inclusion of elected staff representatives and, on the regional councils, an officer or employee of the Authority nominated by the National Director. The additional positions for representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions on the Australian Council were provided to allow for the inclusion, amongst those representatives, of persons from the State trades and labour councils. This is intended to strengthen the link between the Australian Council and the regional councils and so facilitate co-operation and understanding between them. As for the regional councils, the representation of the relevant trades and labour councils was increased to maintain the existing ratio of representation and it reflects the inclusion on those councils of elected staff representatives and an officer-employee of the Authority nominated by the National Director.

As to the accountability of the body to parliament, again the situation is as was very succinctly put by Senator Ray. The Authority is and will remain responsible to the Parliament through the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I might also mention that section 8 of the Trade Union Training Authority Act expressly provides that the Authority is to comply with the directions, if any, given by the Minister to the Executive Board in relation to the performance of a function or the exercise of a power by the Authority under the Act. Except that the reference to the Executive Board will not be changed to a reference to the Australian Council, that provision will be quite unaltered by these amendments.

I conclude by saying that, although one can well argue-Senator Harradine has chosen understandably to do so-about the vehicle for these amendments-they really ought not to be regarded as contentious or controversial. They are designed to improve and streamline the administration. They are compatible with continued parliamentary accountability. They have been approved, for what that is worth, by the National Labour Consultative Council representing government, employers and trade unions and I hope that they can now be approved by this Parliament in order that, as Senator Robert Ray has said, the Trade Union Training Authority can very quickly now, under its proposed new direction, in the next few months become the viable organisation that it needs and deserves to be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not want to delay the Committee but the fact that we are now into a full-scale debate on the merits or otherwise of what are now conceded to be substantial amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act indicates that this is certainly not the appropriate vehicle for those amendments. I feel that I need at least to insist upon going forward with the amendment which I now foreshadow, that as far as pages 112 to 117 are concerned, leave out proposed amendments up to and including proposed new section 29.

SPEECH.PARA: I have listened to what Senator Robert Ray and the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) have said. What has been said in effect is that this is an attempt to improve the efficiency of the organisation. I would dispute that in certain respects; I acknowledge it in some respects but I dispute it in other respects, and I will deal with that matter in a moment. The Government has said that this legislation will improve the organisation's efficiency, it will increase the size of the Australian Council, it will reduce the size of the Executive Board and it will establish regional councils. It will not reduce the size of the Executive Board; it will actually abolish the Executive Board. The Executive Board has been established by statute. There may have been some problems about forming quorums as far as the Australian Council was concerned, but as far as the Executive Board was concerned that was not a problem. There may have been other problems in the operation of the Executive Board. I am aware of those problems and they are quite serious problems. But what the Government is doing by this measure is abolishing the Executive Board whose constitution, functions, meeting procedures, et cetera, are laid down by statute. But that does not give to a statutory body the authority for the day-to-day running of the Council. What it does do is state that the Executive Board will be called the Executive Committee.

I ask the Minister and the Government to tell me where, in this legislation that is before us, does this measure give power to the Council to establish an Executive Committee? Who will constitute that Executive Committee? Let us face it, it will be the Executive Committee that will have the responsibility for the day-to-day operation and the week-to-week operation of the Trade Union Training Authority. The Australian Council will be called together only once every three months or six months. The Executive Committee will have the authority. Will the Minister please tell me where, in this piece of legislation, there is provision for the constitution and the functions of the Executive Committee? We are really talking about the running of the Trade Union Training Authority. It will be the Executive Committee that will do that whereas previously it was the Executive Board.

We have heard from Senator Ray that the Australian Council could not get quorums. In fact, it was run by the Executive Board and I know the problems there. We are now saying: 'Abolish the Executive Board'. It was actually some of the membership of the Executive Board that was the problem, not so much the statutory constitution and the functions required by statute. The operation of the Executive Board was at fault. It was the failure of the Australian Council to get quorums and to take the leadership in that area that was at fault in at least one case. What the Government is asking us to do now is to remove from the statute the strict provisions which would operate as far as the Executive Board's constitution and functions are concerned, and simply to abolish that Executive Board and to establish an Executive Committee which, under this statute, will have no constitution and no functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, I am somewhat confused by your amendment. You have talked about the Executive Committee, which is covered by proposed new sections 29A through to 29D. Your amendment refers only to proposed new section 29, pages 112 to 116. Will you please clear that point up for me?
—I do not think I can be blamed for the situation in which we find ourselves.
—I am not suggesting that.
—We are dealing with a major matter.
—We have to go to page 117.
—Yes, we have to go to page 117. I did say '117', although it is written as '116'.
—Yes, you did mention it. That is why I wanted to be sure about it.

—I am sorry, Mr Temporary Chairman. I have floated that amendment in trying to respond to Senator Robert Ray's concern. I acknowledge that there is a need for efficiency, but I certainly do not accept that the changes to the State councils will contribute to efficiency. That is one area at which we ought to be looking. I will certainly be proposing an amendment, if to nothing else, to the constitution of the State councils.

—I do not want to prolong this debate unduly, but it has to be said that there has been possibly some misunderstanding on the part of Senator Harradine as to what is going on here. The Executive Board is being abolished. Its policy making functions are being totally combined in the Australian Council, which hitherto had limited functions when it came to policy, many of which were vested in the Executive Board. The Executive Board will disappear and be replaced by an Executive Committee, whose functions and composition are defined with some precision in proposed new section 29A, on the bottom of page 116 running over to page 117. The Executive Committee is formed wholly from the membership of the Australian Council. It exists essentially as a small management committee, of a kind which any organisation has to have to deal with non-policy matters between meetings of the larger body. It is an entirely familiar organisational arrangement, which I imagine Senator Harradine would have come across a thousand times in his diverse career up until now. It is not intended to vest any policy responsibility in the Executive Committee; it is simply there to keep the wheels turning between meetings of the Australian Council, which will be the proper policy making body in a way that has not been able to be established so far. Against that background, if Senator Harradine reads carefully what is in proposed new sections 29A and 29B, against the functions which will be vested in the Australian Council, he will see that it is not as draconian or difficult as he imagines. I understand the difficulty he is having because he is trying to respond to all of this on the run, but I can only suggest to the Senate that there is nothing justifying contention in this particular matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I acknowledge what the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) said. I am not trying to interfere with a proposition which would affect the efficiency of the organisation. I know that there have been problems, and I acknowledge what the Minister has said-I have seen that here. The Australian Council, however, is now to be changed by taking off the two members of parliament and increasing by three the membership from the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It can be argued whether it is appropriate to take off the two members of parliament. We can all see that this shows that this is not the appropriate place to deal with that. The Minister said that the reason for the extra three members from the ACTU being appointed is to ensure that there is representation from the State trades and labour councils. Of course, there are six State trades and labour councils.
—They can rotate.
—They will be rotated?
—Some concept like that, to get a continuous flow of input from your old stamping grounds.
—I understand that that would be desirable, but again that is not a matter which will remedy a technical defect.
—This legislation is about not only technical defects, but also small administrative matters.
—They are not small, and many of them are not administrative.
—They are policy.
—Policy, as Senator Macklin said.
—Uncontentious policy matters.

—Let me go to one matter about which I can see some contention arising in all of the States, that is, the situation of the State councils which will be removed and called regional councils for the State. What is the difference between regional councils and a regional council for a State? Is it envisaged that there will be a number of regional councils within the State and a regional council for a State? That is one question. The key issue is this: The functions of the State councils are clearly defined by this amendment. The functions of the State councils are to advise and make recommendations to the Australian Council in relation to matters of trade union training in the State or Territory and to ensure that the training provided by the Trade Union Training Centre for State or Territory is in accordance with the policy formulated by the Australian Council.

SPEECH.PARA: Now I come to the constitution. At present the constitution of the State councils is as follows: One person appointed by the Minister, one officer of the Department appointed by the Minister, five persons appointed by the relevant trade union organisation, one person to represent the branch of the Confederation of Australian Industry and one person appointed by the Minister to represent the interests of technical and further education in the State. The original legislation says 'promote', and this amendment omits that and inserts 'represent'. That is a technical matter; that is fair enough. The amendment adds another three members to the State councils. In my view, one could argue that the presence on such a body of two of those members was not entirely appropriate. The amendment of paragraph 20 (1) at page 114 provides for the alteration of the constitution to add certain persons to the State Authority by inserting after paragraph (c):
one person, being an officer or employee of the Authority, appointed by the Minister on the nomination of the National Director;
one person, being an officer or employee of the Authority, to represent the officers and employees of the Authority--
has one ever heard anything so incestuous--
elected in accordance with the regulations by the officers and employees of the Authority employed in the State and appointed by the Minister.

We are talking about a council for trade union training. The effect of this would be to give the club-that is to say, the people who are running the show-the real power. I do not think that that is a good idea. That is not an efficient way of going about things. If this is to be a council for trade union training, it should respond to the wishes of those in the area, that is to say, the industrial officers, the rank and file members and the like. But here the proposition is to appoint a person nominated by the National Director. By the way, it need not be the State Director. There might have been some sense in it if it were the State Director, although I do not agree with that, because the State Director is present at all of these meetings.

Additionally, it refers to a person from the staff. In fact, we will have a small State trade union training centre with two people from the staff on the committee deciding what ought to be done in the area of trade union training in that State. I do not think that is entirely appropriate. I am generally in agreement with staff-elected representatives, but not on the type of advisory body that these State councils are. I make it clear that these bodies are not executive bodies; they are advisory bodies. Why should members of the staff of the Authority be on those bodies so as to influence unduly the area advice to the Australian Council? They can put their advice to the Australian Council through their bureaucratic means.

If there is great concern about this matter, I am prepared to propose an amendment for two reasons. Firstly, I believe that the Government's amendment to paragraph 20 (1) (c) will not increase the efficiency of the organisation. Secondly, I am concerned that the current councils will all be abolished. On page 113 it is proposed that section 9 be repealed and that the proposed new section read:
Upon the commencement of this section, the councils established by sub-sections 9 (2) and (3) . . . as in force immediately before that commencement cease to exist.
They will just go out of existence. What will happen? Will they have to have new elections?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—They do not?

—No. It is a change of name from State to regional to allow for the Territory councils which are proposed to be established by regulations, as it says in proposed sub-section 9 (4). That is the sole reason for the change of name.
—But it is adding to those councils?
—Adding to their composition.
—But it significantly changes the composition. I accept that the change of name can well be a technical--
—It is designed to cope with the reality of the Territories; that is all.
—I acknowledge that it is a technical matter, but I do not acknowledge that the change in composition is a technical matter in any shape or form. Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 114, Schedule 1, proposed amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975, leave out amendment to paragraph 20 (1) (c) and proposed new paragraphs (d) and (e).

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we have the amendment in writing?

— While Senator Harradine is putting that in writing I will take a little time to return to page 99 and Schedule 1, and the amendment proposed to the Public Works Committee Act 1969, consideration of which was deferred earlier. As a result of the discussion which has taken place, it appears that it will be best if the Joint Committee on Public Works puts to the Senate in writing, clearly and formally, what it wants and then the Senate can deal with what has been placed before it formally by that Committee. In the meantime, I accept the undertaking given by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) in relation to the procedure which will be adopted until such time as that other procedure has been followed and the matter comes back before us. I also understand that the Minister will co-operate in ensuring that the business is listed if any amendment needs to be made. On that basis, I withdraw my proposed amendment.

—I am grateful to Senator Peter Rae for reacting in that way. I am a little puzzled that he did not fully clarify the record by saying that he was acting on behalf of Senator Sheil. As I understand it, Senator Sheil misunderstood what had transpired in the Joint Committee on Public Works; there had been no resolution by that Committee to endorse the Opposition amendment. I make no imputation whatsoever against Senator Sheil in that respect but simply say that, in a rather confused flurry of circumstances, it was evident that there was some misunderstanding. Senator Foreman's account to the Senate was, accordingly, correct, as was my briefing. That having been said--
—I tried to avoid this.
—I just think that, since so many allegations about misunderstanding were thrown around by people in various parts of the chamber, it is as well to clarify the record.
—I still do not have the foggiest idea what Senator Foreman was talking about.
—I accept what has been said by Senator Rae and I think that that is an appropriate way of doing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not withdraw what I said about Senator Sheil; nor do I accept that Senator Sheil was wrong. I simply believe that it is in the interests of this chamber that we proceed on a sensible basis by withdrawing this matter until the Joint Committee on Public Works places before us in writing what it wants done. That is what I propose to do. I do not propose to get into an argument with Senator Evans over his lack of grace in wanting to lay blame on one person and his saying that somebody, who I consider made an absolutely unintelligible speech, was correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Peter Rae's)-by leave-withdrawn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has now submitted his amendment in writing. The question now is: That the words proposed to be left out by Senator Harradine's amendment be left out. Those of that opinion say aye; the contrary, no. I think the noes have it.

INTERJECT.PARA: A division having been called and the bells being rung-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek leave to call off the division.
—Is leave granted to call off the division? There being no objection, leave is granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I want to make very clear what has just happened. Despite all the arguments that have been presented on this matter, despite the very substantial amendments which are included in this legislation, which are not of a technical nature at all-including amendments which withdraw representation from this Parliament on the Trade Union Training Authority, including amendments which change the constitution of the Trade Union Training Authority-and which have been acknowledged by both sides of the chamber to be very substantial amendments indeed, the Liberal Party of Australia has agreed to support the Government in getting these amendments through by this means. Admittedly some of the measures contained in these amendments are appropriate, but they are not appropriate to be included in a Bill which is designed simply to correct technical deficiencies. I defy anybody to say that this is a proper exercise. But Liberal Party members supported the Government, presumably because these amendments have been rubber stamped by the National Labour Advisory Council. I do not care that the employers and the NLAC believe that just because they agree with something it ought to be rubber stamped by the Parliament, but of course I care about and consider what the trade union movement says and what various employer groups say. I have studied carefully what they have said and am in fairly regular contact with them.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as I am concerned, what we have seen here has been really an exercise by the Liberal Party deliberately not to understand, accept or acknowledge the validity of arguments that have been presented in this chamber about matters that come before us. As it has been told by the employers that it is okay by them, so it is okay by the Liberal Party. As far as I am concerned that is a retrograde way for the Liberal Party to act. It is quite contrary to what ought to be the approach adopted in this chamber to matters of very grave character indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened, as we all have, for a long time to Senator Harradine speaking on this particular aspect of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. I was hoping that the debate on this legislation, which already has been prolonged excessively, might have been brought to a close, but I cannot let Senator Harradine's remarks go unanswered. When this debate commenced I pointed out the fact that the Opposition did not believe it was appropriate that there should be so many and such important amendments as those to the Trade Union Training Authority legislation, included in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill, and I also referred to one or two other examples. The Opposition is opposed to that sort of policy. However, when the Minister representing the Attorney-General, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), responded, he expressed the Government's agreement with that view and also tabled guidelines which indicated that the Government would accept that view in the future. I am glad of that as the criticism which the Opposition had on this matter has been met by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We studied the legislation in detail and decided that although there were some aspects of it that we wished to amend-those amendments have been moved to other areas such as to the Defence Act and, although there has been some confusion about it, to the Public Works Committee Act-there were other provisions of this Bill to which, although we believed they should not have appeared in this legislation, we were not opposed. That is why we took the course we did, unlike Senator Harradine, who had not studied the legislation at all and who came into this chamber only because he had heard me speaking during the second reading debate and saying that the Bill contained substantial amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —He had thrown it in his waste paper basket.

—Yes, I think he said he had thrown it in his waste paper basket. That is how little attention he, as a member of the Senate, has paid to a whole range of major amendments to legislation. Now he has the gall to get up and accuse the Liberal Party of not acting in a parliamentary manner. The fact is that we had studied this legislation and formed views about it, and it was only because I mentioned some aspect of it which interested Senator Harradine that he came in here at all and spent an hour or more debating the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I cannot let that matter go past without saying that I acknowledge that I had assumed that the normal guidelines would be observed by the Government in dealing with the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. I believed that the Bill was simply a measure to rectify technical defects which had been created in legislation and which had emerged as being such. That is why any person in my position would say that if they are technical matters they ought to be dealt with as technical matters. With all the other major pieces of legislation being amended I took the view, which I believed was the correct one, that the Government had acted properly, and I assumed that it had included in this legislation only amendments of a technical nature. When I heard what Senator Durack had to say in the debate I hurriedly retrieved the legislation and found that in fact there were 60 very substantial amendments to the Trade Union Training Authority Act. It did not take me long to study the legislation because I was a member of the interim council of the Trade Union Training Authority and have had a great interest for many years in developing trade union training in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Opposition has not acknowledged the validity of the arguments that have been presented on the merits of the case. The very fact that arguments had to be presented on the merits of the case shows that the clauses are not of a technical character. There is no dissent in any shape or form by the Opposition with the arguments I put forward, particularly as they relate to the composition of the various councils. The shadow Minister, Senator Durack, still acknowledges that the matter had been predetermined by his Party. The Opposition is not susceptible to reasoned argument when the matter comes before the chamber.

We have had plenty of occasions in the last week when the Liberals have not listened to the arguments. They have said: 'This is the Government's legislation. The sitting of the House of Representatives is suspended. We will let the Government change the laws as it proposes. It can live with it'. I believe that the Senate is a House of review, although I acknowledge what Senator Durack has said. He attempted to amend these provisions so far as they relate to the defence legislation. I listened to his arguments, understood them and supported them. However, I would have hoped that the same courtesy would have been applied to my arguments and that the Opposition would not have voted in accordance with some predetermined position for a Bill which contains provisions which alter principal legislation very substantially when the form of this Bill is designed solely to correct technical defects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that Senator Harradine does not stand alone on this matter. The Australian Democrats made it quite clear that we were willing to vote with him, principally because we believe that a message should be sent to the Government that it is not acceptable practice for the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1) 1985 to contain changes of direction in policy. The areas to which Senator Harradine has referred are matters of substance which reflect the Government's policy and they should be in a separate Bill which can be debated appropriately in this place. I also agree with the comment made by Senator Harradine that this week we have seen a new coalition in the Senate. It is rather disappointing to see the Government, the Liberal Party and the National Party voting together so frequently and ignoring, in the case of the Opposition parties, their responsibilities to represent people who will be affected adversely by the legislation which has been passed this week. This may well be another example of that practice. However, the main reason for my speaking is to ask the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) to take on board the very real concern of the Senate that this type of legislation is not acceptable in the format of Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT BILL 1985BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1985TELEVISION STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes this package of Bills-the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1985, the Broadcasting and Television (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1985, the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1985, and the Television Stations Licence Fees Amendment Bill 1985. It agrees with the purpose of the Bills, which is to remove the confusion and complexities which presently exist, and lends its support to what the Government is doing. Because we support the Bills I will not speak at length. I remind the Senate that the initiatives we are seeing are in line with initiatives which were being developed under the Fraser Government. Accordingly, the majority of these initiatives, which we were developing in government, now appear in this legislation. They are in line with the direction intended to be taken by Liberal and National Party policies and by the coalition during the later stages of its term. Therefore, we have no disagreement with the thrust of the four pieces of legislation which make up the package although some matters will be raised, I believe, by the Australian Democrats in the Committee stage. We will be interested to hear the response of the Government to particular concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: It might have been better, because of the great complexity of these Bills, had the Government laid them on the table to provide the opportunity for all interested parties to give them more scrutiny before they were passed. However, the Opposition is not unsympathetic to the Government's need to resolve the question of licences for remote areas of Australia and to the need for the Government to be able to go ahead immediately with the issue of these licences when the Acts are proclaimed. So, although we would have preferred more time for those with interest and concern to have examined and responded to the legislation, nevertheless we understand why the Government has pursued the course it has. There was no need for urgency, in a sense, as the regulations and proclamation may not occur for six months. However, again we understand that the Government has a timetable which it wishes to follow.

The legislation proposes to change the way in which broadcasting and television licences are granted. Instead of a body being licensed to operate a transmitter as at present, licences will now be required to provide a service to a specified area. So people will now be able to get licences for certain areas rather than licences to operate one transmitter. One point of controversy is the associated provision for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to hold an area inquiry into the adequacy of all the services in the service area as a supplement to, or possibly as a substitute for, individual licence renewal hearings. This will be a considerable change from what occurs at present. We have no real understanding as to how it will operate on the ground. We just hope that the hearing of inquiries regarding the adequacy of services to an area will work effectively.

The Bills will implement a number of recent Government decisions regarding, among other things, first, the revision of the broadcasting legislation to relate it to services rather than to technologies, and secondly, the licensing of services to outback areas utilising the satellites of Aussat Pty Ltd. This will be either the remote commercial television service or the remote commercial radio service.

The Bills also relate to changes to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's inquiry procedures additional to those passed in 1984. I believe that when Senator Vigor speaks he may raise a matter in relation to this part of the legislative package. The legislative package includes the extension of some rights of appeal against decisions made under the Broadcasting and Television Act and the deletion of some obsolete provisions of the Act. One consequence of this Act to which the Senate's attention should be drawn is that the legislation will prevent in an effective way the major networks from providing a service to remote areas by way of incidental reception of their program relays.

Honourable senators will be aware that there has been considerable argument for the last two years as to what is the role and the place of the major networks in providing services to non-metropolitan Australia and there has been an equal concern by rural networks that they should be able to survive with the new technological capacities which will be conferred by the existence and operation of the satellite. In fact, the major networks will be prevented effectively from providing a service to remote areas by way of incidental reception to their program relays unless they are specifically authorised by a remote area licence. The major networks will be required to seek an area licence for incidental reception to become allowable. Honourable senators may wish to consider whether that is the best resolution of the problem. As I say, the Opposition supports the legislation and supports what the Government has decided to do.

The discretionary powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal have been widened in this legislation insofar as it will have greater freedom to determine the parties to a hearing as well as restricting participation by any party at a hearing. In relation to particular clauses of the legislative package, the Opposition's spokesman, the Hon. John Moore, drew attention in another place to problems in relation to clauses 8, 10, 12, 19, 23, 42, 65 and 92 of the principal piece of legislation. I do not intend to canvass these again. The Opposition supports this legislation and will vote with the Government in securing its passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by thanking Senator Peter Baume for his lucid explanation of the Opposition's position on this matter. As appears from his remarks, the Opposition agrees with the general thrust of this legislation, though there are some details about which it has some reservations. Firstly, the legislation, as Senator Baume pointed out, provides for a new means of licensing radio and television services. Until now the stations from which the transmissions have been made have been the subject of the licensing. From now on, areas to which the transmissions will be made will be the features that will be licensed. There is a change in that respect and that should help the technical advancement of the stations and their ability to update and to keep viable the services they provide.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, this legislation introduces licences for transmission to remote areas. The remote commercial television and radio services will provide a mechanism which will give people quality viewing and listening services which until now have been available only to people in more settled areas. It is in the area of remote licences that most controversy over this legislation has arisen, although not so much perhaps in Parliament as outside it.

Thirdly, this legislation grants additional power to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Tribunal will be empowered to have an area inquiry; that is, an inquiry into a particular area in which a particular station broadcasts or puts its television signal. The Tribunal will be able to assess whether that particular area is being properly serviced by the stations involved. Tribute in this matter is due to the considerable skill and determination of the Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, who has guided this legislation to its success. He has acted as a Minister should-with great determination-and has brought this legislation to its fruition.
Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, until 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be raised and discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his reply to a question without notice last Monday the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) referred to the edited remarks of the Chief Minister for the Northern Territory, Mr Tuxworth, in the Australian Financial Review of 27 May. The Chief Minister was reported as saying that the Territory is 'provided with no more, no less than the States' in the level of financial assistance from the Commonwealth Government. I would say that with remarkable prescience Senator Walsh gave a prepared reply which has since been tabled in this chamber. Senator Walsh pointed out that the Commonwealth payments to the Northern Territory in 1984-85 are estimated to be some $932m and that this represents a level of funding five times larger than equivalent payments to the States on a per capita basis. Unwittingly or otherwise the Minister has misinterpreted the Chief Minister's remarks, for the only reasonable interpretation of what the Chief Minister said in the Financial Review article is that he considers the Territory to be provided by the Commonwealth with a level of assistance which enables the Territory to provide a range and level of government services broadly on a par with those provided in the States.

SPEECH.PARA: The memorandum of understanding which was negotiated between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory at the time of self-government-I have referred to it several times before-sets out the basis for Commonwealth- Territory financial relationships. The memorandum is designed to allow the Northern Territory Government to function by reasonable effort at a standard not appreciably below the standards of the States. This is in line with the principle of fiscal equalisation, a principle which has been fundamental to Federal financial relationships in the Commonwealth for over 50 years. In simple terms this principle means that all Australians, regardless of where they may happen to live in the Commonwealth, are entitled to some basic level of government services. The Territory's level of financial assistance from the Commonwealth has been assessed in considerable detail on a regular basis since self-government by the Commonwealth's own advisory body on Federal financing arrangements; that is, the Commonwealth Grants Commission.

Up until its most recent report the Grants Commission has always found that, first, the level of Commonwealth funding was justified and, secondly, supplementary assistance above and beyond the normal funding arrangements was justified; for example, in its 1981-82 report the Grants Commission recommended a special grant of some $17m. It is interesting to note that in its most recent report the Commission assessed the Territory to have been overfunded by $13m or about 1.5 per cent of total Commonwealth payments to the Northern Territory. The Territory has approached the Commonwealth to bring funding arrangements back into line with the States following this assessment.

The essential point to be grasped is not that Territorians are being accorded privileges at the hands of the Commonwealth Government which the States do not enjoy, but simply that it costs five times as much on a per capita basis to provide basic government services in the Territory as it does for Australia as a whole. These higher per capita costs arise for a number of reasons. Principally, they are because of the Territory's isolation from the main centres of population and economic activity in Australia. Secondly, they arise from the dispersion of the Territory's population into small, widely scattered population clusters and the smallness of the population relative to geographical size, for the Northern Territory has a population of around 140,000 people scattered over an area that is 20 per cent larger than that of New South Wales and Victoria combined.

Thirdly, there is the distinctive composition of the Territory's population, particularly the fact that Aboriginals constitute approximately one-quarter of the Territory's population. To illustrate the implications of this for the provision of government services, I point out that approximately half of the total cost of health services provided by the Territory Government equals nearly one-third of the cost of education services after services to Aboriginal people. The population of the Northern Territory is some 0.8 per cent of one per cent of the total for Australia. Total net payments by the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory represent about 1.5 per cent of the total of all government spending in Australia.

Viewed in that light, Senator Walsh's claims of substantial overfunding for the Territory have a hollow ring. His attacks make much of the per capita level of Commonwealth funding to the Northern Territory, but he has failed to look at the other side of the coin. For example, he fails to acknowledge that the growth rate of the Northern Territory is the fastest of any State or Territory in Australia, at 3.2 per cent against a national average of 1.2 per cent. He also fails to recognise that the Northern Territory's per capita exports for 1983-84 amounted to some $4,080, or more than three times as much as the $1,510 national average, and more than four times as much as New South Wales which managed $970 per capita.

It is regrettable that Senator Walsh's zeal for economy and matters affecting the public purse, laudable enough in itself, has developed in this instance to a somewhat less than magnificent obsession about the level of Territory funding, one that reveals, I believe, a serious misunderstanding of the Territory situation. I have here two scales; one is the dollar values of exports on a State by State basis for 1983-84, which shows that the Northern Territory-the lowest-need not be ashamed with its $567 billion. I seek leave to have the table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
