TALK.START.PARA: —The table also sets out Australian exports on a per capita basis State by State, and shows that the Northern Territory, on $4,080 per head, is the highest in the Commonwealth against, as I have said before, the Australian national average of some $1,510. Very briefly, I think that Australia should be heartened about the development in the north and in the interior. Indeed, we have heard over the years the story of the empty north, the undeveloped north, but now it is expanding and we are seeing young people from Australia moving to the north, to the north coast; we are seeing that the population of the Northern Territory is the fastest growing area in Australia. We are seeing the various industries which are attracting employment, including the pastoral and mining industries which have tremendous potential. We see the enormous development of tourism with international and national companies coming in, building up tremendous capital structures and bringing about immense employment. There was a criticism, of course, by the Minister about the amount of money that is spent on advertising. Might I say that this amount of money that has been spent on advertising is bringing handsome returns in the way of capital investment and the development of the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing I raise one matter that concerns me. I mentioned this in Hansard of the Senate of 22 May during the adjournment debate, when I was talking about the possibility of indirect taxation and the effect on the people of the north and in the interior. At that time I was speaking of the implications for the Northern Territory of a retail sales tax and it is not my intention to go through that again. All I am warning the Commonwealth, the Parliament and the people of Australia is this: If you want the continued development of the north, which is so essential for security, and all those things that the people of the south and of Parliament say are most highly desirable, please do not forget the people who live up there now and are living under extremely difficult circumstances.

I have illustrated the cost of living in Hansard of 22 May. If these young people are to be encouraged to continue coming to the north, please do not think that the people of the outback are being overfunded. It is over to the Commonwealth, it is over to the people. The growth is tremendous up there and I believe I have indicated the other day and today that there is no argument to support the Commonwealth Minister who claims that the funds going into the Northern Territory bring about a situation where there is overfunding. What I am saying is that the Commonwealth and the people of Australia must spend more to encourage the development of the north and the interior.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I want to use this debate very briefly to bring to the attention of the Senate a very worthwhile suggestion that has been made to me which would increase the number of blood donors, especially women blood donors. The blood transfusion service is, as everybody knows, concerned to attract more women donors because of the stricter rules about donors arising out of the spread of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Many more donors are needed, many more regular donors. The suggestion is that child care facilities be provided for a specified few hours each week at each Red Cross blood bank. This would involve the employment of a graduate child carer on specific days and times, identified as suitable by transfusion service staffs. In large cities, the graduate could be mobile and could service five centres a week. As a backup, undergraduate child care students from technical and further education colleges could use the transfusion centre casual care as an applied skills placement. I understand this would be in line with the national core curriculum now in place in most TAFE colleges.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an urgent need to increase the numbers of women blood donors and this concept would allow people with children-women in particular-to donate blood knowing that their children were well supervised. As an incentive, perhaps an extra hour or two of care could be allowed after the donation of blood to allow the donor to go shopping or indulge in some other respite activity. This proposal comes from Joan Fitz-Nead who is head of the Child Care Department at the Hobart Technical College and it is supported by Dr Young, the Medical Director of the Red Cross Blood Transfusion Service in Hobart. I think it is an exciting idea which I have already discussed with the Minister for Health, Neal Blewett, and the Minister for Community Services, Don Grimes, who have both reacted encouragingly to it.

I urge them to bring it into fruition as both a child care project and a health project. It is possible that there are funds available under the allocation for dealing with AIDS. It does involve co-operation amongst the Government, the Red Cross and TAFE colleges, and I trust that the necessary co-operation will occur and that the proposal will be implemented as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to draw the Senate's attention to the urgency to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act to uphold the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal over standards in Australian content. I wish to raise the context in which the need to do something straight away has arisen. For a long time experts in communication law have known that the Broadcasting and Television Act probably would not survive any court challenge in this area. As long as the Australian Broadcasting Control Board and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal did not do anything to assert their powers under the legislation, everybody was content to leave things be. But as soon as the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal moved to assist the Australian film production industry there were challenges which appeared from all sides.

—Order! Senator Vigor, you have on the Notice Paper the Broadcasting and Television Amendment (Tribunal's Powers) Bill which has been adjourned. You are not entitled to anticipate that debate. I have not got the Bill before me; I have not got your second reading speech. You may not initiate that debate now. You may carry on with other unrelated material.

—This is related to the Bill and brings up a problem which the Bill attempts to solve, but I was not going to bring up the Bill itself in this debate. There has been an enormous debate within the community and the Bill mentioned was an attempt to handle this matter. I believe that this legislation should be taken up by the Government. There has been a lot of debate in the media concerning the control of standards for children's television. I would like to quote from an article in the Hobart Mercury of Thursday 23 May 1985 concerning the controlling of standards for children's television. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The standard of television for children has come under greater scrutiny in recent years as concerned parents and educators have worried about the often distorted images of society to which children are continually being exposed. Improving the quality of children's television is obviously a difficult task requiring adequate funding and greater co-ordination of professional advice.

However, the recent quashing by the High Court of an attempt by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to vet samples of children's television before they go to air shows how inadequate the law is in this area. In what is a victory for the commercial television networks the decision enforces the ludicrous situation whereby the Tribunal will only be able to check the suitability and adequacy of children's programs after they have been screened.
This is a really serious problem which was addressed as early as 14 February by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). In a Press release on 14 February 1985 the Minister said:

The Government will amend broadcasting legislation to remove any threat to film and television production in Australia flowing from doubts about the validity of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal standards.

The Minister for Communications, Mr Michael Duffy, said today the Tribunal standards, both qualitative and quantitative, were crucial in supporting the local film and television industry. Without a firm commitment through legislation to these standards, industry employment and the expression of Australian culture through the broadcast media will suffer.

Mr Duffy said later in the Press release that it was in the public interest that doubts over the Tribunal's powers be removed. The Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 was amended as soon as possible to reinforce the Tribunal's powers to make standards. He continued:

The amendments will not add to the Tribunal's function but merely confirm the long accepted task it has carried out in this area. The Tribunal's ability to set quantitative standards is important as often it is the only effective way of achieving a qualitative objective. The specific subjects dealt with under the quantative rules include: (1) Broadcast times for children's programs, and the number of minutes of advertising in children's programs, (2) the quantity of advertising permitted per hour; and (3) the level of Australian program content.
The Minister committed himself to introduce legislation as soon as possible on this subject. We have not seen this legislation during this session. He went on to say:

The Tribunal's comprehensive set of program and advertising standards benefited the Australian film and television industry in its development phase and remains important to the industry's continued growth and development.

The standards have ensured that Australians have gained expertise and experience in film and television making. They have also helped the industry reflect Australian culture and assisted in the preservation and expansion of jobs.

The particular case which went through to the High Court has thrown all of this into question. We no longer have any guarantee, except for a statement by the Minister in his second reading speech to the legislation amending the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act which we are currently debating in the Senate, that he will introduce this again as soon as possible. We have had an enormous delay between 14 February and now. We still have not had the introduction of a Bill to amend the Act in that way and we are now being promised the same thing; the Minister has said that he will introduce it first thing next session. In the meantime the large television networks are able to cut costs and able to handle their television standards commitments in a cavalier way. This is really very disturbing.

The suddenness of the High Court's decision has apparently caught the Government unprepared. It is still awaiting the ruling of a Full Bench of the Federal Court on the Saatchi case which is dealing with Australian content in advertising. If it is held that the power to make standards is not an effective power of the Tribunal, that 'standards' means only technical standards, it means that there is nothing guaranteeing that the Australian advertising industry can survive the onslaught of material coming in from the United States and other parts of the world. This will result in widespread job loss and the local advertising industry will face considerable dislocation.

It is extremely important that these standards should be maintained. I have received a number of telegrams from different organisations which raise this point and I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a telegram chosen from several telegrams from various organisations. This particular telegram is from the South Australian Council for Children's Film and Television. I have obtained permission from both sides of the House for its incorporation.
Leave granted.
The telegram read as follows-
Senate AA62326
Telcom AA88765

Attn Senator David Vigor: South Australian Council has telexed Communications Minister Duffy urging him-''To introduce qualitative Australian Broadcasting Tribunal Television Standards Amendments today in light of High Court decision.
Amendments are needed now not in August.
1. To ensure they happen.
2. To maintain children's television programme standards.
3. To stabilise industry programming for children's television''
The Council asks for your support.
. . . South Australian Council for Children's Films and Television Inc. Attn P Dight ADO17 Senate AA62326
Telcom AA88765

TALK.START.PARA: —The telegram points out the real problem associated with children's television. Why should we put our children's television industry at risk when we are just starting to get an international reputation in this area? If there are no standards, I believe that the commercial interests of the larger producing organisations and the large networks will mean that the Australian content will go down, or at least the quality of the Australian content will go down. I believe that it is extremely important for the Government to grasp the nettle. It has an opportunity now of bringing on the Bill which I introduced into the House and we would certainly support that going through the Senate. Under those circumstances, as the Government has recalled the House of Representatives it has a chance of passing the Bill now and solving some of the problems which have been left by the High Court case. I call upon the Government to do this in the interests of children's television and the interests of parents.
—Senator Vigor, you are again transgressing into the area of the subject matter of your Bill.

—Right. I apologise, Mr Deputy President. I feel that it is extremely important for the Government to do something about this. It is extremely important for us to look very closely at the Broadcasting Tribunal's powers. It used to have the ability to give what is called a C classification which allowed certain programs to count towards material suitable for stations' quota of children's television. However, in this morning's Australian Financial Review there is an article headed: 'ABT Raps 9 over the knuckles, failure to meet Australian quotas'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Nine television network has failed to meet the Australian drama contents standard for the third year in succession, this time provoking the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to act.
Later on it states:

The findings could spell trouble for the network, which has made it clear that first-run Australian drama was not easy to find, and its production budgets could be further strained by its apparent decision, expected to be announced today, to buy a satellite transponder.
It is quite obvious that the commercial decisions of these large networks are going to militate against high Australian content and good television programs.

Currently censorship is left in a very strange way to the Film Censorship Board to classify just overseas films for television. The acceptance of commercial advertising is left to the Commercial Acceptance Division of the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations. This is the only type of control we have in that area. I believe we need an independent body, like the ABT. The ABT needs all the support it can get from the Government in order to be able to carry out its task effectively in the interests of the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I want to alert the Senate to some figures that have been sent to me from some people in New Zealand. The first ones, sent to me late in April show that on the 24th of that month it was stated that 44,500 New Zealanders left that country on a one-way basis and the bulk of them came to Australia. That figure is up 10,000 on the previous year. The interesting figure is that for the same 12-month period only 241 persons arrived in New Zealand on a one-way basis. Then I was given some other figures which appeared in the New Zealand Herald of 21 May and showed that the unemployment dole payments in New Zealand are dropping quite considerably. It is a short article headed 'Big Drop in Dole Payouts'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The number of people getting the unemployment benefit has fallen to 31,721, a drop of nearly 28 per cent compared with a year ago.
The latest figures released yesterday by the Minister of Social Welfare, Mrs Hercus, showed a drop of 3 per cent in the two weeks to May 10.
The number of those aged under 20 getting the unemployment benefit had also dropped dramatically, she said.
There were now 8,740 young people on the benefit compared with 13,189 this time last year . . .

That was a fall of about 34 per cent. It seems to me that when you put those figures together, the young people's dole payouts dropping and the number of people coming to this country, a lot of the people who are on the dole in New Zealand are coming to this country. I believe that they are going on the dole in this country, too. I have heard of some who come over here to go to university and they get assistance under the tertiary education assistance scheme where some Australians cannot. I think it is time that the Government woke up to this situation and stopped offering free access to this country and opening the Treasury coffers to all of these people from New Zealand. It seems to me that the Government should stop taking over New Zealand's unemployed and should refuse payments to all people until they have been gainfully employed in this country for some years. I do not think we should continue to allow New Zealand to export its unemployment problem to this country.

There is one other matter that I think bears raising in the same context, and that is that in Australia pensioners are rightly or wrongly-I believe wrongly-assets tested. If they are over the limit there is a penalty on them. I have asked this question before: What happens when a pension is sent to people who have chosen to leave Australia and live in another country? How are their pensions assets tested? Who is responsible for that testing? Do we send people away at great cost to spy on the way a pensioner lives in another country? The whole idea of sending pensions to those who choose to live in other countries, I believe, is one of the crazy things that happen and are supported by this Government. If a pensioner lives in Australia he spends his pension here and the general community benefits.

I ask: What benefit do we get from a pension that is spent in an overseas country? None whatsoever. I am sick and tired of seeing taxpayers' money sent overseas. If people choose to live-I emphasise 'choose to live', rather than just go on a holiday overseas-overseas and the Government is crazy enough to ship bucketfuls of taxpayers' money out of the country I believe that such pensions should be reduced to cover the assets situation and the multiplying effect of the spending that such pensions would have if they were spent in Australia. I suppose I should make it quite clear that I am really against any payment of pensions overseas. I suppose by saying that I will upset some of my friends who have made this country their home. Of course if they do remain here I have no objection to their getting their fair share of the pension.

The economy of this country, I believe, is on a knife edge at the moment. Our deficit is in cloud-cuckoo-land and the Government is going to attack every individual by increasing taxes. The Government is going to have to do that to make up for the expenditures in past years. In Australia it is time the Government recognised that the party is over. This country cannot afford the benefits that the Government is throwing around like a drunken sailor. That time has passed. I am not impressed by a reply from any Minister who says: 'Your Government did it too'. Sometimes I despaired for that Government too.

The situation is now so much worse than it used to be. As I said the other day in a debate in the Senate, next year we are going to spend more on public debt interest than on defence. This is the first time that our public debt interest has exceeded our defence spending. What is more alarming is the growth in interest payments on the public debt. In 1974-75 the figure was 4.98 per cent of our Budget. In 1987-88, on conservative figures, it will be almost 11 per cent of a much bigger figure of course, but 11 per cent of Budget. The projection is that nearly 11 per cent of our Budget will be spent just in servicing the interest on our public debt. Defence spending in 1974-75 represented about 9 per cent of the Budget. It is just over 10 per cent now. The figure that is increasing so dramatically, as shown in the Forward Estimates that were given to us a few days ago, is this public debt interest. Everything else is staying about constant but the public debt interest is increasing at something like 15 per cent per year.

I believe that the magnitude of our present credit problems is, as I said, such that this country is on a knife edge. Even before the devaluation of the dollar earlier this year the Age last November reported that it was a fact that on bankers' criteria Australia ranked as a debtor with some of the troubled countries. If we compare our position with that of our Tasman neighbour we see just how badly things could go in this country. If we look at the way the interest payments on public debt have gone in New Zealand and plot them as a graph alongside the Australian figures we see a marked similarity and something that has a very frightening exponential trend to it. I really do not know what is going to happen to the national debt. Something dramatic has to happen or we are certainly going to get into a very critical situation and we will be heading in the same direction as some of the banana republics of South America.

I read with interest Mr Stone's article in the Australian last weekend. I have not got it here to quote from, but in essence he said that whereas once upon a time we looked to the United States and said 'That is where Australia will be in a few years time', it is now obvious to those of us who follow the finances of this country that we should look to New Zealand and say: 'That is where we will be in a couple of years time'. That means most probably a much lower dollar; not straight away, it is going to be a gradual thing. It will mean difficulty in paying our debts and a reduced standard of living for everybody in this country. Of course, Tasmania-my State-with its low per capita income, I believe, will be one of the hardest hit.

I have been of late consistently trying to draw attention to the percentage of expenditure which is being outlaid on public debt interest. It is my belief that our national debt can be reduced to acceptable levels only by cutting heavily into government expenditure. Instead, this Government's only reply has been to shave minute amounts from its Budget Forward Estimates. Yet I believe we are still in a financial graveyard spiral, and Senator Collard would know, as an aviating man, just where one ends up in a graveyard spiral in an aeroplane. I quote from an article by Terry McCrann in the Age of 17 May. The article is headed 'Iron Man Keating'-and I think that is said rhetorically-'Helps Build a $55 billion Deficit'. It starts:

Despite Tuesday's mini-Budget, honoured more in the rhetoric than the substance-and speech, after Churchillian 'Battle of Britain' speech from Bob Hawke and Paul Keating-the undeniable truth is that Australia remains on that streetcar named Deficit, careering almost uncontrollably down a crazy path towards a fiscal hell.
Mr Deputy President, I have shown this section of the article to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
IRON MAN KEATING HELPS BUILD A $55 BILLION DEFICIT

Despite Tuesday's mini-budget, honoured more in the rhetoric than the substance-and speech after Churchillian ''Battle of Britain'' speech from Bob Hawke and Paul Keating-the undeniable truth is that Australia remains on that streetcar named Deficit, careering almost uncontrollably down a crazy path towards a fiscal hell.

The evidence is displayed in the table at the bottom of this column. The data, except for the last line, comes from the 1984 Budget papers. The bottom line, the fiscal ''aims'' for 1985-86, is calculated from Mr Keating's answer to a question from his predecessor John Howard in Parliament on Wednesday.

Mr Keating said that the public sector borrowing requirement-PSBR or, as presented in the table, the total public sector deficit-would come down from 7 per cent in the current fiscal year ''hopefully'' to nearer 6 per cent in 1985-86.
I have been charitable and assumed Mr Keating succeeds in getting it all the way down to 6 per cent.

But at that level it would still be among the highest in recent history in Australia. And in money terms it would be a quite staggering $13,700m or so, or barely a billion off 1983-84's biggest ever figure.

And further, consider, it would mean that over the four years to the 1985-86 year Governments in Australia would have collectively spent around $55 billion more than they would have collected in taxes and other revenues.

That money doesn't just fall from the sky, in some magic fulfillment of our, perhaps more sophisticated, cargo cult fantasies. It has to be paid for and it has to be serviced-out of taxes and charges-in the form of a floodtide of rising interest payments.
In just four years the nation's public debt will have risen by a sum equal to about one quarter of our total national output over the course of a year.
And Mr Keating is proud of his toughness, proud of his record.
Some toughness, some record.

The next financial year will be the third of recovery-assuming the upturn continues-from the 1981-82 recession. And yet we will still be running mammoth deficits in Canberra and across Government generally.

What happens if the economy dips into recession? Will we gaily pump the total public sector deficit up to 8 per cent of GDP, 10 per cent? And on top of the mammoth increase in the nation's debt burden over the last four years?

How sharply the centre of the debate has shifted; how inured we become to the ever-rising tide of Governmental red ink; how readily the Pavlovian dogs in some sections of the business community bark their praises of Mr Keating's fiscal muscle-power.

Only three years ago Malcolm Fraser managed to screw the federal budget deficit down to $548 million or less than half of one per cent GDP (Gross Domestic Product). And the total PSBR was around $6000 million or 4 per cent of GDP.

Now Mr Keating says that if Tuesday's-hard as warm butter-budget doesn't get next year's deficit below the 1984-85 figure, by gum he and the government will stick out their collective jaw and make further cuts in August's full Budget.
What an ambition! To get the deficit below $6700 million or ''well under'' 3 per cent of GDP-and on top of the masses of red ink in 1983-84 and 1984-85!
Perhaps Mr Keating believes that if he says ''tough'' often enough, the entire capital market will behave like well-trained Pavlovian dogs and both believe him and bark his praises.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. We are heading for the taxation debate. I said a moment ago that I believe everybody in this country is going to be taxed more heavily to pay for what the Government has spent over the last few years. It is no good saying it was the previous Government's fault. People of this country are not worried about past problems; they are worried about this problem that now faces them. They expect the Government they have to fix the situation. We are in a terribly dangerous financial situation in Australia and unless the Government can increase taxation by mammoth amounts we are not going to get out of this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the debate about taxation is out of control. Every day we see different things reported and it is obvious that the people within the Labor Party have many different views. The different sections have different views of just what should be done. But there is a truism, I think, within political life that tax reform-I always hate it when Labor Party people use the word 'reform' because it usually means dramatic change-always means increased taxes. Mr Keating can say to us loud and clear and often that taxes will not be increased, but the people of Australia and I do not believe him. The first two years of Mr Hawke's Government has seen government expenditure increase by an average of 7.1 per cent in contrast to Mr Fraser's government expenditure increase of an average of only 2.2 per cent. So Australians will soon see that tax reform is only a front for allowing this Government to raise more revenue to support the lavish expenditure that is going on.

I believe the Government's intentions are clear and that the people of Australia recognise it. The Government is saying clearly that taxpayers are going to be expected to make significant sacrifices, sacrifices which the Government is not prepared to make. There would be no need for a change in the tax system at all if the Government would simply show a little bit of discipline in its expenditure. Anyway, what guarantee does the taxpayer have that a substantial part of any new money raised will not be squandered? Mr Hawke is effectively asking taxpayers to give him their money and then to trust him to give it all back. But where has that trust been returned in the past? Ask the elderly people with their assets test or the Queenslanders held to ransom by their unions, or the sick under Medicare. Ask any Tasmanian without some of the essential freight subsidies that have been cut to that State.

Where has the Hawke magical mystery tour of faith taken us? The Government has broken promise after promise and, even if we do trust Mr Hawke's intentions, there is no guarantee that he will correctly predict the effects of inflation or the correct income compensation that is necessary if a broadly based tax is imposed. Monday's release of the Finance Department's overestimate of provisional tax receipts shows just how large this Government's miscalculations can be. While Mr Hawke continues on his cosmetic taxation public relations exercise the deficit time bomb, the deficit cancer, gets worse and worse. Eventually when the deficit explodes so that other countries do not trust our ability to pay and when they put us in a section where we are not in a triple A rating, this Government will be the one to blame.

Australia's per capita debt already exceeds that of Mexico, Chile, Poland and Argentina and, as I said, next year we will be spending more on interest than on health, education or defence. I believe that very few people can believe that this socialist Government led by Mr Hawke can or will do anything but increase our taxes at the tax summit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 23 May during the debate on the dairy legislation Senator Black made certain remarks concerning the purchase of a farm by a Mr Pat Rowley. Anyone reading those remarks could see them as imputing improper motives. Mr Rowley is the President of the Queensland Dairymen's Organisation and as such is on other industry boards both at a State and national level. So my brief remarks are mainly to put on record the facts about the purchase of this farm so that people within the industry will have no cause to doubt the integrity of one of their industry leaders.

SPEECH.PARA: As indicated, the farm was purchased on 12 February 1981. The point I want to make is that the farm was purchased lock, stock and barrel on a walk-in walk-out basis. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have at the moment the Premiers of the various States meeting in this building, negotiating on the share of grants from the tax take to be given by the Commonwealth Government. We in Tasmania have been told by the Commonwealth Grants Commission report that we should take a cut of, it first of all said, $40m. Later that figure was revised to $56m. Perhaps here a minor point should be made, Mr Deputy President, that last Tuesday Senator Aulich, a Tasmanian senator, in a question to Senator Button, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to newspaper reports published today which predict job losses of 4,300 people in Tasmania should the Commonwealth Government implement the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Report.
He asked:
Were any of the Grants Commission members appointed by the current Labor Government?
Senator Button in answer to that question said:
The fact is that members of the Grants Commission were appointed by the Fraser Government. They reported to this Government and the question of what is in their report requires objective analysis.

That is what Senator Button said and he picked that up from Mr Hawke, who on Sunday made the same statement which is entirely wrong. The facts are that two of the three commissioners were appointed by the Whitlam Government and one by the Holt Government. The Chairman, Mr Justice Else-Mitchell, was reappointed by the Hawke Government just last year and it is a pity that Senator Button takes for granted that what Mr Hawke says is accurate and does not do his own checking, because he is entirely wrong. However, that is just a minor point and I make no comment on that.

Following the Grants Commission report Mr Gray, the Premier of Tasmania, commissioned an independent inquiry into the likely effects on Tasmania if that recommendation, the first recommendation, for the cut of $40m was implemented. That was an independent inquiry. It was chaired by Sir Harold Cuthbertson, a very well known businessman in Tasmania, and it had many other members on it. It was a completely independent inquiry. The results of that inquiry have been quite devastating to Tasmanians. The inquiry was making its report on the original $40m cut and said that there would be 2,700 jobs lost to Tasmania. It said that we ought to be jumping up and down about it because, if we did not, the economic situation in Tasmania would be disastrous.

The inquiry said that the social effects would be wide-ranging and most Tasmanians would feel them; that the situation would be to stifle further development in Tasmania, especially capital expenditure by State governments and that jobs affecting education, health and the police force would be very much affected. It predicted that strong cuts in those areas would result in an increase in death and injury on the roads, the crime rate and drug rate and drug problems would also increase and social disorder would escalate. Some of the high schools would need to be closed.

This revised $56.5m cut recommended by the Grants Commission, we have been assured, would create twice as many problems. The second report came out from the independent Centre for Regional Economic Analysis at the University of Tasmania. It referred to much more serious effects projected than those contained in the Cuthbertson report. Mr John Madden, senior research fellow at the Centre, again substantiated what would happen as a result of the cuts that Mr Cuthbertson had brought forward. He said that if there were a $56m cut, we would have 4,300 jobs lost and a $70m drop in wages and incomes with lower State production.

What the Grants Commission has ignored is that Tasmania is a very decentralised State. The average population in the capital cities of the other States is 70 per cent of the total population. In your State of Victoria, Mr Deputy President, 70 per cent of the population resides in Melbourne. In Tasmania it is 40 per cent. As a result, the services have to be spread more widely. We have to provide services equally, not only in the south where the capital is, but also in the north and the north-west. Hence considerable extra cost is entailed for the State Government in this regard. Tasmania certainly earns its share. Our export earnings relative to our population far exceed those of any other State.

We have just heard that we are to get disastrous cuts. Let me go back to last Sunday, because we then had our Opposition Leader, Mr Wriedt, decide that Tasmania could cope with a $56m cut. He said that it could be done, that we would have to have additional taxes raised but that Tasmania could cope. Having said that on Sunday, he then chose to come to Canberra to try to undermine the elected Premier of Tasmania. He is only an Opposition member; he came to Canberra to try to undermine the elected Premier of that State and he made such a mess of things that he went home with his tail between his legs. Having said on Sunday that Tasmania could cope with a $56m cut, he then came up here and tried to talk Canberra into the fact that perhaps we could not after all.

He had not even bothered to read either of the independent reports which made it very clear that Tasmania could not cope with that sort of cut, but he decided off the top of his head, the great expert on economics, that Tasmania could cope and he came up here. He was treated so badly by the Government up here, treated so lightly, that when he asked for appointments with the Treasurer and with the Minister for Finance he was denied; he was told that he could see one of them but he certainly could not see both Ministers. How dare he come up here. How dare he come up here as an Opposition leader and try to do the work of an elected Premier. He has gone home, as I say, completely empty-handed with his tail between his legs but the amount of damage he has done by his statements has been absolutely horrific.

In the Hobart Mercury we had the headline 'Hawke Horror Story'. The article explained to Mr Hawke, who came down to our State over the weekend, just what a mess it would make of Tasmania if he adopted those sorts of recommendations. Mr Hawke said:

In no way will Tasmania be singled out for harsh treatment, that is not my way or the Labor way. It will not be the way of any government that I have the honour to lead and that is my direct answer to Mr Gray.
He said on another occasion:
Any suggestion that Tasmania is going to be saddled with new, unrealistic burdens, or that we would allow drastic, draconian, curtailment of Tasmanian services and standards should be dismissed.

It sounds fine, sounds reassuring, and I am sure that many Tasmanians were reassured by that. But what has happened today? Tasmania has been told that it is going to lose $50m; it will be down $50m. Taken in line with the mini-Budget where we lost $20m and $3m for roads, it is a total of $73m Tasmania will be cut if the Prime Minister has his way; that is $500 per family in Tasmania. Mr Acting Deputy President, this cannot be allowed to happen. I am well aware that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Wriedt, has mucked it, has undermined and sabotaged Tasmania; he has made no effort to fight for the State. I understand that the Labor senators in this place are not likely to fight for Tasmania and that it has been left to the Liberal senators here to do so. But the Premier, Mr Gray, I am quite sure, will not allow that to happen.

Mr Hawke has disadvantaged Tasmania in so many ways since he has been in government; he now claims that this is all the fault of someone else and tries to put the blame on the commissioners who, he told us so untruthfully, were appointed by Mr Fraser. There is no way the Tasmanian people will accept those untruths and there is no way the Tasmanian people will ever forgive Mr Hawke or this Government if they attempt to introduce such draconian measures against my State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate a matter that I consider important, not only for South Australians but for all Australians. It is a matter I had intended to raise in the adjournment debate last night, but as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, will know, circumstances arose that prevented that happening. The matter I wish to raise in general is that of housing development near airports and in particular in close proximity to military airports, that is, air bases. The specific matter is housing development south of the Royal Australian Air Force base at Edinburgh in South Australia. I wish to raise this matter partly because of the noise factor that should be considered when looking to, or at, developments near airports but more particularly as a consequence of the safety factor.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware that, a few days ago in Darwin a Mirage fighter found itself in mangrove mud flats as a consequence of losing power while making a final approach to landing. The pilot, reports inform us, had only seconds to turn the aircraft towards the sea before he could eject from the plane; the plane then proceeded on its path to the mud flats. The connection between this incident and what I wish to talk about, which is the housing development near Edinburgh Air Force base, is quite simply this: I am informed, reliably I believe, that the Mirage fighter that came down near Darwin was on a critical flight path. Honourable senators may well be aware there are two critical flight paths-take-off and landing-and the aircraft that had to crash land, if you want to put it that way, near Darwin was in the critical path of landing. Considering that critical flight path in relation to Edinburgh Air Force base, there is not only some development but also some recent much higher density development than has ever been there before. That development, as I have said, is near the Edinburgh Air Force base and in particular it is just south of the Air Force base.

I will take a few minutes to provide the Senate with some particular information about Edinburgh Air Force base to fill in the picture. The main runway runs more or less on a north-south axis and this critical flight phase area is immediately south of the runway. The Air Force base has six units. It has the aircraft research and development unit, the No. 1 recruit training unit, No. 24 squadron, 92 wing airman-aircrew training school and a significant base squadron as well. Another matter relating to Edinburgh that should be brought to the Senate's attention is that it is an area where there is a significant number of birds; by that I mean flying birds and, in particular, seagulls. It is common knowledge that when birds are sucked into jet engines the operations of those engines can be severely impaired. Passengers and crew are at risk, there may have to be a shut-down prior to landing or a take-off may have to be aborted.

The sorts of planes we are talking about coming in and out of Edinburgh are Orions, Mirage fighters, FIIIs, and a variety of other aircraft including training aircraft. I believe there is the possibility that the new FA18 Hornet will be flying in and out of Edinburgh as well. I remind honourable senators that this is an Air Force base where training flights are regularly undertaken and where live weapons are regularly carried on aircraft. I do not want to be dramatic and I am well aware of the capable and responsible actions of Air Force personnel when dangerous circumstances arise. I know that they are instructed to and do at all times avoid, where possible, loss to persons or property. That the Darwin pilot managed to turn the plane towards the sea or, in this case, the mangrove swamps before ejecting, is a classic example of that sort of care. Nonetheless, the Darwin incident does show that circumstances can arise that would create danger to development in the environment of an Air Force base. In these circumstances, fuel may have to be jettisoned, weapons may have to be jettisoned or the aircraft may have to be abandoned.

I accept that these circumstances are unlikely to arise. It is not very often that newspaper front pages report that the Air Force has managed to land one of its very expensive planes in the mud flats. Nonetheless, they are circumstances that can arise. I simply make the point that to have zoning that will allow new houses immediately under the critical flight path at Edinburgh Air Force base seems to be taking an extraordinary risk. To have zoning that will allow new schools to be built immediately under the critical flight path at Edinburgh Air Force base seems to be taking an extraordinary risk. It is a risk that I do not believe should be taken.

With respect to the noise factor, Mr Acting Deputy President, I am informed that portions of the new housing development south of Edinburgh Air Force base and some of the existing houses are well within noise zones that are considered unacceptable for development near a number of airports around Australia. The House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise will be in a much better position to make any comments with respect to the noise factor than I am at this stage. I raise this matter today in Federal Parliament because the Edinburgh Air Force base is a Commonwealth facility and the incident in Darwin has highlighted the potential problem of residential development being permitted close to an Air Force base. I happily accept that planning is a State and local government matter and so it should remain. It is, therefore, with the greatest respect that I call on the State authorities to give serious consideration to restricting further development in this area.
Sitting suspended from 1.47 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs had returned from overseas and would be present at Question Time. As my question is to be addressed to him, I will defer it until he arrives in the chamber.

—I refer the Minister for Education to the document entitled 'Aboriginal Social Indicators', which states that the percentage of Aboriginals with some educational qualifications has increased fourfold in the past 10 years. What steps is the Government taking to increase Aboriginal participation in tertiary education? Will the Minister tell the Senate what is the success rate for Aboriginal people in the tertiary field?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I studied carefully the report entitled 'Aboriginal Social Indicators'. Although it revealed a situation of very gross disadvantage for Aboriginal people in virtually every area of social policy, it was not an entirely depressing document because it also indicated that over the last 10 years there has been some progress in some areas. I am pleased to say that there has been some progress in education. In proportional terms, there are now many more Aboriginal people in tertiary education than there were 10 years ago, but, of course, the numbers are very low and, in relation to the rest of the Australian population, they are still extraordinarily low.

ANSWER.PARA: Our Government has taken a number of steps to increase the participation of Aboriginals in tertiary education. Before I reply in detail as to what steps the Government has taken, I point out that any strategy for increasing Aboriginal involvement in tertiary education needs to be underpinned by a strategy for improving Aboriginal participation in schooling and secondary education. As with the rest of the population, if we have a situation where Aboriginal children are not able to finish their secondary schooling and are dropping out well before reaching a satisfactory level of secondary schooling, they will not be in a position to take advantage of any new opportunities that are open in tertiary education.

In schooling, the Government has done a number of things, mainly in the area of capital. Up to this point, we have devoted some $12m to Aboriginal school projects, mainly in remote areas such as the Kimberley region in Western Australia, the remote area of Senator Elstob's State, and in the Northern Territory. Quite a large number of school buildings are now being built, thus providing for the first time the opportunity for Aboriginal children in these areas to get schooling, particularly secondary schooling. Also, $500,000 has been earmarked under the participation and equity program for expenditure on programs that will assist Aboriginal students to finish their secondary education.

In the tertiary area, the Government, through the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, is providing $839,000 in 1985 to support a total of 200 additional places for Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders at universities and colleges of advanced education throughout Australia. In 1986 and 1987 funds will also be available through the CTEC for additional intakes of Aboriginal students and for the continued support of the 200 students that will be taken in this year. An additional 100 special teacher training awards have been established for 1985 to help meet the target set by the National Aboriginal Education Committee of 1,000 trained Aboriginal teachers in schools by 1990. I remind the Senate that an initial 100 awards were available in 1984. So there are now 200 such fellowship holders studying to be teachers. We have also increased the level of allowances for Aboriginal students undertaking tertiary education. They are up by 3.9 per cent. There have been increases in funds for special support programs.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask Senator Ryan to ignore the interjections and complete her answer.

—Yes, Mr President, I will complete my answer. I had almost finished. I must say that it is a matter of some regret to me and, I am sure, to other senators on this side of the chamber that Opposition senators have so little interest in the very serious problem of improving participation of Aboriginals in tertiary education.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, I was informing the Senate of the amount of money spent on enclaves and bridging programs for Aboriginals to increase their access to tertiary education. Some $3.5m has been made available for 1984-85-an increase of $0.5m on the previous financial year. The Government is taking steps to increase the participation of Aboriginals in tertiary education, and those steps are proving to be successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the document from which she was obviously quoting.
—Will the Minister table the document?
—Happily.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question by welcoming back the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister heard, he is among friends. I refer the Minister to his speech delivered one year ago today to the sixty-eighth annual congress of the New South Wales branch of the Returned Services League of Australia in which he said in part:

QUESTION.PARA: Let me also say firmly that it is not the intention to change the onus of proof which rests on the Commonwealth in deciding if a disability is service-related.

Given the Government's Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill, which does alter the onus of proof, will the Minister resign from his ministry because of this clear breach of an undertaking and his inexcusable absence overseas when the Bill was debated in Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I should say that an invitation was extended to the Australian Government for me to participate in the Battle of Crete celebrations, which was accepted. Subsequently, we were also invited to attend the celebrations for the seventieth anniversary of the landing at Gallipoli, which invitation the Australian Government also accepted. Contrary to what some people have attempted to suggest, I believe that attending both those commemorations was very useful from the point of view of the Australian veteran community. I was able to meet the presidents of Turkey, Greece and France at the VE Day celebrations. Australia gets a great deal of credit for its participation in those events.

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the specific question Senator Collard asked, I have no hesitation in saying that I won the battle on section 47 before I left Australia. The agreement I got from the Government was that section 47 would be retained for those personnel who fought overseas during world wars I and II and subsequent wars; in other words, if they had overseas wartime service, the application of section 47 would remain unchanged. However, the Government made decisions in respect of peacetime service after 1972 and most of those who did not serve outside Australia during World War II. The civil standard of proof will exist in respect of that group of people, whereas the onus of proof for those who have overseas wartime service-that is the great bulk of the veterans-still rests with the Commonwealth to disprove any applications. So, quite contrary to what Senator Collard said, I believe I have acted properly to protect the interest of veterans in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to proposals on income splitting for tax purposes? Do those proposals offer any prospect for a fairer tax system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time propositions are put to allow couples to divide their incomes for taxation purposes. Most notably, I suppose, a series of propositions was put prior to the last election by members of the Opposition. On this question, as on so many other questions, the Opposition of course speaks with a multi-forked tongue. There were some non-specific proposals and undertakings given by the Leader of the National Party of Australia to the effect that all couples, no matter what their income, would be able to divide their income in whatever way they chose for taxation purposes. There seemed to be contained in that multi-forked tongue approach something close to a specific proposal advanced principally by the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Howard, who said that up to $9,000 in income would be permitted to be transferred from one income earner to another. Such a move was sold quite fraudulently to assist what is known in some quarters as the traditional Australian family, that is, a single income household with a dependent spouse, probably children and a fairly low household income, say of $16,000.

ANSWER.PARA: The effect of that sort of proposal, that is, allowing a maximum of $9,000 to be transferred for that single income household with a dependent spouse and dependent children, from the income earner to the dependent spouse would be that the tax payable by that household would be reduced by $294. On the other hand, for a household of precisely the same composition, that is, a dependent spouse and dependent children, with a $50,000 single income, if $9,000 of that single income were transferred from the income earner to the dependent spouse, that household would have its taxable income reduced by $3,269. In other words, for the household with an income of $50,000 the tax saving is 11 times higher than the tax saving for the $16,000 household.

The Opposition had the audacity to try to market that proposition as something which would be both fairer and more equitable. Most fraudulently of all, of course, it tried to market it as something which would help the fairly low single income household with dependent spouse and children. However, the cost of the Opposition's proposal was far from insignificant. The cost to the revenue would be in the vicinity of $1 billion if such a proposal were enacted. The associated child care taxation rebate would represent about another $240m. If any government has $1.25 billion of tax cuts and a desire to spread them around lower income households there are of course much more effective ways than that of helping such low income households. I understand that of course Senator Walters is very keen on this proposition because she comes from the class and represents the class of people in the $50,000-a-year-plus income bracket.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, pursuant to standing order 363 I ask that the document from which the Minister was quoting be tabled.
—I have not got a document.
—The Minister asserts that he was not quoting from any document.

—My question follows on from Senator Walsh's last statement which is a typical attempt to build up resentment and class feeling. I simply ask him whether it is a fact that many income earners who earn $50,000, or whatever figure he cited, a year are, under the present state of law, able to split their incomes with their spouses because if the income is earned from a business or something of that sort one can very easily divide the income whereas wage and salary earners in general are precluded from it. Is there therefore a high degree of tax injustice in the present inability of all income taxpayers to adopt that option?

—In my view there is a high degree of injustice in the present taxation system. I think that is also the view of the Government. If the Opposition is interested in cleaning that up it will probably get the opportunity to start doing that legislatively before the end of this year. However, that makes absolutely no difference to the point that the Opposition, prior to the last election, was attempting to market a fraudulent policy-I use that term advisedly-which the Opposition claimed would help the fairly low single income household with dependent spouse and children. The facts which I have already given are that for a $16,000 single income household, with half of that being transferred to a dependent spouse, the tax savings are $294. For a $50,000 household and $9,000 of income transferred from the income earner to the dependent spouse, as seen to be proposed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition before the last election, the tax savings would be $3,269-11 times as much for the $50,000 household as for the $16,000 household.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister agree that the tax policy put forward by the Opposition before the last election involved a ceiling on the income at which tax splitting would be permitted which, in fact, limited that advantage to people on relatively low incomes and provided no additional benefits to people above that level of income?

—As I said in answering the earlier question, prior to the election, the Opposition on that issue, as on so many other issues, spoke with a multi-forked tongue. According to the Leader of the National Party, all couples would be able to divide their income equally or a single income could be divided equally or two disparate incomes could be divided equally between a couple for tax purposes. That was the policy advanced by the Leader of the National Party. The Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party I think came closest to announcing a specific proposal. As I understand it, that specific proposal was that up to $9,000 may be transferred from one income earner to a dependent spouse for tax purposes. It was on that basis that I answered the question.
—Mr President, again I ask, as the Minister has cited figures in detail by reference to a document, that he table the document pursuant to standing order 363.
—Order! I ask the Minister whether he has quoted from a document.

—Mr President, I have not got a document. I have a pad page with figures written down which say $294 and $3,269. I am not going to table it because I have a lot of other things written on that page as well.
—In other words he is lying.
—Order! I ask Senator Peter Rae to withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw the remark which I made, Mr President. I now seek to pursue the point which I made under standing order 363, which is that the Minister table the document from which he quoted. He has admitted that he quoted from it. This is a document which he has before him and about which he inaccurately stated previously that he had not quoted from.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. It is very common in this place, in fact, an almost daily occurrence, that under standing order 363 Ministers are asked to table papers from which they have quoted. The Minister initially indicated that he did not quote from a paper and then, in a further explanation, he went on to say that he merely had a number of figures written down, which were the figures he actually used in his answer. There was no statement by the Minister that what he was using was a document of a confidential nature. The fact of the matter is that this Minister has recently been exposed as having documents on which were written some of his more coarse and vulgar epithets that he has thrown at the Opposition. It may be that he is just embarrassed about tabling the document. But I think he should be called upon to table it, Mr President.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I think we are getting to quite a ridiculous stage in this place, even though it is late in the session. I am sitting next to Senator Walsh. Senator Walsh has a bit of paper with figures scribbled on it.
—That is what he should be tabling.

—Wait a minute. That can hardly be considered a document. I sat here during many years of opposition and heard honourable senators read answers out, including the famous Senator Webster who read out great and detailed answers. We accepted that Ministers read answers from briefs which they had. Very occasionally they were asked to provide documents. If we are going to be in the situation in which every Minister in this place has to table every bit of paper which is lying in front of him or her, quite frankly, what I am going to do is have in front of me a bit of paper stating 'Fred Chaney is a dill' or something like that on it and I will table it every time I am asked to table a document. This is madness; this is silly business.
—That is exactly the sorts of bits of paper we have been getting.
—It would be more accurate than some of the briefs I have had.
—Order! The Minister is speaking to a point of order, not to an interjection.

—I am speaking to a point of order. I am sure that Senator Walsh has no difficulty with tabling at least the paper from which he was quoting, if that is what the Opposition needs. But why should he, and how often will this performance go on in Question Time? The problem is that, because honourable senators on the other side cannot remember figures as Senator Walsh can, they do not believe that Senator Walsh can. That is the great difficulty that the Opposition has.
—Firstly, I ask Senator Walsh: Does he as a Minister of the Crown claim under Standing Orders that the document is of a confidential nature?
—It is not a document, Mr President. That is not a claim; it is a fact.

—Order! The Minister has stated that he cited figures from a paper that was before him. The Chair would regard a paper as a document. I ask the Minister: Does he regard the document as being one of a confidential nature?
—It is not a document, Mr President.

—Mr President, I was going to withdraw my request in the interests of saving time, having learned that there is embarrassing material of an obvious kind in relation to the rest of the document and we do not wish to embarrass the Minister. Thus I do not pursue my request.
—Order! The request for the tabling of the document is withdrawn.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware of an interview between an Australian Broadcasting Corporation reporter, Mr Andrew Saw, and a woman named Virginia Perger which took place on the National program on Monday, 13 May 1985? Was the interview arranged through an agent of Miss Pergers? If so, what is the name of the agent? Was Miss Perger paid, either directly or via the agent, for appearing on the program? If so, does the ABC have a policy on cheque-book journalism?

—I am told by the Minister for Communications that he has been advised by the ABC that a $1,000 fee was paid to an associate of Miss Perger for assistance and research involved in arranging the interview. The ABC does not know whether any of the money was paid to Miss Perger. The ABC says that it has no formal policy with regard to such payments for news items. The ABC has advised that it would not normally engage in such practices and would consider payment to providers of information only when there was no other way to obtain a news item which it was believed the public had a right to know. If I may add an editorial comment, I think that is a highly euphemistic description of that item.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of a report in the Age on Friday, 24 May, which alleged that an unreleased paper commissioned by the Government's Economic Planning Advisory Council stated that increasing indirect taxes would not only raise prices, costs and wage claims but also place pressure on monetary policy and the Australian dollar? Can the Minister confirm that such a paper was commissioned by EPAC and can he explain why the paper was not made public? Can the Minister explain why the Government has made a move towards a broad-based consumption tax when the Minister for Social Security has apparently cast doubt on the possibility of compensating low income earners for price increases and a number of independent-that is non-Treasury-economic forecasters have predicted that a move to broaden the indirect tax base will result in lower growth, higher levels of unemployment, increases in inflation, pressure to increase wages, problems with managing our money supply growth-
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to bring her question to a conclusion.
—I have half a dozen words left, Mr President-and downward pressure on a weak and volatile Australian dollar?

—Firstly, EPAC is responsible to the Prime Minister, not the Treasurer. I do not know whether EPAC has prepared such a paper. I have not seen the report in the Age of a week ago or thereabouts. However, it is a fact that, given the way the consumer price index is currently defined, if there were a net increase in indirect taxes on items within the consumer price index regimen the rate of increase in the CPI would be higher than it would otherwise have been. That is just a simple, arithmetic fact which I would have thought even the Australian Democrats could understand. One does not have to have the economic expertise of EPAC, or even any economic expertise at all, to understand that. Whether the increase in the CPI was translated into a new and higher continuing threshold of inflation would depend on other matters.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen Press reports that the Soviet leader, Mr Gorbachev, during the visit of the Indian Prime Minister, Mr Gandhi, to Moscow, called for an all-Asian security conference? Will the Minister give to the Senate any further details of this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has received reports of remarks made by the Soviet leader at a dinner in Moscow a couple of weeks ago for the Indian Prime Minister, Mr Gandhi. Mr Gorbachev apparently called for an all-Asian security conference to reduce tension on the continent along the lines of the 1975 Helsinki meeting. On the information available to the Government, it appears that the speech made on that occasion was simply a restatement of an old idea.

ANSWER.PARA: An approach to Asian collective security along similar lines to the Conference on Security and Co-operation in Europe was proposed by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics as long ago as January 1976. The concept of collective security in Asia goes back even further. The then Soviet leader, Mr Brezhnev, made a speech at a dinner in June 1976 in honour of the visiting Indian Prime Minister, then Mrs Gandhi. Not only the occasion but also the nature of his remarks on Asian security resembled very closely what is reported as having happened in Moscow. Therefore, the Government's initial assessment would be that Mr Gorbachev's remarks contain nothing new and to that extent are unlikely to find a more favourable response than similar Soviet proposals that have been made in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to the Government's commitment to full consultation with ex-service organisations before any change is made to veterans entitlements. I ask the Minister to engage in semantics by trying to quarantine that promise to particular legislation. Why has the Government betrayed ex-service personnel? Why did it use the back-door method of tacking changes on to the May mini-Budget instead of dealing with them in the entitlements legislation to be debated this afternoon? Was this simply a ploy to make it more difficult for the Parliament to reject part of a government financial package?
—I will have to take that question on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. One aspect of the Treasurer's May economic statement referred to the direct access by veterans to dental prosthetists, optometrists and ophthalmologists. Will the Minister inform the Senate as to the reasons behind the decision and what benefits are likely to accrue to both beneficiaries and the Department as a result of the decision? What is the likely impact of limiting the annual amount of non-service-related dental treatment to $300 per pensioner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I became a Minister I received deputations from the Australian Optometrical Association as well as from the dental prosthetists, who told me that they had been pressing the government for some years to allow veterans direct access to the services they could provide and that this would be of great assistance to aged veterans in that rather than their being forced to go to doctors or dentists in the first instance, they would be able to have direct access to those particular services. Several conferences have been held with me in the intervening two and a half years, and it was agreed earlier this year that we would consider providing eligible veterans with direct access to optometrists and that a similar process would be made available to those requiring dental assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: The consequence of that in the May statement, contrary to some irresponsible comments made about that statement, is that extensions and increased facilities have been made available to veterans, who will now have direct access to optometrists and also will be able, on advice, to go to a dental prosthetist for assistance. The reason why this has been restricted to certain categories of veterans and to $300 a year for non-service-related dental treatment is that there has been a dramatic increase in the cost of that section of my budget-indeed, a 40 per cent increase in the last financial year. Honourable senators may be aware that rather than patients having teeth extracted and plates provided, it is now possible for dentists to restructure the tooth or teeth generally, and fees of anything up to $3,000 or $4,000 can be incurred by one applicant. Whereas most people are happy to have teeth removed and dentures supplied by my Department, some have taken advantage of the restructuring and new technology in the dental industry, and the costs have risen accordingly. Having regard to its overall approach to economic expenditures in all departments, the Government has placed a limit of $300 a year for certain categories of veterans. It will not apply, however, to those who have accepted dental disabilities by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, follows his very detailed answer on the subject of veterans' teeth. I ask him a much simpler question. Why did he not introduce changes to the entitlements of veterans in legislation which was allowed to lie on the table for months for veterans' consideration? That straightforward undertaking was given by the Minister. Can he remember why that undertaking has not been honoured and why the changes were introduced as part of the mini-Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to Senator Reid because I did not, because of my hearing disability, hear the full import of her question. I did, however, hear what Senator Chaney said. The Veterans' Entitlements Bill proposals were laid on the table in the Senate this morning. It was my intention to do that, but all planes out of Sydney this morning were delayed for somewhere between three and four hours. Therefore, the legislation as such has been laid on the Senate table for consideration. The consequence of that is that there will now be, as promised by both the Prime Minister and me, extensive consultations with the veteran community. I refer to the promise which the Prime Minister and I made in respect of the Bill which will be considered in the Budget session.

ANSWER.PARA: I have read some ill informed comment suggesting that there has not been adequate consultation with the veteran community in respect of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. That is not true. I suppose I would have had anything up to six to eight meetings with the advisory committee and with veterans' organisations, and at a number of conferences I have outlined the Government's intentions and what I was prepared to recommend to the Government in respect of the proposals in that Bill. Some 84 Acts are being put together in one piece of legislation, and it is proper that opportunity should be provided for the Bill to be laid on the table for consultation, on the basis of the Government's recommendations, directly with the veterans' organisations. On that basis the Government will formulate its policies for the Budget session and bring forward legislation on the basis of whether the Government accepts my original propositions or whether amendments should be made following consultations with the veterans' organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Veterans' Affairs for his answer, and I accept that he was not able to hear the question the first time it was put in a slightly different form. As a supplementary question, I ask the Minister why the changes to section 47 and the entitlement changes included in the mini-Budget were not made part of the legislation which is to be tabled this afternoon and which is the subject of the undertaking given by the Minister to the veterans' organisations.

—It is pretty clear, of course, that if the legislation were amended in the Budget session it is more than likely that the changes that would be made would take effect from some date after the decision of the Parliament or after the adoption of the Budget. The Government, in its wisdom, felt that there was a need for some savings in all government departments. I am sufficiently cognisant of my responsibilities in that area. The Government therefore decided to make some changes at the time of the May statement which will take effect, as I understand it, from 1 July. That is a decision taken by the Government or the Cabinet, as distinct from any negotiations or discussions that took place with me prior to my leaving Australia. There could have been a hundred Ministers for Veterans' Affairs present, but the Government made that decision at Cabinet level and decided that those savings would take effect in all government departments and ministerial responsibilities. Accordingly, the same principles were applied to the Department of Veterans' Affairs as to all other government departments.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the glowing analysis of the Australian economy by the Commonwealth Bank in its latest Economic Newsletter? Does the Minister agree with the Commonwealth Bank that the economic recovery in Australia has entered a more mature phase involving greater reliance on privately sourced demand? Is the bank correct in concluding that the most encouraging trend over the latter half of 1984 was the emerging shift from government stimulus to higher levels of spending by the household and business sectors?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fortuitously, I have with me at the moment a copy of the Commonwealth Bank's Economic Newsletter dated May 1985. It does, as Senator Maguire said, state that the recovery has entered a more mature phase involving greater reliance on privately sourced demand, that is, consumer spending and business investment. It goes on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: The most encouraging trend over the latter half of 1984 was an emerging shift in the sources of growth from government stimulus and 'one-off' factors (such as the breaking of the drought) to higher levels of spending by households and businesses.

It says that the continuation of strong levels of activity during 1985 depends on the maintenance of that sort of demand, and adds that consumer spending strengthened very appreciably in the second half of 1984. This is consistent with recent comments by similarly well informed economic commentators, such as Mr Gittins, who wrote in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday:
. . . the economic recovery which began miraculously a month or two after Bob Hawke's economic summit in April 1983 continues apace.
I continue to quote Mr Gittins:

Just think of it: the prospect of the economy growing by 5 per cent a year for three years in a row. We rarely did so well in the halcyon days of the 1950s and 1960s. In the decade to 1982-83, real GDP grew by an average of only 2.4 per cent a year.

Retail sales, seasonally adjusted, at current prices were almost 9 per cent higher in the March quarter of 1985 than in the same quarter of 1984. Another important indicator of consumer demand-motor vehicle registrations-is buoyant. For example, seasonally adjusted new motor vehicle registrations were a whole 17 per cent higher in the March quarter than in the March quarter of 1984. Private fixed capital expenditure is expected to be 41 per cent higher, in current terms, in the June quarter of this year than it was in the March quarter of this year. It is now expected to be more than 10 per cent higher, again in current prices, in 1984-85 as a whole than in 1983-84, and so on. I am aware of the Commonwealth Bank's comment and of the fact that, leaving aside the odd crank one tends to find in some of the Murdoch papers, that is the opinion shared by economic commentators in general.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, refers to the earlier question asked of him by Senator Chaney when the Minister admitted that he had been rolled in Cabinet on the question of section 47 of the repatriation legislation being amended. I ask the Minister whether he agrees that the fact that the Government overruled him in relation to section 47 being incorporated in the mini-Budget rather than the Veterans' Entitlements Bill constitutes a denial of the solemn undertakings to consult with veterans given by the Minister before he left Australia.

—Contrary to what Senator Messner has said, I was not overruled in respect of any changes that were made or suggested in the May statement. I was consulted on them and I expressed my views. I believed that the retention of section 47 for overseas wartime service was the most important aspect of my portfolio. I indicated that it was essential to retain that aspect, and it was retained. The reason for that is fairly simple, that is, that those who serve in front line or forward areas during a war are not always able to produce sufficient records to attest to their disability or illnesses and, consequently, the onus of proof should be on the Commonwealth.
