I remind Senator Messner that that onus of proof, which was in legislation introduced by the Labor Government in the dying days of World War II and in the immediate post-war years, was designed to change the processes which existed under previous conservative governments where the onus of proof was on the applicant. The reason why it is essential, therefore, to keep that provision for the substantially greatest number of serving personnel in World War II is that records and memories are not able to be authenticated easily. I believe that the maintaining of section 47 for that group of veterans is a recognition by the Government of its responsibilities to the veterans' community.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer but I ask him whether he agrees that he has denied the solemn promises to consult with the veterans' community, because apparently he acquiesced in the decision taken by the Government to incorporate the amendment in the mini-Budget and not the Veterans' Entitlements Bill.

—No, I do not agree with Senator Messner's interpretation. When certain judgments and legal decisions made by courts make a travesty of the intention of the Government-the O'Brien case illustrates that very circumstance-I believe there should be, and I would have thought that a responsible opposition would take the same view, a relevancy between disability and illness and wartime service. For persons aged 60, 70 and 80, having passed their three-score years and ten, to suggest that some illness is attributable solely to war service and not to other factors in their lives is quite absurd and is a matter that required further consideration by the Government. The Government gave that consideration to this matter when it dealt with the May statement, and, keeping paramount those who served in forward areas outside Australia, the Government has not contemplated changing the provisions.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is in four parts. What would be the consequences for Alice Springs and its inhabitants of a nuclear attack on Pine Gap? What would be the response of the Australian and American governments if Pine Gap were seriously debilitated by sabotage, and what would the consequences be for Alice Springs? Are there missiles or other weapons protecting Pine Gap and are any of these based on Australian soil? Finally, how much of the costs of the present expansion of the facilities at Pine Gap is being contributed by the Australian Government?
—This is an extremely good question and I have an extremely good answer with me somewhere, but I have lost it. I may need to put the matter on the record at the conclusion of Question Time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer him to the questions that he has answered today and, in particular, to his last answer where he said that entitlements for people who have had war service have not been changed and were not contemplated to be changed. Is the Minister aware that section 100 of the Repatriation Act, which deals only with those with war service, was changed and that the words 'direct combat' were inserted?

—In respect of section 47, a veteran still has the capacity to present his case under the amended legislation, which has already been approved, I think unanimously, by the Parliament. The onus of proof on the Commonwealth to disprove that applicant's increase or application for a pension is enshrined both in the Veterans' Entitlements Bill and in the May statement. In no way has that changed for any existing beneficiary or any person who participated overseas in any war. I reiterate that no existing beneficiary will be affected either by the May statement or by the new legislation unless, of course, the Senate in its wisdom takes steps-as the majority rests on the other side of the chamber-to make changes different from those which the Government is prepared to recommend.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. The legislation was not approved unanimously. Is the Minister denying that the words 'direct combat with the enemy' were inserted in section 100 of the legislation to deal with situations where, in the opinion of the Repatriation Commission, people were on war service?

—Senator Macklin, who is the spokesman for the Australian Democrats on these matters, obviously does not understand the circumstances in which veterans' entitlements exist. I would have thought he would have done his homework in that respect. Any person who served during any of the wars in a forward area outside the three-mile limit is judged as having been on active service. Consequently he or she is entitled to all the benefits existing in the 1984 Acts to which I have referred and will still be provided for in the Veterans' Entitlements Bill, unless it is amended by the other side of the Senate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QUEENSLAND POLICE RAIDS ON FERTILITY CONTROL CLINICS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, refers to the recent raids by the Queensland police on fertility control clinics and the removal by the police of patients' confidential files. I ask whether the patients who have had their personal medical files confiscated can take any action under Federal law to preserve their privacy. If not, is there any Federal agency which can investigate the matter and act on their behalf?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Human Rights Commission has power to inquire into any act or practice that may be inconsistent with or contrary to any human right. Human rights are defined, in turn, among other things, as the rights and freedoms declared in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. The action in Queensland would appear to be in breach of Article 17 of that convention, which provides:

ANSWER.PARA: No one shall be subjected to arbitrary or unlawful interference with his privacy, family, home or correspondence nor to unlawful attacks on his honour or reputation.

The Human Rights Commission is considering this week the issues involved in the Queensland abortion raid and will, no doubt, report in due course. It should be said, however, from all the information on the public record to date, that no one could be in much doubt that an invasion of civil liberties of the most scandalous and disgraceful kind has taken place in Queensland. That view has clearly been expressed on behalf of this Government by the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, who has no personal sympathy whatsoever for the pro-abortion position, as is well known. I note from recent survey reports that it is also the view of the overwhelming majority of Queenslanders. The Queensland Premier and Cabinet, by their actions in this matter, have shown themselves not only to be thuggish and discredited, which we have always known, but sick as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Minister aware of the capital gains tax proposal outlined by the Treasurer to business representatives in Canberra yesterday, which was presumably explained to officers of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in Melbourne last week? If he is not aware, I will give him the newspaper cutting. If he is aware, will he confirm that capital gains will be treated as income-that is, will be taxed at the normal income tax rates? Does the Minister now agree that it is as certain as night follows day that Australians will be hit with some new form of capital gains tax?

—I was not present at the discussions reported in today's paper, which were supposed to have taken place yesterday between the Prime Minister, Mr Keating and representatives of the business community. Senator Baume assumes for the purpose of adding colour to his question-if I might say so-that the same information that was allegedly given to the business representatives yesterday was given to the ACTU on some previous occasion. I do not know the precise details of any such sets of discussions, but I adopt Senator Baume's expression that it is as certain as night follows day that certain things will happen. It is as certain as night follows day that a discussion of capital gains taxes will be in the White Paper on taxation which will be released by the Government, because no consideration of taxation reform which is broadly and seriously considered can lack a discussion of such matters. I assure Senator Baume, as night follows day, that there will be a discussion in the taxation White Paper and I suggest that he should read it when it is published.

—I refer the Minister for Education to Press reports which quote the National Secretary of the Independent Teachers Federation, Mr Patrick Lee, as saying that the Government's attitude in setting conditions for the establishment of new non-government schools should be supported. Is the Minister aware of other comments which have been made by Mr Lee, when he described as deplorable comments made by Senator Baume and Senator MacGibbon when the new guidelines were announced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the fact that the Independent Teachers Federation is supportive of Government policy and has been particularly supportive of the policy for new non-government schools. It has made its reasons for that quite clear. Not only does it believe that it is right that the Government should have a non-government schools policy which allows for a rational, properly co-ordinated development of non-government schools in relation to existing government and non-government schools, but also, naturally, being a union, it is very concerned that non-government schools should be proper employers and provide members of its union with proper employment conditions. That has not always been the case in the past. Because there is now a more rational approach to the development of new non-government schools, it is much more likely that teachers in those schools will universally achieve proper working conditions.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware also of the fact that the Federation has been critical of Opposition spokespersons, especially Senator Baume, who have chosen to try to make some political mileage out of the fact that there has been some very muted criticism from some quarters of the non-government sector about a more rational, planned approach to the new non-government schools policy. Overall, I stress that the policy has been very well received throughout the non-government sector by administrators of non-government schools, non-government school organisations and also now by the representatives of the teachers teaching in those schools. The Government is pleased to note this high level of approval.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Is it true that the capital gains tax option proposed in the White Paper on taxation will assume realisation of gain at the time of death or on transfer to another person? If so, given that as recently as the 10th of this month the Minister said 'I am not in favour of wealth taxes or death duties', will he oppose this introduction of a death duty by stealth?

—I do not propose to discuss any more what is in the White Paper. When I answered the earlier question about capital gains tax, I meant what I said, and I meant what I said about death duties. I do not regard any capital gains tax which is realised at death or any other time as necessarily being a surrogate form of death duties, as Senator Rae said.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a reply he gave on Tuesday to a question from Senator Bolkus in which he noted with deep regret the recent executions of Indonesian dissidents arrested in 1968. Given further articles in yesterday and today's Age in which it was made clear that the Indonesian Government intends to press ahead with the executions, and the Minister's response to Senator Bolkus's question that 'It is very difficult to believe that the carrying out of such a penalty could ever be justified for someone who has been imprisoned for 17 years', will the Minister consider making formal representations to the Indonesian Government to have any further executions stayed?

—There have been further reports that the Indonesian Government is planning to carry out the executions of three former members of the Indonesian Communist Party, namely, Rustomo, Djoko Untung and Gatot Sutaryo. As I have previously stated, the Government deeply regrets the execution a few days ago of Mohammad Munir, a trade union official and PKI member. As I said earlier, the Government would hope that reason and compassion will prevail. It is certainly most concerned at any suggestion that the death sentences of the remaining three PKI members will be carried out. As to whether it is possible, appropriate or likely to be productive to make representations of the kind suggested by Senator McIntosh, I will raise that question with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and see what response he gives.

—I ask the Minister for Finance whether he believes that he can be fairly criticised for reducing the standards of living of public servants and not worrying enough about the gap between rich and poor, as reportedly alleged by Mr Charles MacDonald of the Australian Capital Territory Trades and Labour Council? Is he concerned that while the recently approved $100m pay rise may improve public servants' living standards, it might also have some effect on widening that gap between rich and poor? Finally, will he heed Mr MacDonald's call to resign from the Australian Labor Party because of his comment that the industrial action which brought about this pay rise was little short of sabotage?

—I have been asked whether I can be justly criticised for all those sorts of things. The answer to that, of course, is no. I have also been asked whether I would heed Mr MacDonald's call to resign from the ALP, or something like that. The answer to that is no, I will not. I have a different view on this, apparently, from that of Mr MacDonald. As a social democrat I regard sabotage of public administration as just that, and I do not believe that that is in conflict in any way with mainstream Labor Party thinking.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask him whether he knows who made the following statement in 1979--

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Coates will continue with his pick-a-box question.
—It was:

QUESTION.PARA: The States can't share the fruits of lower inflation from Commonwealth economic policies and still expect the burden to be carried by the Commonwealth.
It is unreasonable of Mr Lowe to expect the Federal Government to shoulder the full burden of economic restraint and discipline while the State basks in the glory of big government spending.

Did the Minister hear Senator Walters's contribution in the debate in the Senate about an hour ago on matters of public interest? Can the Minister give the Government's reaction to the sentiments expressed by Senator Walters in 1979 and today? Can he say whether the present circumstances are similar to those in 1979?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked whether I knew who had said:

ANSWER.PARA: The States can't share the fruits of lower inflation from Commonwealth economic policies and still expect the burden to be carried by the Commonwealth.
It is unreasonable of Mr Lowe to expect the Federal Government to shoulder the full burden of economic restraint and discipline while the State basks in the glory of big government spending.
That was published in the Launceston Examiner of 3 July 1979. I am sure Senator Coates will be amazed to know that those words were spoken by Senator Walters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr President. He will have to produce the document and the evidence to convince me that those were my words.
—There is no point of order.

—I have noted especially the last line in which Senator Walters castigated Mr Lowe for, as she put it, 'basking in the glory of big government spending'. I have noted that in particular, and I have also noted that spending by the present Tasmanian Government has increased by 35 per cent in the last two years. I assume that the present Tasmanian Government is doing just what Senator Walters accused a different government of doing in the past, that is, basking in the glory of big government spending. Of course, the fact is, as is revealed in that sort of expenditure increase, that the Gray Tasmanian Government has embarked on a reckless spending spree in recent years at the expense of the rest of the Commonwealth of Australia. Knowing that Senator Walters is a woman of high principle, I expect her to accept that, in this period of financial stringency, all the States must be expected to make some contribution to it and that States which have been indulging in reckless spending sprees, or as Senator Walters once put it 'basking in the glory of big government spending', ought to be willing to offer up a somewhat greater than proportionate sacrifice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time, Senator Robertson asked me a question about Pine Gap to which I am delighted to be able to say I now have a full reply from the Minister for Defence, which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SECURITY OF JDSRF PINE GAP AND ALICE SPRINGS
Background
The Alice Springs Peace Summit has posed four questions relating to the Security of Alice Springs and the JDSRF Pine Gap.
Suggested points for reply

Studies have been made of the hypothetical circumstances of a nuclear attack on the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap. The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence looked at this question in 1981 in its study of the threat to Australia.

Conclusions about the possible consequence of a nuclear attack depend entirely on the assumptions made about the possible nature of the attack, especially the size of the weapon and the nature of the burst. Assumptions used by the Joint Parliamentary Committee in its Study suggested that an attack on Pine Gap might result in no loss of life in Alice Springs and only minimal damage (broken windows, small fires).

The first concern of this Government is that all Australians, including the residents of Alice Springs, will never suffer the horrors of a nuclear war. The whole of Australia would face extremely grave problems in the wake of a general nuclear conflict. Any such conflagration would be followed by the most devastating long term consequences arising from the prospect of a nuclear winter, and the attendant environmental and economic disruption. These problems would be in addition to the more immediate consequences of any direct nuclear attack on Australia.

The whole thrust of the Labor Government's policy is to ensure that not only is global nuclear war avoided, but that the risks of such a war occurring through accident or miscalculation are significantly reduced.

One way in which Australia contributes toward these objectives is by hosting the joint US/Australian defence facilities, as the Prime Minister made clear in his statement to the Parliament on this subject on 6 June 1984.

Our intelligence and defence authorities have for many years assessed the risk of nuclear war to be remote and improbable providing effective deterrence is maintained and to which the joint facilities contribute. In the unlikely event of nuclear war it would be reasonable to assume that Soviet missiles would be targetted primarily against weapons systems able to strike at the USSR itself, and secondarily at those systems able to attack Soviet military capabilities.

The Government will not comment on detailed security arrangements and on contingency plans for the joint facilities or other high security areas because to do so would only weaken the effect of those arrangements but I can say there are no missiles or similar weapons at Pine Gap.

The facilities are not military bases. There are no combat personnel or equipment there, no military stores or workshops, no plant or machinery or laboratories for research or development, production or maintenance of any weapons or combat systems of any type.

The distribution of costs associated with the establishment, maintenance and operation of the Facility is decided by the Australia and United States governments in accordance with the government-to-government agreement of 1966 relating to the establishment of the Facility. The costs of the present works at the Facility are being borne largely by the United States. This is of course only one element in the 'jointness' of the Facility, in which the requirement for full knowledge and concurrence extends throughout the decision-making process concerning the roles and activities of the Facility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a one-page extract from the taxation policy issued by the Opposition before the last election and a one-page extract from the policy speech issued by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, before the last election on the issue of family tax reform, income splitting and family tax relief. I do that simply to correct the misstatements made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) about the Opposition's family tax proposals at the last election. I do not think it would be in order for me to comment further. I simply seek leave to incorporate the two documents in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Opposition's Taxation Policy
5.3 Family Tax Reform
(a) Income Splitting
We propose from our first budget to make a start in giving personal tax relief to families with one or more dependent children. This will be done in two ways:
(a) through the progressive introduction of income splitting; and
(b) the progressive introduction of tax rebates for child care expenses.

Under income splitting a husband and wife with one or more dependent children may if they wish submit a joint tax return. If they choose to do this they will be assessed for tax purposes as if each of them had received half of their aggregate taxable income.
A limit will be placed on the aggregate amount of family income which can benefit from income splitting. The limit will be determined by budgetary conditions.
The choice of income splitting will be available to both one and two income families.

Thus, for example, in family (A) the husband works and earns $18,000 per year and his wife has no income. They will be assessed for tax purposes as if each had received $9,000 per year, with a benefit up to a certain limit determined by budgetary conditions.

Likewise in the case of family (B) the husband earns $18,000 per year and his wife $6,000 per year from a part time job. They will be able to split the family income and receive the benefit of splitting up to a limit imposed.
Couples who elect to split their aggregate income for tax purposes will lose entitlement they might have to the dependent spouse rebate.
The joint return will be completely optional. If there is no personal tax advantage then couples will presumably opt to be assessed in the current manner.
The greatest potential beneficiaries are one income families and some two income families where the partners have substantially unequal incomes.
Income splitting will only be available to families with one or more dependent children.
It will be phased in over time. The start will be made in the first Budget.

The proposal will be introduced in a way which ensures that the greatest relative benefit goes to lower income families with children. One option to achieve this is to limit the dollar benefit to any taxpayer to the benefit provided to a single income family at say $18,000 (Illustrative purposes only) and to an average two-income family at a lower dollar level.
Income splitting will increase the freedom of families with children to choose to have one parent to stay at home to look after the children if that is the way they wish to organise their lives.
Policy Speech of Leader of the Opposition
FAMILY TAX RELIEF

Families have been particularly hard hit by Labor. There are additional expenses involved in raising children and families with children have a reduced capacity to pay tax. Previous Liberal Governments increased the value of the spouse rebate and introduced family allowances, but under Labor, families with dependent children are worse off in comparison with other taxpayers.

So the next Liberal Government will give top priority to income tax justice and relief for families with children, including arrangements to give families a genuine choice of whether or not both partners will work.

In our first budget out family tax relief will give couples with dependent children the choice for tax purposes of splitting their total income up to a set limit. Each partner will then be taxed as if they had received half of a specified amount of the total income. In other words we will treat the family as a team in which both partners are recognised as making a contribution to the team effort.
It would be irresponsible to promise too much immediately, given Australia's present budgetary position. But we will make a start in our first budget.
There would be a limit to the level of aggregate income that could be dealt with in this way.

One example is where one parent works and earns $18,500 per annum and his wife has no income. If $18,500 is in fact the limit then they will be assessed for tax purposes as if each had received $9,250 per year. The benefit available at that income level would also be the maximum benefit available for higher incomes. This inclusion of a limit contrasts with the previous income splitting proposal by Mr Hawke and the ACTU under which the higher the income-the higher the tax cut.

The Coalition family tax relief will make it easier for parents who choose not to work to stay at home. The pressure on parents to enter the workforce regardless of their personal wishes will be reduced.
The income-splitting scheme also has the following advantages:
It reduces the impact of tax creep, particularly in the 46 cent bracket, around which the large majority of one-income families are concentrated.
It restores equity for mostly PAYE wage earners with workers who already have access to splitting.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts has completed its Second Report on the examination of annual reports, the Committee may send the Report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President, and in that event-
(a) the Report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate;
(b) the publication of the Report is authorised by this Resolution;
(c) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the Report; and
(d) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, shall lay the Report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(2) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, insofar as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my adjournment speech last night I quoted Ms Maureen Horder, the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, as having accused the Minister for Territories, Mr Gordon Scholes, of allowing the dishonest administration of the community development fund of the Australian Capital Territory. That is an allegation which I did not then support, nor do I now support it. However, having today read the Hansard report of the speech that I made last night, I believe that a malicious misinterpretation of the final paragraph of that speech might imply that I had questioned the personal integrity of Mr Scholes. I had no intention of reflecting on the honesty of Mr Scholes. Indeed, when I referred in that speech to the need to make one Minister responsible for all the Australian Capital Territory's administrative functions during this transition period, I had Mr Scholes in mind.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Chaney proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The loss of confidence in the Government due to its failure to make decisions in the national interest.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition brings forward this matter of public importance because, as the session draws to its close, we are faced with a rush of legislation following the Government's mini-Budget and on other matters which precludes our having many opportunities to discuss the issues which are of broader concern to the Senate and to Australia. It is a fact that there are alarming indications of a loss of confidence in this Government to a point where Australia is being damaged. We have been sitting for about four months. We came back here in February. It is almost impossible to understand how it is that in January our dollar was worth US81c and today it is worth about US65c. We have seen a massive drop in the value of our currency during that time.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also seen a massive drop in the popularity of this Government. We returned to the Parliament in February at a time when the Government, according to the polls, was supported by 49 per cent of the Australian people. But the latest polls show that it is now supported by 43 per cent of the Australian people. On the other hand, the position of the Opposition is, as it so often is, a mirror image of that. Whereas in February, before the Parliament resumed, the Opposition had the support of 42 per cent of the Australian people, it now enjoys the support of 49 per cent of the Australian people. I suppose the most remarkable change is that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for a few months before February enjoyed a popularity rating of 75 per cent. By February that was down to 63 per cent and it now stands at 52 per cent. He is very much back among the mortals.

Only today we were told that the level of consumer confidence in Australia is the lowest it has been since the second half of 1983. We have come to a point where now more of the respondents to those surveys have unfavourable opinions about economic conditions than favourable ones. What we find is that the index of confidence in Australia and in our economy has slipped very badly over recent months. There is a very simple explanation for that slippage of confidence. It relates very squarely to the failure of this Government to make it clear to the Australian people that it is prepared to govern in the national interest. Instead, what is very clear is that it is prepared to govern in the interests of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and it is prepared to govern in the interests of whatever factions manage to weld together some sort of coalition within the Australian Labor Party for the moment. What has been evident is a confusion in the Government, an inability to come to grips with the issues which face Australia. There has been nothing but a ridiculous flaying about in the areas which are of great concern to us.

In a 20-minute speech I have little time to do other than touch on some of the areas in which the Government has shown that lack of deftness of touch which is fatal to its welfare and indeed, very damaging to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it cannot make decisions.

—Senator Peter Baume interjects that it cannot make decisions. That is the problem, but the reality is that the Government is locked into a situation where its inability to make decisions is likely to continue because of its subservience to groups within the Labor Party and to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. An example that has recently been conceded by the Government as involving the economic sabotage of Australia and yet it was a process which was rewarded by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission by a rise in pay last week, was the way the Government dealt with the Public Service dispute. In that dispute, which happened during this current session of Parliament, we saw the outright defiance of wage fixing processes by public servants, who simply refused to collect $1 billion of government revenue. They cost the Government $18m directly in additional interest. They disrupted private industry and they stopped the importation of goods. They had a weak response from the Government, which eventually, having abolished the Commonwealth employees employment provisions legislation, sought stand-down powers from the Arbitration Commission, eventually got them, and used them in a very half-hearted manner.

SPEECH.PARA: The extraordinary thing about the outcome of that sabotage-sabotage is the word that was used not by a member of the Liberal Opposition but by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh-was that the unions went back before the Arbitration Commission, received the support of the Government for pay rises, and were rewarded to the extent of $100m a year. It is only a week since the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) was in this place complaining that the Opposition sought some relief for the rural community in this country, which is at the moment so hard pressed by rising costs and difficult conditions, and he said that that would cost $67m a year. He regarded that as something which was unconscionable, something which could not be supported. Yet the Government of which he is part handed over an additional $100m a year after public servants had struck against a decision of the Commission and indulged in what Minister Walsh called economic sabotage.

There are probably much more important issues that go to the long term interests of Australia. Let us look at the handling by the Government of the MX missile crisis, which occurred at about the same time as the Public Service dispute. We had reports of Government agreement for some very limited logistic support for the United States of America in the conduct of trials of a missile which was not armed. The United States was asking its great friend and ally Australia to permit the landing of United States aircraft so that it could monitor the splashdown of unarmed missiles somewhere in the South Pacific. It is history now that Mr Hawke went away, leaving his Ministers backing that decision, and while they were publicly defending it he changed his mind and announced that we would not support that proposal. That was a humiliating backdown for Australia. No one has suggested that that was a change of mind made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the basis that it was in Australia's national interest. That was a perfect example of the Prime Minister kowtowing to the factional manoeuvring within the Labor Caucus. That goes to our relationship with the United States. It is a serious matter. It is not a matter which should be determined on phone calls going around the world because Labor members were spread around the world. I believe that backdown was certainly one of the important starts in the loss of confidence in this Government.

Our whole relationship with the United States within the ANZUS Treaty was cast into doubt by this Government. Once again we have had a series of conflicting and damaging statements by Government Ministers and Government back benchers. I suppose the high point of the disarray was when Senator Ryan, the Minister for Education and a member of the Cabinet, had to face a few branches of the ALP in the Australian Capital Territory. In the teeth of their opposition she chose to claim that the ANZUS Treaty was in need of review. We are told by the official spokesman for the Government in this area that that is not the Government's view, and yet we had a Cabinet Minister calling for a review of ANZUS and being excused by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) on the basis that she had to face the fearsome might of her constituency party in the Australian Capital Territory. That was a fairly contemptuous rescue operation by Mr Hayden, but it is again a sign of the instability and uncertainty that has afflicted this Government and led to the loss of confidence in it that is now so clear. Where have we finished up with ANZUS? Where have we finished up with respect to the Treaty that is still claimed by Ministers of this Government to be so important to us and to be a very key part of our foreign relations and of the Western alliance? The Foreign Minister has said that we are not a non-aligned country, we are an aligned country and, of course, the main formal vehicle for that alignment is the ANZUS Treaty. In March Mr Hawke said that ANZUS still exists but that the trilateral arrangements are inoperative. Again there is confusion, there is compromise, there is kowtowing to influences within the ALP, not on the basis of decisions being made in the national interest but on the basis of what can be made to work within the ALP.

In the area of crime, the Age tapes and the granting of indemnities to the people involved with that matter, again we have had a similar record of chaos and confusion. This came up early in the days of the new Parliament, and of course we were suspicious about the responses of the Government because of its lack of enthusiasm in dealing with previous allegations relating to criminality and organised crime. What we had from the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen)-not some mere Cabinet Minister but the Deputy Prime Minister, the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party in this Parliament-was a rejection of the idea that indemnities should be granted for the police who were alleged to have tapped phones. I suppose that might have been regarded as the beginning of a highly civil libertarian stance on the part of the Government. Here was the Government weighing up the pros and cons, the balance that has to be drawn between the preservation of civil liberties and the pursuit of crime-quite a difficult question. What we find, of course, is not the beginning of some principled approach by the Deputy Prime Minister but a somersault on his part. After it was cleared by Premier Wran that perhaps indemnity should be granted-that was publicly announced by the Premier-we got a very quick turnaround by Mr Bowen.

As far as organised crime is concerned, we have had the response to the Costigan Royal Commission of Inquiry on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which has been widely interpreted by commentators, quite apart from the Opposition, as being a damp squib. This Government has talked tough about crime but it has done little or nothing. It has again shown that total inability to maintain a consistent course. I believe that in the long term this Government will be judged most harshly on the pattern of reluctance which emerged to tackle crime, particularly in the State of New South Wales. It is impossible to debate these matters in full as yet in this place because there are still many trials to be heard. In fact the record is clear: Allegations raised, allegations resisted by this Government and the Government of New South Wales. It is only when the allegations have been pressed by both the Opposition and the media that eventually inquiries have been made and charges have resulted.

One might have thought that we should simply stand by and welcome the fact that in economic policy there have been some changes by this Government. We might have expected that it perhaps would show consistency in the field of social policy. The Australian people have been sadly disappointed in any search for consistency as far as social policy is concerned. Questions have been asked in this chamber over recent weeks on the issue of Aboriginals and land rights. I am sure that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, as a Queenslander would be well aware of the very many clear statements made by your colleagues in this place on what was going to be done with respect to land rights when a Labor government was elected to Canberra. We have had read out in this chamber over recent weeks some of the very fine statements that were made by Senator Susan Ryan as the then shadow Minister in that regard. We have had two years of the Hawke Government now-two years, I might say, in which the Government has had the clear support of the Australian Democrats for any land rights proposals it might have liked to bring forward. What have we found? We have found vacillation and total confusion. Mr Hawke has added to this reputation for vacillation in almost every field. In regard to the assets test he changed his mind on an aeroplane flying into Australia, or was it out of Australia? He changed his mind in regard to the land rights issue. When he went to Western Australia before the last election he tried to create the impression in that State that the Government was totally in agreement with what Mr Burke, the Premier of Western Australia, was doing. Yet what Mr Burke was proposing to do was certainly not consistent with the principles which were being espoused by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding and, apparently, by the Government.

What we have had over the last couple of weeks is, at last, a meeting between the Prime Minister and representatives of the Aboriginal community. That has produced a real decision. What is the decision? The decision is: 'Put it off. Let us have some more talks and perhaps we will do something next year'. What is quite clear in this area, as in so many others, is that the Government is wreaking great damage by its total indecision. Instead of the Government defining a position it can realistically support and put forward, it is simply making empty promises which will come to nothing. There is no clarity in the Government's policy in this area. Questions evoke simply vague responses and evasions. The reality is that the Government will do nothing. It will go on doing harm by raising expectations and not meeting them.

Let us look at the recent experience with respect to the Queensland blockade. What really has been the position of this Government with respect to the Queensland blockade? We had debate on a Bill in this chamber yesterday and in the other place over recent weeks. We had the quite extraordinary claim by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, that the Government had always opposed the blockade and had done it in a very firm way. I do not believe that there is a single person in Australia who believes that the Hawke Government has in any sense opposed the Australian Council of Trade Unions in its running of a quite illegal blockade of Queensland.

What we have had from this Government is not a clear embracing of the principle that the rights of the people of Australia and the people of Queensland should be protected. What we have had instead has been the use of whatever technicalities were available to the Government to get the matter out of the hands of the Queensland authorities and into the hands of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I say only that, again, no one in Australia would believe that the manoeuvring of the Government on this issue will produce the results that the people of Australia want, namely, some guarantee of the continuation of essential services, some guarantee against the sort of industrial blackmail which is rendered illegal by sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act and some guarantee that those sections will never be activated by the Government. Many private people would be too frightened to use them because of the powers of the trade unions to come back on them. Again, we have seen nothing but uncertainty and vacillation. In the end, the Government has not been prepared to back the interests of the Australian people. It has simply got into bed again with the ACTU and backed the interests of its friends.

Probably, in the long term, the most serious area of indecision which has cost the Government a great deal in terms of international confidence, including the confidence of international commentators, is wages. I am glad that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, is speaking in this debate because perhaps he can do something to clarify the confusion to which he has added. We have had Ministers saying things which are quite different and a total refusal to make the sort of straightforward statement that would have done something to restore the market's confidence in the direction this Government is setting.

After a good deal of backing and filling we had what appeared to be a clear statement in the mini-Budget. Mr Keating, the Treasurer, brought down in the Parliament a statement which I thought meant, quite clearly, that the Government would not have any part of arguing for the discounting of the consumer price index in the August or September wage case. Mr Keating cast doubts on the meaning of his statement within a day of bringing down the mini-Budget. Within a week of being questioned in this place the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, said that it was quite clear that there was a decision not to discount. What Senator Button's answers mean I do not know. I invite Senator Button in this debate to clarify them by simply indicating whether, if there is a measurable increase in the cost of living in Australia, in the consumer price index, by the time of the next national wage case, the Government will be prepared to argue that that increase should be a discounting factor in the national wage case. A simple and direct answer to that question would do something to restore the confidence of people that this Government has a genuine wages policy, a policy which aims to take the full advantage of the severe devaluation of the Australian currency. The sad reality is that the Government-Senator Button included-does not seem to be prepared, does not have the courage or is not able to make that simple, clear statement. That is doing enormous harm to us all.
Mr Willis has had what perhaps will be, sadly, the final word in the wages case. He was reported in the Bulletin yesterday as saying:
We have made no decision. We have made no decision on the next case, or on the case after that or on the case after that.

I concede that it would be proper for Mr Willis to say that the Government has made no specific decision on what amount of discounting it would argue for. The simple question I ask is whether the Government will adopt the principle that, if there is an increase in the CPI due to devaluation, it should argue that it ought to be a factor for discounting.

Within the last day or so, Mr Laurie Oakes, whom I have never regarded as being a sworn enemy of the Government, but who I think is a reputable journalist and who writes sometimes favourably of this side or that, made the comment that there might be a whiff of Whitlam about this Government. There might be a whiff of Whitlam, but I suggest that there is an absolute stench of subservience. There is subservience to the ACTU in regard to wages, taxation, industrial relations and the blockade. There is subservience to factionalism in regard to Australia's security and Budget matters. It is no wonder that confidence in this Government has failed, and that this Government is now seen as a shabby and indecisive Government. We can point to every reason for each decision that has been made, except one reason. One can very seldom argue that the decisions of the Hawke Government have been made in the national interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It surprises me to realise that it is only two years and two months since the Hawke Government was first elected to power. It seems a lot longer than that for some reason. In 1983, the Australian people, having suffered the economic collapse which eight years of the Fraser Government's economic and social policy had created, elected the Hawke Government. The legacy of the Fraser years was, sadly, a contracting economy with gross domestic product falling, an official unemployment rate of over 10 per cent-the fall in employment in 1982-83 was the largest for 30 years-a wages policy that had led to a massive wages explosion which exacerbated inflation and severely reduced Australia's international competitiveness, an inflation rate of 11.4 per cent, a huge Budget deficit blow-out caused by rising unemployment with the Government initiating spending programs in a panic reaction to the economic chaos it had created and interest rates so high they were forcing people out of their homes because they could not keep up with rising mortgage repayments when their wages were frozen. That is a fair description of the legacy this Government inherited from the Fraser years.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, I think it is appropriate that the Liberal Party of Australia should raise today, as a matter of public importance:
The loss of confidence in the Government--
this Labor Government-
due to its failure to make decisions in the national interest.

It was not only the collapse of the economy and the fact that that was forcing two million Australians to live in poverty that gave the Australian Labor Party a convincing victory in 1983. Australians turned to Labor in the expectation that it would be able to deliver a better deal for Aborigines, rural producers, small business and home buyers. Those who were concerned about the destruction of Australia's natural environment which was occurring under the Liberal Government believed that Labor would go beyond saving the Franklin and expected that, under a Labor Government, conservation of our environment would be given the highest priority. Those who were, and still are, concerned about the threat of nuclear destruction expected that Labor would implement its platform and stop the mining, milling and sale of Australian uranium. They trusted Labor to negotiate the removal of American bases in North West Cape, Nurrungar and Pine Gap. These bases are the greatest immediate threat to the security of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should they trust us to do that when we never said we would?

—I will come to that. The Government now admits that these bases make Australians nuclear targets since the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics would have little option but to destroy these bases in order to reduce the capacity of the United States to deliver accurately its nuclear arsenal on Soviet targets. Hence, the loss of confidence in this Government cannot be attributed simply to the decisions it has not made. It is a clear sign that those people who voted for the Australian Labor Party are not impressed with the decisions that the Hawke Government has not made and the decisions that it has made. They are disappointed that the Government has broken its promises and that it is now so pragmatic and so conservative that there is basically no difference between the Hawke Government's policies and the Fraser Government's policies.

SPEECH.PARA: It is easy to carp and to criticise, but I think in such a debate as this, it is fair to acknowledge in passing-although even my friend Senator Button would not expect me to spend most of my time in remarks eulogising his Government-that I give the Government full marks for many achievements that it has had. For example, I think the prices and incomes accord is probably one of the great achievements in the history of Australia. I do not know of a time when we have had such stability in wages and in industrial relations generally. I commend the Minister at the table, Senator Button, for having the enormous courage to stand up to big business and the trade unions in the way in which he has tried to reorganise the automobile industry. I give him full marks for that action because that was a matter of screaming urgency.

I commend the Government for trying to do something about the assets test. With respect, I say that it has not sold it very well. In fact, it has sold the assets test very badly. But the basic motivation behind the Labor Party in introducing the assets test was to be able to increase the pensions of the needy. I think that is the one message out of this whole sorry mess that has not got across to people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government hasn't done it; that is why.

—In answer to Senator Chaney's interjection, the purpose of it was allegedly to try to increase the base pension to the needy and, in doing that, the wealthy people who were getting pensions had to suffer. I commend the Government for reintroducing the national health scheme. Although it still has some warts, it is a national insurance scheme which we desperately needed. Not the least of the achievements for which I commend the Government is the almost record low level of industrial disputation. I think this is a remarkable achievement by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: After two years of Labor Government, seasonally adjusted unemployment still stands at 8.5 per cent or 514,000 people. This figure reflects a substantial improvement in levels of economic growth, but it is also a warning that massive levels of unemployment are becoming a permanent feature of the Australian economy. Insofar as the figure represents a reduction in the labour force participation rate, it indicates how many people have stopped looking for jobs. Young people have become particularly disillusioned by permanent massive levels of unemployment. Youth unemployment for the 15 to 19 age group in April this year was at the breathtaking figure of 20 per cent. If we include the 20 to 24 age group, more than 32 per cent of young people-over 272,000 young people-face the misery, degradation, poverty and lack of individual fulfilment that is imposed upon them by unemployment.

Inflation is set to rise again. The Government's decision has topped the free market deregulatory Liberal dries. They were not able to get their way against Prime Minister Fraser but have now got their way, ironically, under a Labor government. We have a floating Australian dollar, which is slowly sinking. Even under the Fraser Government, it was not possible for the dries to have such a victory. Foreign banks will now be able to speculate against our dollar from within our own country. The almost inevitable deregulation of home interest rates will bring us back to the frightening Fraser years-and the days when families were thrown out of their homes because they could not afford the ever-rising mortgage repayments.

This Government has become obsessed with expenditure cuts. Reducing the Budget deficit has become the most important sign of the economic success of this Government. This has shades of Fraser's razor gang et al. This economics of restraint, stringency and despair is Fraserian economics revisited. It gives the Government the theoretical justification to pursue expenditure cuts which savage the income and benefits of returned servicemen, servicewomen and war widows, to reduce the availability of child care to single mothers and low income families, to reduce community services for the aged, the poor and the unemployed provided by local government and to contemplate the reintroduction of tertiary fees. No wonder the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) are happy to attack the Australian Council of Social Service which dared to remind the Labor Government that its policies, unlike the Fraser Government's policies, were not supposed to sacrifice the unemployed and the poor to deficit obsession and economic restraint.

Last week, on 21 May, at the national Anglican welfare conference, David Scott, a former Director of the Brotherhood of St Laurence, publisher of Australian Society and a dedicated pioneer in the fight against poverty, said:

. . . We have failed in efforts to reduce poverty . . . Consensus politics, by definition, favours the status quo and muffles the challenges that should be made in the interests of poor people . . . We now have a generally conservative Federal Government opposed by an even more conservative Opposition-Where do the poor go now for political support?

Given political will, poverty is not necessary. Each year the world spends $800 billion on weapons, enough to wipe out poverty in every country on the planet Earth. Yet the Hawke Government is making us part of the arms race and in the economy it is giving priority to forging an alliance between big labour and big business. Poor families and the unemployed are not part of the Hawke Government's accord and their advocates are being told to toe the line or else.

In the area of foreign affairs and defence, the Government has made the wrong decisions in an attempt to square the circle-to reconcile the irreconcilable. The Government connived with the United States to monitor the testing of the pernicious MX missile and the testing of the Navstar global positioning system, and conspired to commit the unfriendly act of spying on our friends, such as Greece and Israel. These actions are not in Australia's national interest. The Government cannot justify its actions and accept placidly ever increasing numbers of United States nuclear ships now armed with the dangerous Tomahawk cruise missile in the South Pacific, an area which in our national interest should be kept nuclear free. The Government's actions have heightened tension in our region, which is in direct contradiction to our national interests, as Senator Chaney said in his matter of public importance.

Consider the continuation of the bases which make us a nuclear target and the visits of nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed ships to our ports. I find the logic of the Government mystifying when it says in a very self-righteous tone that it will never allow nuclear bombs to be carried over Australian land by B52 bombers, and yet it allows ships carrying nuclear bombs as big, as powerful and as destructive to tie up in Australian waters at Australian ports. I find the lack of logic of that is quite breathtaking. The use of Nurrungar for the Star Wars program and the development of the electro-magnetic rail gun are not reconcilable with this Government's oft stated objective of a nuclear freeze, a zone of peace, and stability in the nuclear balance.

Before being elected to Government, the Labor Party made many grand promises about conservation. Some Australians even believed that the Labor Party national platform contained promises that a Labor government would honour. I place on record my enormous gratitude to the Labor Government for its enormous courage in stopping the damming of the Franklin River. I put that on the record. However, the hypocrisy of the Government has now shown how sadly misplaced its belief in conservation was. I will give a few examples, as they are not hard to find. Seventy-five per cent of Australia's rain forests have already been destroyed by the white man since we colonised this country. The Labor Party's national platform contained a commitment to save Australia's rain forests, at a bare minimum to ensure that all types of rain forests were adequately protected in national parks. Since coming to Government, the Labor Party has done nothing. It has allowed those bandits in Queensland, for the sake of making a few miserable dollars in real estate, to plunder and to savage the most beautiful rainforest in Australia-the Daintree Rainforest-and, because it would represent a States' rights fight, it has allowed work at Daintree to go ahead. Surely the performance of the present Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) must be one of the great disasters in this Labor Government. The Daintree-one of the most magnificent rain forests in Australia-is continuing to be plundered, and the Government has stood by shaking in its boots at the thought of how Joh would punish it were it to take action. It has allowed the Daintree to be plundered, despite the fact that it has been nominated by the Australian Heritage Commission for world heritage listing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you say, Senator Bjelke-Petersen? Do you reckon he would?
—Senator Button may laugh.
—Not at you, Senator; I would not laugh at you. I was having an exchange with Senator Bjelke-Petersen.

—If Senator Button has a reason for the Government allowing the Daintree Rainforest to be destroyed other than fear of Sir Joh, let him say so. The Australian Democrats have introduced Bills on the Daintree Rainforest and the other Australian rain forests. If the Government were serious in its commitment to the environment, it would have supported those Bills; but it simply has not done so.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the mining of uranium. This is the most dramatic example of the Government breaking a promise. Two years ago I asked Senator Walsh how the Government could justify uranium mining, given the following statement in the ALP platform:
A Labor government will declare a moratorium on uranium mining.

That was in the Labor Party platform. I am as critical of the Liberal Party's policy on uranium mining and matters nuclear as I am of the Labor Party. We Democrats have been disagreeing with those policies for years. If anyone were to ask what was the main reason for my resigning from the Liberal Party, I would have to say that it was its policy on uranium mining. But at least the Liberals are honest about it. At least, they have always been consistent. They have always been gung-ho about mining uranium and about ANZUS; but not so the Labor Party. I asked Senator Walsh what he meant by saying that a Labor government would declare a moratorium on uranium mining. 'That is easy,' said Senator Walsh, 'there is significant scope for differing interpretations of what is written in the Labor Party platform on this matter'. Humpty Dumpty said much the same. Senator Walsh should remember what happened to that erstwhile great fencesitter.

Next came an even more extraordinary assertion from him. According to Senator Walsh, uranium mining at Roxby Downs was simply incidental to the mining of other minerals. I prefer a Minister with the honesty of Senator Button, who comes in here and tells the truth. If he believes something, even knowing sometimes that it is unpopular with his colleagues, he will say it. The Opposition, quite properly, gives him opportunities to do so, and he always accommodates the Opposition. He is an honest man. He is an honest Minister. I wonder how honest Senator Walsh is when he says-

TALK.START.PARA: —He is much more honest than Senator Button!
—Senator Walsh said that uranium mining at Roxby Downs was simply incidental to the mining of other minerals. Does Senator Chaney suggest that that is an honest statement? Senator Walsh said:

SPEECH.PARA: A possible view is that 'incidental' means anything less than half. That is a view that some people might hold.

This is a statement from Senator Walsh, the present Minister for Finance. What absolute humbug! I think it would come as a surprise to most Australians to know that, because uranium represents only 40 per cent of the value of the minerals initially to be extracted from Roxby Downs, Senator Walsh says it is incidental. As everybody in the world knows, Roxby Downs has the biggest single uranium deposit in the world. Only a government based on doublespeak, or only a Minister expert in doublespeak, could depict the mining of that deposit as incidental to the mining of other minerals.

I conclude with comments on the Kakadu National Park. In March 1984, in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, this Government announced that the whole of the water catchment area would be added to the Kakadu National Park, as Mr Justice Fox had recommended. That has not yet happened. After all, the Government has had only a year in which to act! Why has this not happened? In the last month or so the mining companies, which would love to get their greedy hands on the uranium deposits in this area, have been heavying the Government. So we had better not hold our breath. There is some good in this Government's record; but, as I have indicated in the short time available to me, there is much to suggest that it should lift its game markedly in the next 10 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chipp for his kind remarks when he conceded that there was some good in this Government. The truth of the matter is that governments, unlike the best efforts of the Australian Democrats, cannot please everybody at the one time. Senator Chaney and Senator Chipp have regarded the debate on this matter of public importance as a sort of end of term discussion in which they have given us a summary. I say to Senator Chaney that I am using the end of term analogy not in any personal sense but, in terms of an old view I have held of this place, in the sense that each of the speeches represented a summary of the respective views that have been advanced by the Liberals and the Democrats over the course of this parliamentary session. This is a sort of wind-up MPI in which everything has been put on the record, as it were.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the general view that the Liberal Party in opposition has always had grave difficulty in distinguishing between the national interest and that of the Liberal Party. In fact, they are sometimes seen as synonomous. I also take the view that that is why the Liberal Party never served this country well in its seven years of government and that is why it is incapable of taking any of the hard decisions. If we were to ask Senator Chaney and Senator Chipp to list items that would be in the common good of this country, the problem is that we would get totally different lists. Senator Chaney would advance some proposals that he thought would be for the good of the community as a whole. Senator Chipp would advance a totally different-and, indeed, economically irreconcilable-list from that given to us by Senator Chaney. Ultimately, governments are judged not on what particular members of the government Party may have said from time to time but on what those governments do.

I shall dwell for a moment on Senator Chaney's speech in this debate which, as he put it, could be headed 'Slippage of Confidence'. He substantiated his argument, firstly, by suggesting that there has been much confusion concerning Government direction and policies and that in some ways, particularly in respect of taxation and wages policies, this Government has been subservient to the wishes of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Ever since we were elected to government we have made no secret of the fact that the issue of wages is constantly on the agenda for discussion with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That is the basis of the prices and incomes accord. While Senator Chaney did not attack the accord, the assumption underlying the accord is that, for very good macro-economic reasons, there should be a prices and incomes policy in Australia. Senator Chipp thinks it is greatly to the credit of this Government that it has established a prices and incomes accord. It should come as no surprise to anybody, except honourable senators on the other side of the chamber, that the Government has continually discussed the question of wages with the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

The second piece of so-called evidence advanced by Senator Chaney was that the Government was in collusion, as it were, with the ACTU on the question of taxation. As I have said on a number of occasions in the Senate, there has been much discussion about the desirability of broadening the tax base in Australia. If one wishes to broaden the tax base in Australia by introducing a consumption tax and indirect taxes, with the greatest respect, I do not believe that any government at all can do it without a clear understanding with the trade union movement of the consequences of that broadening of the tax base for wages policy. So if one wants to maintain a prices and incomes policy and to broaden the tax base, those two things are integrally bound up. It is the Government's view that that is absolutely necessary.

A Liberal Government might say that we do not need a prices and incomes accord or that we do not need to consider the position of wage earners when broadening the tax base, and so on. We disagree with that. That has been made quite clear in the policy announcements that have been made and the policy discussions that have taken place. That is why, during seven years in Government, while there was a lot of talk from Liberal Party spokesmen about broadening the tax base nothing was done about it. I believe that was because ultimately it would have been politically unpalatable. It would have involved hard decisions and hard discussions in relation to wages policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did defeat some legislation.

—I understand that limited effort in respect of indirect tax. With respect to Senator Chaney, some of those discussions by Liberal spokesmen at the time-in my view quite admirably-went a lot further than that. Therefore, we make no public apology, in terms of policy development, for continued discussions with the Australian Council of Trade Unions on these matters. If Senator Chaney wants to characterise that as collusion or something, that is all right.

SPEECH.PARA: There were a number of supplementary suggestions about the boycott of Queensland by the ACTU. Those have been matters of debate in the Senate for a long time but, in particular, yesterday. I make the point again that there was a problem of national concern in relation to that situation. It was quite clear that the situation in Queensland would not be resolved. It was quite clear that we had responsibilities as a national government to take steps to resolve that. We have done so. As I said yesterday in the Senate, if those steps fail I have no doubt that honourable senators opposite will remind us of that fact in the Budget session. As I said yesterday, I will cop it. I do not mind that. I have to deal with Senator Chaney's speech at greater length because he is the leader of the putative Opposition of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government of this country!

—No. I meant putative Opposition because I was thinking of Senator Chipp as the alternative. Senator Chaney is the leader of the majority Opposition party. I thought there was a rather desperate catalogue-
—I am the leader of the second largest party.

—Yes, and Senator Harradine is the leader of the third largest party. I thought that over the term of this Parliament there had been a rather desperate scraping of the barrel, as it were, to point to alleged areas of Government indecision and failure. Senator Chaney chose to refer to the strike by Public Service unions at the start of this year as an example of Government failure. He then went on to say that Senator Walsh had described it as sabotage of the Public Service and that, in some way, the Government had connived with the rewarding of sabotage. I reject that quite clearly. I make it quite clear that from the beginning the Government expressed the view that the more lowly paid public servants involved in that case were entitled to some alleviation of their wage situation under the anomalies provision of the wage fixing principle. We maintained that position right through to the more recent case.
—And the Commission disagreed.

—I am sorry, Senator Chaney; the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission did not address the question of merit on that issue in the first case. It did not address the question of merit as to whether those public servants were entitled on merit under the anomalies provision to a wage increase. It was only in the second case that that question was addressed. I think if Senator Chaney checks the record he will find that to be so.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, at no time did I as Government spokesman welcome or embrace the actions of the Public Service unions in February this year. The question, as Senator Chaney well knows, is what one does about it. I suppose his remedy propounded in another debate would have been to impose penalties of one kind or another under the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act on the Public Service unions at the time of the problem in February this year. All I want to say to Senator Chaney about that is that if he wants me to get a dorothy dix question about his handling of the Public Service when he was Minister for Social Security and indicate what time was lost, what revenue was lost and things such as that, I will certainly oblige him. That remedy did not in fact work. It caused more disruption in the Public Service than even the incidents earlier this year.

There was a number of other matters to which Senator Chaney referred. For example, Senator Ryan had the misfortune to say something at the Canberra branch of the Australian Labor Party. I confess that this Government has not taken much notice of the Canberra branch of the Labor Party and its deliberations. I apologise to it for that, but I doubt that we ever will. The sort of issues raised are indicative--

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait until they get self-government and you will.

—I think they had better wait. These are not indicative of great government failings of one kind or another. I make some basic points for the record because this is a wrap-up session. We have been criticised by an opposition. Ultimately, the people of Australia have to make a decision between governments on the basis of what they do and not what they talk about. We are chided on a number of minor points by an opposition which failed miserably in government and which now offers itself as the alternative government. It failed in terms of wages policy in respect of which we are criticised. Award wages grew by 16 per cent in the year to March 1982, the last calendar year of the Fraser Government. In its last year of office 186,000 people lost their jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last few years of the Fraser Government we had very high levels of industrial disputation. In the last few years of the Fraser Government unemployment rates were over 10 per cent. In terms of economic policy, in the last year of the Fraser Government, in which some of these honourable senators here were Ministers, there was double digit inflation and an enormous potential deficit. In the last year of that Government there was a lot of talk about deregulation, but nothing was done. In the last few years of that Government, in fact for the entire seven years of that Government, there was talk about the desirability of needs based welfare systems but nothing really was done. In the last few years of that Government there was talk about government cost cutting and reductions in expenditure. We had that extraordinary razor gang, that review of Commonwealth Functions exercise, in which no real savings were identified even 12 months later. In terms of industry policy there was no clear direction but a series of disastrous plans were inflicted on particular industries. In terms of tax reform there was a lot of talk but nothing was done. All these issues are hard. I understand that. These issues were too hard for the Liberals. That is why nothing was done.

I make the point that in our period of government we have undoubtedly caused our popularity rating to run into difficulties. We have embarked on a prices and incomes policy which has resulted in 341,000 new jobs since April 1983-a month after we were elected. Real unit labour costs are down to the level of the early 1970s. The unemployment rate is down to 8.5 per cent. The level of industrial disputes is the lowest for 17 years. The growth rate of the Australian economy is up by 4.1 per cent in the six months to the December 1984 quarter. That is the highest growth rate for a number of years. Inflation has been halved under this Government. Investment was up 4.6 per cent in real terms in the December quarter of 1984. The level of economic spending generally is buoyant.

In the course of our government we have embarked on a number of real structural cost cutting exercises in relation to the deficit. We have embarked on the deregulation of business. We have moved to needs based welfare in several areas. We have embarked above all on the very difficult question of tax reforms. We recognise that these processes of change cause difficulties for government. We are in a difficult period at the moment. However, we have seen a government prepared to take hard decisions and prepared to bite a few bullets, which its predecessor was never prepared to do. We will never satisfy the Democrats. We will never satisfy every section of the Australian community. However, in respect of the basic concerns of this country and the need for sustained economic growth, this Government has the best performance of any government we have seen in Australia for many years. We will keep on with that, even if it involves hard decisions and carping criticisms from time to time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Opposition welcomes the tabling of the long-awaited Handicapped Programs Review report. I would like to apologise for a misunderstanding that occurred this morning in relation to the tabling statement by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes). I understand that some misleading information was imparted to me but the problem was on my side of the Senate chamber rather than that of the Government and I apologise to the Minister.

The report we now have before us is a most significant and important one. It relates to a major review-I believe that this is the first time it has been done in such a comprehensive way-of all of the programs currently being operated by the Federal Government in respect of the physically and intellectually challenged. Of course we have not yet had time to look at this report in detail and examine all of its ramifications. However, on the surface it appears to touch all of the major concerns of those in the disabled community. Indeed, from a quick glance at the report, many of the complaints appear to be major ones and are being brought forward almost daily by the various organisations that represent the physically and intellectually challenged in the community.

It is perhaps with some regret that I note the considerable delay in the presentation of this report. I think it was first expected in September or October last year-before the election-but that did not occur.
