It is now two months since we were advised by the Minister at an Estimates committee hearing that the report was at the printers and would be received any day. Of course two months or more have passed since then. I mention this matter not so much as a criticism but rather to indicate that the Opposition has been anxious to see it, as have many organisations in the community that have been concerned with the presentation of information to the inquiry.

I believe that there is a certain weakness in the tabling statement. It does not give us any indication of the Government's intentions in handling the various recommendations on behalf of the disabled community. Indeed, numerous matters have not been referred to at all in the tabling statement. I would like to mention some of them. First of all I refer to the question of income support for the disabled. The report makes six specific recommendations relating to income support. I think the Minister will acknowledge that this is the area of greatest concern to the disabled. They are concerned about the level of pensions. This must be one of the great concerns in the minds of disabled people. However, when we consider the Government's lack of commitment to its promises made before the election in 1983, in particular its promise to lift the basic pension rate to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings-it has failed to do this-we realise why people do not have a great deal of hope that the Government's promises to the disabled will be met.

Concern about various aspects of income support are revealed in questions about the handicapped child's allowance in particular. One of the report's recommendations adopts one of the Liberal and National parties' policy recommendations made on this matter before the last election. I refer to the payment for up to a maximum of 30 days for respite care for handicapped children rather than the present seven days which is causing a great deal of hardship in the community.

Disability allowances are the subject of inquiries and pilot studies at present. This is related to certain attendant care pilot studies that are going forward at the moment and which are due to terminate early next year. At present we are receiving-I suppose the Minister is also-a number of representations from community groups and individuals who are very concerned about the Government's objectives-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Grimes) agreed to:
That so much of the Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Messner speaking for a further 10 minutes and Senator Haines speaking for 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for moving that motion, thus allowing us further time to discuss this important matter. We are receiving numerous representations as to the Government's intentions on this matter. I look forward with a great deal of interest to what the Minister may have to say later about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area of very great interest and concern-one to which I know the Minister has been paying some attention lately-is the present program of aids for disabled people. The PADP scheme has been an extremely valuable one. It was first introduced by the Fraser Government in 1981. A fairly limited amount of expenditure was authorised on it. It provided an opportunity for State health departments to distribute aids for the disabled, thereby encouraging independent living and enabling the disabled to get around more freely in the community. It is obvious that this type of program is under-funded. Indeed, a vast queue of people is waiting for aids under this program. There are also some difficulties in distributing the aids through the various State government authorities. That is something to which the Government should give immediate attention because it is an area where hardship can be relieved very quickly.

The Minister drew attention in his tabling statement to the lack of uniformity between the States with regard to eligibility requirements and the lack of components to cover the maintenance of such aids. We in the Liberal and National parties believe that the PADP scheme should be extended to cover the maintenance of such aids. One can easily imagine that an electrically driven wheel-chair may well require a great deal of maintenance in order to keep it in proper working order. The chair would be of absolutely no use to a disabled person once it stops operating. We believe that the maintenance of aids should be incorporated in the funding given to various State governments and we hope that the Government will take action on this matter in the not too distant future.

Taxation is another important question when thinking of aids for the disabled. A number of aids are subject to Federal and State government imposts. Import duty on wheel-chairs is one example. We in the Liberal and National parties made our policy clear before the last election. We promised to 'remove taxes and other imposts from aids for the disabled and support Australian manufacturers through bounty or subsidy'.

I turn now to a few other matters in the Minister's statement. The Minister said that he intends to introduce a new disability services Act to replace the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and Part VIII of the Social Security Act. The requirement for this measure is obvious. There is now a vast body of disparate and separate legislation in various parts of the social welfare field that ought to be brought together. There should be a common body of legislation for the administration of assistance to the disabled. I hope there will be continuing consultation by the Government with welfare and community organisations which no doubt will be most interested in the detailed drafting of that legislation. One might observe that had the Government sought to maintain its original promise on the repatriation legislation and consulted more widely, it would not have brought about such terrible redress from the veteran community as has happened in the last couple of weeks.

When the legislation is finally before the Parliament for debate, I hope that it will be more than just an attempt to make simpler the administrative procedures for handling problems of the disabled and will be more oriented to assist more generally the problems of the disabled. That is an important point when the Minister comes finally to consider the draft legislation. We note with some concern that it may be more than a year before the legislation is dealt with in this Parliament. That means that since the Hawke Government was first elected in March 1983 this process of examining programs and finally bringing the matter to a head through new legislation will have taken more than three years. I am not sure that the Government is pleased with the rate of progress, but there is a certain anxiety in the community that this process has taken so long. I also note from the Minister's statement that the Minister intends to develop new funding and program directions. In that respect he said that there will be:

. . . ways of enabling people with disabilities to live independently within the community, of improving their access to mainstream community services and ensuring that better and more realistic training and employment opportunities are opened to them.

Naturally enough, the Liberal and National parties do not disagree with any of those goals. In fact, our policy as laid down before the last election reflected those themes of improved access, better training and employment, and recognised the desire and right to independent living while noting that this option was not open to all those who are physically or intellectually challenged.

The Minister's statement outlined five areas of key reforms to be brought about and his goals were set down. I refer in particular to his heavy reliance on the use of the new home and community care program. Judging by the experience of the last eight to 10 months, we must caution those in the disabled community about the lack of money and new initiatives in this area. We all know that before the last election the Government touted a new $300m program for home and community care for the aged and disabled which, after the election, turned out to be a program that was to cost the Government only another $10m. That sum would go very little distance in assisting the aged and disabled across the whole of Australia. It was something of a confidence trick, as has been verified by statements from Labor Ministers in the State governments, particularly in South Australia, who claim that the program was substantially oversold during the election campaign.

The Liberal and National parties will be monitoring the Government's actions closely now that this report has been presented. We hope the Government will take every opportunity to consult further with the community, and will ensure that the final legislation represents the views of those disabled people who are expecting something more than just simple changes around the edges of the present legislation. Our view is that disabled Australians should have opportunities to develop their abilities to the maximum possible extent. Like all other Australians, they are entitled to choices about their lives so that they can take the fullest part in contributing to our shared future. The Liberal and National parties' aim will be so far as possible to reduce the limitations and constraints which prevent the physically and intellectually challenged from exercising their freedom of choice. As we said in our policy statement last year, we shall be closely studying the findings of the Handicapped Programs Review as part of the process of developing our own alternative policies. The presentation of this report is just the beginning of work in this area not only for the Government but also for the Liberal and National parties. We look forward with a great deal of pleasure to examining in greater detail the report presented by the Minister today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian Democrats welcome the report of the Handicapped Programs Review and the positive statements made by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) in response to it, although I would ask the Minister to consider at some time in the very near future changing the title so that it fits in more with the way in which the community refers to people with disabilities. I think reference to 'handicapped' is a little passe.
—But that is what the programs are called.

—Yes, I am aware of that. I simply ask the Minister at some time to look at that point. In many ways the establishment of this review was long overdue, the needs of disabled people having been ignored for far too long by a succession of governments. Most people with disabilities want to be recognised as people, individuals in their own right. They rightly believe that they are people who happen to have a disability of one sort or another. They also believe that, in the main, they are not only capable of putting across a point of view, but also entitled to do so when decisions are being taken that will affect them. It is long past the time when we ended the rather paternalistic approach that was taken not only to people with disabilities, but to women and to disadvantaged groups of one sort or another. We must realise that these people are not statistics to be discussed in some objective sort of way, as if they can be moved around at will. They have the normal feelings other people have, though they have a few more needs than those of us who do not have obvious disabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The report has identified the major concerns of people with disabilities. Because it is based on an extensive range of submissions and consultations, I hope that it will provide a sound basis for future action by this Government, and possibly by successive governments. The focus of the report on the aspirations of disabled people themselves is particularly pleasing because in the past the policies have often been based only on the views and opinions of service agencies. The emphasis of the report on the provision of independent living options for disabled people is a direct reflection of the changed focus that this Government is apparently attempting to pursue. As the Minister has already pointed out, there are some 52 recommendations in the report covering a wide range of areas and they seem, at least on the surface, to address the urgent need to provide better and wider choices for disabled people in training, employment, education, leisure activities and so on. Whether the decisions relate to those sorts of areas as well as to housing, transport, sport, access to buildings, sales tax concessions, health care, access to finance or whatever, there is no doubt that most people who have a disability of one sort or another should be able to nominate the solutions to the problems in those areas. After all, they are the ones who have experienced the problems in the first place and have the best idea of how those problems can be circumvented.

The report identifies several areas of past inadequacy, poor co-ordination between State and Federal programs, and the lack of specified objectives, which attracted adverse comment from many of those who made submissions to the review. The Minister has also acknowledged the restrictive nature of existing legislation and has indicated his intention to undertake a major review of that legislation. The Australian Democrats welcome this and will examine carefully the proposed new disability services legislation when it is introduced. We hope that the same consultative process which attended the review will occur in the development of that legislation and that we do not see a recurrence of the sorts of things that have happened in the Senate occasionally, most recently with the repatriation legislation, when consultation with the people affected by it was about the last thing that occurred.

The Minister also announced a range of new funding and program directions which he has correctly identified as urgent. Again, it is pleasing to see that the focus will be on the needs of disabled people rather than on the needs of the funded organisations. The specific reforms which the Minister has announced seem likely to achieve this, although again we will have to keep a weather eye on those reforms. We can only do that when more details are available to us.

The pressure placed on families who have a child, a parent or a spouse with a disability are enormous. For many years there has been an increasing demand for respite care in a form which is beneficial both to the main carer and to the disabled child or other family member. Whether the recommendations will meet those needs remains to be seen. Certainly any extension of the family day care program will be difficult, I suspect, although it is one of the recommendations, given by the Government's deficit-cutting exercise and the strains already on that service, strains which I mentioned in a speech earlier this week. Nevertheless, as I have said, the Minister has indicated that there are urgent areas for review and he intends to undertake that review. So it is not just the official Opposition that will be keeping a weather eye on that but also the Australian Democrats.

The strengthening of the Commonwealth rehabilitation service and the proposed Office for Disability, as well as the new emphasis on a consumer-oriented approach, should ensure that future policies affecting people with disabilities avoid the often appalling inadequacies of the past. It remains to be seen whether the new directions detailed in the report will be definitive or merely the beginning of a more appropriate approach to problems facing people with disabilities, or whether it will turn out to be simply another futile exercise in examining a problem only to have partial implementation of the recommendations, with the rest shelved or put into the too hard basket. However, the Government is to be commended for setting up the review process in the first place and the Minister is to be commended for bringing down what is essentially a very positive response to the recommendations contained in the report.
I am a trifle concerned, however, at a comment in the Minister's statement which seems to add a rider to the positive nature of the rest of the statement. He says:

Clearly the major reforms I have outlined will not be achieved overnight but will require much consideration, negotiation and hard work by everyone concerned with disability matters. I look forward to initiating action and achieving results on these matters in consultation with my Government colleagues, State governments, non-government organisations and community groups and, in particular, disabled people themselves.

Nobody in his right mind would suggest that the scope and breadth of the recommendations contained in the report could be achieved overnight. I hope that consultation which has to take place, not only with the Minister's colleagues but also with his State colleagues, will not result in undue delays, in particular, I imagine, in consultations with certain States in this country that do not have a particularly good record in their concern for disadvantaged people. I will not mention any State in particular but I am sure the Minister will not have to take 20 guesses to work out the State to which I am referring. I hope that, whatever legislation is implemented, the processes that are put into operation will not be stalled because of deficit-cutting requirements from one of the Minister's colleagues, or because one State government is being a little obdurate, or because the community groups themselves are placed in a position of having to square off, so to speak, against one another and make their own decisions about the priorities. All in all, this review is overdue. The recommendations cover a wide range of areas. I hope that the Government looks at them with speed and efficiency as the essence of the exercise and that it is not held up by problems from State governments of one sort or another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want briefly to place on record my comments about the report of the Handicapped Programs Review. I do not wish to canvass the areas already covered by Senator Messner and Senator Haines, but I think such a review is a reflection of the seriousness and thoroughness with which the Government has approached this and many other areas of concern. It is quite clear that we need to hasten slowly sometimes so that that slowness actually allows the Government to be thoughtful and comprehensive in the areas it covers. I simply wish to make a comment about what the review found to be the specific outcomes most important for consumers with disabilities before I make a comment in particular about sport and leisure. I find it very interesting that people with disabilities listed these outcomes in the following order: A place to live; paid employment; being competent and self-reliant; participating in community activities; feeling secure; having choices in life; and having an image which is regarded positively by other people. I suppose that that list would not be too different from a list made out by any member of our community. It is probably quite unlike what health professionals in the past have decided should be a priority list for handicapped or disabled people. I think we have now moved to the use of the preferred word 'disabled'. There is a brief heading in the report entitled 'Sport, recreation and leisure'. It is a very brief item which simply reports:

SPEECH.PARA: Sport and recreation options for people with disabilities have traditionally received far less emphasis than residential or vocational programs.

Disabled people interested in participating in mainstream sporting and recreational activities are often unable to do so either because they are unable to get there owing to transport difficulties or because the venue concerned is physically inaccessible or inappropriate for them. I appreciate that those concerns are actually included in this report, and I would like to comment on a recent experience I had on the Working Group on Women in Sport. One of my committee colleagues was Libby Kosmala, a gold medallist in the paraplegic Olympic Games last year. Her gold medals are for shooting. Libby Kosmala illustrates very well a disabled person in our community who, to all intents and purposes, is a fully participating citizen in this community, if I can use those sorts of words. She certainly made sure that the Working Group on Women in Sport particularly addressed the needs of disabled people, not only for those who might achieve gold medal status at Olympic Games, but also for participation in everyday recreation and sporting facilities. If ever anything illustrated a nicely normal way of living in this country it is the opportunity to participate in sport and recreation programs and facilities around the country. That participation is part of community health, part of being a member of the mainstream of the community and part of being nicely normal. I think it also allows disabled people to feel very much part of the mainstream community. Again it provides an opportunity for members of the community to see, by playing sport and recreating with disabled people, that disabled people are, to all intents and purposes, not too different from them; they simply have a disability.

I commend the review and in particular I commend the emphasis that the members of the Committee have brought to our attention for regarding disabled people as members of the community who are equal to anybody else, with their own particular needs. I am particularly interested to see that the list of important requirements for disabled people is unlike the lists that we have had in the past which have been given to disabled people. I think it is very encouraging to see that the list now reflects what disabled people themselves want. I am pleased that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) in his comments on this report stressed the importance of involving consumers and clients in the planning as well as the program delivery and review. I think that the voice of disabled people in the provisions of their own services and planning will guarantee that we do not have a return to the Dark Ages for disabled people that we have experienced in the past in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move motions for the introduction and first and second readings of the six Bills referred to in notices of motion Nos 44 to 49 as if the Bills were being taken together, on the understanding that the Bills will be listed as separate orders of the day on the Notice Paper and the questions for the second reading and all remaining stages will be put separately in accordance with the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express my deep gratitude to the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and Senator Harradine for the courtesy they have extended to me in allowing me to bring forward these Bills in this way today. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the passage of aircraft carrying nuclear weapons through Australian airspace.
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the passage of nuclear-powered ships through Australian waters.
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the passage of ships carrying nuclear weapons through Australian waters.
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the manufacture of nuclear weapons in, and the introduction of nuclear weapons into, Australia.
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the importation of nuclear hardware, and for purposes connected therewith.
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the exportation of nuclear materials, and for purposes connected therewith.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills presented by Senator Chipp, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
AUSTRALIAN AIR SPACE (NUCLEAR WEAPONS PROHIBITION) BILL 1985
AUSTRALIAN WATERS (NUCLEAR-POWERED SHIPS PROHIBITION) BILL 1985
AUSTRALIAN WATERS (NUCLEAR WEAPONS PROHIBITION) BILL 1985

These Bills offer a hope to the people of Australia, particularly the young people who believe that there is no future for them, and who believe it is better to live for today because there may be no tomorrow: Not because Reagan or Gorbachev are madmen, but because of a computer error or a single disturbed person sitting in a submarine presses the wrong button. To evade the reality that a nuclear exchange would be far from the cities of Australia, off in missile silos elsewhere, is absurd. The targets will be ships and planes just as much as military bases. These nuclear targets are unacceptable risks, and the series of Australian Democrats' Bills are aimed at eliminating the whole gamut of these nuclear threats to our very survival. Not only do many honourable senators here appear to embrace the exposure of their fellow citizens to these risks, but in doing so they are effectively blocking off the only faint hope for lasting peace in our region: The nuclear free zones proposed for our region in the Pacific and Indian Oceans, as well as the Association of South East Asian Nations proposal. The Australian Government's support for disarmament in general and a nuclear freeze in particular is farcical in the light of its support, collusion and even encouragement of the nuclear strategy of the United States of America. Are these people aware that, in so readily handing over our sovereignty and integrity as a nation, in the future we may not be able to redeem our rights as a nation to do what is in this nation's interests?

All in all there are six anti-nuclear Australian Democrats' Bills. For Senator Tate, who was so genuinely concerned about the immunity aspect of one of our Bills that he could not vote for it, we have altered it; not because we believe that it was any different in that regard from the many Acts since Federation covering similar areas, but because we believe it does not detract from the Bill's effectiveness to accommodate him. For those honourable senators who said there was nothing in the Bills they could object to-except that they were introduced by me-I made the offer inside this chamber, publicly, and then personally in a letter to each of the Government senators in which I said: 'Bring in your own Bill on this and my colleague Democrat senators and I will vote for your Bill'. None of the senators responded positively. I really do not care if it is my Bill or theirs, but since they have no Bills I must introduce mine on behalf of my colleagues in the Australian Democrats.

Each Bill forms a part of the anti-nuclear package. The Australian Airspace (Nuclear Weapons Prohibition) Bill 1985 I believe is vital at this point. While it is true that Foreign Ministers Street and Haig signed an agreement in 1981 that United States B52 bombers in Australian territory are to be unarmed and carry no nuclear bombs, it is true that the United States is not prepared to disclose which of its aircraft are nuclear armed and which are conventionally armed. This was said by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, speaking on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in reply to a question from me in this House on 27 March 1985. To take his reply one step further, the agreement is only what is euphemistically known as a gentleman's agreement. In other words, we have an agreement with the United States which is at present unverifiable by us. It is not even possible to verify that the B52s are unarmed, let alone not nuclear armed. We are not allowed to, or we are afraid to, ask the Americans. In other words, we have these aircraft flying over our land-it does not just relate to our ports-and yet, according to official Government policy, we do not or will not ask them whether they are armed or whether they are carrying bombs. In other words, we rely on what is euphemistically known as the gentleman's agreement.

The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) tells me that the B52 flights through Australia-Busy Boomerang Delta and Glad Customer are their names-are for low level navigation training over Queensland, the Northern Territory and Western Australia and sea surveillance and navigation training over the Indian Ocean. Yet the Commander in Chief of the Pacific Command, CINCPAC, testified in February 1984 before the United States Senate Armed Services Committee that he is looking forward to the B1, fitted with cruise missiles, being added, with the existing B52s with conventional arms, to the functions of the Strategic Offensive Forces at Guam, which include surveillance flights over the Indian Ocean and staging through Australia. How, in the face of this evidence, can the Australian Government repeat childishly that no B52s are armed and will not in the future carry nuclear weapons? The Government does not know, it has not asked and it will not ask the United States. In this Bill we propose to give the Australian Government the power to verify this. It is not a question of the planes being nuclear armed or conventionally armed because, according to the agreement, they are all unarmed planes. Surely on that basis the United States Government could not object to the passage of this Bill, seeing as it says that it has nothing to hide.

Furthermore, the B52 agreement is an agreement which is supported by both the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Opposition; a Liberal Government negotiated it. This Bill merely takes it to its logical conclusion, that one of the signatories has the right to verify the agreement. After all, this does affect our land.

Most alarming are the recent developments in the upgrading of the United States operations in Guam. In particular, the B1s are fitted with cruise missiles and the B52s are also to be fitted with cruise missiles while the newer B52Gs will carry nuclear short range attack missiles. All are to be deployed to Guam in the next 12 months. Article I of the agreement states:
The agreement of the Government of Australia shall be obtained before the facilities are used in support of any other category of operations.
Article VII states:

Arrangements shall be made for consultations to ensure that the Government of Australia has full and timely information about strategic and operational developments relevant to B52 staging operations through Australia.

We can only assume that these negotiations are afoot now. Now is the time to take responsibility for Australia's foreign policy and establish that no nuclear planes and no nuclear bombs are being carried by United States planes over Australian territory now or will be in the future.

I turn now to the Australian Waters (NuclearPowered Ships Prohibition) Bill 1985. From 1971, during the McMahon Government, to June 1976 the visit of all nuclear-powered ships to Australian ports was suspended-this was under Liberal governments-until satisfactory guarantees against accidents were given and the practical requirements in the different circumstances of each Australian port could be assessed. The report which followed the suspension recommended limiting the acceptance of nuclear-powered warships to those ships with power reactor levels less than 100 megawatts thermal. Point 21 of that report stated:
The chance of a reactor accident, though remote, cannot be entirely discounted and the risks from nuclear powered subs and surface warships is no greater than from civilian power reactors.

Given the Three Mile Island incident, that is hardly reassuring. The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission in the last month presented evidence before the United States House of Representatives Sub-Committee on Energy, Conservation and Power. It put the chance of a melt-down at a nuclear reactor somewhere in America in the next 20 years at 50:50. This is a chilling forecast: It put the chance of a melt-down in a nuclear reactor somewhere in America in the next 20 years at even money. To be told that the chances are the same with nuclear-powered warships is hardly heartening, particularly when one contemplates that regularly those ships tie up near centres of heavy population such as Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane and Perth. The Australian report considered sinkings, collisions, explosion, loss of propulsion and abnormal occurrences in port of nuclear powered ships up to 1976 and recommended that for planning purposes an area within 600 metres radius of the berth should be capable of urgent and immediate evacuation. It identified a core melt-down as the principal risk of a nuclear ship visiting an Australian port. It stated:
The probability of a core melt-down accident will not be greater than one in ten thousand per reactor per year.

Of course, accidents of a far more dramatic kind could occur as a result of a catastrophic failure of the reactor pressure vessel or from a high speed collision or sabotage. However, the reality is that Australian authorities have no control over operating techniques or safety precautions carried out on board the nuclear-powered vessels. Nor can the Australian Government assure us that there is no unauthorised discharge of radioactive waste into the port environment. It has not initiated services necessary to safeguard the public in the event of a release of radioactivity following an accident, as was recommended by the report. I quote again from the report:
The remote possibility of an accident or failure leading to the release of radioactive fission products to the environment has to be accepted.

I now turn to the final Bill of this set, the Australian Waters (Nuclear Weapons Prohibition) Bill 1985. The mystifying lack of logic of the Hawke Government is highlighted by the fact that, while nuclear-powered and nuclear-armed ships are allowed-no, welcomed into Australian ports-by this Government, the Government is categorically opposed to nuclear-armed planes or even conventionally-armed planes flying over Australian territory. In other words, the logic of this Government seems to be: We will allow nuclear bombs into our ports but not over our land. Of course, there is no logical difference; it is just hypocrisy. Nuclear-armed ships are just as much nuclear targets as are Pine Gap or Nurrungar in the case of a nuclear conflict. While the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, can admit that the United States installations in Australia are Soviet targets, and they have done that, they have not been prepared to admit that any nuclear warship in an Australian port would equally be a target.

These warships are not part of our ANZUS obligation, just as they are not part of New Zealand's ANZUS obligation. Somewhere between the beginning of the 1970s and now, the United States has unilaterally altered the terms of ANZUS. Somewhere along the tortuous path of United States foreign policy, allies have lost their right of independence-the right to act in their own country's national security interests as they see them. An ally, even a powerful ally such as the United States, should not exact such a price from its friends and partners. It is very heartening indeed to see that within the last month Iceland, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, has decided to follow the courageous leadership of New Zealand and not allow nuclear armed ships into its ports.

It is interesting to compare the way the United States treats non-allies with respect to nuclear warships. Communist China can lay down conditions. Egypt can lay down conditions, and that nation has a long-standing policy of not allowing nuclear warships through the Suez Canal. Countries that are not allies of the United States are treated as having rights and are respected accordingly, but not allies such as New Zealand or Australia. To Mr Reagan, alliances are there only to assist the United States in its super-power rivalry with the Soviet Union-nothing more. To end nuclear ship visits merely requires an act of determination, not of enormous sacrifice. Australia does not even need to take the lead or to break new ground. Other nations have already done this. It merely requires the Government to carry out the wishes of the millions of Australians who wish to disentangle this nation from the nuclear insanity of the super-powers.

I conclude by drawing the attention of the Senate to the admission by the United States Defense Department that there had been 31 major nuclear accidents up to 1981 and the fact that the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute found that 113 such accidents had occurred in Western forces before 1977. God knows what the figure would be in 1985. The United States Congress has reported that 5,000 Service personnel have been removed from weapons duties because of alcohol or drug abuse, criminal negligence or mental problems. Now is the time to act. As weapons control systems become more complex, human error becomes more likely. Yet this Government, like successive previous governments, has embraced the complete nuclear vulnerability of this nation against all the evidence and against all common sense. I commend these three Bills to the Senate.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the second reading speeches on the Nuclear Weapons Prohibitions Bill 1985, the Customs (Prohibition of Importation of Nuclear Hardware) Bill 1985 and the Customs (Prohibition of Exportation of Nuclear Materials) Bill 1985.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
NUCLEAR WEAPONS PROHIBITIONS BILL 1985
This legislation is part of the 6 anti-nuclear Bills proposed by the Australian Democrats.

It would in effect be a great step towards establishing Australia as a nuclear weapons free zone. The Bill would prohibit the development, testing, manufacturing, transportation, storage or importation of nuclear weapons into Australia. For the purposes of this Bill, Australia is defined as the land mass to the low water mark including external territories. Territorial waters, harbours and airspace are excluded as these are covered in other Australian Democrat Bills.

The prohibitions in the Bill apply to the Commonwealth; a person on behalf of the Commonwealth; a corporation; the Government or Defence Forces of a foreign country or any person on their behalf. The Commonwealth is prohibited from entering into an agreement with a foreign country that would allow that foreign country to import, store, test or transport nuclear weapons within Australia. Remember that when we refer to Australia we are referring to the land mass of the continent and the external territories.

The reason for this Bill is very simple. The nuclear arms race is accelerating out of control. The super-powers' negotiations for nuclear arms limitations have ground to a halt. In the light of this, it is necessary for the non-nuclear states to take their own initiatives and put into legislation a nuclear weapons free zone.

This Bill is designed to give legal effect in Australia to the United Nations General Assembly resolution to create a nuclear-weapon-free zone in the South Pacific. It is the policy of the present Labor Government to promote such a South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone proposal bans the use, testing, stationing or development, manufacture, receiving or acquisition of nuclear weapons.

In declaring Australia a nuclear free-zone we are in this Bill focusing solely on nuclear weapons. It is open for any country or group of countries to ban on their territory whatever it wishes through a unilateral act. If Australia wishes to ban all nuclear activities of any kind, whether as a symbolic repudiation of that technology or on the grounds of environmental concern over, for example, reactor safety, it is free to do so. As a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty Australia has already declared its intention to remain a nuclear weapons free country. This does not make this legislation any less vital. It is precisely when there are no nuclear weapons on Australian soil that Australia can sensibly outlaw any future weapons involvement. This is the reason for the success of the banning of nuclear weapons in Antarctica, the seabed and outer space.

I wish to stress that this Bill does not in any way inhibit peaceful nuclear industries in accordance with the NPT and the Latin American Zone-Tlatelolco. What it merely does is establish in law that Australia forfeits the option of nuclear weapons.
The Hawke Government has renounced any desire for Australia to have a nuclear weapons capability.

The very first plank of the Disarmament, Arms Control and International Security section of the 1984 Platform of the ALP reads: 'Labor is committed to the elimination of nuclear weapons and the ultimate achievement of general and complete disarmament'. To support this Bill the Government does not have to make enormous sacrifices. This Bill is part of the Government's publicly stated policy; by passing this Bill, the Government will be closing the nuclear weapons option for Australia once and for all.

The concept of nuclear weapon free zones can make an enormous contribution to disarmament initiatives. The absence of nuclear weapons from various regions increases the threshold between the use of conventional and nuclear weapons. Decision-making time in case of a conflict is increased, reducing the prospect that an outbreak of fighting would automatically escalate to a catastrophic and global holocaust. All these reasons would lead to an increase in confidence and stability.

The East-West border in central Europe is the region that most needs to be a nuclear weapons free zone. Australia will not have a great deal of direct influence on that issue. However, if we ourselves are a nuclear weapons free zone our diplomatic influence would be vastly increased because we would be an example of what we are asking for. This Bill would put our domestic affairs totally in line with our international concerns. If, as a unilateral initiative, Australia moved towards being a nuclear weapons free zone through the proposals contained in this Bill, we would be able to exert considerable influence towards establishing similar zones in the South Pacific and the Indian Ocean. Nuclear war would be a more distant prospect if these zones were to be established.

This Bill is consistent with Labor Party policy. By passing it, the Government would be backing its commitment with not only words, but with action. This Bill is the guarantee that Australia needs to repudiate a nuclear weapons option for all time.
CUSTOMS (PROHIBITION OF IMPORTATION OF NUCLEAR HARDWARE) BILL 1985
This Bill deals with one area of Australia's involvement in the nuclearisation of the world.

In broad terms, this Bill imposes a general prohibition on the importation of nuclear hardware. Hardware which would be essential if Australia wanted to establish nuclear power plants, uranium enrichment plants or nuclear waste reprocessing facilities. There are exceptions for medical and industrial uses. The Minister has the power, under this Bill, to grant permission for the importation of nuclear hardware to the Australian Atomic Energy Commission for the medical and industrial uses of isotopes. For the benefit of those honourable senators who require further definition of the words ''isotopes for industrial use'' I wish to make it quite clear from the outset, that this includes agricultural uses and research in the ''medical'' and ''industrial'' uses of isotopes, all under strict Parliamentary scrutiny of course.
All the evidence indicates that a nuclear industry for Australia is a shortsighted, uneconomic and totally repugnant path.
By putting our eggs in the nuclear energy basket we would be rejecting the abundant alternatives in energy efficiency and renewability as well as increasing the risk of nuclear proliferation.

The reality is that solar and wind power supply twice as much energy to consumers now in the United States of America as nuclear power does. If it were true that nuclear power could replace oil as a source of power then one would have expected a rapid increase in the number of nuclear reactors in OECD countries after the 1973-74 oil crisis. The truth is that there has been a dramatic decline in the number of nuclear reactors in OECD countries since 1974.

To take the US figures to February 1984, 108 nuclear power reactor orders had to be cancelled. The William H. Zimmer reactor was 97 per cent completed when the project was abandoned as economically unviable.

The cost of constructing power plants is only one of the factors which determines the cost of the fuel they produce. The nuclear industry has received billions of dollars in subsidies all over the world for research and development, uranium enrichment, and of course the imponderable deferred cost of nuclear waste disposal.
The US Department of Energy itself admitted to Federal subsidies of $37 billion to the nuclear power industry from 1950 to 1980. These figures did not include tax subsidies or loopholes.
As a nation that has a genuine interest in peace, the connection between a civil nuclear industry and nuclear weapons must be accepted.

It is just so much harder for a country to develop nuclear weapons if it does not have a nuclear industry. The civil nuclear programmes of India, Pakistan, South Africa, Iran, Argentina and South Korea have put them on the road to nuclear weapons.

Nor can involvement in the nuclear fuel cycle be used as a lever to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons. The US, in spite of considerable pressure to prevent India or Pakistan developing nuclear weapons, has failed to have any effect on those countries. If the US cannot affect the nuclear policy of other nations, how in all honesty can anybody pretend that Australia could succeed in pressuring nations where America has failed?

The fact that there is no permanent method of waste disposal should be enough to convince people that Australia should not be party to nuclear energy in the future. There is no safe method of disposal of radioactive waste, and saying, as some honourable senators have, that nuclear waste is just a question of will and money does not help.

After more than 30 years of nuclear waste, the world is no closer to a permanent solution. Since nuclear reactors have about a 30 year operational life the larger problem of what to do with a spent nuclear reactor has not even been contemplated.

This nation must declare itself to be on the anti-nuclear path. We must spurn every part of the nuclear cycle. Unless it is for medical or industrial uses nuclear isotopes have no place in this country.

The Government members know in their heart of hearts that there is nothing wrong with this Bill. It is a philosophy that many honourable senators on both sides share. The ALP platform on nuclear power states that a Labor Government will ''prohibit the establishment in Australia of nuclear power plants and all other stages of the nuclear fuel cycle''. On an issue such as this it is meaningless not to have a tripartisan policy for the benefit of this country's future.

The passage of this Bill would close off the nuclear option. The Government keeps its nuclear options open if it does not support this Bill. The purpose of this Bill is to prevent Australia establishing a civil nuclear industry and then nuclear weapons.
All the rational arguments are against nuclear energy, I commend the Bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS (PROHIBITION OF EXPORTATION OF NUCLEAR MATERIALS) BILL 1985

This legislation is to prohibit all exportation of uranium from Australia. This is one of six Bills the Australian Democrats are bringing before the House which would cut off once and for all Australia's involvement in the nuclear insanity which is pervading the world.

Honourable senators will no doubt be aware that this is not the first time I have brought a Bill such as this before the House. I am doing so again not only because it is an issue of such vital importance to me and the Australian Democrats, but because it reflects the hopes, ambitions and desires of millions of Australians.

Australia, and the politicians who represent the people of Australia, cannot ignore the fact that this country has enormous uranium reserves. This is an issue about which we cannot pretend that what Australia does is irrelevant to the proliferation of nuclear weapons. We are helping to place the world in peril of the ultimate Armageddon.
Uranium has two purposes only, it can be used as a fuel, and it can be used for nuclear weapons.

The reality is that to justify the selling of Australian uranium on the grounds that it is for civil use only is patently absurd. We do know that the establishment of a civil nuclear industry provides the basis for the manufacture of nuclear weapons. It is just so much harder, in fact, a great deal harder for a country to manufacture nuclear weapons without a civil nuclear industry. The civil nuclear programmes of India, Pakistan, South Africa, Iran, Argentina and South Korea have put them on the road to nuclear weapons. A path which every sane person in this world deeply regrets.

Nor can honourable senators hide behind the argument that because we are supplying uranium for civil industry in other countries we will be able to influence the course they choose; and somehow keep them off the manufacture of nuclear weapons. There is not a single shred of evidence to prove that any country, let alone Australia, has been able to keep any nation's nuclear industry civil, when they wish to develop nuclear weapons. The United States, in spite of considerable pressure, has been unable to prevent India or Pakistan from developing nuclear weapons. Is anyone seriously suggesting for one moment that we can succeed where they have failed?

The leverage argument passed into history when the Reagan Administration between July 1981 and June 1982 issued 57 export licences for nuclear-related technology to the nuclear programs of India, South Africa, Argentina and Israel. All these countries refuse international inspection of their nuclear facilities and have not signed the Non-proliferation Treaty.

Australia must take her share of the responsibility for the proliferation of nuclear weapons as long as she sells uranium. The recent report that Australia may sell uranium to Egypt is a disgrace. Does anyone honestly believe that this will finally be for non-weapons purposes, given the fact that Israel and Iraq have nuclear weapons, and Libya and Iran are developing them. In the light of the highly volatile nature of the Middle East, and Australia's long expressed desire to see peace and stability in that region, this act can only be interpreted as an act of international vandalism.

Recent events in Australia involving uranium sales to France show once again the complete and continuing hypocrisy of this Government's position. Labor Party policy, agreed to at the 1984 ALP National Conference, states that a Labor Government will 'refuse to allow the supply of Australian uranium to France until France ceases testing nuclear weapons in the South Pacific region'. Less than one year later we have a Labor Government selling out yet again-in March of this year the Government announced the export of 100 short tons of uranium to France.

Underneath the complex contractual aspects of the statement by the Minister for Trade on 21 February this year, the truth stands out: Australia is selling uranium directly to France, because, in the words of the Minister for Trade, to not do so would ''prejudice Australia's trade interests''. This statement makes it crystal clear where the Government's priorities lie: with its own monetary interests, and the interests of uranium companies.

In exporting uranium we must accept our role not only in nuclear proliferation but in the long term problem of disposal of radioactive waste. Despite the fact that the nuclear industry has been around for over 30 years and has been churning out radioactive waste for 30 years, the world has not found a permanent solution to radioactive waste disposal. None of the four areas-spent fuel rods, high level liquid waste, low level waste and uranium mine tailings-of radioactive waste have a safe, permanent disposal system. Even more alarming is that there is no system likely in the foreseeable future. Given the fact that there are some 16,000-24,000 tons of spent nuclear fuel rods, and 1.2 to 1.8 million tons of liquid waste in the western world alone, this should be reason enough to cease all uranium mining and exportation until a safe system of waste disposal is established.
Even if all nuclear production were to cease now, the world would still have to deal with the problem of the enormous volume of radioactive waste, waste with a life of thousands of millions of years.
The final point I wish to raise is that nuclear power, for those who advocate it as an energy source, is economically unviable.

The delivered electricity price of US reactors commissioned from 1982-84 varies from 7c to over 20c per kilowatt hour. Australian electricity prices 1981 range from 1.28c to 6.92c per kilowatt hour depending on user designation. Unfortunately many of the official industry costs simply ignore many of the factors which add to the cost of nuclear power.

The cost to the taxpayer in the US in the form of subsidies to the nuclear industry is around $40 billion; in France the figure to 1982 was $19 billion. In Japan the capital cost for research and development to the taxpayer is in excess of $19 billion.

These sorts of figures are the reason why the nuclear power industry is collapsing. In the U.S. the last order for a nuclear power station was in 1978. It is why 78 per cent of Swedes in 1980 voted for a phasing out of nuclear power by 2010. The message is clear to anyone: Without enormous Government handouts nuclear power cannot stand by itself economically. The trend is clear round the world. Nuclear power is not cheap.

I would like to end with a sobering thought. The world's nuclear plants produce about 40 metric tons of separated plutonium each year. That is enough to make 5,000 to 20,000 nuclear bombs a year. By ending uranium mining as this Bill proposes, we would make a great contribution to the world in the face of nuclear madness.
I commend these Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, has this afternoon reintroduced, in a slightly different form, six private senator's Bills-the Australian Waters (Nuclear-Powered Ships Prohibition) Bill 1985, the Australian Waters (Nuclear Weapons Prohibition) Bill 1985, the Nuclear Weapons Prohibitions Bill 1985, the Customs (Prohibition of Importation of Nuclear Hardware) Bill 1985, the Customs (Prohibition of Exportation of Nuclear Materials) Bill 1985 and the Australian Air Space (Nuclear Weapons Prohibition) Bill 1985- which he introduced into this Parliament previously. I am disappointed that this has occurred at the conclusion of the session and at a time which prevents there being a substantial debate, involving all the parties in this chamber, about the issues which have been raised by Senator Chipp.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills cover a series of quite different propositions. There is a Bill which proposes to make Australia part of a nuclear weapons free zone by barring the possession of nuclear weapons in this country and declaring Australia to be a nuclear weapons free zone. We go from that Bill to a proposal that there be a prohibition on the importation of nuclear hardware, which moves into the quite different area of the importation of material which might be related to the peaceful use of nuclear energy, although there are some specific exceptions relating to medical uses and some other limited uses. A further Bill relates to the export of uranium, which would be prohibited under that legislation. Then there are the Bills-the second reading speeches on which were fully presented to this chamber a few minutes ago-which involve the prohibition of nuclear weapons in our air space, the prohibition of visits by nuclear powered ships into our waters and also the prohibition of nuclear weapons within Australian waters. The Bills which are brought forward in this form by Senator Chipp warrant debate and, just as importantly, warrant dissection because they raise quite different and very important issues which need to be addressed in this Parliament.

I suppose the major concern I have about the Bills coming in in this way is that they seek to mix up totally the question of the peaceful use of nuclear energy for the generation of electricity with the question of nuclear weapons. That is a linkage which the Opposition believes needs to be contested and which sits very oddly with Australia's obligations under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. I do not know whether the Australian Democrats have ever specifically said that they are opposed to the Non-Proliferation Treaty, but it seems to me that the proposals they consistently put before this chamber are quite inconsistent with Australia's obligations under the treaty, which include obligations to take part in the development and use of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes. It is quite inconsistent with the Treaty, as it is presently cast, that we would consider the sorts of prohibitions which are contained in a number of the Democrat Bills.

More fundamental concerns arise on the nuclear weapons issue. It needs to be said each time this issue is brought forward that there is a fundamental difference between the Australian Democrats and the Government and the Opposition because the Democrats proceed on the basis that simply removing Australia from any involvement with nuclear matters can lead to a reduction in the possibility of nuclear war and an increased possibility that there will be peace. Of course, the Opposition has long held the view that this sort of approach is not consistent with the interests of Australia and is not consistent with advancing the cause of peace. I think it is important to note that there is a high degree of commonality between the Government and the Opposition on this issue. When we last debated the Bills in this group in the Senate, on 25 February 1985, I quoted at some length from the contribution made by Senator Gareth Evans to the debate in September 1984, when he drew out one of the principles which are common ground between the Government and the Opposition. The unfortunate conclusion that we draw from the views put forward by the Australian Democrats is that they do substantially increase the risk to Australia of nuclear war rather than decrease it, on the basis that the option which is available to Australia to prevent nuclear war at the moment is to take part in a system of stable deterrence and, within that framework, to work for disarmament on a phased, verified and agreed basis.

I look forward to there being an opportunity for more significant and lengthy debate on this subject, involving all parties. It has interested me that, since before the last election, when the issue of whether the Australian Democrats are in favour of unilateral or multilateral disarmament had been raised, there have been strong expressions, certainly by Senator Chipp and Senator Mason, that the Australian Democrats stand for multilateral disarmament. It fascinated me that when I raised the same issue with Senator-elect Jo Vallentine-who will be joining us after July-she also professed herself very staunchly as being in favour of multilateral disarmament. If the Democrats and Ms Vallentine, by saying that they are in favour of multilateral disarmament, mean that they would like all sides to disarm, that is one thing. The real question is in what sense they believe in multilateral disarmament as requiring that we should engage in disarmament, not on the basis of Australia taking unilateral steps but rather, to quote the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia, by seeking:
. . . agreements involving mutual substantial and militarily significant reductions of nuclear and conventional arms, with effective verification and compliance.

I read the next sentence from the Liberal policy statement because it expresses very well the concerns I have about the propositions which are being advanced by Senator Chipp and, independently, by Ms Vallentine. The Liberal policy states:
Any approach to arms limitations which ignores the needs of verification and continuing stability is ineffective, undesirable and dangerous.
The whole question of mutuality, verification and compliance is central-

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely someone has to give a lead.

—Yes, but I am trying to say that this is central to the point of difference between us. I understand the point Senator Chipp is making. I simply say to him that if that lead involves Australia unilaterally taking steps which substantially reduce the deterrence of the Western alliance-if I may use that broad expression-it may be a contribution to instability rather than the moral lead which Senator Chipp is seeking to provide and which he hopes will be followed by other parties. From the words which Senator Chipp has used it is quite clear that he is seeking Australia's unilateral action. Whether it would be described as unilateral disarmament we might argue at greater length in another debate. However, he is certainly seeking unilateral action on the part of the United States.
—It is not the same thing.

—Senator Mason shakes his head. However, let me quote from the second reading speech on the Nuclear Weapons Prohibitions Bill, which has just been incorporated in Hansard by Senator Chipp. I thank him for making it available to me. Page 2 of the typescript of that speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is open for any country or group of countries to ban on their territory whatever it wishes through a unilateral act.

Quite clearly, what is being sought in the banning of weapons, of exports, of uranium and of this and that is unilateral action by Australia. It may well be that Senator Chipp believes that this will lead later to actions on the part of others which will give rise to what he would describe as multilateral disarmament. I simply say that this sort of unilateral action, which is not part of an agreed program of a mutual reduction of arms at this stage, is a course which is fraught with danger.

TALK.START.PARA: —But, Senator, it is not seeking unilateral action from one of the powers. That is confusing the situation.

—The simple fact is that it is seeking unilateral action on the part of Australia which would, of course, have a substantial effect on our allies. I do not think the Government or the Opposition would seek to deny that Australia has a quite important role to play in the Western alliance. We have a very large land mass in an important part of the world. The access of the United States and other countries to our ports is an important part of the World's Western alliance defence system. Just as importantly, we have important Australian-American strategic facilities in Australia. The fact is that Australia, in acting unilaterally, affects not only itself but also the ability of its allies to maintain a position of strength. I say, in a debate which I know it is not wanted to prolong-
—Yes.

—The Minister for Community Services has made it quite clear that he thinks the debate should cease now. I can only say to him that there has been agreement to waive further General Business in the interests of Government Business. The matter is important enough to warrant some comment. It is fundamentally important that in the debates in the next Parliament, when it resumes for the Budget session, there be some detailed examination of the concept of unilateral action by the United States and how that can possibly fit into a concept of multilateral disarmament. It is very important to Australia and ultimately very important to the world. My main object at this stage is simply to reaffirm the very strong concern of the Opposition about this issue. We believe that the pursuit of peace is as critical a matter as is faced by Government in Australia today. We believe that it is very important. Our difference with the Australian Democrats is that we are not happy with the line they advance as being one that will further the cause of peace. It is my hope that we will have opportunities for serious and, if necessary, lengthy debate on this issue in the next Parliament so that some of these matters can be drawn out and our position on the matter advanced in various ways.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the contributions made by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, and other Government speakers to the debate in this place last September and in February, and, if one looks at the contributions by speakers on behalf of the Opposition, one will find a consistent thread in that they all seek peace. One will also find a consistent thread in that they believe that avenues other than those being pursued by the Australian Democrats need to be pursued in preference to the Australian Democrats' approach. I seek leave to continue my remarks later in the hope that, in the Budget session, we will have an opportunity to debate this matter with all parties involved in a way which will advance our thinking on the matter and which will, in the end, advance Australia's interests.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I present the report on changes in the presentation of appropriations and departmental explanatory notes, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This matter arises because of the Government's introduction of a pilot scheme of program budgeting. The matter was referred to the Committee on 19 March 1985 following the recommendations made by Estimates Committee A in its report of October 1984 that the issues arising from planned and/or implemented changes to appropriations and possible effects on departmental explanations should be examined by the Finance and Government Operations Committee. At the Committee's invitation the Department of Finance made a submission and officers of that Department gave evidence at the hearing held by the Committee on 22 April 1985. Copies of the Hansard report, which includes the submission, are available from the Secretary to the Committee. The Committee in its report recommends: That the Departments of Finance, Employment and Industrial Relations and Industry, Technology and Commerce present their Budget estimates and explanatory notes for 1985-86 in the program format outlined in the report; that Estimates Committees A and C examine those departments' explanatory notes and report to the Senate on their format and content; that the Finance and Government Operations Committee review the reports of those Estimates committees and report the results of its review to the Senate and, finally, that the Department of Finance prepare a handbook on documentation requirements under program budgeting in consultation with the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.
