DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I present a report on Commonwealth law-making power and the privilege of freedom of speech in State parliaments.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have pleasure in speaking to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the reference relating to the Commonwealth law and the privilege of freedom of speech in State parliaments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has considered the statement by the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Solicitor-General, hereafter called the joint opinion, relating to the rights of members of State parliaments for complete immunity from the application of Federal law in reference to their statements made in Parliament. The joint opinion arose from a statement made in the South Australian Parliament by Mr Peter Duncan, then a Member of the Legislative Assembly. The joint opinion expressed the view that State parliamentary privilege was subject to control by the law imposed by the Commonwealth, whereas the majority of this Committee is of the opinion that it is not. The law officers and the whole of the Committee thought that the law, as it stands, does not subject State members to any control in the performing of their privileges as members of a State parliament, but the majority of this Committee has concluded that under no circumstances can the law of the Commonwealth be applied so as to restrict such rights of State members.

We believe, and set out in some detail the reasons for our opinion, that the Commonwealth in this area is restrained not only because section 106 of the Commonwealth Constitution guarantees the inviolability of State Constitutions but also because there is an implied limitation on Commonwealth power in respect of the privilege of freedom of speech in State parliaments. The overriding of the freedom of speech of State parliaments would amount to a substantial interference with the State's capacity to govern and the functioning of Parliament is an 'essential State function' which could not exist without that freedom of speech.

The report examines the establishment of this privilege which is held by State parliaments either by inherited law, or by application of the doctrine of necessity or by express provision made for it in State legislation.

The Committee has considered the provisions of section 106 of the Federal Constitution which preserves the Constitution of the States 'subject to this Constitution' and considers that section 106 operates to prevent a State's privilege of freedom of speech from being overridden by Federal laws operating under section 51 of the Constitution. It rejects entirely the concept adopted by the joint opinion that the defence power of the Constitution can be used to override State parliamentary privilege. It finds that any other conclusion would reduce section 106 to a nullity, would lead to wide ramifications and allow the use of the powers under the Constitution to override State powers.

The majority of the Committee also relies on the doctrine of Federal implications of the Constitution to deny Commonwealth power to be applied in this manner. The Committee believes that the right of freedom of speech is necessary to establish the State's capacity to govern. It refers with approval to the 1984 statement of the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege when it affirmed:

Without this fundamental right Members would fear to express themselves with the bluntness and directness parliamentary life so frequently demands, and the Parliament could become a shell devoid of content or meaning.

The Committee goes on to consider certain ancillary matters. It concludes that publication of statements made in State parliament are subject to similar overriding privileges. It believes, with the New South Wales Solicitor-General, that statements made in Parliament already constitute matters belonging to the public and that such matters are not complementary, reasonable, appropriate or incidental to any head of power in the Commonwealth. Furthermore, it does not share the New South Wales Solicitor-General's doubts that, even in time of war, the Commonwealth has any power to restrict reporting of parliamentary privileges.

The further matter relates to the law of contempt as related to royal commissions. The Committee finds persuasive the views of the Chairman of the Australian Press Council that a royal commission, exercising an executive and not a judicial function, should not be interpreted as having any powers of contempt and considers that the expression 'wilful contempt' in relation to criticism or debate of the subject of a royal commission should be defined and restricted so that serious, critical discussion of the work of a royal commission may be published for the information of the public.

Senator Tate and Senator Puplick dissent from the view held by the majority of the Committee as to the substantive question of whether the Commonwealth has power to override State parliamentary privilege in specific circumstances and their separate conclusions and arguments are annexed to this report. They are of the opinion that the law officers are correct in their advice to the Government. Senator Tate, unlike Senator Puplick, disagrees also with the conclusions formed by the Committee in respect of the application of Commonwealth legislation to media reports of statements made in State parliaments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 November 1983 the Senate appointed the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare to inquire into:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the question of animal welfare in Australia, with particular reference to:
(a) interstate and overseas commerce in animals;
(b) wildlife protection and harvesting;
(c) animal experimentation;
(d) codes of practice of animal husbandry for all species; and
(e) the use of animals in sport.

Advertisements were placed in the national and rural Press in mid-January 1984 calling for written submissions with a request that they be forwarded to the Committee by 9 March 1984. This was a nominal rather than an absolute deadline to ensure that the inquiry got under way within a reasonable time. To date, 479 submissions and many supplementary submissions, other correspondence and petitions have been received by the Committee. The submissions cover all areas of the inquiry and reflect many shades of opinion, particularly on the more prominent and contentious issues. As it will be a long inquiry covering many diverse areas of animal welfare, the Committee will continue to receive and consider written submissions and supplementary submissions.

In May 1984 the Committee began its program of public hearings. These were preliminary hearings designed to cover a range of topics so that members of the Committee could get a better appreciation of the general and specific issues in the animal welfare debate. As a result of these hearings, the Committee decided to concentrate first on two areas and report on these to the Senate. It would then proceed to other areas and report on them progressively through the inquiry. The first two areas selected by the Committee were kangaroo welfare and the live sheep export trade.

The kangaroo harvesting program had attracted criticism both in Australia and overseas. The European Parliament was considering an investigation into the harvesting program in order to decide whether a ban should be placed on the importation of kangaroo products into the European Economic Community, a move strongly recommended by Australian and international animal welfare organisations. Dr D. Eisma, who was then a member of the Environment Committee of the European Parliament, accompanied by Dr W. Jordan, a British veterinarian, visited Australia to investigate kangaroo harvesting. Dr Eisma and Dr Jordan met with the Committee on 4 May 1984 during a visit to Canberra. At that time the Committee expected to report on the kangaroo question by the end of 1984. Dr Eisma told the Committee that the Environment Committee would examine the issue late in the year and would give careful consideration to the Select Committee's report. The United States Government had lifted its ban on the importation of kangaroo products but had maintained red and grey kangaroos, the main species harvested, on the threatened species list.

The second area accorded priority by the Committee was the live sheep export trade. At the time the Committee conducted the preliminary hearings, the trade was subject to criticism from animal welfare organisations, particularly the Australian Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and the Australian Federation of Animal Societies. There had also been serious industrial disputes between the industry and producers on the one hand and the Australasian Meat Industry Employees' Union on the other.

Late in 1984, the Committee agreed to add a third area for immediate examination. That was the keeping of cetacea-whales and dolphins-in capacity. A proposal to establish an oceanarium at Keysborough in Victoria, in which cetacea would be kept, provoked a keen debate in Victoria with repercussions in other States and overseas. An application for approval to catch cetacea in Commonwealth waters was rejected by the then Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, now the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, but the Minister added that he would review his decision in the light of the recommendations of the Committee on captive cetacea. The Victorian Government deferred a decision on an application to keep cetacea at the oceanarium so that the Committee's findings and recommendations could be taken into account in making a decision. The Committee's inquiry into captive cetacea will cover the subject in general terms and will not be simply an examination of the proposed Keysborough project.

Except for a number of hearings on other matters, mainly on animal experimentation, the Committee has, from July 1984 onwards, concentrated on these three areas. The Federal election, preceded by a long campaign period and followed by Christmas, interrupted the conduct of the inquiry. The second half of the Committee's program of hearings and inspections had to be telescoped into a fairly short period early in 1985.

So far in the inquiry the Committee has held public hearings on 27 days in Canberra, Sydney, Melbourne, Perth, Brisbane, Adelaide and Hobart. It has taken evidence from 184 people representing 75 organisations and individuals. The Committee has conducted several inspections during the course of the inquiry, including two live sheep carriers and feed lots of three States. In February 1985, the Committee visited mid-western Queensland to examine the kangaroo problem and to discuss with graziers the animal welfare problems of the grazing industries in that area. The Committee intends to conduct similar inspections in western New South Wales and in other States.

Three of the four members of the Committee-Senator Jack Evans, Senator Hearn and Senator Scott-will retire from the Senate after 30 June 1985 and this will break the continuity of the inquiry. To minimise the disruption to the Committee's work, the Committee recommends that the Senate appoint replacements for the retiring senators before the end of this period of sittings, with those appointments taking effect from 1 July 1985.

I depart from the statement for a moment to acknowledge the work of the three senators. There is an opportunity tomorrow for us to speak concerning the senators who are to retire, but I take this opportunity to say a few words about each senator. Senator Scott's term in the Senate has paralleled mine and I think we have all found him to be a person of considerable intellectual capacity, with wide experience of the rural industry. We all know his characteristic of quiet and incisive discussion and contribution to various debates. His work on the Committee was invaluable because from time to time we were concerned with many areas with which he was familiar. He will be a loss to the Committee, and of course to the Senate and, without doubt, to the National Party of Australia.

Senator Jean Hearn approached her work on the Committee with an empathy for all living things. Her approach was of a great value to the Committee because it immediately began to consider matters from the animals' point of view. We gave the benefit to the animals. We were concerned with their welfare. We put economic considerations in a secondary position. Senator Hearn came easily to that position. I am reminded of her first speech in the Senate. If honourable senators read that speech they will realise her approach not only to animals but also to humans in general. The pity of this inquiry is that the longer one is involved in it, the more sympathetic one becomes to animals and the less sympathetic one becomes to humans. I value, and the Senate should value, Senator Hearn's contribution to the Committee.

I refer also to Senator Jack Evans, who, over the past few days, seems to have been indicating that he intends to be here forever-if not physically, certainly in spirit. The tenacity that he has contributed to the debates over the last two or three weeks, knowing that tomorrow will be his last day in the Senate, is the sort of tenacity that he has applied to the work of this Committee. Looking at the Hansard record of the Committee's proceedings, which is now about 1 1/2 feet thick, one finds that much of the questioning has been carried out by Senator Evans, with a determination to get the information that that Committee requires. I thank Senator Evans for his work on the Committee.

The Committee had intended to present reports on each of the three areas presently being examined before the retirement of the three members. This would have enabled the Committee, with its new members, to examine other areas of animal welfare. The Committee recently reviewed its position. As a result, the reports on the live sheep export trade, cetacea in captivity and if possible, an interim report on kangaroo welfare will be presented by 30 June 1985. The final report on kangaroo welfare will not be presented to the Senate until the spring sitting period. There are a number of matters of concern relating to the kangaroo inquiry which need further investigation. This will be done after the other two reports have been finalised. For that reason, I conclude by asking for leave to give notice of a motion.
Leave granted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator GEORGES

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Select Committee on Animal Welfare has completed its progress reports, the Committee may send the Reports to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President, and, in that event-
(a) the Reports shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate;
(b) the publication of the Reports is authorised by this Resolution;
(c) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the Reports; and
(d) the President or the Deputy-President, as the case may be, shall lay the Reports upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(2) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, insofar as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator GEORGES

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall address myself briefly to the statement by the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, Senator Georges, because I am aware of the exigencies of time. As I am leaving this Committee I think it is appropriate that I should at least have an opportunity to make a few observations on the work of that Committee to this point. My first observation is about the Chairman. I believe that Senator Georges, like all of us from time to time, becomes slightly more emotional than reasonable when dealing with this sort of inquiry. I do not think that any Australian is likely to react in any other way. The important thing in the long run is not to allow a totally emotional view to prevent us from making a proper, responsible and well-ordered determination which would be a contribution not only to animal welfare but also to those basic Australian industries that are so closely involved with animal life. I place on record my appreciation of Senator Georges's efforts, his fairness and his genuine questioning in this extraordinarily wide inquiry which is perhaps too wide to be overcome in one effort. My colleagues and I on that Committee have been able as a team to advance so far and increase significantly our knowledge of the subject and our ultimate capacity to bring down a responsible determination.

SPEECH.PARA: We should be aware of the realities of the Australian circumstances. Australia has a distinguished history of involvement with the animal world. I believe that Australia can be proud of the fact that it is one of the leaders in the world in the areas of animal husbandry, research, breeding, nutrition, and the control of animal diseases. It is a fact of which we ought to be clearly aware and we should make known. If we need finite evidence of the sort of determination and capacity of those involved, we have only to look at the vast number of highly qualified people and organisations that are involved directly and absolutely in animal welfare. I refer to organisations such as the State and Federal departments of agriculture or their equivalents, the National Parks and Wildlife Service, the Australian Bureau of Animal Health, the Australian Veterinary Association, the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the National Farmers Federation, and the Livestock and Grain Producers Association and its associate bodies around Australia. We can add to this list those involved in pig and poultry research and so on. There is no doubt at all that there is a great consciousness of animal welfare and animal husbandry in this country.

I believe that it is our duty to identify weaknesses. That is one of the things that this Committee has done significantly. It has been able to draw this issue to the attention of Australians across the board and has given them an awareness of the problems involved in the relationship between the animal world and mankind. That awareness has been increased by the existence of this Committee. I am sure that basically that is a plus. As I see it, the only problem that can arise really stems from the immensity of the task that faces the Committee. The task is so great that there is a real possibility that in most cases unavoidable delay may build up into long delay. That sort of thing across the wide spectrum of animal industries in Australia can only lead to indecision, doubt and concern. That is not good either for animals or for the people who tend to them and who are directly involved with them economically or otherwise.

I believe that there is also a measure of irritation, at least it is a measure of irritation to me, that we are constantly concerned with the views of and pressure from small groups of people from many countries around the world who are more or less implying that in dealing with animals Australians are perhaps cruel and uncaring. I do not believe that that is true. It is extraordinarily irritating that from time to time these relatively small pressure groups from many parts of the world bring pressure on us in regard to looking after an area which I believe we have the tradition and capacity to look after now and in the future.

We have to be aware of one or two matters. In the socio-economic world in which we live we cannot dictate demand; we can, and ought to seek to create it. I say that in reference to the common argument often put that so far as the Middle East is concerned we should forget about the live sheep trade and seek to replace it with trade in frozen or chilled mutton. Of course, that is a very reasonable and very responsible view, but we cannot do that sort of thing overnight. That is not the situation that exists today, and I think we have to recognise that. All I say is that one can seek, and ought to seek, to create a demand, but one certainly cannot dictate a demand.

I have mentioned the problem arising from approaching such matters from an emotional standpoint. It is quite impossible not to be involved emotionally, at least in some measure, in this sort of inquiry. Indeed, the more one understands and knows the animal world the more likely is that to be the case. The consequences of being overcome by the emotional approach can be quite horrifying. Looking at it in a liberationist sense, we were to liberate the millions of domesticated animals around the world, that liberating would be condemning them not to a superb life of freedom but rather to a slow, and not so slow, death from a range of diseases and, indeed, from preying upon each other. We ought to look responsibly at what liberation literally means literally.

So far the Committee has received a range of evidence over a period of 12 months. In the main that evidence has been sincere, solid and, quite clearly, the product of dedicated groups of people. The live sheep export trade is the only area where we have really reached a point upon which we are able to make some deliberations. We have had a very wide inquiry in that field. The live sheep export industry in this country has a long history, although a significant history dating back only over the last five to ten years. That is the period in which it has become a sizable industry, involving as it did last year the export of some 7.3 million sheep.

I come back to my reference to the creation of demand. It is quite ridiculous to assume that, certainly in the short term, one could convert a demand for 7.3 million live sheep into a demand for an equivalent number of carcasses. Maybe that will happen over many years; one does not know. In the short term that really is not an intelligent option. Briefly, the statistics of the live sheep trade indicate that it represents some $200m to the Australian producer. It represents very much more than that when we look at the wide range of integrated operations and employment that are directly involved in that quite extensive industry.

It is appropriate that I should refer very briefly to the meat workers and the job loss in that area over recent years. That loss is significant; no one could deny that. It is due to a number of things which I do not think are normally considered. I suppose it is due chiefly to the quite dramatic fall in export markets for beef, for instance, and the fall in the size of the Australian cattle herd. The herd has fallen from some 32 million to 22 million, or by one-third, in five to ten years. That is one obvious cause of the job loss in the meat industry. There is also a distinct loss in the market's taste for mutton, and that is relevant to the loss of jobs. There is extreme competition from pig, poultry fish and other food sources and that has caused a loss of meat workers' jobs. Finally and regrettably, there is the recurring industrial unrest and lack of productivity which in many cases puts our product at a disadvantage in an international trading situation.

On the positive side, there is a significant area for employment. That area includes the stock feed industries, where there is significant employment in and around the feed lots and on the wharves. Of course, the collecting and delivering of seven million sheep annually has had a significant effect on employment in the transport industry. There is a demand for stockmen, both in feed lots and on board ship. The demand for veterinarians is one that, hopefully, will increase as more and more ships carry veterinarians. So there have been some significant pluses, even in the employment area.

In fairness, one should observe the very significant research carried out in this industry into feeding and watering, particularly in relation to feed quality, into feedlots, the nature and type of troughing, shade and shelter, sprinkler systems and so on. Sometimes as a result of disasters-how often this happens in most fields of human behaviour-we have seen great research into the ventilation of ships and fire control on ships. These are matters of which the industry is aware and into which it has carried out significant research. There is no shadow of doubt that this research should continue and, in many areas, increase in intensity.

I do not propose to speak at any great length. I think perhaps two minutes more would be more than generous. I will cover very briefly two other areas. Kangaroo management and welfare is enormously important. In that respect one or two things have become patently obvious in the time we have been conducting this inquiry. The first is that Australians have a great regard, indeed a love, for the kangaroo. There are vast numbers of people in Australia, many of them farmers and graziers, who have no objection to kangaroos on their land in reasonable proportions. It is equally clear that there are occasions when kangaroos by their very numbers become a great problem. They cause problems to facilities, to watering and fences, to pastures on which other animals seek to graze. There is a warning note there because droughts come and go in this country and kangaroo numbers increase and decrease dramatically in a 12-months period. We have to be aware of this. We have to monitor kangaroo numbers and we have to continue research into monitoring efforts. I have been impressed by the National Parks and Wildlife people and their dedication to a task which I am sure they will pursue.

It will become clear that the numbers of kangaroos have to be controlled for the good of the kangaroo as well as for Australian society. As the numbers have to be controlled there seems to be a logical reason for the proper control methods and for kangaroos to be controlled by an integrated system, an integrated industry, and by professional shooters who do the job properly, quickly and absolutely.

Finally, I will say a few words on cetacea. In my view we have not had a full enough look at this problem. On the surface cetacea in captivity sounds a terrible thing. Some things are clear. It should be mandatory that tanks be of a significant size and that facilities be the best. I have been impressed with the way cetacea in captivity appear to be in a relaxed state and by the care-particularly the veterinary care-that is given to them. In any case I believe there are very few cetacea in captivity. If one takes that to its logical conclusion one must ask: Are we suggesting that we should have no zoos, no animals at all in captivity? That is the type of question with which we must confront ourselves. We must ask questions about the value of animals in captivity from the point of view of research, education and the enjoyment of children and adults in our society. I do not believe that a total ban, even on cetacea in captivity, is justified. However, it is certainly justified that we should look intelligently and responsibly at the whole of that area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address a few remarks to this statement and in doing so I commend the Australian Democrats for moving a motion for the establishment of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. The Committee has a wide-ranging reference and I very much regret that I will not be continuing with the Committee's work. The reference to the Committee is animal welfare in Australia. The concern of the community and animal welfare groups about the treatment, use and well-being of animals in Australia is something which cannot be ignored. If we look at history we see that it was not so very long ago that similar groups of people and individuals with human sensitivity expressed their deep concern about the use of child labour and the slave trade. Because of their concern those abhorrent practices were abolished.

SPEECH.PARA: There are still areas in the world where human labour is exploited and has almost become slave labour, such as in the Philippines. But even looking at the three areas of live sheep trade, cetacea in captivity and the kangaroo problem, one is very conscious of the different interests which emerge. These are the welfare of animals, which is our primary concern, the economic interests of people involved in the activity and the social aspects of this question. When considering if animals should suffer for economic gain we must be very mindful of the social effects, the effects on the community of accepting the suffering of animals and what can flow from that. No doubt the use of child labour was profitable to those who exploited it, as was the slave trade, but that did not justify it.

The dangers of a trend to a mechanical and dehumanised society are becoming very apparent to many thinking people and we must be alert to the things that contribute to that. I think we have to question the ethics of using animals as machines and of denying them the right to a natural environment. Perhaps it is the fact that we now live with the nuclear threat and the acceptance of its inevitable result by some people that the value and unique quality of life is trivialised and negated. We must note with great concern the incidence in this country of child abuse, violence to the human person and the reduction of human rights and human values in this world. Herbert Spencer said:
The behaviour of men to the lower animals-and their behaviour to each other-bear constant relationship . . .
Gandhi said:
The greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its animals are treated.

The progress report on the live sheep trade, which will be presented in June, highlights a number of concerns, such as the future uncertainty of the trade due to the very volatile political climate in the Middle East and the lack of consistent standards for the welfare of sheep on board ships-there are some very old ships which do not measure up to the standards which one would expect. The conditions of feed lots and whether proper consideration is being given to the transition from farm feed to pellets need firm guidelines.

Another area which the Committee must examine includes animal experimentation. If animals are unlike humans why need we use them? If they are like humans is it not immoral to subject them to pain, fear and torture? Is that not as immoral as it would be if we were to use that treatment on human subjects? In addressing the validity of animal experimentation we must face the moral and ethical questions as well as the welfare and economic ones. Lord Platt, president of the Royal College of Physicians from 1957-1962, said:
No amount of testing can make a drug absolutely safe, if only because humans react differently from animals.
John Vyvyan in The Dark Face of Science 1971, said:
Knowledge without pity or compassion may well be the greatest danger that besets the world.

Vivisection is a social evil that advances human knowledge at the expense of human character. It is my hope that activities which cause distress, fear and suffering to animals, activities which can desensitise our society, will be abolished through this Committee's work. I am sure that the incoming members of this Committee will bring the sensitivity and wisdom that will be necessary to the tasks which they will have to do in the interests of the well-being of animals in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare was formed because of a demand by many concerned Australians that the standards which were being used in the handling of animals in this country were unacceptable. I do not think that the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Don Chipp, was representing only the Australian Democrats in initiating this Committee and proposing that it was time this Parliament recognised its responsibilities and acted to justify the demands, the concern and the very serious feelings of a lot of people about the way we are treating animals in this country. For the first time, I suspect, the welfare of animals was put on the political agenda in this country in the pure sense that we were looking primarily at the welfare of animals. I have been delighted at the way the members of the Committee have accepted the responsibility, particularly the way they have given that priority to the welfare of the animals under consideration, even above economic considerations and, sometimes, even above human benefits such as the benefits of commercial exploitation that advantage some humans, or the benefits some humans get from entertainment provided by or through the use of animals.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very proud on behalf of the Australian Democrats to be appointed to this Committee, partly because it fits neatly as a committee into some basic philosophies of the Democrats-philosophies which would have us protect the weak and the vulnerable-known in some quarters as the politics of compassion. Those philosophies insist that we preserve our ecology not just for ourselves, but for all people who come after us. These basic philosophies flow into the need which was accepted by this Committee to accept the responsibility of humans for the welfare of all life on the planet in a realisation that we are part of that life, and in fact dependent on it for our very survival. We also accepted as a base for our approach that we should allow neither avidity for material gain, nor sporting instincts to override our concern and our compassion for animals. We humans share with other higher animals consciousness and sensitivity to pain. I do not believe that a difference in species justifies a limitation to our respect and concern for animals and for their suffering.

We have seen during this progress of the Committee's investigations some dramatic changes to the attitudes of Australians towards animal experimentation. I am the first to commend the scientists who are involved in animal experimentation, whether for scientific purposes or purposes of experimentation to advance the cause of medicine, they have realised that they themselves are under the microscope, and that their ethics committees will have to maintain standards, and in some cases to set those standards for the first time. The ethics committees have increased in number in the various universities and medical and scientific laboratories around Australia. But, far more importantly, they have increased in quality in the sense that they are now admitting community representation on to those committees-people whose only concern is the welfare of the animal, and not specifically the result of the experiment or the justification for it in scientific or medical terms. People are now being admitted to those communities because they have a genuine concern for the welfare of the animals, which may be part of the research program.

With that person on the Committee, the whole ethos, the whole approach to animal experimentation, changes-not because somebody is browbeating them, or demanding that a different approach be taken, but simply because a new item appears on the agenda. I refer to the item: How will this effect the animal on which we are conducting experiments? That will be a constant; it will exist whether the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare is still sitting, or way beyond the existence of the Committee. People in this Parliament are expressing concern and, as long as such people are on ethics committees, we can be sure that the concern for the animal will be constantly part of that vigil.

During the progress of our inquiries, research and travels, which have been many and varied, we have seen the slaughter of kangaroos and have had to consider whether it is justified. We have had to consider whether it is indeed aimed at preserving the species, which some people claim. In some instances I have no doubt that that is part of the reason for culling or the humane killing of kangaroos. We must take into account the impact of great numbers of kangaroos on farms, particularly in droughts. What has come through to me as we have been conducting this research in the fact that on both sides of the debate there is a lot more noise than there is reason. On one side are extremists who are genuinely concerned about animal welfare but who express that concern in extreme language and exaggerated terms. This makes it difficult for the average Australian to accept the validity of their case. On the other side of the argument, we have representatives of the rural communities who plead that thousands and thousands of farms are at risk because of the population of kangaroos and the explosion of that population. I believe that we have already established that there are comparatively few farms at risk, and they need to be considered in deciding what should happen to the kangaroo population. But we need to recognise that the comparatively few farms that occasionally are at risk do not give us the justification for creating and exploiting kangaroos for commercial purposes-for creating a kangaroo-killing industry.

We need to look closely at this, because we discovered that the interests of the farmers frequently conflict with the interests of the kangaroo industry. That industry wants to maintain the kangaroo in vast numbers. It becomes uneconomic for members of that industry to have to travel many kilometres around the country to find their quota of kangaroos, so the industry wants an explosion in kangaroo numbers. That is the only way that the industry can remain viable. Conversely, the farmers want the kangaroo population reduced; they want it kept at a manageable level. At some time, hopefully in the next few weeks, the resolution of that conflict will be part of the report of this Committee.

There have been contrasting standards in the care of the cetacea-the dolphins and whales-in captivity in this country. No minimum standards are set nationwide, and in my opinion we witnessed some appalling conditions. Here I am probably departing from the point of view expressed by Senator Scott, which did not happen very often. There were not many differing points of view. When we had all the evidence before us, we managed to reach consensus most of the time. But on this occasion having seen the great contrast in standards, I must say that there is no doubt in my mind that keeping in a fish tank a few dolphins which are let out from time to time to entertain human beings, is not an acceptable standard-and perhaps it is not even acceptable to have dolphins and whales in captivity even in larger ocean areas. But that is another question that has yet to be addressed to determine the final recommendation.

I touch briefly on the subject of live sheep export. This is a very real problem for the people of this country once they bear in mind the welfare of those sheep. If we are prepared to say that sheep are there to be exploited and they are there simply to be produced and slaughtered and nothing that happens between those two points matters, I guess that we will not be terribly worried about the conditions under which these sheep are taken to feed lots, fed a new diet-to which most of them adapt, but to which some of them do not-and then put on to a ship where only that new diet is available to them and, if they do not adapt on board ship, that is their bad luck; they die. We know that a proportion of them die as a result. We cannot ignore that. I do not believe that we, as human beings, can say that that does not matter. I do not believe that it is fair for us to expect Australians to accept the conditions under which these sheep are exported, transported and fed, because that demeans all of us. We now have realised the need for research-I know that the strongest of recommendations will be coming through in our report-into all facets of the welfare of sheep in this industry. At the very least, we would want to see more veterinarians on those ships.

The value of this Senate Committee and the work that it has done, I believe, has illustrated the value of all Senate committees. We have on this Committee four people with divergent philosophical bases who have joined in an endeavour to find an agreed solution to the problems of thousands, if not millions, of Australian people and millions more Australian animals. I am very proud to have served on this Committee. I wish its continuing members the same success and the same pleasure of working in the harmony that this first Committee experienced. I pay a special tribute to our Chairman, Senator Georges-a very patient and tolerant human being. If ever people want to see an illustration of that patience and tolerance, I invite them to attend one of the Animal Welfare Committee hearings.

My Senate colleagues, Senator Hearn and Senator Scott, have been a joy to work with. I thank them for the opportunity to work with them and to see a Senate committee working towards consensus in the way that they have made possible. I pay a special tribute to the staff of the Animal Welfare Committee who have displayed a degree of professionalism of which any private or government enterprise would be justifiably proud. I compliment them and I know that my colleagues will agree with me.

The very existence of this Animal Welfare Committee ensures that there is a forum in which to express and consider the maturing views of Australians on the welfare of the animal kingdom which is in our trust. This Committee, in a sense, gets a point of view from the animals' perspective into this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the report which has just been brought down by Senator Georges. I address my remarks to the kangaroo industry, to which Senator Georges and other honourable senators have referred. I was fortunate enough to be able to take Senator Georges and Senator Scott on an inspection tour around the western areas of Queensland. Unfortunately, Senator Hearn and Senator Jack Evans were unable to find the time, or they had other commitments and were unable to go. Senator Georges and Senator Scott, who has been involved in the rural industry for a number of years-met with graziers, farmers and groups of kangaroo shooters and their families. I wish to put on the record of the Senate how much the people of rural Australia, particularly rural Queensland, appreciated Senator Georges and Senator Scott finding the time to go out and investigate their problems and listen to their concerns about animal welfare, not only on kangaroos but also on the husbandry methods used by the grazing industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make some observations that I think should be on the Senate record. There are more kangaroos in Australia now than there ever were. In Queensland, the lowest estimate-that made by the conservationists-is six million kangaroos. The Queensland National Parks and Wildlife Service put the kangaroo population at 30 million and the Federal National Parks and Wildlife Service put it at 17 million. I always use the theory that there are more kangaroos than people. People certainly are not an endangered species; nor are the kangaroos.

Senator Scott and Senator Georges were told continually in my presence that no one wanted to see the kangaroos shot out or the kangaroo industry in any way discriminated against. The graziers expressed their concerns to Senator Georges and Senator Scott and stated that, whilst they appreciated kangaroos and wanted them on their properties, they felt that they had to be in such proportions that they would not hurt them financially and they were not prepared, or felt that they should not be asked, to carry the kangaroo population of Australia.

Senator Georges spoke to the grazing industry and to the kangaroo shooters and he also went out on a kangaroo shoot. I wanted to take him out because I wanted to show him the professional shooter at work with the correct gear and the correct rifles. I wanted to show him how accurately the industry worked and how, within a fraction of a second, a kangaroo was shot in the head and felt minimal pain. I asked him to note the difference between the kangaroo industry and an abattoir.

The farming industry has provided food by way of crops, such as wheat and sorghum, and it has provided water in the form of dams and bore drains, and as a result the kangaroo population in Australia has exploded. There has to be some form of culling and some form of harvesting. Certainly, no one in this Senate and no one in Queensland would believe that the kangaroo industry should be dictating terms to the parks and wildlife authorities, both Federal and State. The industry is there to be used as a tool to keep the numbers of kangaroos at a manageable level. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, has enunciated that policy and I believe that no one in Australia would disagree with it.

I put this proposition to the Senate: If there is no culling or harvesting industry there will be a way in which the graziers and the farmers will reduce the kangaroo population. They cannot be expected to sit out there and have themelves eaten off their properties. They will find a way. What I am saying to the Senate is that the way in which the industry works now is in the best interests of the farmers and the kangaroos because we have professional people who are shooting accurately, who are shooting to put the kangaroo down right on the spot so that they do not have to chase a wounded kangaroo around the bush. They will hit accurately and they will drop the kangaroo where they can find it. If those people are prevented from doing that, or if the industry is closed to them, we will get sporting shooters who are not as professional and we will get--

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that now you get both.

—Certainly, but there would be more of these types of people who cannot shoot accurately and who would not be as professional. There would be also other actions that the graziers could take. I say to the people who will be coming on to this Committee that, although no one likes to see anything killed-it is an emotional thing to see something shot, particularly for people who have not lived in rural areas-it is very necessary to have a kangaroo industry so that the kangaroo population can be culled in a professional manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the luncheon adjournment I was paying tribute to the work of Mr Duffy in this area. I include in that tribute the advisers to Mr Duffy and those from his Department who helped to make this legislation what it is.
—Particularly his comments about Australia Post at Redfern.

—The fact of the matter is that this is a very difficult area in which to legislate. One may well have imagined that there would be problems with it, but the general thrust of the legislation has found acceptance across all the parties in the Senate and it will go through the Senate by general agreement. In those circumstances, I will not spend long going through the legislation. There is one aspect of it which I wish to talk about, and that is the varying proposals that have been put forward as to how the remote areas of Australia should be serviced. There are about 650,000 people who now will be able to get receptions as good as those of their city cousins.

SPEECH.PARA: Two proposals have been put forward as to how those areas should be serviced, and that area of the Bill has received most publicity. The first proposal which was put forward by the Minister for Communications was that the mechanism by which the signals be put out to those areas will be through four footprints, as they are called; that is, signals exclusive to those four areas will be put down. That is in contrast to the network scheme where signals from Melbourne and Sydney are spread throughout Australia. The first proposal clearly is the better one, if one thinks about it, because of certain factors to which I will refer. The first factor is that the regional proposal, which divides Australia into four areas and puts down signals exclusive to those area, accommodates the difference in the time zones across Australia, so that people in Western Australia receive signals at appropriate times, rather than a broadcast that is sent out from here at a particular time and is received in Western Australia at a most inappropriate time of the day. The second factor in favour of the proposal put forward by the Minister is that the reception equipment required by the receiver will be cheaper, and that is a big factor to take into account. The next thing is that the program under the system of regional television and radio-

TALK.START.PARA: —That may cease to matter over time as prices come down.

—I accept what Senator Baume says about that. The point I find most attractive is that programs can be tailored to meet local needs and demands. In other words, instead of a common program being beamed out from Sydney or Melbourne to everyone, people with different interests and needs can have those interests and needs catered for.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude on this thought: Australia, as has been said again and again, is a multicultural society. We have all come to accept that Australia's character and quality has been and will be largely influenced by the diversity of interests, backgrounds and aspirations. That is perhaps most commonly thought of in terms of ethnic diversity. Much work has been done in Australia to cater for that ethnic diversity; but ethnic diversity is only one form of diversity-there is diversity of locality, lifestyle and interest. The regional system of beaming out signals will cater for the needs of people in remote areas, will cater for that diversity and will build up what all of us hope will be a maintenance of the Australian culture and its improvement in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: — We are dealing with a package of broadcasting Bills which mark the start of a major change in the industry; the transition from licensing of transmitter based systems to licensing of a service for a defined geographical area. This is a significant change which is both welcome and somewhat overdue. The effect of the Bills is in keeping with the ideal of removing pointless regulations; we see no reason for red tape. This is done by giving licensees responsibility for a properly defined geographical area, which could eliminate problems of pockets of poor reception and poor signal interference within a licensing area. Licensees will be able to make the appropriate additions or adjustments to the technology they are using for transmitting their signals, to ensure satisfactory reception for the whole of their potential audience, or even to use alternative technology such as cable or other technology that may become available.

SPEECH.PARA: These changes will not require prior approval from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and there will be no need for a formal inquiry, which wastes valuable time of both Tribunal and licensees. Problems will be dealt with quickly, without squandering resources which could be used more productively in other areas, which I will mention later. We will not have to rewrite the laws every time a major change becomes possible. That will mean that we can actually use new technologies, like fibre optics and local transmission facilities and, maybe, even integrate some of our broadcasting with areas such as computer terminal networks.

Major improvements will be made in the way in which inquiries can be conducted by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. However, we believe there is still room for improvement. The streamlined hearing procedures will mean that those involved will have a better chance to make their point. The uniform inquiry procedures will not prevent matters going to the courts or to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, but they will make it more likely that, perhaps, after one or two tries people will not try to delay proceedings on technicalities alone. Over a period it will be possible to develop regulations which will govern how matters come before the Tribunal. These regulations will come before Parliament and will be examined for their fairness. It will be possible to hold a general inquiry into the adequacy and comprehensiveness of a broadcasting service provided to a collection of communities served by more than one licensee-something that is not possible currently under the existing Act. That will enable general matters to be raised by the public and various interest groups and allow these matters relating to particular licensees to be dealt with separately at a separate part of the hearing.

The idea of area inquiries is to be commended. There will be no need for repetition of the general points when specific promises of performance are under examination. There will no longer be fiery arguments over who is or who is not entitled to present evidence or to raise particular matters or lines of questioning. Instead of people having to show that they have a legitimate interest in the proceedings, it will be sufficient for them to have lodged a document that the Tribunal considers relevant to the inquiry. The Tribunal will be able to take the public interest into consideration when deciding whether other people should have an opportunity to enter the proceedings. This will be a major improvement. The Tribunal will also be able to determine the extent to which various groups and individuals can participate in any hearing. The Tribunal does not have the resources to arrange or provide legal representation for parties to any hearing. However, it will have the responsibility to see that all people appearing have a reasonable opportunity to present their case and that the absence of legal representation will not hamper the case. This has certainly been a problem and a bone of contention among public interest and community groups which have tried to get themselves involved in licence hearings.

I wish the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal luck in its attempts to restore an ordered informality to the hearings that it conducts in the future under this legislation. I share the concern of many people that lawyers have taken over these proceedings and that points of law overcome the legitimate points of view which are put by community groups which do not have the financial resources to brief counsel. I understand that when significant decisions are being made about desirable community resources, large and vested interests will often feel that it is worth delaying things while they apply pressure. Escalating legal costs can be counted on eventually to force the withdrawal of those with only meagre resources.

The legislation brought forward would have clearly made absolutely pointless some of the cases that have gone to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the courts in the course of the current hearings into applications for a third commercial television licence in Perth. Other matters may have been tried just to test the courts' interpretation. To illustrate this, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document prepared by the legislative section of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on 30 April.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document summarises the progress in 12 cases that had arisen from the Perth hearings at the stage when the document was prepared. I urge the Government and interested senators to seek a yet more clear expression of the Tribunal's powers in the conduct of hearings so that proceedings do not get bogged down in obscure technicalities but get straight to the substantive issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) for his approach to broadcasting to remote communities. It is significant that his major opposition has come from short-sighted elements in his own Party. I am glad that the Minister stood firm when some of his colleagues wanted to dismantle another plank in the Australian Labor Party platform. I believe that most Australians welcome the way in which the Minister handled the issue when, if one is to believe the Press reports, the pressure was really on.

In its satellite program services report released last year the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal mentioned the Department of Communications estimate of 650,000 Australians who do not receive an adequate commercial television signal. That Department, State governments and community groups in isolated areas all favoured a regional approach to providing services. The receiving dishes that pick up signals from satellites can be much smaller and much less expensive when just a regional spot beam is involved rather than the more powerful national beams. Properly organised, the four-spot-beam model for remote area broadcasting opens up a major television market for independent film producers. That is an absolute must as we must try to diversify the sources of program production and distribution in Australia and aim to open up the overseas acquisitions area to more participants.

The Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill has a reference to the public broadcasting sector. Sponsorship announcements on public stations are now described in service-based language. I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate the increasing interest communities are showing in public broadcasting right around Australia. I am sure that Mr President takes particular pride in what has happened since he found back in 1974 that the Wireless Telegraphy Act of 1905 could be used to issue experimental licences. There are now 60 public broadcasters operating in this country. The latest additions have been community and special purpose licensees in Launceston. Another 150 groups are working towards a goal of obtaining a licence. Of them some 50 have already displayed substantial technical competence. Nearly all these stations are run on the proverbial shoestring. Altogether the 60 stations need about $7m a year to run, which was roughly the price of the two Special Broadcasting Service stations 2EA and 3EA as they were costed together before the mini-Budget. Of course, the only way that this can be achieved is through real community support and the enthusiasm of volunteers. Some 20,000 Australians are directly involved in public broadcasting in one way or another. The service-based licensing arrangement will suit them. Public broadcasting has in recent years become the training ground for people who go on to carve out careers in the national or commercial sectors. That has to be recognised and duly acknowledged.

The Labor Party platform devotes a section to public broadcasting in its chapter on communications. It states that public broadcasting must be adequately funded to realise its full potential, and commits a Labor government to develop funding methods which are stable, diverse and contribute to an adequate income for each station. I believe that this objective can be met by earmarking 5 per cent of the moneys collected as commercial radio and television licence fees for disbursement to the public broadcasting sector. I wish this had been included in the Bill. At the moment the Public Broadcasting Foundation is carrying out a major needs study in its own area. Information has been collected about resources, methods and extent of fund raising and steps taken to encourage Australian talent and the ways in which participation by a wider community can be fostered. I look forward to the circulation of the report in the near future.

I understand that the upgrading or replacement of outdated equipment prone to breaking down weighs heavily on various groups which have only limited funds. The falling Australian dollar will certainly not make it easier for anyone to import the equipment. We are on the brink of major broadcasting changes and the Government should look closely at those sectors providing training and recreation for the young and unemployed, for senior citizens, for music buffs and for people in all areas of education. This is what the public broadcasting sector is doing. We should remove sales tax on specific broadcasting materials. That would be a very concrete way in which this Government could salute and encourage those who put time and energy into public broadcasting projects. Employment opportunities are there for people who pick up the necessary studio and production skills while still enjoying their community involvement.

It is pleasing that public broadcasting is being considered the significant component of our broadcasting industry. Last year the Public Broadcasting Foundation was given the responsibility for distributing $150,000 to Aboriginal broadcasters on public radio stations.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension we were discussing the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and I was applauding the inclusion of public broadcasting in the provisions of the Bill. I stated that the Public Broadcasting Foundation, which was founded two years ago, was responsible for distributing $150,000 to Aboriginal broadcasters on public broadcasting stations. There are 20 such stations at the moment. Just a month ago the British Broadcasting Corporation news showed great interest in the opening of 8KIN, which broadcasts in English and three Aboriginal languages.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal community at Yuendumu created a first in public television. Public television is an idea whose time has come. It is an essential component in a diversified media mix for which most Australians are looking. I hope that we will have it included as a proposition in future amendments to the Act. As I understand it, the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill has been two and a half years and nine drafts in the making. No wonder it is a somewhat voluminous document. Nevertheless, it has some significant omissions that I want to canvass. On 14 February the Minister for Communications issued a Press release to assure the public that the television standards power of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal would be clarified as soon as possible and that draft amendments in this area would be included in the next set of amendments. However, as I said when I canvassed this as a matter of public interest today, this has not been the case. The Minister, in his reply to a question without notice from the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) last Wednesday, said that because of possible effects-of such legislation and fears expressed by various sections of the broadcasting industry, it was decided to exclude the provisions from the Bill and to allow consultation with the industry. I hope that the Minister can let us know what these objectionable powers are. My understanding is that they largely involved substituting the stronger term 'conditions' for the word 'standards' wherever the latter appeared in the current Act. That does not strike me as an earth shattering change. I ask the responsible Minister to tell the Senate just what further consultations were in mind when the decision was taken, and whether last Tuesday's High Court of Australia decision that the power to impose standards did not extend to deciding in advance whether particular programs met those standards was a power the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal had.

In answering a question upon notice last Monday, Senator Gareth Evans was most instructive. He pointed out that the Film Censorship Board would continue to do what it had been doing since 1956 while the Government sorted out the implications of the High Court decision. That is very interesting because it has been well understood for many years that the wording of the Broadcasting and Television Act was rather nebulous and probably incapable of surviving a court challenge in this area. For many years there seemed to have been an unspoken understanding that, so long as none of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's powers were exercised, no one would challenge them. During the last year, however, there have been no fewer than 10 major court cases revolving around the powers of the Tribunal. I seek leave, Mr Acting Deputy President, to have incorporated in Hansard an annotated list of those cases prepared by the Tribunal's Legislation Section on 3 May. I have consulted both sides of the House about this list.
Leave granted.
The list read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. What we are finding is that challenges are being made to every conceivable corner of the Broadcasting Tribunal's power. It starts to look like a systematic attempt to undermine the Tribunal itself or to seek to bring it into public disrepute through incessant litigation. Of course, court action is the right of every corporation or citizen. What we must ask ourselves is: What is the long term aim of such activity? Unless we act immediately, the Broadcasting Tribunal will not be able to exercise effectively the role that everyone understood it to have. Just when we were developing a children's television industry of world repute, uncertainty might drive the top creative talent overseas to greener financial pastures. Perhaps they will never return.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government seems to be able to put together Bills very quickly when it comes to matters such as denying local government 2 per cent of personal income tax sharing monies or depriving veterans of their dues. It should be prepared to give interim relief for Australian advertising and film production industries and for the protection of Australian children with the same enthusiasm.

In dealing with the questions of television standards, one of the difficulties is that various sections have been tacked on to the principal Act from time to time, without sufficient attention being given to making them all compatible. This is one of the reasons why the Broadcasting and Television Act often seems so inaccessible. For instance, the Government has previously come up with a good wording for controlling concentration of media ownership, and yet we find the most unwieldy, unworkable wording preserved in the revamped sub-section 92FAA (2) (C) (iii).

I turn to the licence fee Acts. A court case last year meant that for the purposes of assessing the gross earnings of a licensee, subsidiary and related companies' earnings cannot be examined to see whether they should rightly be included as part of the assessment. There has not been any attempt at clarification of either the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Act or the Television Stations Licence Fees Act despite these amending Bills being before us to correct this situation. So we still have the possibility of large companies breaking up in order to avoid licence duties. I hope that this will be fixed fairly soon.

Despite a huge waiting list of applicants for supplementary licences, there is nothing in this legislation to expedite individual hearings. In those admittedly few cases where the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal determines that an independent licence is viable, the matter has to go back to the Minister for further processing, unless the Minister at the outset says to the Tribunal that it should proceed immediately with a licence hearing in the event that an independent licence is viable. I would like the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) representing the Minister for Communications to assure us that in practice the second hearing will follow straight on from the first if the Tribunal determines that an independent licence is viable.
The concept of local origination set out in the new section 99A is welcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the honourable senator like to seek leave to incorporate his speech in Hansard? He is reading it.
—Yes, to expedite matters I would be pleased to do that. I seek leave to incorporate the remainder of my speech in Hansard, Mr Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-

Quite a deal of work will have to go into sorting out some of the thorny issues it raises, so presumably the section will take effect at a time well after 1 January when most of the Bill will come into force. I ask the Minister to undertake that at the same time as local origination and local content is thrashed out, thought will also be given to embodying channel sharing provisions as an option in the legislation.

Among the transitional provisions is one which theoretically allows the service area of a licensee to be enlarged to a whole state or the whole nation, by administrative action alone, during the process of moving from transmitter based licences to area-based licences. I would like an assurance from the Government that clause 99 of the amending Bill will not be used to bring in national networking through administrative stealth.

Mr Deputy President, we are entering into an exciting new era in the broadcasting field. If we make sensible choices that give us greater media diversity and enhance access, our democracy will be strengthened. I trust that the Forward Development Unit is examining ways of untangling media ownership, making the television market more accessible to independent film producers, and ensuring that increased infrastructure costs do not lead to a decrease of quality local production (channels). I look forward to receiving and reading the Unit's report and to inspecting the public record that has been kept of representations made to the Forward Development Unit by interest groups, corporations and individuals that it has consulted.

Although the Bill package has one glaring omission in the television standards area, the Democrats see no reason to delay its passage. I invite the Government to bring on my private members' Bill before we rise. I await the Minister's reply to the specific matters that I have raised, and in relation to which I have sought reassurances and I hope the Minister can make an undertaking that the Department of Communications will in the near future closely examine the problem areas that I have briefly mentioned and give us legislation to solve those problems at the very start of the next session. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — We are dealing cognately with a number of Bills relating to broadcasting and television in Australia. Many of the provisions of those Bills are welcomed; others are not: And there are some significant absences from the Bills. Many of the matters I wanted to discuss have already been dealt with by previous speakers and particularly by Senator Vigor. I want to address the problems that have emerged over a period in regard to program standards on television and the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will recall that, on the day when the decision was announced by the High Court of Australia, I asked a question of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) representing the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) what the Government was going to do about the attack that had been made by the industry against the qualitative powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, bearing in mind that the Government has repeatedly indicated to the Senate and to the public that it regards self-regulation in the industry as completely unacceptable and that there is a need for a tribunal such as the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to set both qualitative and quantitative standards.

The Senate will also recall that the High Court decision on 21 May was the result of a challenge by certain television stations. It was specifically directed at the pre-assessment powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Those powers require the licensee to submit new programs to the Children's Program Committee in advance of screening in order to obtain a 'C' certificate. Unless a 'C' certificate has been obtained, such a program is unable to be shown between 4 p.m. and 5 p.m. on weekdays, and it is unable to form part of the recently introduced children's drama quota. The High Court decision in effect has reduced the Tribunal to something like impotence on the very vital question of children's films to be shown at children's viewing times. That matter is of very great interest and concern to all Australians whether they are parents or not.

The quality of those programs is very important. In addition, the decision of the High Court not only affected pre-assessment of children's programs, but also the whole classification system. Again, this is a matter which must-I know it does-exercise the mind of the Minister.

Senator Vigor has described the situation elsewhere quite adequately. He introduced a private senator's Bill which is directed, in part, to overcoming these particular problems. I think he deserves congratulations on his initiative. But, as he said, as far back as February this year the Minister was very well aware of the fact that doubts had been cast over the power of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to insist on both qualitative and quantitative standards for television in Australia. I have the Press release made by the Minister for Communications on 14 February this year in which he talked about the qualitative and quantitative standards. It states:

Doubts over the Tribunal's ability to determine both quantitative and qualitative program and advertising standards for commercial radio and television came to head recently in a Court challenge to the Tribunal's powers.
That was a previous court challenge. He then described that particular court challenge. The Press statement continued:

Mr Duffy said it was in the public interest that doubts over the Tribunal's powers be removed. The Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 would be amended as soon as possible to reinforce the Tribunal's power to make standards.

The Minister was talking about both qualitative and quantitative standards. Those people who have kept an interest in this question are perfectly well aware that amendments were drawn up for this purpose. In fact, amendments were to have been included in the legislation now before us; but they are not there. Discussions have taken place with the industry, but we are now told, in the Minister's second reading speech, that those amendments are not in this package so as to enable further discussions with the industry. Surely from February until May would have been sufficient time to have those questions resolved not only in the interests of the viewing public and particularly the viewing children, but also, surely, in the interests of the industry itself. As I understand it, the Minister has proposed that in the Budget session there will be amendments which will go to the question of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's powers. Those amendments will be effective retrospective to the announcement made by the Minister. That is a perfectly acceptable proposition. But why are the amendments not included now so that everyone would be aware of what the ground rules are?

I feel that it is important for the Minister representing the Minister for Communications to reassert the situation so that the commercial interests in the industry do not get away with a view that they can apply the heat to the Government or to members of parliament in the hope that these foreshadowed amendments will not come about, be introduced or be passed in the Parliament. If the Minister were to state on behalf of Mr Duffy what I understand to be Mr Duffy's attitude to the matter-that the amendments will be introduced as early as possible, namely, on the first day of the Budget session-I feel that that would provide the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with the necessary powers to determine qualitative and quantitative standards for television, including a provision to ensure the pre-assessment of children's television programs. I feel that it would have been appropriate for amendments along that line to have been moved to this legislation, but I understand that if such amendments were moved they would not at this stage receive the support of the Opposition. I hope that the Opposition will also state its firm intention to ensure that with further amendments to this legislation early in the Budget session the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will be provided with those necessary powers to determine qualitative and quantitative standards for television in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to delay the conclusion of the debate for much longer. It has probably already gone on for longer than it need have done-longer than it would have done if it had been fully completed before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. The Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, in the House of Representatives during his second reading speech on 15 May, gave an undertaking that amendments would be introduced to deal with program standards as soon as possible, considering the need to develop fully the necessary legislation. Drafting work has been done. However, it is necessary to consult all interested parties to ensure that adequate consideration is given to important issues such as civil liberties. It is the Government's intention to introduce appropriate legislation as early as possible in the Budget sittings.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 is an admission by the Government that it was wrong in the course it took in 1983-84. Not only is Medicare bad in principle, but aspects of it were misconceived. This Bill seeks to correct some of the worst features of Medicare-features about which we expressed concern at the time the legislation came in. Unfortunately we could not get the Government to listen to our concerns. The Government was too stubborn to understand or to admit the errors in the Medicare program when it was introduced and because of this patients have suffered. Indeed, the Government has had to come back now and introduce amendments which it would not introduce in 1983-84, which we asked it to introduce at the time, but which it refused even to consider.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has used the past one and a half years to threaten and browbeat doctors and has been largely responsible for the difficulties many patients have faced and which they continue to face in my State of New South Wales particularly, where it is true to say that the public hospital system is at an almost complete standstill. Being a doctor, I have many very close friends in the medical profession.
