I talked to some of them last week and they told me that going back to work has not resolved the problem because the hospitals are in no position, through lack of staff and money, to allow them to start doing their work again. One of my friends who is a surgeon said he went back to work and asked when his first operating day would be to help Medicare patients. He was told that the hospital could not offer him any prospect of an early return to operating. There is no doubt that health care in New South Wales has been undermined. Not only has the public hospital system deteriorated; its morale has gone and the people operating the system are in despair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the 35-day rule.

—As my colleague says, the 35-day rule has not helped. It is one of the additional burdens that people have had to bear. All this has culminated in unprecedented numbers of resignations by doctors from public hospitals, in public disputation, and in the very obvious public argument which has occurred over several months.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems and events that have occurred were anticipated by the Opposition when Medicare was introduced in September 1983. Time and time again the Opposition called on the Government to end the confrontation that was hurting members of the public. Now, of course, the Government is taking our advice. It has now produced a peace package to end the New South Wales dispute, and we hope that this will restore some normality to the New South Wales hospital system. The Government's package is long overdue. We think that some of the damage that has been done to the hospital system in New South Wales may be irreparable. Some of the bitterness that exists in the system now may take years and years to go. We think that the rundown in services and staff may take years to correct.

Let us consider this legislation which is part of the Medicare peace package. The package contains seven elements. Three of the elements will be implemented by this Bill. Four will be implemented through agreements with the States. So we have to make it clear from the beginning that all the Federal Government can do through this legislation is produce part of the package. The four items to be implemented through the States are: First, the automatic classification of privately insured patients as private patients unless they specifically opt out and wish to become Medicare patients; secondly, the allocation of additional funds, which I understand to be $150m over three years, for capital works in the teaching hospitals; thirdly, cost sharing arrangements with New South Wales to increase payments to the visiting medical officers; and fourthly, the funding of the introduction of modified fee for service to ensure that even at peripheral district hospitals there is an adequate service by qualified visiting medical officers. Those are the four components which will be implemented by the Commonwealth and New South Wales acting together and by New South Wales legislation.

This Bill, however, implements three other matters. First, it repeals the parts of section 17 introduced in the Medicare Bills. Secondly, it provides for an expansion of the basic private insurance table; and thirdly, it provides for all health insurers to be brought under the appropriate Commonwealth legislation to ensure compliance with the principle of community rating. By so doing this Bill will restrict the operation of commercial insurers who at present are offering certain forms of hospital insurance.

I now consider these changes seriatim. I deal first with the changes to section 17. The Opposition has consistently opposed and fought against the Medicare amendments to section 17 and now, in this Bill, they are to be repealed. I remind the Senate that during the Committee stage on 21 September 1983, when the Medicare Bills were before this Parliament, I moved to amend the appropriate clause which introduced these changes to section 17 of the principal Act. Of course I could get no support from the Government and nor could I get sufficient support from the Australian Democrats to carry my amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know?

—I could not in 1983. I am talking about history. I am saying that we are back here now to repeal these elements in respect of which, in the light of experience-I must say that not everyone would have had a background in medical care-our concerns have proved to be well founded. Later, in March 1984, when it was apparent that the medical profession would not accept the changes to section 17, I introduced a private member's Bill to repeal these amendments. On both occasions I was unable to gain sufficient support to achieve my purpose, but today we are back here to do the very things which I tried to do, on behalf of the Opposition, not once but twice; on the first occasion by moving an amendment to the Bill and the second time by trying to get through a private member's Bill. I remind the Senate that on 28 March 1984 the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot and will not be deterred from the principle of section 17.

Of course he is and he will be, and the Government is coming in here now deterred from the principle of section 17 because section 17 is wrong. Following that statement by the Minister we witnessed hostility build up to confrontation and confrontation build up to resignation. The Government's slowness, reluctance and failure over many months to admit its mistake hurt the public, patients and the system of health care which I was proud to grow up as part of and to go through when I was training as a doctor in a country that had the best health care system. It avoided, on the one hand, the extremes of the British system and, on the other hand, the extremes of American medicine. I was proud to be a part of it. But so much of it has been lost.

These amendments to section 17 were totally unacceptable because of the power they gave to the Minister for Health. One can have a benign and honourable Minister for Health one day and a very different Minister another. It was simply unacceptable for that kind of power to be given to the Minister. The Minister, whoever it would be, was given the unfettered authority to alter or cancel new or existing contracts governing the terms and conditions of employment between salaried or visiting medical practitioners and recognised hospitals. It was the belief of the doctors that such a power removed the normal contractual rights which they enjoyed. Understandably, doctors were not prepared to give them up.

The second thing this Bill sets out to do is to expand private insurance. It provides that there be gap insurance for certain hospital treatment. It provides, in addition, a capacity to offer front-end deductible tables; that is, people may determine to carry certain costs themselves before they qualify for certain benefits. Clause 11 of the Bill provides for the inclusion of benefits under the new basic private tables for specified surgical implanted devices. This has been necessary because it was not possible for patients to get benefits for these procedures in private hospitals. This Bill will correct that.

The third thing the Bill seeks to do is to bring all health insurers under the Health Insurance Act. It will require all health insurers to operate under the same Act. As we understand it, it will be done to ensure the continuance of the community rating principle. The Bill also allows for an automatic annual review of fees in the Medicare schedule by an independent tribunal. We support that. It contains certain other amendments not directly related to the peace package.

Some of these amendments cause the Opposition difficulty. I will refer to at least one of them. Clause 13 (db) of the Bill uses the words 'occupies a bed' and relates to the benefits which are payable for certain short-stay patients, usually patients whose stay is less than a day. The provision seeks to alter the present situation whereby a Commonwealth bed day subsidy is payable where any patient is in a hospital bed for more than eight hours. It will substitute new conditions before such a Commonwealth bed day subsidy is payable. It is true that the development of a special bed day subsidy could open up new and desirable opportunities for short term patients to be treated. However, it may be that what is being offered in this legislation without consultation with the industry will deprive hospitals of considerable income they have been receiving. It may cause patients to be asked to bear greater costs than they have borne. It may, quite perversely, act as a stimulus for some hospitals to keep patients in overnight, thereby qualifying those hospitals for the benefit which this clause seeks to change.

There are questions as to what is meant by an approved bed and what is meant by the phrase 'occupies a bed'. I understand that it is the intention of the Department that a bed be occupied at midnight for the Commonwealth bed day subsidy to be paid. Since behaviour often follows the provision of a subsidy-my colleagues tell me this not infrequently-it is quite possible that some of the private hospitals may respond to this change by altering their behaviour. This would produce exactly the reverse effect from that which the Government is seeking. What the Government is seeking is to make it possible for more patients to be treated in day hospitals for minor surgery under this new benefit.

The Opposition and the Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association of Australia are concerned about clause 8, which substitutes the words 'that includes part of an overnight stay' for the previous words of 'more than eight hours' for the reasons that I have just set out. I remember that in 1983 a similar provision was introduced and when it came to the Senate I proposed an amendment. Senator Grimes, in talking to that amendment, said that he not only accepted the amendment but also agreed with it. He said that it was a sensible amendment. That was an amendment to change the eight hours back to 12 hours in order to provide what was a more reasonable approach for the private hospitals. We now have this new attempt to impose restrictions on private hospitals. I fear that all that will happen is that many day care patients will be held in hospital overnight and that others may be asked to bear extra costs.

I emphasise that I am in no way decrying a move towards a day care subsidy or towards the stimulation of more care being carried out in day hospitals. I am just worried that the mechanism the Government has adopted may not be the most sensible one.

I finally just add a couple of comments about what we are trying to do for the Australian community in health-health as opposed to health insurance; health as opposed to the financing; health as opposed to the money; and health as opposed to Medicare and health wrangles. I start by acknowledging that the Government has shown an appropriate sense of priority by allocating $150m to New South Wales teaching hospitals over the next three years. The Opposition, like the Government, is concerned about the health of every Australian. The Opposition is concerned about the prevention of illness as much as it is about cure. Let us try to put all these Medicare upheavals behind us. Let us get this peace package in place. Let us get the doctors in New South Wales back to work. Let us get the hospitals working again and let us work for better health for all Australians.

What we must be concerned about is health and health outcomes. We already know where the great health problems lie in Australia. Many of them are preventable. I remind honourable senators that Dr Knowles, an eminent American medical educator, when writing about health in that country, and he could have been writing about Australia, said:

Many Americans have come to look on sloth, gluttony, alcoholic intemperance, reckless driving, sexual frenzy and smoking as constitutional rights, and they've come to expect government-financed 'cures' for all the unhappy consequences.

He pinpoints in that one sentence many of the preventable known causes of illness in Australia. They are problems which will not be eased even by the most efficient method of paying for or providing medical services. It will not be until we come to grips with some of the underlying issues that we can really look to a healthier society.

We know the damage tobacco does. Most of us in this place know that. We are loath as a nation, however, to take effective action, in spite of our knowledge. We know what causes much of the carnage on the roads but we seem overly sensitive to club and industry interests when it comes to doing anything about that problem or to putting any effective programs in place. We have a Special Premiers Conference on a National Campaign against Drug Abuse which does not really want to know about tobacco or alcohol, although together they account for 97 of every 100 drug related deaths in Australia. We would welcome more emphasis on measures to address these problems. We need more 'Life. Be in It', 'Quit for Life' and 'Belt up and Live' programs in this country-programs which we can use to try to prevent the need for some medical services. It only remains to say that in spite of this peace package we are still faced with the reality of Medicare and with the long term deficiencies which we believe Medicare poses for the Australian people. For that reason I intend to move an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill, which I hope has been circulated to honourable senators in the chamber. I move:
At end of motion, add: ', but the Senate notes that-
(a) the long and unnecessary delay by the Government in implementing the changes to Medicare embodied in the Bill has caused intolerable pain and suffering; and
(b) the amendments fall short of the urgent and fundamental changes required to Medicare to restore a high standard balanced private and public health delivery system.'.

Having moved this amendment, we will support the Bill because it contains the peace package. We look to the Government to explain to us why the changes to the Commonwealth daily bed subsidy will not produce perverse effects in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — As has already been pointed out by Senator Peter Baume, the legislation before us tonight-the Health Legislation Amendment Bill-is the culmination of extensive negotiations between the Government and the Australian Medical Association to resolve the New South Wales doctors dispute. This is really a polite way of saying that the purpose of the legislation is to get the doctors off strike and back to work in the hospitals. It was with some keen sense of irony, therefore, that I heard Senator Baume castigate the Government for not moving fast enough to legislate to end this strike, when only some days ago the Liberal-National Opposition was in a veritable frenzy because the Government was actually legislating to end a strike in Queensland relating to the other end of the political, social and economic spectrum. So a delightful double standard applies to some honourable senators on this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: During this dispute, however, the actions of one man have remained completely clear and are worth commenting on. I refer to the extraordinary perseverance of Dr Lindsay Thompson. It is important that we commend members of the executive of the AMA, and in particular Dr Thompson, for their perseverance not only in their commitment to fighting for the needs and the rights of their professional colleagues, but also in their concern about and commitment to the well-being of patients in New South Wales. They also deserve some commendation for their willingness to negotiate, to withstand the assault which came from the far right of their profession and to work for what in fact was of benefit not only to the members of the medical profession in New South Wales but also to hospital patients generally.

Of course, this legislation is not a perfect package-everybody admits that no compromise is a perfect package-but it does deserve the full support of everyone here, and I think it will get that support if only because it goes some way towards meeting the concerns of ordinary members of the medical profession. For instance, the Bill provides for automatic annual review of fees in the Medicare benefits schedule. It deletes from section 17 of the Health Insurance Act the provisions inserted by section 18 of the Health Legislation Amendment Act 1983. It amends the National Health Act of 1953 to permit registered health benefit organisations to offer a greater range of benefits in the basic private table. It supports the community rating principle. It permits variations in the waiting period imposed on contributors by health benefit organisations. All in all, it goes a long way to meeting many of the complaints that the doctors on strike in New South Wales had of the treatment that they were receiving at the hands of the Federal Government and, of course, of the New South Wales Government, which, I suspect, was more than half to blame for the problems that arose in New South Wales.

The main problem with the legislation, however-there is a significant problem with it-arises in regard to clause 8. Present legislation allows private hospitals to claim Commonwealth bed day subsidies when the patient occupies an approved bed for eight hours or more. This Bill will change that and require a patient to remain in hospital for what it calls part of an overnight stay prior to being eligible for benefits. However, there is no definition of 'part of an overnight stay'. Clearly, the legislation has confused a lot of people. The Australian Private Hospitals Association is particularly concerned at the effect that this will have on its running of hospitals and the impact it will have on patients and the benefits those patients receive.

Hospitals generally admit patients at specific times of the day. For example, a patient would be admitted late in the afternoon for treatment the following day. However, as was pointed out to me by representatives of the Australian Private Hospitals Association on Monday when I was in Sydney to talk to them, today's increased technology and sophistication of services mean that many procedures can be performed, indeed should be, without patients needing to stay overnight. The first question I have for the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) is just what does 'part of an overnight stay' mean? Does it mean that one is in a hospital for more than that 12-hour period which is classified as day and we then move into night or is it a case of being there at midnight and turning from Cinderella into a pumpkin?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the other way round.

—Or from a pumpkin into Cinderella, or the glass slipper, or Prince Charming. It really does not matter. Some metamorphosis must take place in the hospital, the bed or the patient at midnight if that is the way the Government regards the legislation. It is important, first of all, to find out exactly what part of an overnight stay is. It is also important to know why the Government has chosen to extend the eight-hour rule to include whatever part of the night time it envisages as relevant. Fairly clearly, if it means that one has to stay in hospital until one minute past midnight before one can claim the benefit it would involve a patient remaining overnight before a normal day's benefit can be attracted. Accordingly, a lower benefit can be expected in those instances in which patients are admitted in the morning and discharged in the afternoon or evening. That is something which frequently suits the patient, the doctor in attendance and the hospital. It does that because cost savings to private hospitals in cases where no overnight stay is involved are negligible as costs are related primarily to treatment.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill clearly compromises the position of private hospitals and private hospital patients. That section of the health care industry regards it-I think quite rightly-not only as unfair but also an underhanded way of affecting its day surgery and day care procedures. There are organisations other than the Private Hospitals Association which are concerned about this. For example, the Australian Catholic Health Care Association telexed me a couple of days ago indicating that it, too, was concerned and dismayed by the changes proposed in the legislation which redefine day patient rules. The Association was concerned at the potential such a change would have to disadvantage thousands of patients, not only through loss of Commonwealth benefits but also by reduction of fund reimbursements which will follow the new rule. The Association urges the Government to preserve at least the existing funding arrangements for day patients. Only a couple of days ago the Health Insurance Restricted Membership Association of Australia again wrote to me and it also referred to clause 8. It stated:

The present position is reasonably well understood by our contributors and is a small bonus back from the compulsory 'Medicare' levy. Any change to the present will create confusion, but more importantly, will result in hospital operators extending the stay of 'minor' classification patients to enable them to qualify for the bed day subsidy. At the same time this will almost smother the attempt to consolidate the proposed feature of a 'Day Care' Benefit.

I understand that in some States, at least, although perhaps not all States, if this legislation is put into operation on 1 September, if it is proclaimed along with the rest of the legislation, patients will be placed in the very invidious position of having to decide whether to pay what could be as much as a $40 excess payment for getting out of hospital early-on good behaviour, so to speak-or inconvenience themselves and stay in hospital an unnecessary length of time in order to qualify for the benefit. I ask the Minister whether he would consider seriously that some accommodation be made for the concerns that have been expressed by the private hospital sector about clause 8.

I suggest that, in the interests of getting the Bill through the Senate tonight and not having to add it to the list of legislation that will go to the House of Representatives when it comes back tomorrow afternoon, the Government should give an undertaking to the Senate that this clause of the Bill will not be proclaimed; or, if that is somehow technically too difficult, the Government could undertake to the Senate that it will amend this section of the legislation in the Budget session after full consultation with the industry. All the industry wanted was full consultation to see, first of all, what the Government's intention was; secondly, what the outcome of the changes would be; and thirdly, whether any other means could be used to get the same effect without the impact on both the hospitals and the patients that this measure apparently will have.

There are other concerns about the legislation, one of which comes from a number of friendly societies. In a telex they sent me three days ago, they indicated some concern that no provisions have been made within the Health Legislation Amendment Bill for the continued operation of ancillary health funds by friendly societies under respective State legislation. The telex stated:

A number of friendly societies throughout Australia have conducted ancillary health funds for a number of years. Most of these funds are based on the community rating principle which the Federal Government is anxious to preserve. The proposed section 67 of the National Health Act 1953, however, will force all health insurers to register under the National Heath Act 1953. As one of the conditions for registration under the Act is that the organisation must operate a basic private hospital table, many societies who do not currently conduct a hospital fund will not satisfy the criteria and may be forced to wind up their ancillary funds.
The telex continues:

It is considered that provisions should be made within the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 for friendly societies to continue operating ancillary health funds under their retrospective State legislation provided they are based on the community rating principle and do not prohibit membership by means of age or state of health.

Any comments that the Minister can give on that issue would also be much appreciated. Finally, some insurance people contacted me about a matter that requires clarification. They want to know, if a commercial insurer becomes a registered insurer following the passage of the Bill, will he still be able to continue cover commitments under existing or ongoing policies? They feel that this is not fully explained in the legislation as it stands, and any clarification that the Minister can give me on that I would also appreciate.

The Liberals, through Senator Peter Baume, have moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading which we are certainly happy to support. It states the obvious-that in fact considerable pain and suffering have been caused by the long delay in the Government implementing changes to Medicare-which makes it all the more remarkable that it is getting itself worked up into a frenzy over legislation to correct yet another source of pain and suffering in another State but implemented from another source altogether.

The second part of the amendment says that the Government's amendments to the legislation fall short of the urgent and fundamental changes to Medicare required to restore a high standard and balanced private and public health delivery system. I certainly support that. Indeed, when I opened the Australian Private Hospitals Association congress in Sydney on Monday one of the points I made was that, while the Australian Democrats certainly support the basic element behind Medicare-that is, that basic health insurance should be compulsory-we also say in our policy that we believe in a complementary and equal private and public health care system which includes the continuing existence of a viable and vital, but not spoon-fed, private hospital sector. I have no difficulties at all in supporting both the legislation before us, with the qualifications I have raised with regard to clause 8, and Senator Baume's amendment to the motion for the second reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reviewing the latest shifts in the Australian Labor Party's health policy it would be pleasant to be able to say that the Hawke Government had seen the folly of socialised health care and had fundamentally changed its position. The truth however is otherwise. Despite some alterations, we still have a system which discourages self-provision, which is exorbitant and wasteful, which hurts the consumer, affluent and poor alike, and which does nothing to provide doctors with a fair and equitable go in pursuing their most important careers. We can of course be thankful that the Government has retreated from section 17 and the previously heavy-handed coercion of doctors. We should note, however, that this massive injustice was avoided only through the resolve of the medical profession, without which the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) would have persisted in his attempt to transform doctors into public servants and to decrease their salaries while pandering to the wage demands of militant unions. Indeed, that objective may still remain even though its future means of achievement will be more subtle and, hopefully, far more difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government clearly burned its fingers through the use of the notorious fraud and overservicing detection system, a classic socialist 'Big Brother' device. FODS proved to be bureaucratic, intrusive and inefficient, notable for its persecution of those making genuine mistakes in paperwork rather than for preventing actual dishonesty. It also penalised those doctors who may have seen fit to take more precautionary measures, by way of a variety of tests, than some of their colleagues. I always thought that doctors should be answerable to their peers for their actions, but this Government wanted doctors to be answerable to Dr, non-medical, Blewett and the bureaucracy. FODS's demise can only improve the health system even though the decision has been forced on the Government through political necessity and not through recognition of wrong policies.

A blow to the private funds and their contributors is the withdrawal of the reinsurance subsidy. The $80m originally cut has not been restored and is now followed by a further $15m in the mini-Budget, leaving the Government contribution at $5m. Surely, however, there is a strong case for assistance to the health funds in their most difficult area, health costs of the chronically ill. There are no prizes for guessing that this requirement could push up the cost of premiums substantially for all customers in the years to come. The young and healthy will be further discouraged from taking out private insurance.

Needless to say, the underlying disincentives for private insurance under Medicare have not changed. People still pay twice for their health care, with the one-plus per cent Medicare levy and the premium that attracts neither a tax rebate nor a tax deduction. The new hospital gap insurance will result in dual administration. The ban on one-stop shopping again is a tangible disincentive for taking out private insurance. At the beginning of April, the Executive Director of the Voluntary Health Insurance Association, Mr Schneider, warned that the Government's original package would cost an extra $100m that would have to be met by contributors. The Government has failed to address itself to the injustice of the 35-day rule whereby long term patients, the elderly and the chronically ill are either forced to leave hospital or be subjected to savage, unfair charges under the reduced allowance payable for nursing home patients.

Members of this socialist Government are still persisting in telling this Parliament, and thereby all Australians, that they will be good fellows by keeping the levy at 1 per cent. I ask the question: How can the Government keep the levy at 1 per cent when it is already-and has been since last year-at least 1.7 per cent? This 0.7-plus per cent taxpayer robbery occurs by the Government needing to cover the shortfall between the levy income and the total cost of Medicare. The shortfall is growing continuously, as admitted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in April of this year. It has to be paid by someone, and naturally that someone is the taxpayer. It is projected now that the shortfall to which I refer will be in the vicinity of $1 billion. This is what will be picked up by the taxpayer.

The same lack of concern appears in the pharmaceutical cut-backs in the mini-Budget. Raising the cost of prescriptions from $4 to $5 will be no hardship for generally healthy people who require pharmaceuticals only on an occasional basis. It will, however, be a very real cost for the chronically ill and for many families with young children.

There are many other things that I would like to cover, but in the interests of time I will restrict my comments. I am particularly concerned about the selective restoration of gap insurance for hospital treatment only, which will only lengthen the queues that we have seen increasing, especially in Victoria and New South Wales, over recent months. That cannot be attributed wholly and solely to disputation by doctors, because it has been evidenced in various areas throughout Australia. Western Australia is yet to see this problem; Victoria has seen it already-and Senator Walsh jolly well knows it. That is why he is embarrassed about it. Medicare has come to mean free health care at the end of the queue, and those hardest hit will be the poorest in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is a shame; I agree with Senator Watson. What this Government has done is absolutely disgraceful. Those queues are attributable to people who are opting out of private health insurance because this socialist Government has made it impossible for people to afford private health insurance cover-the best cover of all. Let us see it restored. If the people have to pick up the tab for that $1 billion, it will be a sad state of affairs; but it is already on the books. So, nothing will prevent Medicare from becoming the running sore of this Hawke Government, especially in the expenditure field. Either it will wreak havoc with future Budgets or arbitrary ceilings will be imposed, to the detriment of those Australians who were promised cheap and comprehensive health cover. Cheap and comprehensive health cover it is not. Senator Walsh may well sleep in this Parliament, because that is the best thing he could do to save us from what he has to say.

SPEECH.PARA: In the longer term the Liberal Party will restore true freedom of choice whereby people can choose what cover they want and what price they want to pay. We will give the people of Australia the choice of what they want for themselves-not what this Government sees best, because this Government is purely and simply a dictatorial government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this for you-the General Practitioners Society?

—For the information of Senator Walsh: I wrote the speech, and I am sorry that it has distressed him so much. Never mind; he may get over it. I suggest that he go to a public hospital and seek medical attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It falls to my pleasant lot to follow Senator Knowles's little tirade. I can assure Senator Walsh that I know where Senator Knowles got her speech from. It is a large lift from the speech given by Mr Porter in the House of Representatives.
—Is it really?
—Yes, I have the figures here.
—Maybe you should compare the two speeches.

—Senator Knowles can throw in some quotations from Mr Carlton's speech too, if she wishes, but I do not wish to worry about that and I do not even require her to table the document from which she was reading. I refer to Mr Porter's comments in the House of Representatives because they indicate, as do many of the figures which Senator Knowles quoted from him and her other colleagues in the House of Representatives, that he does not understand all the history of this debate at all. On page 2920 of the House of Representatives Hansard for 22 May 1985 he is recorded as referring, as have many of his Liberal colleagues in the past, to the alleged cause of the New South Wales doctors' strike. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Last year the Minister caused the first doctors' strike in Australia's history.
Senator Knowles's Liberal colleagues have said this on a number of occasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't they go on strike?

—From Senator Watson or someone in the Opposition comes the added voice that that is right. I merely refer Opposition senators to the Senate Hansard for 2 April 1984, which shows Senator Crowley elaborating on three doctors' strikes that have happened previously in this country. I do not want to go over that again. For honourable senators' edification, it is recorded on page 1042 of the Senate Hansard for 2 April 1984 and proves that not only Mr Porter but also some of his colleagues who are here today do not know the facts. Do read it.
—Read it!

—At least those on the other side are alert and awake. I am glad, because honourable senators need to wake up when intelligent words are put up on the air. We know that the medical profession claims to be very happy about the repeal of the amendment to section 17 of the Health Insurance Act. I find that quite interesting. I listened to Senator Peter Baume's comments on this matter and, as he might expect, I disagree with his interpretation of why the legislation had to be changed by the Government. We know very well that members of the medical profession are very tender when it comes to an analysis or regulation of their incomes. They do not like regulation and, in the face of evidence that they do not restrain themselves to the schedule fee, still have the gall to insist that they ought not to be regulated. In fact, they insist on the right to do what they like in large part and very often charge more than the schedule fee.

SPEECH.PARA: The schedule fee is a very reasonable setting of a scale of return or estimate of costs for services. The Australian Medical Association puts in a submission on behalf of the medical profession for the estimation of a schedule fee; yet, even in spite of that responsible decision on what a schedule fee should be, many doctors charge well above it. Doctors in my State of South Australia have a reputation for largely charging within the schedule fee but even they challenged that record during the recent fight over Medicare. Members of the public have reason to be suspicious of the good faith of doctors in terms of their ability to self-regulate. One has only to follow and understand what happened in the New South Wales doctors' strike. The strike was not about the care of patients; it was about conditions for doctors, which spelt how much they would be paid. It was very much a disgrace. It was not about the care of patients but about conditions for doctors.

My comments here pertain largely to specialists, far more than to general practitioners, many of whom I know have experienced a real or relative reduction in their incomes over the last three to five years. They were not major players in the New South Wales dispute. Their vote in the AMA ballot indicated their difference from the specialists. The AMA ballot also indicated the great discomfort that many doctors had about the behaviour of the specialists and the bad faith that was being established for the medical profession.

I think one point that Senator Baume and I have in common is the disappointment and unhappiness we would feel about the falling reputation of the medical profession as a consequence of that very protracted, unreasonable and nasty strike, as it turned out to be. I think the Government has reason to be suspicious about the doctors' ability to regulate their own fees. The Government bent over backwards to accommodate the doctors in New South Wales during that strike. Yet the doctors prove to be extraordinarily recalcitrant in negotiations, if and when they knew how to negotiate. In the early days of the strike they quite clearly indicated they did not even know how to do that. In the face of recent evidence, the public and this Government can take little comfort or consolation that the doctors have considerably shifted their attitudes. But I say again that I think we can take some heart from the Australian Medical Association ballot which indicated that a very large majority of doctors in this country were pleased to see the strike settled, were pleased to co-operate with the Government in negotiations and were pleased to see in sight an end to the bad name that the medical profession was getting as a consequence of that strike.

Yesterday I sat in the Senate and listened to Queensland senators ranting and raving about the dreadful people in the Electrical Trades Union who went on strike and denied a necessity to the people of Queensland. Yet never did I hear the same earnest supporters of people's rights to access for necessary services complain about a doctors' strike in New South Wales. I think we should ask the Queensland senators: How necessary is health care, compared to electricity? I would have thought that both of them belong in the necessity category. I ask: How can people afford to be so outraged about the Queensland problem and so accepting of the New South Wales difficulties? I entirely concur with Senator Haines's opening comments to that effect. The doctors' strike was an outrage against the people of New South Wales, against the care and service provision, against good order and due process and against efforts over and over by this Government to negotiate a settlement.

I congratulate the Government and the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, for patience, for persistence and for sticking in there until a solution was reached that allowed health care to resume in New South Wales and which also allowed for the upgrading of public hospitals in New South Wales to the tune of some $150m over three years and $16m for the remuneration of doctors for private work in public hospitals. One of the things that did emerge from that whole debacle was the difference between the provision of health and medical services in New South Wales from other States in this country. Both the medical profession and the people of New South Wales will be entirely satisfied with the contribution to upgrading the provisions of public hospitals in New South Wales. I am not suggesting they will be satisfied with the number of dollars, but they will be happy with the contribution. The acknowledgement for the need of that kind of upgrading will be of benefit to all the people in the State. If that is part of the solution to the strike I suppose we can be grateful for that.

I wish to make one last point. All of these items, particularly the health insurance item-I do not wish to list them; they have been well covered by Senator Baume and Senator Haines-seem, in some ways, to be only remotely related to the negotiations required to settle the New South Wales doctors' dispute. Yet they are included here as part of the settlement, as part of, I suppose, a so-called gentlemen's agreement in reaching that settlement. So much of our society depends on honourable expectations of how people will behave. I suppose we can take up the debate about whether gentlemen and honour do equate on some other occasion. For the record, I merely use them analogously this evening.

The Government, arising out of its negotiations, has moved these amendments as part of an understanding of the good faith and expectations that people will behave honourably. Members of the private insurance funds had the opportunity to contribute in arguing their case in this whole debate. In some ways some of these amendments do not directly pertain to the New South Wales doctors' settlement at all. It is interesting to consider that private insurance funds have won the right to allow front-end deductibles-one of the points which has been protested-to provide health insurance outside the community rating principle. I am not quite sure why something is wrong when it is outside one's care and acceptable when it is suddenly within one's parameters. It is a fine point. The point is that the health insurance funds, the New South Wales Government and the doctors have reached an agreement where legislation is only part of the settlement. The legislation has its limitations. In the end, much of the satisfactory outcome will depend on the honourable behaviour of people in acting out that legislation, in living within the terms and intentions of that legislation.

I ask: Where was the gentlemen's agreement when matters of privacy, matters of agreed practice about doctors and patients anywhere in this country, matters of respect for privacy of doctors and their referring practices and matters of privacy about information on treatment provided by doctors to their patients, in that recent invasion of 47,000 records held in family planning clinics in Queensland? Again I find the juxtaposition of what is required under the provisions of this legislation and what is tolerated and encouraged in Queensland absolutely contradictory. In fact, I do not believe one could hold both views without being guilty of hypocrisy.

It is a matter of serious import that tonight we are trying to negotiate, agree on or debate amendments to the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act, the implementation and effectiveness of which require responsible and mature behaviour under the provisions of that legislation. What do we say about people who flagrantly break those understandings and rules about privacy, regard for patients, regard for doctors and regard for general good order in society? I have been accused in this place by honourable senators opposite of doctor bashing and many other things beside that. Tonight I say that I am appalled at what the Queensland Government has done in the nature of doctor bashing. It has named doctors and their treatment practices. Worse than that, it has named patients. I cannot let this occasion pass without drawing what I think is the contradictory parallel between what is required as part of the New South Wales settlement or this package of legislation before us tonight and the untenable behaviour of the Government in Queensland, which is actually a matter very close to the heart of medicine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Health Legislation Amendment Bill. These amendments represent a further backdown on Medicare by the Government. As Senator Baume has already said, they are a clear indication by the Government that it was wrong. The Opposition said early in the piece that Medicare just would not work as the Government had wanted it to work. The Government, with Australian Democrats support, assured us that Medicare would work, but it has all been proved a disaster. At last the Government has come to the recognition that it was wrong, much like it was wrong about the assets test. The Government was wrong about that and has already had to make many changes.

SPEECH.PARA: We were told-indeed, the second reading speech of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) says this-that these alterations were a result of the doctors dispute in New South Wales. We were told that disputes such as that can be resolved only through consultation and negotiation and not by confrontation. The Government is in an incredible situation now when it is pretending that there was no confrontation. I will quote from one of the news releases put out by the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, during the early part of the dispute. He said:
I am sure that the public will see the AMA's attitude for what it is-an arrogant determination that the public hospital system should be run for their benefit and not the patients.

That was said of the Australian Medical Association. But now we are told that all this was achieved through consultation and not confrontation. Of course there was confrontation. Dr Blewett was even sent overseas as a last resort so that Mr Hawke could manage the situation. He and Senator Grimes tried to manage the situation because Dr Blewett was so confrontationist. We were told that the doctors were greedy, that the whole dispute was over the doctors' salaries. But then we find in the Minister's second reading speech that that really had nothing to do with it. He said that some of these changes would have been implemented as a matter of course in the coming months as the Government reassessed the Medicare operations over its initial 12 months. He said:
The changes put forward in this legislation are all--
I stress 'all'--
sensible and rational changes to health insurance policy . . .

What utter double-talk that is. We were told by the Minister that the majority of doctors-indeed nearly all of them-were behind the new changes in Medicare. We were told the doctors wanted to return to work. The Minister said that this was evidenced by the 75.6 per cent national vote for a return to normal services in the Australian Medical Association's plebiscite of all doctors, and the number of doctors who have now returned to work in New South Wales hospitals. What an absolute distortion that is. A total of 33,000 members of the medical profession were sent a plebiscite through the mail. That is the most comprehensive list of doctors that we know-33,000. Guess how many replied? We are assured that there was a 75.6 per cent vote of all doctors. How many replied? Only 13,000 replied. So roughly one-third of the doctors replied and 75.6 per cent of those voted in favour of returning to work. That was not 75.6 per cent of 33,000. Roughly only 10,000 doctors out of 33,000 were in favour of returning to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Be fair. It was 75 per cent of those who voted.

—That is exactly what I am saying. It was 75 per cent of those who voted. If one works that out, one sees that 13,000 out of 33,000 replied and 75 per cent of 13,000 means that roughly 10,000 doctors out of the 33,000 who received the plebiscite agreed with the AMA. I am just rectifying the figures in the Minister's second reading speech. It seems incredible to me that those figures were so distorted.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the things that have been altered in this legislation. First, patients have been given the right when they are admitted to a public hospital to have the doctor of their choice. They are not automatically classified as public patients. A patient is now asked if that is what he wants-to have a doctor of his choice. That is not necessarily a benefit to the doctor, but it is certainly a benefit to the patient. Secondly, there has been the acceptance of the recommendation of the Penington Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals on the need for new equipment in public hospitals in New South Wales. Over three years a total of $150m will be spent. This is because the hospitals were starved of funds. Again, because the hospitals were starved of funds, this is a benefit to the patient.

Let us look at the increases in wages of New South Wales doctors. In total, $16m has been allocated to those very greedy visiting medical officers who we were assured were only on strike because they were after money. They have been provided with an amount that brings the funding base for visiting medical officers just on to a par with that enjoyed by doctors in other States. Another $10m a year will be provided towards meeting 50 per cent of the cost of sessional payments of visiting medical officers who currently are providing honorary services, without charge, and for the extension of fee for service remuneration to country hospitals where there is no resident medical officer. Of the 4,003 visiting medical officers, 1,401 were honoraries working free of charge. These are the terribly greedy doctors we heard Dr Blewett talk so much about-1,401 working for nothing at all. While on the subject of doctors' wages, I see that section 17 has finally been abolished. This is one area in which the doctors stuck out and the Minister has backed off. This section was introduced even though it was completely unnecessary. By the time Dr Blewett recognised that there was no need for it the dispute had really got under way.

Let us look at some of the other benefits for patients, not doctors, that have been implemented because the doctors, not on strike but having resigned from their positions, forced the Government to bring them in. There have been alterations for gap insurance for medical services in hospitals. Many patients have come to me and said that they desired gap insurance, that it was essential to them as they felt they could cover themselves for that insurance. At last the Government has given way in that area. Medical benefits are now available for surgical implants-the replacement of joint implants-again a benefit for the patient and not the doctor.

Clause 8, which is an alteration to the Commonwealth bed day subsidy, again is a benefit for the patient and not the doctor. The present situation, as Senator Baume said so clearly tonight, is an alteration to the Commonwealth bed day subsidy. Surgical bed day centres in private hospitals have been a cost benefit saving for the Commonwealth and for health care generally. Minor operations that require under eight hours hospitalisation have not to date incurred a Commonwealth subsidy, but anything over eight hours has incurred a Commonwealth subsidy. Now the Commonwealth has decided that if a patient is in hospital for over eight hours but does not spend the night in hospital he is no longer entitled to a hospital subsidy. That will mean that the health insurance industry will have to cover that, and of course that will put up the contribution rate. As Senator Baume has said, it could well alter the mode of looking after patients in hospital over eight hours. I believe the Government has been very foolish in this because if it does encourage hospitals to keep patients in overnight that will certainly be a backward step in cost saving in this area.

Another alteration has been in community rating, and the opposition certainly agrees with this. The good risk patients such as the young and the healthy should certainly assist the bad risk patients, otherwise contribution rates will be too high for the elderly to afford. As the Minister said in his second reading speech, the principle of community rating, which ensures that the good risks assist the bad risks, is essential for a just health insurance industry. However, the Government recently undid all this good by taking $15m out of the reinsurance pool in the mini-Budget. That really underlines the fact that the Government has no commitment to community rating at all. It is not willing to play its part and pull its weight in that bad risk area that the reinsurance pool normally covers.

Finally, the Government has said that the pre-existing illness provision should be reduced from two years to one year and that the two-month waiting period for the basic table again is to be waived for a period. We are told that all these additional costs to hospital insurance rates will not amount to very much, but that is not what the hospital insurance industry tells us. It believes that these additional costs will add quite considerably to the contribution rate of the patient.

We have been told that Medibank Private is going to be pretty magnanimous. We are told that Medibank Private will totally waive the pre-existing ailment rule for three months. It will waive the rule not just from two years to one year but for three months to any of its former contributors who may wish to rejoin. I certainly hope that that does not result in the Government having to give Medibank Private a grant, which has certainly happened in the past when we have had to prop it up with a $10m grant out of the blue because it nearly went broke. I hope that it will not reach that stage by being too magnanimous.

I am very pleased that the Government has backed off in this area and changed Medicare. It certainly needed changing. The assets test needed changing. The Government is gradually coming to its senses and taking account of what the Opposition has been asking it to do for some time.

The only other thing I say tonight is that I hope the Government will not show as little concern for the Tasmanian railway workers as it has shown tonight for the ill. The Government has tried to abolish the railways in Tasmania and with it 1,100 jobs. If it tries to negotiate with my State in the way it has done in regard to the country's ill it will be doing a pretty poor job and a disservice to the contributors to Medicare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to give qualified support to the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 and also to support the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading of it. This Bill amends two Acts, the National Health Act 1953 and the Health Insurance Act 1973. It represents the Government's response to the doctors dispute in New South Wales. I noticed that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) says that this Bill is a result of consultation, negotiation and reconciliation. I do not know why he did not throw in all the words that his boss uses. Obviously, the Bill is not the result of all that. It is the result of a confrontation that almost became a conflagration. As the Minister marches in his little fumaric, socialist world-this is where I stopped reading his second reading speech-he thinks that the changes which are made by this legislation would automatically have been implemented over the next few months as the legislation settled down. That is just simply not true. If it had not been for the confrontation there would not have been any of these changes at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The conflict between the Government and the medical profession, involving in fact a great deal of the whole health industry, has gone on for many years. It came to a head in New South Wales because of the circumstances in that State where the private doctors are more dependent on the use of public hospitals for the treatment of private patients than they are in other States. That is why the dispute happened in New South Wales. On top of everything else in this dispute, not only was the Federal Government ranged against the specialists in New South Wales but also it connived and colluded with the New South Wales Government trying to get the doctors to toe the line and behave in a manner towards their patients that the Government thought fitting and not in a manner the doctors thought would be fitting.

This sort of situation is not seen just in Australia. The history of it is common to several countries around the world. I cannot recall there ever being doctors' strikes or mass resignations in the history of the medical profession until recent years. I think the first time I read about it, it concerned a doctors strike that occurred in Austria after the war. The Government decided to dictate to the doctors how it wanted the doctors to practise. The doctors rose up and went on strike. In more recent years, of course, there have been many more doctors striking. That has been seen in Canada. In fact, those strikes are continuing to this day. The reason is that the Government takes over the funding of medicine and in doing that it tries to control the way the doctors practise; the doctors revolt and so they go on strike.

TALK.START.PARA: —They strike because the system is not in the best interests of their patients.

—That is right. It is the patients they are thinking of first. If the doctors find that their practices are interfered with, they just cannot bear to or want to work under that sort of system. The Medicare system that we have in Australia is based on the Canadian system. Our little Minister for Health went to Canada and studied that. It is a wonder that he did not learn from it because Canada has had nothing but trouble. The Federal Government ran it for a while and when it found it getting absolutely out of hand it handed it over to the provinces. All it did was hand all the problems over to the provinces and, instead of the strikes being federal strikes, they became provincial strikes.
—We seem to have followed the mistakes of other countries in Australia.

—Yes. There is no need for us to go down this track. I am sure it is an ideological track we are going down. There is a difference between a professional and a tradesman. A professional is highly trained and is competent to do his work. He takes complete responsibility for his work and he does not have to have his work inspected. On the other hand, a tradesman is competent and highly trained but he does have to have his work inspected. A professional takes complete responsibility for his work. That does not mean that he does not have to have extra training. For example, the top tennis players take coaches around the world with them. Martina Navratilova takes a coach around the world with her.

SPEECH.PARA: All professional people keep upgrading their work and doctors particularly are upgraded, not only by their peers, but by people who refer patients to them, by their work in the hospitals, even by the staff in the hospitals; so there is a constant upgrading process. In fact, they cannot survive if they do not keep upgrading. Nevertheless, governments keep trying to bring in peer reviews, service reviews and professional review bodies, all of which have been tried around the world. They have exactly the opposite effect to that which they purport to bring about. Instead of bringing about higher standards of work, they bring about lower standards of work. Instead of reducing costs, they increase costs. The evidence is there to see. Yet all these sorts of things are being introduced in Australia when there is no need for us to go down that withered road.

When the Minister was tootling down this socialist road he started off by trying to get control of radiologists and then pathologists because they were the high expense areas as far as the Government computers were concerned-and no doubt they were because lots of tests were being done. The radiologists and the pathologists objected to this and, of course, the Minister for Health made the mistake of saying: 'This is just the crack in the door. We are going to put these same controls on the rest of the profession'. That is when the warning buzzer sounded and all the other doctors woke up to what he was trying to do. All this Bill does is retreat a little along the socialist road. The retreat has been forced because the thunder clouds gathered.

Not all the fault can be sheeted home to the bully boy socialists in the Australian Labor Party. We have had a creeping paralysis in the health field ever since the introduction of medical benefits in Australia. Way back then the funding was a third by the Federal Government, a third by the medical insurance companies and a third by the patients. Once we had the Government paying a third of the bills, that immediately rendered the whole system uneconomic, and the system being uneconomic, the Government had to keep pouring more money into it in order to make it work. It was not until the Government was paying over 50 per cent of the medical bill that it took control of the medical insurance companies. They are really completely controlled by the Government now. Their rules are set by the Government. Their rebates are set by the Government. The contribution rates are set by the Government. The reserves they have to keep are set by the Government. They are really all just little arms of government which think that they are private insurance companies. This is a very sad situation. We realise now that the way to get back to private medicine is to reduce the amount of money that the Government is putting into all these areas so that we can get back to working on an economic basis and so that once again we will have the best and cheapest medicine in the world.

Once the Government stepped in to the pharmaceutical industry and said to the people, 'Here you are-free pharmaceuticals are available to all', it had to start restricting their availability. The system was very good until the Government realised that the number of prescriptions was more than it could afford. So it started telling doctors how many pills and repeat prescriptions they could prescribe and what pills they could use for certain diseases. This extended through the whole practice of medicine. The Government told the medical profession the conditions for which people could be put in hospitals and how long they could be kept there. It was a system of regulation that just got bigger and bigger and worse and worse.

On top of that, the big government computers have now started analysing doctors' prescribing, visiting, consulting, operating, hospital admission and referral habits. Every part of a doctor's practice is analysed on computers. The statistics on each doctor are compared with the area average. If a doctor's statistics differ from his area average, the Federal Government sends out a counsellor to counsel him, to bring him back to the area average. This is done because the basis of the entire exercise is to reduce the costs to government and not to give better medicine to anybody. It is a reduction in costs. It is a restricting, limiting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There is the classic example of some practices treating mainly pensioners.

—Some doctors mainly treat pensioners. We call some doctors 'referologists'. They keep referring people to others in the medical profession. They do not have any equipment in their surgeries. This creates a lower and poorer standard of medicine. If doctors persist in not obeying the counsellor they are called before a fraud and overservicing detection system panel or committees of inquiry and star chamber tactics are used. This sort of action has created enormous resentment in the medical profession. There is now great hostility between the vast bulk of practising doctors and the Government. This is the exact opposite to what we set out to do in the first place-namely, to create a better health care system and to make it easier for people to get access to medical services.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that we have a time constraint. There are a couple of measures in the Bill which I am pleased about. At least the Government has reintroduced gap insurance for private hospital insurance. It should have gone the whole way because by ruling out by law gap insurance for medical benefits it is virtually forcing people out of private medical insurance and pushing them to join Medicare. In turn, this is increasing Medicare costs. I am pleased that benefits have been reintroduced for specified surgical implants. I note the anomaly relating to single day care. That will cause dislocation and distortion in private hospitals. It is discriminatory against private hospitals. In public hospitals day care patients can be treated on day care trolleys rather than on beds. Private hospitals are licensed for a certain number of beds. They have to use those beds and are not allowed to have any extra. So if they wish to treat extra patients on a day care basis, they have to use the beds normally required for acute patients. I ask honourable senators to look at the anomaly that will cause. These hospitals cannot have their acute beds occupied by day care patients when they are in the middle of the ordinary week day rush hour. I point out that anomaly to the Government. I hope that the changes that the Minister felt would be introduced naturally over the next few months will extend to fixing the day care anomaly that has not been rectified in the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought we were to hear the view of just the General Practitioners' Society of Australia in this debate, but we seem to have heard some views that have gone beyond even that. It seems that Senator Sheil is advocating the withdrawal of subsidies to private hospitals and the withdrawal of any subsidy on pharmaceuticals.
—Too right.

—I am glad that I interpreted Senator Sheil correctly when I said that he wanted to charge the consumer the full cost of the pharmaceuticals. Senator Haines asked whether the existing contracts of commercial insurers will be affected by the requirement that they become registered under the National Health Act. The answer is that contracts will continue as they currently stand until they become due for renewal. Contracts that are guaranteed renewable will not be affected and will continue so long as the insured party desires. Section 14 provides that liabilities assumed before the announcement of the section are not affected.

SPEECH.PARA: Both Senator Peter Baume and Senator Haines asked about the Government policy on day care benefit. The Bill provides that the Minister for Health shall determine the rate for day care benefits in private hospitals or surgical day centres. The Minister can also determine different rates of benefit for different categories or classes of patient. No rates have yet been set. Such rates will be determined after full consultation by the Commonwealth with interested parties such as the Voluntary Health Insurance Council of Australia and the Australian Private Hospitals Association. The Government has access to a variety of material on day care costs, including material on Australian day care centres. These studies show that there are definite savings in cost to the hospital or surgical day centre and hence to patients in providing simple surgery through day care as opposed to overnight accommodation.

The Government is prepared to undertake that the level of day care benefits eventually set will be in line with the costs incurred by hospitals and day surgery centres in providing such care. To give the Senate an idea of the general benefit level for day surgery, I can give an assurance that the benefit will be at least $70 a day. As I said earlier, there is provision in this legislation for the Minister for Health to set a range of benefits for day surgery. A higher benefit can be set for a particular class of patients who, while they do not stay overnight, still incur a high level of treatment costs. The particular example-

TALK.START.PARA: —You say it can be done. Can I take it that if it is reasonable that is the course that will be taken?
—That what in particular will be done?
—For higher cost patients there may well be a higher benefit.
—I do not know whether I can give that assurance.
—You have raised that as a possibility.

—I would interpret that as meaning it may be. The particular example that comes readily to mind is that of renal dialysis. Because of the expensive equipment and staffing involved this treatment is relatively more expensive than most day hospital treatment. While renal dialysis in private hospitals is not common, I can give the Senate an undertaking that where this occurs the Minister for Health will set a higher benefit in line with the particular cost of treating renal dialysis patients. This matter and the higher benefit for such classes of patients will be determined after consultation with the hospitals affected.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 7-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 8 (Daily bed payments)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I did not enter the second reading debate. I have had discussions with a number of honourable senators about clause 8. I feel that there needs to be some clarification of the comments made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) a moment ago as he concluded the second reading stage. This clause seeks to omit from section 33 the words 'of more than 8 hours' and to substitute the words 'that includes part of a overnight stay'. This concerns daily bed payments. On pages 924 and 925 of the Senate Hansard of 22 September 1983 it is recorded that the words 'of more than 8 hours' were put into the legislation by total agreement of this chamber, and indeed Senator Baume quoted Senator Grimes as saying that it was an excellent suggestion. Now it comes before us with no explanation and without any suggestion that it is part of the package. I ask: Is this actually part of the package? Why was it decided to insert this provision without any consultation with the persons or groups most likely to be affected? I heard what the Minister said about the Minister for Health deciding on certain amounts for particular procedures. What effect will that have? For example, under the present legislation, if a person stays for more than eight hours, of course that person qualifies for the daily bed Commonwealth benefit payment. That then entitles the patient to payment from the health insurance company for the daily rate, as I understand it. If the Minister for Health determines a particular sum in respect of a particular procedure, what will be the result insofar as the payment from the health insurance company is concerned? I think that is an important question. The Minister will appreciate that one cannot deal with these things on a pro rata basis. There are standard costs for beds, and one really cannot deal with that on a pro rata basis.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw the Minister's attention to the request by Senator Haines and by Senator Peter Baume for an interpretation of what the term 'part of an overnight stay' means. What does that term mean? With that request, I believe that Senator Haines, in her speech at the second reading stage, sought some guarantees from the Minister in the hope that either this will not be proclaimed until such time as there have been consultations, or, alternatively, some more satisfactory amendments are presented to the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On clause 8, I, too, would like some clarification of what the Minister said. I appreciate that Senator Walsh, as Minister for Finance, is not terribly au fait with this particular piece of legislation. I understand that it is difficult for him to give off the cuff comments about it. But I would like clarification of some points in the answer that Senator Walsh gave to the queries that were raised by me and by Senator Peter Baume. Did I understand the Minister to say that the Government is meeting the private hospital sector's concerns about the impact of clause 8 by setting different rates of Commonwealth benefits according to the type of treatment required by patients who do not stay in hospital for part of an overnight stay-whatever the definition of that term turns out to be?

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I repeat Senator Harradine's question: What effect will that have on the private health insurance benefit that is paid to those patients? The private hospitals are obviously concerned that patients will stay overnight, because obviously, they would not stay until one minute past midnight, if that turns out to be the magic hour, and then go home. Patients will not want to do that and hospitals will not want their procedures changed like that. To do so, of course, would place an extra cost on everybody concerned. It would be extremely awkward for patients and hospitals, or a nuisance, anyway. Furthermore, this practice could take up a bed which could well be occupied by someone who genuinely needs to stay, not just for part of the night, or partly overnight, but for the whole night.

Finally, the Minister started to tuck his chin down into his neck towards the end of his answer and he muttered some words that I did not quite catch. Will he clarify this: Did he say that as far as the Government is concerned, clause 8 will be essentially non-operating until full discussion has been undertaken with the Australian Private Hospitals Association, the Australian Catholic Hospitals Association, the health insurance funds and anybody else who needs to be consulted and whose views need to be taken into account over the impact of this particular clause? It is important that on this matter we have quite a clear undertaking about what the Government intends to do to hold this clause in abeyance until full discussions have taken place with those sections of the industry that are concerned and full explanations have been given by the Government concerning the impact on the hospitals, the patients, the funds and everybody else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The basic intention of clause 8 is to put the free-standing surgical centres on the same basis for subsidy as private hospitals. I am advised that there are already three free-standing surgical centres-one in the Australian Capital Territory, one in South Australia and one in Victoria. The Government believes that, at least in the case of some medical services, these centres will deliver services in a more cost-efficient way than private hospitals, but for the same sorts of services the same levels of subsidy will be provided. In answer to one of the other questions that Senator Haines asked, the subsidy is likely to be at least $70 for standard services, but under special circumstances such as the one to which I referred before-renal dialysis-significantly higher levels of subsidy will be provided.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal is that this clause should commence operation on 1 September, and in the time between now and 1 September the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) will be holding discussions and consultations with the health insurance associations and the private hospital associations.

Senator Harradine asked what the term 'part of an overnight stay' actually means. I am advised that in practical terms it means a patient's stay when that patient is in hospital for a period that extends beyond midnight, although not necessarily to daybreak the next morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his response. I am a little concerned about his remarks equating private hospital day care with surgi-centres. While I think everybody fully approves of the establishment and the development of additional surgi-centres, there are only three of them at the moment-as the Minister pointed out, there is one in South Australia, one in the Australian Capital Territory and one in Victoria-they are not the sort of thing that everybody who needs day surgery can attend. It sounds suspiciously to me as if this clause is some kind of back door cost cutting exercise to force the private hospitals to conform with some pricing, cost effectiveness or provision of service arrangement, something that I am still not particularly clear about. I would have thought that incentives should certainly be given to encourage more private hospitals to establish surgi-centres, but that cannot be done overnight and I do not think that in the meantime we should have absolute disincentives applying to private hospitals that want to provide short term care, the sort of care that does not require an overnight stay or even part of an overnight stay.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the other matter, I would like to know, albeit that the clause will not become operative until 1 September anyway, whether the consultation that the Government is undertaking to have with the industry will be undertaken with a view to changing that clause or not putting it into effect at all if it turns out that the effect will be damaging not only to day care but also the real health care needs of the patients who need something less than an overnight stay or part of an overnight stay, if that means remaining in hospital until a minute past midnight.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that I can say much more than I said before. The Government's intention is that where the same sort of service is delivered the same level of subsidy will be provided. Quite frankly, I cannot understand why anyone would object to that or would want to object to it.

—I understand what the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has said but both Senator Harradine and Senator Haines have raised an important matter. Senator Walsh has given an accurate answer, but the way in which equality is going to be obtained is by reducing the subsidy to one class of patients to bring them into line with all the others. That is the concern that really has not been answered. One group is having a benefit taken from it. If these subsidies do not come into effect until 1 September, as I think he advised the Committee, and if these concerns have been expressed I urge that the Government, as a matter of common sense, undertake really urgent consultations with the Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association of Australia to iron out some of the problems it sees because otherwise we fear that some perverse effects will be produced and some of the concerns expressed by Senator Harradine and Senator Haines may well prove to be all too real.
