—Can the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) indicate what regulations are likely to be involved with the implementation of clause 8 and any of the clauses that have an impact on clause 8? We are all aware in this chamber tonight that the passage of this piece of legislation is important if the peace package is to be put into effect. None of us wants to jeopardise that at all but, by the same token, none of us wants to be put in a position where a piece of the legislation which is detrimental to a type of care and to the patients who want that care is sneaked in, for want of a better word, on the grounds that we are, indeed, keen to see the rest of the legislation passed. I think it is important that we are told quite clearly that the private hospital sector in Australia will not be adversely affected by this legislation, indeed that it is not going to be affected by it at all, until an opportunity is given for it to consult with the Minister and the Department and, if necessary, have changes effected-either a repeal of the clause or picking up any necessary consequential changes in the Budget session. I do not think that that sort of undertaking is too much to ask from the Government when we consider the seriousness of the alternative steps.

—Senator Peter Baume asked whether I would give an undertaking that urgent consultations would commence. I will not be doing the consultations, but I understand that it is the intention of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) to do just that. Senator Baume seemed to assume-this incorporates the further assumption that the actual cost for delivering a comparable service in a free-standing surgical centre is lower than it is in a private hospital-that the level set for all would be the level of the lowest cost and most efficient surgical centre. I think that is not necessarily the case. But more generally, I am advised that when the levels of day care are set it will be done by a regulation, which is subject to disallowance by the Parliament anyway if anybody at that time thinks that it is not appropriate. If Senator Haines thinks she cannot trust Dr Blewett or somebody else, she will have a chance to dispute the decision that is finally made then.

—I think we have all been forced into a position, partly because the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is not normally the Minister who would be dealing with this matter, of accepting it as far as it goes. I must say that I am still extremely uneasy. I can foresee, if what I think is the Government's intention is actually put into effect, that we are going to have private hospitals changing their whole admission procedures, doctors changing their lifestyle and people being admitted at 6 o'clock at night, having the treatment that they need and being let out at five minutes past midnight. That may not be a bad way of circumventing any particularly insidious prospects the Government has for the Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association and the people it represents. Obviously I cannot get any further information out of the Minister. I appreciate the position he is in, but I would also like the Government to appreciate the position the Committee is in.

— I think Senator Haines has put the point squarely. We are concerned particularly about the patients. Many of these patients do not wish to be in the situation where they have to stay in hospital overnight. They have families to go back to and so on. I would like the Minister to answer two of the direct questions that I asked. The first question I asked was: Is clause 8 an integral part of the settlement of the doctors' dispute in New South Wales? Was the inclusion of that clause insisted upon by the doctors in New South Wales? Secondly-I repeat the question-in the event of the establishment of certain fees for procedures, what effect will that have on the payout from health insurance funds to the individual contributors?

—As to the first question, clause 8 was discussed with the Australian Medical Association during the last couple of months. However, it probably should not be regarded as an integral part-I think that was the term used-of the settlement with the doctors in New South Wales but, rather, as an improved housekeeping measure. I think I heard this correctly: I am advised that the payment from the private health funds to the individual contributor would be the same regardless of whether the service was provided in a free-standing surgical centre or a private hospital. The payment would be the same if the service was the same.

— I have just a very brief statement to make. I did not mean to ask whether the payment would be the same regardless of whether it was provided in a free-standing surgical centre or in a private hospital. What I meant was that at the moment, under the current provisions, if a patient is in the hospital for more than eight hours that patient qualifies for the Commonwealth benefit. That qualification, in turn, qualifies that contributor to the appropriate payment from the hospital benefits fund, as I understand it. If that is to be turned into an entitlement to receive a payment for a medical procedure, what effect will that have on the current amounts being paid from the health insurance funds to the contributor? It is terribly important to the individual contributors throughout Australia to know this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I have understood the question properly or whether my previous reply has been understood. The payment will be at least $70 a day and for some of the special services it will be more than that. But I think, if I understood Senator Harradine's question correctly, it really dealt with the procedures which would establish the entitlement of a contributor to a payment from the private fund. I am advised that they would be entitled to the private fund benefit but there would not be a Commonwealth benefit for day surgery. The funds will pay benefits at the levels determined by the Minister, which is the existing procedure, if I recall correctly.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I just wish to raise the question that was raised originally by Senator Haines in relation to clause 14. This matter was raised with her by the friendly societies, which have telexed quite a number of senators. They have been in existence for many years under State Acts-some more than 100 years-and they have over 80,000 members and more than $15m in funds. Senator Haines asked earlier why friendly societies should be put to the expense of obtaining Federal registration when they are now operating under State registration. The Minister responded that current contracts would still be able to be honoured and would not be affected by the legislation until they ran out. He also said that current liabilities would be honoured and would not be affected by the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: However, that does not go to the question of the additional expense and paper work that will be involved in these funds which are now registered under State registration. They have made it perfectly clear that they agree with the idea of community rating. They are upset about some of these other individual funds-not friendly societies-which are going after the healthy and issuing cut rates for premiums. I am concerned that these funds have not been consulted and I wish to register my concern because the people who belong to them are mainly rank and file people, including many unionists. Many of them have belonged to these funds for many years and it is of concern to note that the Government has not really consulted the funds before putting this amendment through in clause 14.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of the friendly societies are already registered under the National Health Act, but there are a few small ones that are not currently registered. The reason that registration will be required from these very small friendly societies is in order to enforce effectively the community rating principle.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPPLY BILL (No. 1) 1985-86[COGNATE BILLS:SUPPLY BILL (No. 2) 1985-86SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1985-86]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to Supply Bill (No. 1), which appropriates the sum of $7.1 billion for extra expenditure to several departments-
—Mr President, are we considering the three Supply Bills together? If not, I suggest that we deal with the three Supply Bills together.
—Order! Is it the wish of the Senate that the three Bills be debated cognately? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

—I still wish to speak to only one Bill, and that is Supply Bill (No. 1). As I said, it appropriates the sum of $7.1 billion. The largest appropriation there is $2.4 billion for the Department of Defence. Defence is the most important duty of this Government and, regrettably, all we ever hear from the Australian Labor Party are a few platitudes from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he is seeking some votes at election time. Yet in the last week we have had two of the most important defence decisions that the Labor Government has brought down. They have been brought down in a clandestine way and sneaked through this Parliament without any comment. The first one is the decision on the project definition study for the new submarines for the Royal Australian Navy. The second is on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence following its defence inquiry last year. I will have something to say about that at another time.

SPEECH.PARA: Since there is expenditure in this Supply Bill relating to the submarine contract, I wish to take a few minutes of the Senate's time tonight-regrettably, nowhere near as long as I would like-to canvas a few points about this most important issue. It is important because we will be asking men to go to sea in these ships and in times of war they will live, fight and die in them. In all the time I have been a member of the Senate I have had one inflexible rule, that is that I would never ask anyone to fight for Australia in any form of equipment that he did not have a fair chance of surviving in. I think that is a fundamental point that everyone in this Parliament must observe. That does not mean that we always have to buy the most expensive equipment. We probably always buy the most expensive equipment when we are dealing with fighter aircraft because the front edge of technology is always expensive. In other cases we might be able to compromise on quality provided survivability and use are there. But we must always buy equipment that gives a fair chance of surviving, and that is very important in relation to the submarine contract.

The second point is that if we are involved in a war we have to win it, and if we have the wrong equipment and we lose the war because the equipment is inadequate, incompetent or the wrong type, we pay the price of our freedom. The third point is that here we are dealing with an enormous amount of money. People think of the F18 contract as being the most important and most valuable one we have had. This is a magnitude beyond. We are going to pay $2.6 billion in today's prices for these submarines and that will mortgage the whole of the defence vote for 10 to 15 years ahead, so it is important that we get it right. I am talking about this because no one in this country, least of all people in informed circles, thinks that we have got it right. There is a feeling around that a blunder of a magnitude that no one appreciates has been made here. I am calling on the Government to come across with the information and justify the decision it has made.

What do we need from submarines in this country? Since we have lost our aircraft carrier, we are in a situation where the under-surface arm of the Navy becomes more important than the surface fleet, because in a contested situation where we do not control the air, we will not live on the surface of the water. I do not have time tonight to debate the pros and cons of the carrier and the decision of the Government to get rid of the Fleet Air Arm, but a submarine force becomes more important than it has been formerly. Many people think that, because the movies of the Second World War showed submarines fighting the battle of the mid-Atlantic, in a war situation when our surface ships are attacked we will be in a position to torpedo ships on the high seas. That is the least likely situation our submarines would be involved in in time of war. They would be used the way the British used their nuclear-powered submarines against the Argentinians-by blockading the harbours and cutting off the ports from which the enemy ships come. In the Australian geographic environment that means a sector of operations from the east coast of Africa right around to Petropavlovsk on the Asian mainland. It means enormous distances that have to be covered. Sydney to Yokohama is about 4,500 nautical miles. Sydney to Mombasa is about 6,500 nautical miles. One would probably get it down to 4,000 miles if one sailed out of Fremantle.

That is why the decision not to consider nuclear submarines is so critical and why there is such a compelling case for the Government to answer. The advantages of moving at three times the speed at which a diesel-electric submarine will move, the ability to be concealed and not to surface off the harbours, not giving one self away with an infra-red signature from the exhaust as one charges batteries, and coming up and presenting something that can be picked up either on radar or visually, are so important. The reason why we did not consider nuclear-powered submarines is a case for the Government to answer. It is also a case for the Navy to answer. It must answer for being so weak that it did not put to the Government that in the 1980s, the 1990s and beyond the only way to go is nuclear power.

We have elected to go for a diesel-electric submarine. If we have gone that way, we have to get the best we can, and this is where the trouble starts. There are two parts to a submarine, as I explained to the Senate a couple of weeks ago. There is the weapons systems fit-the way one finds the targets, the way one puts the information together, the offensive weapons one carries, and the way one launches them. That is one group. It is really an electronic group. The other group is the hull and the propulsion system. This Government has selected two consortia of manufacturers to compete to supply the weapons system part of the contract. There is no argument that the best weapons system suppliers in the world are the British and the Americans. I do not want to go into weapons systems in detail. I do not know much about the high technology part of it. I have some information, but it is moving into an area that is highly classified. All I will say is that the leading electronic suppliers in the world are not on the list the Australian Government has selected. We are definately operating in the second league with the firms we have selected. On the evidence I have and from my experience, I do not believe that there is any possibility of their putting the weapons system together with the sophistication we need.

Then there are the hull manufacturers. The Government has put up two manufacturers, the German firm Howaldtswerke-Deutsche Werft and the Swedish firm Kockums. The Kockums group has been put in just for the contrast, the way the ladies of the Spanish Court used to keep monkeys so that they looked attractive. Kockums is there to make HDW look attractive. What about this HDW company? When the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) answered a question last week he misled the House of Representatives because he implied that HDW was a reputable company. He said that HDW produces something like 50 per cent of the boats sold in the conventional submarine area. That may be. On my information, HDW has sold 60 boats since 1960, but it has sold them to countries such as Ecuador, Chile, Peru, Venezuela, Colombia, Greece and Turkey-hardly the front rank of submarine powers in the world. It has sold boats to Norway, Denmark, the Federal Republic of Germany, Indonesia and India. They are all low-technology boats. There is no confidence at all, with a boat that exists purely on paper and is four times the size that HDW supplied to the Federal Republic of Germany for its navy-the largest ship the FRG has in its submarine fleet is 450 tonnes-that HDW can come up with the paper boat the Australian Government has bought.

By coincidence, in the early 1980s the United States Navy considered the provision of diesel-powered submarines as a supplement to its nuclear attack and strategic fleet. The Americans went into this very thoroughly. They were not interested in building the boats themselves. They were interested in buying them from a European source. I quote from a paper by Mr Lehman, the Secretary of the United States Navy and one of the great historic Secretaries of the United States Navy, a person who will rank in history with Forrestal. Lehman said in that report that the HDW design was found to have 'some attractive features' but does not meet current American standards relating to submarine silencing, safety, maintainability, and manning. There can be no more damning criticism of a design than that it did not meet the standards of submarine silencing because that is how submarines are found and killed. He went on to say:

In order for a German-designed submarine to be sufficiently upgraded to be acceptable for US submarine operations it would be necessary for the government of the United States to convey an extraordinary amount of engineering, development, and design technology to the Germans.

The transfer of this information would eliminate exclusive US control of the advanced submarine silencing technology that currently provides much of the advantage US submarines have over those of other nations.

There are many other technical shortcomings with this boat, but I suggest to honourable senators that the company that we have selected has not built a boat of the capabilities of the present class of submarine we have and to assume that it will suddenly acquire that skill in the fulfilment of the Australian contract requires a very great deal of optimism and faith.

One of the strangest parts about this is that there is a good boat that is available-and that is the British 2400 design. Vickers Shipbuilding and Engineering Ltd has been building submarines for over 100 years. It has been building them both in nuclear-powered and conventionally-powered forms. The important thing about the Vickers boat is that it incorporates all the nuclear submarine technology. A nuclear submarine operates in an entirely different field from the field in which the short range, shallow diving, light weight boats that the Germans and the European powers build. They operate at far greater depth. They operate under far greater stress. They operate at high speeds and high turning rates. They operate with steep descent and steep ascent profiles. They are very much stronger and very much tougher. They are built to withstand the blase of nuclear depth charges. This is the engineering that is in the British boat that is offered to us.

Furthermore, the British have offered us the choice if we go this way of modifying their fleet so that we have commonality with a fleet which is actually being built for the Royal Navy. Most importantly, in light of the remarks I made first of all about a nuclear-powered version, the Vickers boat will be available with a nuclear-powered engine in the years to come. There is the great advantage of having the best of both worlds; having a common fleet and common equipment with two power sources.

As I said earlier, there is no confidence in the defence community that the right decision has been made. If we look at previous decisions of Labor governments, if we go back to the Whitlam years and look at the Leopard tank and the FFGs-two of the worst buys this country ever made-we see a parallel between them and the submarine contract. It is for the Government to justify what it has done, to justify the expenditure of money, the way the Royal Australian Navy's future is being mortgaged on what is on the surface a very inferior and very third rate weapons system that the Government is proposing to lock the Australian Navy into for the next 20 or 30 years. If the Government does not do that, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia have made it very clear what they will do. When we get into power-in six weeks, six months or 12 months or whatever it is-we will go back to first principles and we will examine this contract from the first and get the best boat for the Australian Navy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Opposition does not oppose the passage of Supply Bill (No. 1) 1985-86, Supply Bill (No. 2) 1985-86 and Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1985-86.
—Shame! Chuck them out.

—My colleague behind me suggests that we should chuck them out. I can well understand why he, having regard to some historical precedents, might think that is a good idea. Whilst I totally agree with what my other colleague Senator MacGibbon has said about the total misfortune of the way in which the Royal Australian Navy submarine purchase is proceeding, it is not our business to hold up Supply. It is not our business to prevent the Government from being able to misspend the taxpayers' money in the way in which it wishes. Unfortunately, the vote which it received in the last election was sufficient, just by a fraction, to enable it to govern and have the power to determine how the taxpayers' funds will be spent. Whilst we complain bitterly and say that it is the highest spending, biggest taxing government in the history of Australia and whilst we say that it has engaged in one of the most despicable slight of hand exercises in recent times with the recent mini-Budget, we do not propose to hold up the passage of the Supply Bills, which Bills will enable the operation of government in Australia to proceed for the next few months.

SPEECH.PARA: In case anybody does not understand what the Supply Bills are all about, the purpose is to provide temporary Supply between the end of the current financial year and the passage of the Appropriation Bills which follow the introduction of the Budget in August. We will have a great deal to say about the Budget which will be introduced in August. The Supply Bills are simply facilitatory to enable government to continue to operate. While we entirely support my colleague Senator MacGibbon taking the opportunity to talk about something of extreme importance to Australia as the disastrous decision taken in relation to the submarine purchase, we do not intend to hold up the passage of the Bills and we will support their immediate passage.
