TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening I discussed matters relating to National Free Enterprise Ltd, a company which was formed by leading Queensland National Party identities on 27 September 1984 for the purpose of passing money on to the Queensland National Party and avoiding the disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Eight days after the company was formed on 5 October 1984 it donated $300,000 to the Queensland Branch of the National Party of Australia. The company's memorandum of association specifically allowed this company to make that extraordinary donation to the National Party. One relevant clause, clause 2 (t), empowers the directors to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . make donations for patriotic or charitable purposes.

This large amount of money, raised at the rate of $37,500 a day, represents an extraordinary fund raising drive, unparalleled in Australian political history. It represents more than 90 per cent of the total donations declared under section 3 by the Queensland National Party in its returns lodged recently with the Australian Electoral Commission. It also represented more than one-third of the total Queensland National Party campaign expenditure of some $842,000 during the last Federal election.

It was more than adequate to cover the $260,000 spent by the Queensland National Party on television and radio advertising. Because the Queensland National Party has gone to such extraordinary lengths to hide the source of this $300,000 donation I think it is only fair to ask the question why it has done so. Did the money come from a number of wealthy individuals or from companies representing very wealthy individuals? When examining possible sources of donations I uncovered the Free Enterprise Welfare Foundation-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is contrary to Standing Orders to be reading a speech. What is happening at the moment is the most blatant exercise of an honourable senator reading a speech because he does not even know what he is talking about but providing an opportunity to put something prepared by somebody else into Hansard.
—That is a reflection on the senator and you know it.
—And I mean it.
—Order!
—You are smearing someone without evidence.
—He is reading it.
—That does not mean he didn't prepare it.

—Order! I ask Senator Robert Ray not to interject. Senator Peter Rae, I take it that you have finished your point of order. There is no point of order. I assume Senator Black is reading from copious notes. I call Senator Black.

—Thank you, Mr President. When examining possible sources of donations I uncovered the Free Enterprise Welfare Foundation Ltd, a company incorporated in Queensland on 18 February 1983. This company was formed ostensibly for the purpose of welfare assistance yet it has included among its memorandum of association clause 2 (x) which empowers the directors to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . make donations for patriotic or charitable purposes.

This clause is identical-word for word-with clause 2 (t) included in the memorandum of association of the National Free Enterprise Ltd that empowered that company to bankroll the last Queensland National Party campaign. The company includes among its directors Mr Brian Ray, company director, of 47 Albatross Avenue, Knobby's Beach; Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, Premier of Queensland, of Bethany, Kingaroy; and Florence Isabel Bjelke-Petersen, senator, of Bethany, Kingaroy. As Mr Brian Ray is currently before the Melbourne Magistrates Court facing charges of conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth and conspiracy against a law of the Commonwealth, I feel that it is completely inappropriate for me to comment any further about him or this company. However, I should point out that Mr Ray has been described openly in the media as a collector of funds for the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation.

I am currently conducting investigations into a number of other Queensland companies which may have made donations to the National Party through National Free Enterprise Ltd as I believe that the Queensland public has a right to know who is bankrolling National Party campaigns in my home State. I am doing this not simply for the Australian Labor Party in Queensland but, of course, for the Queensland Branch of the Liberal Party, which is even keener than the Labor Party in Queensland to uncover the sources of these funds. I will be putting these facts before the Senate at a later date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take some time in the adjournment debate tonight to speak on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the Australian Defence Force's structure and capabilities which was tabled in October 1984. In particular I refer to the response last week of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). This report involved the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee in a great deal of work. It is a report whose scholarship will stand up to any examination. It is very disappointing first of all that the response of the Minister was sneaked through the--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is it in order for Senator Black, having just made what may be regarded by some as a rather dastardly attack, firstly, to hand over the written notes from which he has read and, secondly, to leave the chamber immediately he finished speaking?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I was saying that the way in which the Minister presented the response-it is the response of the Executive Government-to a closely reasoned and important report on the Australian defence forces was a long way short of satisfactory. We have had no opportunity to debate it so I have to raise the matter tonight in the adjournment debate. The Committee report was unanimous with respect to all its major findings and recommendations. It is true that Senator Lewis and Mr Shipton put in minority reports but they were on fine detail and had nothing to do with the general line of argument in the Committee's report.

SPEECH.PARA: I could paraphrase the findings of the report in a few sentences. First of all, we found that the capability of the defence forces at present to react immediately in a general sense to a low level threat was very inadequate. We found that supplies of ammunition, fuel and the rest of it were not adequate to sustain any operations for more than a very brief period. More importantly, we rejected the concept of the no threat doctrine on which Australian defence has rested for many decades. Instead, we put forward the concept that the defence forces should be told that their duty is to protect Australia, and that means not only the Australian mainland but also our island possessions such as Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands because they are very important to us. The Cocos (Keeling) Islands get very little attention at all. I put this to the Senate: India is certainly the largest democracy in the world, but unfortunately Mrs Gandhi was murdered last year and it is not impossible for the democratic Government in India to change and for India to take an aggressive view of its activities in the region. If India took the Cocos (Keeling) Islands the key to the whole of the Indian Ocean would be lost. If the Cocos (Keeling) Islands were taken there would be no way in which Australia could take them back. So it is very important to be able to hold them and deny them to an aggressor. That was the first task we set. We said: 'Your first duty is to hold the Australian mainland. Your second task is to have such a deterrent capability that you will make the cost prohibitive for anyone in the region to attack or invade Australia.' That deterrent capability is within Australia's capability.

The report was very well received by the Services. All three Services thought that the report had a lot going for it. There were detailed comments by each relating to its own part of the Services but the overall view was that it was well worth while and it provided something to be seriously thought about. The reaction from the civilian component of the Department of Defence was one of shock and horror because the report shot its sacred cow-the no threat document-and drew attention to the shortcomings in the present structure of the defence forces. The Department of Defence embarked on a burial operation of submerging the report and hiding it. We can see the consequence of that in the way in which this report, written by the civilian component of the Department of Defence, was presented by the Minister for Defence in the dying hours of the Parliament. All I can say about the Minister, despite his charming personality, is that he did not read the report presented by the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you speaking about me again?
—No, not at all.
—I heard you refer to a charming personality. I naturally assumed it was me.

—I was referring to the Minister for Defence. If the Minister had read the Committee's report, he certainly did not understand it; and he does not understand what a defence force for Australia is about. I cannot understand how anyone who knew anything about defence could have had the lack of pride to present this report, which is an intellectually barren document and a document which fails to deal seriously with the reasoned case put by a bipartisan committee of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The hour is late and I do not propose to go through this report in the way it should be done, but there are a couple of points I wish to make in passing. In the introduction to the report, the statement is made that the Committee's report displays some misconceptions about defence. It does not go on to say what those misconceptions were but it creates the belief in the reader that perhaps the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence was wrong. Later, on the same page, it says:

. . . the report then attempts to address the nation's defence capacity and priorities. It is in this discussion that the Government has reservations about some of the conclusions, particularly the scope for them to be implemented within realistic financial planning estimates.

So the Government cast light on the credentials of the Committee, first of all, by referring to misconceptions, then it invoked the sacred cow about cost. Later in the introduction, the Minister hides behind the fact that a review into defence is to be undertaken by a respected consultant, Mr Paul Dibb. Mr Paul Dibb is a respected strategic analyst, but he knows nothing at all about weapons systems or force structure. He knows nothing at all about the operational doctrine of our forces. Quite bluntly, Mr Dibb's capabilities to do the assessment are less than the capabilities of the parliamentary committee which looked into the same matter. Mr Dibb is being used to delay any hard decisions by the present Australian Government in defence because, by putting Mr Dibb in to review the defence forces, the Government is employing a technique which allows it to get away from making the hard and difficult decisions that need to be made to get our defence into shape.

Again in the introduction, while we are on the subject of errors, the claim was made by the Minister that most of our maritime, combat and transport aircraft could be made ready in a matter of weeks, if necessary. The Committee had criticised the lack of capability of our maritime aircraft. It is nonsense, and it is quite untrue for a Minister to claim, that maritime aircraft can be brought to readiness in a matter of weeks. We have fewer than seven operational crews in each of the two long-range maritime patrol squadrons we have. Crews cannot be trained in much under six months. LRMP captains cannot be trained in that time. It is blatantly untrue and misleading of the Minister to make a claim such as that.

Then we move to the detailed response of the Department to the Committee's reports. The Department, selectively, chooses only 48 points out of the many that were raised there. I do not propose to deal with all of those 48 points; I shall deal with a mere half dozen or so. The first point with which I deal is the business where the Minister claims:
A supposed attack out of a 'clear blue sky' is simply not a sensible basis for judging Australia's defence preparedness.

This is a complete reversion to what the Committee disproved, and that is the belief that there is any sense in supporting a no-threat doctrine. There have been about 67 major wars since the end of the Second World War, and there have been hundreds of minor ones. I would say that 95 per cent of those armed conflicts have not been preceded by any warning at all. The doctrine that the Minister puts forward in this paper is the old doctrine, the rejected doctrine-rejected by this Parliament-that we shall get warning before an attack.

What the Department is saying here is, first, that there is no threat at present; if a threat emerges, we shall see a dramatic shift in the political situation in a country in the region. Following on that, it says, we shall see overt military preparedness. We shall notice that preparedness, the aggressive intent, and we shall react and prepare against it. That is simply not true, and it is the point that the Committee took considerable pains to demolish.
The response also says:

Some elements of the Australian Defence Force are structured to meet higher level contingencies which are credible only in the longer term. It is not necessary to keep these elements at a high state of readiness at present.

One can only assume from that that the Government has further cuts in mind with respect to our meagre preparedness. I said in my introduction that the Committee said that we had essential areas of interest, yet the Department rejected this view with one of the most glaring examples of bureaucratic journalese I have ever read. It said:

Given the nature of the strategic region in which Australia is situated, and the absence of formal defence alliances between Australia and its neighbours (except for New Zealand), there are presentational and practical constraints in defining the area within which our forces would be required to operate in the way suggested by the Report. Rather the Government believes we should take account of the influences right across the region . . .

That means nothing at all. We can know what is going on in the region, and if our priorities are that we defend Australia first and have a deterrent capability, what is going on in the way that the Minister suggests is irrelevant.

The Committee came up with certain recommendations of priorities. Those priorities were that we developed a capability to know what was going on in the area, with surveillance equipment; that we had airborne refuelling capabilities; and that we had some decent maps and charts. The Minister makes the claim in his statement that the Government has done a lot to improve the charting of the country. The evidence the Committee got was that if the navy worked as hard as it was going, it would be 60 years before we got modern charts. That is hardly, in any sense at all, dealing with this is a matter of priority.

I do not wish to go into this matter at great length tonight. I come back to where I started: The statement fails to answer the serious points raised by the Joint Parliamentary Committee; it deals with them with an intellectual barrenness, which guarantees that the report was written right at the senior levels of the civilian component of the Department of Defence; and it is a matter that I shall debate in detail at a time when the Senate has a little more leisure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish this evening to raise a few matters that have particular relevance to South Australia. The first is a matter raised in the Senate on 13 May in the form of a question in relation to the Adelaide Access Handover Centre. The response was given by Senator Gareth Evans on 14 May. In his response he indicated to the Senate that an independent valuation of the Handover Centre pilot project and comments by the Adelaide Central Mission, which ran the service, had been received and were being examined. He went on to make a few other comments, but he finalised his response by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . no funding to the Adelaide Centre by the Commonwealth is being considered at this stage.

I wish to make two points in relation to this matter. Firstly, I regret that Senator Evans chose not to inform the Senate that the independent evaluation that had been received and was being considered concluded that the Centre was a good idea. It recommended that it should continue. I would have regarded that as a fuller, more appropriate and perhaps more decent answer to give to the Senate. I do not wish to impute any improper motives to Senator Evans in not informing the Senate that the independent evaluation recommended that this pilot project should continue; nonetheless, the fact is that he did not inform the Senate of that. There has been plenty of comment in the Press over the last couple of weeks to the effect that if a person is old, young or an ex-serviceman the Australian Labor Party wants to get him, and it seems that the same thing applies if one happens to be divorced and is having trouble sorting out access arrangements.

I commend the Government for having funded this pilot project and for having had an independent evaluation of the project undertaken. I condemn it, however, for choosing to ignore the advice offered in that independent evaluation and for choosing not to continue funding that Centre. It seems to be somewhat of a waste of money to set up a pilot project and then set up a system to work out whether the pilot project was a good idea and, having been informed that it was a good idea, decide not to continue anyway.

I referred several days ago in this chamber to the second matter I wish to raise; that is, the setting up at Elizabeth of a special primary school particularly for Aboriginal children. Mr President, you may recall that I expressed some anxiety over the setting up of this school and urged that its development be watched closely. I had that concern because we had heard from other countries that separate development is good development, and that parallels could be drawn between the separate development in education at Elizabeth and the separate development in South Africa that people in this Parliament, and indeed the whole country, are so very rude about.

TALK.START.PARA: —And rightly so.

—I agree with Senator Georges-rightly so. I feel duty bound to inform the Senate that I now know a bit more about South Australia's view with respect to this school than I knew at the time. There have been many letters to editors in relation to this school. I think some of the comments made are worth repeating in the Senate. One person wrote informing us that the State Minister of Education, Mr Arnold, alleged that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . being constantly in a minority, constantly on the fringe, it is clear many Aboriginal children are not able to succeed in the normal school system.
The writer went on to say:
Yet more than 100 ethnic groups in Australia are in a similar minority position. Can each of these demand a separate school fully funded by the Government?

Some of the other letters informed us that the Minister was reported to have said that a separate school would improve race relations. The person who wrote that letter went on to point out that she thought this would set up an apartness, drawing an analogy, obviously, to apartheid.
Perhaps a bit more telling about politics in South Australia is the comment by a person named Cucksey from Elizabeth East who says:

Elizabethans have been waiting since the December by-election to discover what form of punishment would be meted out for their impertinence in electing the people's choice in preference to the party's--
that is the Labor Party's-
choice. The Minister for Education has ended that wait by decreeing that Elizabeth will be subject to yet another social experiment.
We are to be the guinea pig for black and white separatism.

I think it is disgraceful that this school has been developed in an environment that is not conducive to improving racial relations in this country. It was clear from the comments I made the other day that the school council and various other bodies that were consulted voted against this school proceeding. As I pointed out the other day, nonetheless, the State Minister chose to proceed. I simply inform the Senate that the expressions by the people of South Australia seem to be confirming the view at the moment that they, as I, would not condone separate development on a racial basis.

The third matter I wish to raise, admittedly in a somewhat lighthearted manner, but as this is nearly the end of the session I feel that is not necessarily out of place concerns a small clipping out of the Adelaide Advertiser of 30 May 1985 with the headline 'Queensland dispute Bill passes Senate'. I remind honourable senators that the Australian Democrats' advertising for the last election ran roughly along the lines of 'You can change the world-vote Australian Democrats'. These advertisements-I congratulate them-did pass on an implication of power and a capacity to achieve. In anticipation of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) being in the chamber I was racking my brain trying to think of the non-sexist terminology for impotence, frigidity or barrenness. I could not come up with a non-sexist term for these, so I will simply have to draw my conclusion in sexist terms. I invite other members of the Senate to do just the same; that is, to reflect on the performance of the Democrats in this chamber over this session and to ask themselves just how much people who voted Democrat have been able to change the world and just how impotent, frigid or barren the Democrats are more and more appearing to be. I turn to the bottom of this article, which states:
Earlier--
that is earlier than some time referred to in this article-
the Australian Democrats in SA said they opposed the Federal Democrats' support of the legislation. Their parliamentary Leader-
that is the State Democrats-
Mr Milne, described the legislation as 'another chip away at States' rights'.

I do not know whether Mr Milne was having a bit of a pun with the 'chip', nonetheless I simply draw this article to the Senate's attention because it has come to my notice that the Democrats have quite often joined with members of the Opposition in cajoling and rubbishing the Labor Party for the factionalism and problems that they have at the moment, all a part of the stern stuff of opposition and debate. I think it is fair to point out to the Senate that as there are those divisions in the Labor Party so this article would indicate that there are those divisions in the Australian Democrats. Mr President, I thank you for your time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the closing stages of this Parliament, the Government of Queensland has come under continued attack from members of the Government who have set themselves up as the de facto opposition and opposition in exile. I believe that they think the Queensland Government has no chance of ever achieving government in its own right so they have taken the matter upon themselves to be the opposition down here. That is probably correct because the latest polls show that in Queensland the popularity of the Australian Labor Party has fallen a further 4 per cent. But the situation is becoming very unhealthy in Canberra. The obsession of the Labor Party senators in relation to Queensland is becoming quite ridiculous. The reason is clear: The Queensland Government is a conservative government and the Labor Party in Queensland is in tatters.

SPEECH.PARA: The stories are getting more inaccurate and ridiculous as this parliamentary session draws to a close. The outcome will be that those people who handle the truth lightly will lose their credibility; it will be destroyed, if it has not been destroyed already. Yesterday at Question Time a number of tall stories were told by way of dorothy dixers asked of Ministers. Let me go through the stories one by one. The first story was that the Queensland State economy is mismanaged. That is rubbish. In this place we hear of one or two negative figures and never positive indicators. For example, with only 16.1 per cent of the Australian population, Queensland accounted for 19.9 per cent of the dwelling unit approvals and 20.5 per cent of the value of the other building approvals for the eight months ended February 1985. With only 16.1 per cent of the population, Queensland accounted for 24.4 per cent of the non-building home constructions and commercial developments-

TALK.START.PARA: —What does 'non-building home constructions' mean?

—If Senator Ray wants to know, it means commercial constructions. Queensland accounted for 24.4 per cent of the commercial constructions for the six months ended December 1984; 23.7 per cent of exports for the six months ended December 1984; and 16.1 per cent of the retail sales for the seven months ended January 1985. There is only one thing wrong with the Queensland economy and that is what is in the minds of the Government senators in this place who should be standing up for their States and who do not. The second tall story is that there is no sex education in Queensland. Honourable senators opposite are wrong again. Sex education is provided by the Education Department for any student who wishes to attend such classes out of school hours.
—At night, after school.

—Let me remind Senator Reynolds that there are parents who feel that it is incumbent on them to educate their own children about sex and they do not want it taught in the school classrooms. The third tall story is about a $5m dam on the MacKenzie River to water a property owned by John Bjelke-Petersen. Honourable senators opposite are wrong for the third time. The dam is 45 kilometres away from the property which has its own anabranch of the MacKenzie River.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth tall story was that the five pilots employed by the Queensland Government were sacked because they wanted to record passengers' names in the log books. That is wrong again. The fact is that the State Government reshuffled the air wing. The pilots were given three months notice and told that they could apply for new positions to pilot the aircraft within the Police Department. The air wing was split into the police air wing and the ministerial air wing. The fifth tall story was that Queensland had accumulated the highest per capita debt of any State. That is wrong again. The explanatory notes of the Australian Bureau of Statistics government financial estimates warn about the use of deficit figures. To save the time of the Senate I seek leave to incorporate a document in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Although this information is reclassified to be on a consistent basis using the ABS classification schemes, a consequence of obtaining data from such a variety of sources is that the figures reflect different accounting practices and this may give rise to differences between States and subsectors in the way the transactions are classified.

'This should be taken into account when making State by State comparisons of the forward estimates which are prepared from data sources providing considerably less detail than those used to compile the historical series of statistics on government outlays and revenue.'

'In recent years the Queensland Government has entered into special agreements with private sector enterprises to cover financing and loan servicing relating to the construction of railways and port facilities solely or mainly used by the enterprises concerned. As a result a substantial amount of capital expenditure on new fixed assets by the budget sector have been financed by security deposits received from the private sector, which are classified in this publication as deficit financing because they are repayable.

'However, a major feature of these agreements are provisions for minimum shipping tonnage requirements and the determination of freight rates and other charges, to be paid by the enterprises concerned, which are designed to ensure that sufficient funds are available to allow the Queensland Government to service and repay these deposits.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now come to Senator Black, who has been in this Parliament for only a short time and who wants to be an overnight star. He wants to see his name in lights and in print. He will have to learn very quickly that in this place fools rush in where angels fear to tread. Last night he tried to make an attack on National Free Enterprise Ltd and he found that he has miscued there.
—Why did he miscue?

—Because he could not even get the numbers; that is why. He comes back tonight and continues that attack. For years the Australian Labor Party has tipped buckets over the National Party, the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation and groups supporting the National Party. Then the ALP does a complete back flip and sets up its own foundation, similar to the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. Not only did it do that; it got the same fund raising organisation that set up the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation to set up its fund. What about the T. J. Ryan Foundation in Queensland, organised to collect money for the Labor Party in Queensland? It would be quite easy to look up the articles of association and the directors of the fund if one wanted to grovel in the gutter with Senator Black. Why should not people in private enterprise support a private enterprise Premier and a conservative government? After all, the Queensland people's lives would be wrecked if the socialists took over in Queensland too. But there is not much chance of that ever happening.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Black failed to address himself to the hundreds of thousands of dollars of union funds that pour into the ALP's campaign coffers and operating funds Australia wide. He failed to say anything about the compulsory levies imposed on unionists which unions direct to ALP funds and their contributions by way of affiliation fees. Many unionists would not want a bar of the ALP. They do not support it electorally and they do not want to support it financially. But of course they do not have much choice in the matter. I ask Senator Black, the Government and all the ALP Senators who support the Electrical Trades Union and the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association whether this is a pay back for the legislation that went through the Senate yesterday. It is an attack on my State rights. Both those unions were mentioned as substantial donors to the ALP in the Electoral Commissioner's report. The National Party has been honest in dealing with these matters as the law requires. All donors are listed in its report to the Electoral Commissioner. The ALP has not disclosed contributions to some New South Wales candidates. It has chosen to release its reports to the Commission piecemeal so it is harder to put together a clear picture of all its operations. Has not the ALP included in its disclosures the operations of its New South Wales money laundering fund-the Australia Labor Party New South Wales Gift Pty Ltd. The company articles of association and aims are very clear yet there are no disclosures about what it has raised. Do we, as a party, have to make company searches to find out who the directors are, to embarrass them? Those directors could genuinely believe that the ALP has something to offer Australians. Should their names have to be dragged through cowards' castle and should all sorts of innuendoes be poked at them and their families? That is what Senator Black is doing-getting right down into the gutter. Do we have to delve into the Curtin Foundation in Western Australia and the Curtin Foundation federally? Do we have to look at every State to find out where funds are raised and who the directors are? Do we have to embarrass people and their families? Do we have to snoop around the Companies Office in every State to find out the Foundations in those States? I say to the Government and to Senator Black: They were elected to govern Australia, not to act as a Queensland opposition in exile. I give Senator Black a bit of advice. He should play the ball, not the man.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, through you I ask whether Senator Boswell will table the documents from which he was reading.
—Senator Colston, you can move for that.
—Mr President, I am well aware that I can move for that, but I thought I would do it in the gentlemanly way and through you ask Senator Boswell whether he will table the documents.
—Senator Boswell, do you intend tabling the documents?
—Mr President, this is the only copy I have. I would be quite happy to photostat it and then table it.
—Senator Boswell will table the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, this has been a terrific debate on what we hope is the last evening of the session, and I am sure it has made us all feel much better and got the adrenalin flowing through our veins and so on! I must say that I do find the debate in some aspects rather pathetic. What we have had is an attempt by Senator Black to play the game of blackguarding Queensland, which has been going on in this place for some time and which I guess reflects the frustration that people such as Senator Black feel from being in a rump party in Queensland which has put in a rather pathetic performance for so long. In any event, let me say that the one thing that honourable senators opposite can be quite proud of is that they probably gave the greatest fillip to public funding and to some examination of these matters with the support of their party, the Australian Labor Party, for the Iraqi breakfast. They ought to remember that their Leader and senior members of their Party sat down with representatives of a foreign government and tried to raise hundreds and thousands of dollars in campaign funds. That is probably the most disgraceful single episode in Australia's history.
—It is; I agree.

—I am glad to hear that Senator Robert Ray, who is distinguished in this place for being a pretty straightforward fellow, thinks that that is an absolute disgrace. A great deal of parliamentary attention has been given to the question of how we ought to run these matters in Australia now. I think Senator Robert Ray was one of the people on the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform-there were others from both Houses-who recommended that we should have a new arrangement in Australia governing electoral matters. I understood that we had an Electoral Commission to supervise these matters, receive complaints and examine the sorts of matters which have been raised by Senator Black. I would have thought there were avenues open to him if he believes there have been fund raising practices which contravene the letter of the law which has recently been passed in this place to refer them to the appropriate authorities. I can only say that I doubt Senator Black's sincerity in this matter, although I think under Standing Orders I am not allowed to impugn his motives. I simply say that I would have thought that if there was a serious complaint it could have been referred to the appropriate authorities. But the way in which Senator Black has gone about it suggests that this is no more than just part of the bucket Queensland campaign that we have seen mainly from the front bench of the Labor Party. There has also been a good deal of it from the back bench as well.

SPEECH.PARA: It really fascinated me to see the papers tabled by Senator Gareth Evans, who answered a dorothy dix on this matter, and to find that there had been contributions to his answer from at least three different sources. We had first of all a nice typed answer for the dorothy dix, then another form of typewriting and then a whole lot of Senator Gareth Evans's own writing. It is obviously a sad but true fact that senior Ministers in this Government have had time to sit down and work out how they might bucket the Queensland Government because obviously it is a thorn in their side. In response to Senator Black I simply say that if he believes there have been illegal actions on behalf of any party in Australia, whether it is his own or any other, no doubt his complaints can be referred to the Electoral Commission, the Australian Federal Police or whomever. No doubt if there are deficiencies in the law they are matters which can also be addressed by the parliamentary committee which I understand still exists to consider these matters.

The night is late. It has been a lot of fun for Senator Black. Senator Colston's gall-I have not heard him stand up much for Queensland in here-in getting up and saying that Senator Boswell should table his notes when there was resistance to the point of order about Senator Black reading his speech, which was promptly handed to the attendant and taken off to Hansard, adds to my repugnance about the debate tonight. I think it has been a fairly pathetic end to a long session. I am sure that if Senator Black thinks he has any substance to his complaints he will forward them to the Electoral Commission, the police or somebody other than to the Senate who will have the authority to deal with the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talking about pathetic endings, we have heard two pathetic speeches in a row from the Opposition benches. The trouble with Senator Boswell is that he really thinks that his State is in tip top condition. Five Australian Labor Party senators represent Queensland. They do their very best but they are hampered by the fact that there is a regime in Queensland which is doing its very best to grind the Queensland economy into the ground. We have only to look at some of the indicators. The indicators have been mentioned here previously and I will not mention them again. Queensland is in a parlous situation because of the regime which is administering the Public Service there and doing what it can to make sure that Queensland is not going to get anywhere.

SPEECH.PARA: I sometimes wonder whether the Premier of Queensland is deliberately doing what he is doing so that he can have a large pool of unemployed and he can further impose on the Commonwealth to pay unemployment benefit to the vast number of unemployed in Queensland, thinking that the Australian Government will be hampered by having to pay all that money. Sometimes I wonder whether that is deliberate.

Senator Boswell comes into the chamber quite often and picks out a few statistics which he thinks will prove that Queensland is in a rosy state. It is not, and that is due to the Queensland Government. We five Australian Labor Party senators do our best to represent Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not good enough.
—Order! Senator Boswell is out of order for two reasons.

—He is out of order again. Senator Boswell's Government is what really hampers us. If he wants to come in here time after time with spurious statistics to try to indicate that everything is rosy in Queensland, eventually we will have to go after him every time, show where he is wrong and indicate how poorly the Queensland Government is looking after its citizens. It is often not known that about 38 per cent of the Queensland population voted for the Government of the Party to which he belongs.
—Thirty-nine.

—It was about 38 per cent. If Senator Boswell wants 39 per cent, he can take it. However, I am taking 38 per cent because I do not count those two renegades, Lane and Austin, as having gained their votes for the National Party of Australia. They stood as Liberal Party candidates. Even if one includes those two renegades who stood for the Liberal Party and who, immediately after the election, swapped horses and joined up with the National Party and even if one claims that their votes are for the National Party, that Party still did not get 40 per cent of the votes in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: If one were looking at a two-party preferred vote one would say that the National Party and the Liberal Party combined probably had a majority. However the fact is that the National Party is ruling on its own with less than 40 per cent of the popular vote. This is the sort of thing we will have to come into this chamber and tell the people of Queensland about and let them know exactly what is happening in their State. I repeat: The only thing that is hindering the five Labor senators from doing better than we are doing in Queensland is what the National Party is doing through its regime to the people of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much to the concern of Senator Georges and probably of Opposition senators, who might find my speech boring in view of the recent events in this place, I wish to speak on a number of topics tonight. However, I cannot let the opportunity pass without saying something about Senator Chaney, who in his normal hypo- critical way made a contribution. Senator Chaney is a bloke who at the Seventh Australasian and Pacific Regional Parliamentary Seminar in October 1984 said:

SPEECH.PARA: What I have found in my ten years in the Parliament is that the same sets of arguments are trotted out on both sides. If there has to be a change of government, what the Liberals were saying in government is said by the Labor people who are now in government and what the Labor people were saying in opposition is said by the Liberals when they are in opposition.

The credibility of Senator Chaney is pretty well rock bottom when it comes to making an assessment of what he is saying tonight. We should also remember that Senator Chaney is one of those members who represents Western Australia. We all recall very well the sort of respect they have for the processes of law and order. Senator Chaney and his colleague Senator Durack presided over a government that kept in the bottom drawer of some junior public servant's office in the Attorney-General's Department a file that was very crucial to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Millions and millions of dollars were evaded because of the inactivity and negligence of people such as Senator Chaney and Senator Durack. We have come to expect that from that side of the House and it is a course of conduct we do not really find very surprising.

The subjects I want to discuss tonight are hardly important in the context of the debate that has gone on tonight. I am glad to see that Senator Boswell has shown some sense in leaving this chamber. Mr President, I know that the topics I wish to raise are of interest to you, and for that purpose I shall pursue them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are they about football?

—Senator Messner mentions football. He would know better than most people in this place that the last thing I wish to talk about tonight is the fact that my football team in South Australia is not winning very many matches. However, next time we play Senator Messner's team I am sure that will be reversed. What has provoked me to speak tonight is what is called an Urgent Message from Europeans to Congress to support the Nicaraguan resistance. The other matter that has provoked me tonight is a matter that was discussed last night, and that is the subject of telephone intercept powers and the question of those powers being given to State Parliaments and State governments. I shall discuss that later in my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of Nicaragua is something which I think is extremely important, although it may not be as important to Queenslanders as it is to people in the rest of the world. This Urgent Message from Europeans to Congress is signed not only by Europeans but by a person called J. Malcolm Fraser, who now pretends to be a European-a former Prime Minister of Australia. It is a message to the United States Congress that has been signed by Malcolm Fraser. It is loaded, it is filled, it is ridden with falsities, lies, and nothing more than that. I feel quite sad that Malcolm Fraser, who I think in his term of office showed a great degree of strength and a great degree of perceptiveness, saw fit to sign this document. Despite the rhetoric and abuse that we on this side threw at Malcolm Fraser over eight years of government, one could not say that the man was a fool. Furthermore, one could not say that the man was not perceptive. However, in signing this document I think Malcolm Fraser was totally misled and totally ignorant. It is a document which states-

TALK.START.PARA: —Ring, ring.

—The Krondorf champagne is telling on Senator Baume over there. There are four major points in this message from Malcolm Fraser. He believes that the Government in Nicaragua is a totalitarian dictatorship. He calls on the United States Congress and a sense of morality to aid the Contras in Nicaragua. He believes that the Sandinistas are a Marxist-Leninist junta, and he believes that they are acting as an object of Soviet policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not pretend tonight to go through the whole of the evidence against the case that has been pursued by J. Malcolm Fraser. However, what I do wish to say is that on all objective assessments, on the objective assessments of those impartial observers who have taken an interest in this country, whether it be the International Committee of the Red Cross, whether it be the America's Watch organisation, or whether it be any other international organisation, the statement to which Malcolm Fraser has signed his name is totally wrong and false.

He talks about four years of dictatorship, when the Sandinistas have been in government for six years. He talks about the Sandinistas being a Marxist-Leninist junta from the start, when he full well should know that for the initial period of their government the American Administration supported them in government. He calls them a totalitarian ruling party. Anyone can perceive that the Sandinistas in government have the support of the Nicaraguan people. They showed their support in an election which was supported, witnessed and observed by international bodies throughout the world, be it the Canadian Government, the Swedish Government or any other international observer.

Mr Fraser says that there is a state of emergency in Nicaragua, which shows that the political agenda of the Nicaraguan Government is that of a totalitarian dictatorship. One wonders where his voice is at the moment while Joh Bjelke-Petersen calls a state of emergency in Queensland. One wonders why he does not see that action as an indication of a totalitarian dictatorship. Mr Fraser went on to say that he believes that the people of Nicaragua need to choose freely their own political future. They have done that. They have done it to the satisfaction of international observers throughout the world.

The most obscene part of the message that J. Malcolm Fraser has signed is that call on the United States Congress, in the spirit of democratic solidarity, in the call to morality, to support those who are seeking to exercise the right of free men. He calls on the United States Congress to support those so-called freedom fighters, the Contras. Time after time, report after report, the International Court of Justice, the America's Watch organisation, the International Committee for the Red Cross or whatever, any independent international organisation, has told Malcolm Fraser and anyone else who wishes to listen to the truth that the Government in Nicaragua is nothing like that at all.

If Ronald Reagan and his lackeys throughout the world are prepared to continue to say that the Contras are the freedom fighters, let them look at some of the hard evidence. Let them look at some of the evidence from respected international independent organisations that can tell Malcolm Fraser and others that the Nicaraguan Government is the most liberal government in Central America and has been for the last 160 years. Let Malcolm Fraser listen to the fact that in Nicaragua prisons are open. Let him listen to the fact that the Somozan generals and colonels and whoever are free to move as they wish. Let him also listen to the fact that although the Nicaraguan Government made some mistakes in the early days it is now prepared to negotiate and is negotiating with whatever organisations exist in Nicaragua in order to provide for and to ensure a democratic system, be it an opposition party such as the Coordinora Democratica, the International Red Cross or any other organisation that wishes to prevail in that country, be it the newspaper La Prensa, the Church or the minority group, the Miskitos. The Sandinistas are showing tolerance on all internationally accepted values. They are showing a degree of sensitivity which other countries in that region-countries supported by Malcolm Fraser and Ronald Reagan and others-are not showing.

As I have said, I do not want to go into this issue in depth; to do so would take quite some time. All I wish to say in conclusion about this matter is that I feel quite sad that Malcolm Fraser in his retirement days has chosen, quite misleadingly, to support this call as a European. One wonders whether he has seen the new map of the world. Even with the new map as it is presented today, I do not think that Australia fits within Europe as we know it.

The other question I wish to canvass tonight was raised in the Senate last night. I refer to the transferring to State governments power to intercept telephone communications. As honourable senators will know, this question was raised last night in the course of the debate on the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985. In response to that Bill the Opposition moved an amendment, with which I did not agree.

It is an amendment with which I believe many members of the Australian Labor Party throughout the country and within Caucus do not agree. Once again I think that to canvass all the issues involved in this matter would take too long and I do not wish to do that. However, what I wish to say very succinctly is that the proposal canvassed by the Opposition and proposed by some members of the Government is that State governments be given powers to intercept telephone communications in pursuit of organised crime and drug related offences.

I have two reservations in respect of this particular proposal. One is that I do not think it will work and, in not working, it will lead to an uncontrolled situation which will give State governments and State police forces power to infringe civil liberties. The second is that I believe that there are alternative proposals which any government within Australia can pursue. These are proposals which have been recommended over the last five years or so by royal commission after royal commission. I believe those proposals would be more fruitful and less of an infringement of civil rights than the Government's proposal would be.

My initial point is that the Government's proposal will lead to uncontrolled interception of telephone communications. The proposal is well meaning. The Government is intent on stamping out organised crime, particularly when it involves drug related offences. I believe that is a motive which should be supported. However, I believe that in supporting such a motive we need to be extremely sensitive, aware and perceptive of what we are doing. We are proposing that the States be given the facilities and power to intercept telephone communications. I believe these facilities will cost about $500,000 for each State. I believe these facilities, once they are set up, will not in practice be controllable by any Federal or judicial organisation.

Let us look at the last few years and see what has happened under State government, State bureaucracies and State control. In recent years we have seen police officers, in collusion with the Commonwealth police, tapping telephones from Five Dock police station in Sydney. Illegal those taps may be. Contrary to the decision of government they may be. But the New South Wales police took it upon themselves to intercept telephone communications. The way that they achieved some sort of notoriety was to leak these communications to the Press. Not one person has yet been arrested or convicted because of the material obtained illegally by those people. I am concerned that if this sort of activity can continue with the collusion of senior officers, once one gives the toys and the facilities legally to State governments there will be no control over what State police forces do.

It does not take all that much imagination to see what a Queensland government would do with a power to intercept telephone communications. As we have seen in recent days, in Queensland the course of justice has been perverted time and time again. The law provides that when an accused appears before a court he or she can be deprived of a statement of the charges alleged against him or her. Despite deprivation of those basic essentials for fair trial, a court, judges and courts of appeal have no right under the law to ensure that the accused has details of the charges. That sounds like an incredible situation but it has happened in the last few weeks in Queensland. With the sort of regard for civil liberties and natural justice that has been displayed by the Queensland Parliament, it does not take all that much imagination to work out what a Queensland government could do with the power and the facilities to intercept.

The Government, in its good intentions, has said that there will be controls over this power of interception. The Government has said that it will be limited to organised crime. It has said there will be imposed on this power of interception conditions which I believe to be in conformity with some of the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission. These are recommendations which pertain to the power of intercept of a Federal Government.

However, let me once again state the point that I do not believe that these powers can be controlled. For example, Joh Bjelke-Petersen could become aware of the fact that certain activities were being conducted in Queensland-activities which would be legal in the rest of Australia and the rest of the world. Let us take the freedom to organise held by the trade union movement. He would not be stopped from ensuring that the media soon became aware of breaches of the law no matter how wrong the law was. The Premier or the media would not be stopped from ensuring that the power that had been given to the States was extended. All sorts of communications would be covered by this power of interception. In essence, what we are talking about is the thin end of the wedge, a wedge that cannot be controlled by any government or any court in Australia.

As I said earlier, I believe that organised crime should be combated in this country and that there are more effective ways of doing it. I could go through a list of something near 100 recommendations from recent royal commissions-for example, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs or reports of Special Prosecutor Gyles or reports of Robert Redlich. When one goes through these reports one finds somewhere in the vicinity of 100 recommendations of such commissions and bodies that would be more effective in pursuing organised crime and drug related organised crime than the proposal to give States the power to intercept telephone communications.

There are recommendations affecting the banking and financial institutions in this country, recommendations affecting foreign exchange controls, recommendations affecting income tax assessment procedures, recommendations affecting evidentiary and procedural aspects of the courts, and I can go on. As I have said there are in the vicinity of 100 or so recommendations. I do not wish to go through them tonight. I believe that in the next few months I will have an opportunity to go through them again.

Alternatively, one could look at another system of operating and conducting telephone intercepts when drug related offences and organised crime are involved, and that is to vest power in the National Crime Authority. It is an Authority which, under the authority and support of this Parliament, has been given the power and responsibility to pursue organised crime in this country. The National Crime Authority has the facility and the responsibility to pursue organised crime and I do not think it would take all that much to ensure that the States, in their pursuit of organised crime, worked in concert with the National Crime Authority to pursue the people who all of us in this Parliament wish to have brought before the courts and ultimately put in gaol.

As I said at the start of my contribution tonight, I do not believe that I will canvass the issues properly. I do not think this is the appropriate time to make a lengthy speech on them. However, what I wish to do tonight in respect of Nicaragua, and Malcolm Fraser's signing of the message to Congress and the proposal to give power to intercept telephone communications to the States is to raise at this stage some of the issues involved for the notice of the Senate and also, hopefully, to provoke some sort of awareness on both matters.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.59 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Kingdom/United States of America Agreement

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Australia a signatory to the UKUSA Agreement; if so, when did Australia become a party to the agreement.
(2) Has the agreement been reviewed since Australia became a signatory; if so
(a) when; and
(b) were there any alterations to the agreement and what were those alterations.
(3) Does the UKUSA agreement have a termination date; if so, what is that date.
(4)What other nations are party to the UKUSA agreement.
(5) What is the purpose of the UKUSA Treaty.
(6) What actions or obligations has Australia undertaken as a party to the UKUSA agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (2) (3) (4) (5) and (6): The policy of successive Australian Governments has been not to provide information that might confirm or deny speculation on this subject. This remains the policy. I do not therefore intend to comment on the matters raised in this question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Government give an assurance that Australian military and bilateral infrastructure aid is not being used by the Marcos regime to suppress human rights in the Philippines, as has been alluded to by several aid authorities and Father Brian Gore.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware of criticisms of the human rights situation in the Philippines and has on many occasions reaffirmed its commitment to the international protection and promotion of human rights. It has taken a particularly active interest in various aspects of the human rights situation in the Philippines, including those associated with the case of Father Brian Gore and his co-defendants. The Government has made its concerns known in the Philippines at the very highest level.

The Australian Embassy in Manila maintains continuing contact with human rights and civil liberties groups in the Philippines and the Government closely monitors reporting by Amnesty International and other non-governmental organisations.

Australian development assistance is given to support individual projects which are carefully assessed in the light of our own special criteria and objectives, the basis of which is a genuine concern for the interests of the people of the country. We also seek to take advantage of particular Australian expertise.

Australia's development assistance to the Philippines is concentrated in the two rural development projects in Zamboanga del Sur and Northern Samar. These projects seek to establish a framework within which the standard of living of essentially poor, rural populations in their respective provinces can be improved. They concentrate on increasing rural incomes through expanding, improving and diversifying agricultural production. Infrastructural development is essential to support this program if the rate of economic growth in these areas is to be accelerated. Road improvement undertaken by these projects is designed strictly to promote economic development and not for military purposes. Recent studies have demonstrated their important economic impact.

The Government has considered suggestions that Australian aid to the Philippines should be discontinued but has firmly taken the view that such suggestions overlook the fact that the result of such action would be to punish the most needy people in a developing country without influencing those who direct affairs.

At the same time, the Government believes that Australian aid in developing infrastructure and alleviating some of the social and economic problems in developing countries can play a positive role in promoting human rights in recipient countries.

Apart from economic and humanitarian aid to the Philippines, Australia also has a small Defence Co-operation Program with that country. This has increased from $0.804m in 1979-80 to $1.66m in 1984-85, although it has remained about the same in both real terms (taking inflation into account), and as a proportion of the overall Defence Co-operation Program (3.4 per cent). The modest Philippines DCP is, with the Singapore DCP, the smallest in South East Asia. In the region, the Philippines DCP is far smaller than that of Papua New Guinea ($15m), and about the same as the Vanuatu DCP ($1.5m). The DCP with the Philippines comprises mostly training and technical advisory assistance related to Australian equipment previously supplied under the Program. No weapons or armaments are supplied to the Philippines under the DCP.
The Government believes that the DCP with the Philippines does not contribute to, or exacerbate, human rights problems in that country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 26 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Where in the Australian Capital Territory are devices available to enable deaf people to communicate by phone.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice provided by the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: For people affected by deafness, Telecom supplies the following range of facilities:
Gliding tone callers
Extension bells

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 28 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What sort of extension, if any, is being envisaged to the Special Broadcasting Service's current program in view of the introduction of AUSSAT.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Committee of Review of the Special Broadcasting Service reported to the Government on 31 December 1984 and the Report contains recommendations on the extension of SBS-TV and utilisation of AUSSAT. A small working group has been established within my Department to examine the report in consultation with other departments and relevant bodies.

My Department is formulating a revised plan of extension beyond the current approved program which will include provincial cities in Australia to be determined in accordance with the perceived planning and technical criteria. This plan will be submitted to the SBS Planning Committee for endorsement.

I hope to include details of this plan in the submission to Government on the SBS Committee of Review's recommendations so that it may be considered in the full context of the future of multicultural broadcasting.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much Australian Government aid is currently going to Nicaragua and for what projects.

(2) Is the Government aware of a project being sponsored by an Australian community group, Committee in Solidarity with Central America and the Caribbean, to build a small hospital in the town of Achuapa, Nicaragua; if so, is the Government prepared to contribute to this project.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian Government aid to Nicaragua from 1 July 1984 to the present has consisted of
$75,000-grant to the International Committee of the Red Cross for its care and maintenance programs in Nicaragua.
$26,000-for infant milk formula, purchased in Australia through the Head of Mission Discretionary Aid Fund.
$1,515-subsidy to Community Aid Abroad for a film on Development Projects and Strategy in Nicaragua.

$10,000-to Norcote City Council under the Non-Government Organisations Projects Subsidy Scheme. The city has a sister city, Masatepe, in Nicaragua. The project involves the building of a small factory for the production of concrete construction materials. These materials are to be used to provide low cost housing, water pipes, latrines and drainage.

(2) Yes. The Government has not been approached to contribute to this project at this stage. Any application for assistance would be considered by ADAB under the guidelines established for the Non-Government Organisations Project Subsidy Scheme.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 18 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has work on the new Darwin International Airport and associated facilities been cancelled permanently; if so:
(a) has over $10m been spent on the project and much more committed by contract;
(b) what compensation will contractors and sub-contractors receive for the cancellation of contract;
(c) how many contractors and sub-contractors are involved;
(d) how many workers have become unemployed as a result of the broken contracts and will the Government give an assurance that no contractor will be forced into bankruptcy;
(e) is it correct that the only contract to be completed is for the water tower;

(f) in light of the vast sums of finance being invested in the travel industry of the Northern Territory, particularly in the Darwin area where the airport terminal would play an integral part of the rapidly growing international and national tourist industry, what action, if any, does the Government intend to take to overcome the problem;

(g) does the Government intend to take any action, as an interim measure, to upgrade the present terminal, an old Second World War hangar, which, with its surrounds, is in a disgraceful condition and does nothing to complement the huge sums invested by private enterprise; and

(h) is the present facility in such a poor structural condition that the building must be evacuated in the event of a 75 knot per hour wind, such as Cyclone Gretel, which put Darwin and other settlements under test on 13 and 14 April 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Work on the Darwin international airport and associated facilities has not been cancelled. The Government has deferred further contracts on the project pending a complete reappraisal of the scope of works to be undertaken.
(a) It is estimated that approximately $7.1m will be expended on the project by 30 June 1985 since its commencement in 1983-84.

(b) The question of compensation negotiations will be between the contractors and the principal for the contracts, which is the Department of Housing and Construction, and it will be within the terms and conditions of the contracts as to what amount will be admissable. It is expected to take some time to resolve and the Department of Housing and Construction is not in a position to provide a realistic estimate at this time.
(c) and (d) The number of contractors, sub-contractors and workers who are and will be affected is not currently known but will be considered in the works reappraisal.
(e) It is not correct that the only contact to be completed is the water tower. The installation of ducts for communication cables is also to be completed.
(f) The Government has asked for a complete reappraisal of the Darwin international airport works and until this reappraisal is completed the Government is not going to pre-empt the findings.

(g) As mentioned previously, the Government has announced that complete reappraisal of the project will be undertaken, including examination of any interim works required to upgrade the Darwin Airport terminal.
(h) The current safety criteria employed at the terminal is that when winds in excess of 60 miles per hour (54 knots) prevail, evacuation procedures are instigated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the President of the International Red Cross, Mr Alexandre Hay, say during a press conference in Geneva on 10 January 1985, that:
(a) East Timor was one of the few countries where the IRC is prevented from giving relief to the victims of a military conflict; and
(b) many countries, including Indonesia, were making it impossible for the IRC to operate in accordance with Geneva Conventions governing the conduct of war.
(2) What agreements currently exist between the IRC and the Indonesian Government concerning East Timor in the areas of:
(a) monitoring, distribution and supervision of humanitarian aid requirements, by IRC personnel on mainland East Timor as well as Atauro, Oecussee and Jaco Island; and
(b) visits to detention centres (inside and outside East Timor) holding East Timorese detainees;
(3) What is the expiry date of the agreements referred to in (2) above.
(4) In which places, and on what dates, have East Timorese detainees been visited by IRC personnel since December 1982, and what number of prisoners were seen on each occasion.
(5) Do IRC personnel have free access to all East Timorese political detainees; if not, what are the current limitations on access.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) At a press conference in Geneva on 10 January 1985, Mr Alexandre Hay, President of the International Committee of the Red Cross, referred briefly to East Timor. Mr Hay said it was difficult for ICRC to visit some areas of interest to it in East Timor.
(b) At the press conference, Mr Hay referred to the Geneva Convention but these comments were not related to Indonesia.

(2) (a) The ICRC has not been involved in general relief activities on mainland East Timor since mid-1983. However, other ICRC activities in East Timor, including its program of protection visits and its relief and medical program on Atauro Island have continued without interruption. There is no specific ICRC assistance program in Oecusse or Jaco Island. The ICRC and the Indonesian authorities are in regular contact concerning ICRC activities in East Timor. In this context, the ICRC hopes to be able, in the near future, to conduct a general survey of possible humanitarian assistance requirements on mainland East Timor.

(b) There is agreement in principle between the Indonesian Government and the ICRC whereby the ICRC may visit all 'GPK detainees' (Gerambalan Pengacau Keamanan-'persons arrested as a result of the events in East Timor'). This agreement covers Timorese held in places of detention in East Timor and in Jakarta.
(3) The expiry dates for the agreements referred to above are not specified.
(4) From December 1982 until the end of 1984, the ICRC made the following visits to East Timorese detainees:
Numbers Detention Centre

The ICRC made a further protection visit to East Timorese detainees in April-May 1985. During this visit, the ICRC visited 182 detainees in Comarca Gaol (Dili), three detainees in Becora Gaol (Dili), and 42 detainees in Cipinang Gaol (Jakarta). The Government is aware that 50 East Timorese detainees have subsequently been released from Comarca Gaol.

(5) The understanding between the Indonesian Government and the ICRC is that the ICRC should have access to all 'GPK' detainees. All visits accord with the standard ICRC requirements, including the absence of third parties during interviews. The Government understands that the ICRC is generally satisfied with the access to East Timorese detainees over the last 18 months.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government aware of a list of 42 East Timorese, allegedly held in Cipinang Prison and Tangerang, Java, Indonesia, which was published by the British human rights organisation, Tapol, in March 1985; if so, can the Government confirm whether the East Timorese listed are or were imprisoned in Java and provide information on the reasons for their detention; if not, will the Government undertake to determine this information.

(2) Can the Government provide information on the total numbers of East Timorese being detained: (a) inside; and (b) outside East Timor, for reasons of a political or security nature; if not, will the Government seek this information.

(3) Can the Government provide information on the numbers of East Timorese: (a) tried and (b) convicted; in (i) civil, and (ii) military courts, on charges of a political/ security nature since June 1980; if not, will the Government seek this information.

(4) Is the Government aware of any observation of trials of East Timorese, charged with political/security offences, by any international legal bodies or Indonesian human rights organisations such as the Legal Aid Institute of Jakarta.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is aware of the report in 'Tapol' of March 1985 which published a list of East Timorese allegedly detained in Cipinang and Tangerang prisons in Java. The Government is aware that there are at present 43 East Timorese imprisoned in Jakarta, all of whom have been tried and sentenced in East Timor. No further details about the prisoners are available.
(2) There are at present approximately 153 East Timorese being held in detention in East Timor and 43 being held outside East Timor.

(3) The Indonesian Government has stated that it intends to bring to trial all detainees. The Australian Embassy in Jakarta has been advised that, of the approximately 196 East Timorese in detention, some 143 have been tried and sentenced. There are no details available concerning the number of East Timorese tried in civilian and military courts since June 1980 on charges of a political/ security nature.

(4) According to the Indonesian Government, trials and detentions in East Timor are conducted in accordance with procedures followed throughout Indonesia. The Government is not aware of any move by an international legal body or the Indonesian Legal Aid Institute to witness or seek to witness such trials.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government aware of a report in the West Australian on 2 March 1985, in which the present head of the Catholic Church in East Timor, Monsignor Belo, claimed that he saw graves holding the bodies of 84 Timorese executed by Indonesian troops, and a subsequent claim by Governor Carrascalao that up to 10 people may have been killed in crossfire.

(2) Does the Government have, and will it provide, any more definitive information on the incident referred to in (1) above, with particular reference to the number of East Timorese killed and the circumstances of their deaths.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is aware of the report in the West Australian on 2 March 1985, concerning the claims by the Apostolic Administrator in East Timor, Monsignor Belo, and of the reported claim by Governor Carrascalao about recent killings in East Timor.
(2) The Government has no information concerning these reports.
